Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are one of Europe’s leading IT services companies, providing a holistic suite of digital services and solutions to over 10,000 customers in 29 countries across Europe, Latin America, North America, the Middle East, Asia and Africa. We are well-positioned in our key geographic markets (France, Spain, Belgium and Portugal) as an end-to-end services and solutions provider, with comprehensive offerings that are strategically diversified by activity, industry vertical and technology. We operate across eight key industry verticals: Public Sector and Healthcare, Financial Services, Transport Travel Services (TTS), Energy, Utilities and Chemicals (EUC), Retail and Consumer Goods (RCG), Telecom Media Technology (TMT), Industry and Services and Defense and Security. We also provide a wide range of end-to-end services and solutions, from custom software integration, solutions development, application management and consulting, to outsourcing and value-added reselling, combining innovation-based differentiation and automation-based efficiency. We categorize our portfolio of services and solutions into seven activities: Application Services, Business Solutions, Infrastructure Services, Value-Added Reselling, Outsourcing, Consulting and Software Solutions. We believe that our wide range of digital services and solutions, coupled with the quality of our work, the proximity-based nature of our delivery model and our local and linguistic expertise, are a key differentiating factor of our business, increasing customer satisfaction and retention, while contributing to our diversified revenue base. The breadth of these offerings gives us exposure to well-diversified end-market industry verticals, with no industry vertical representing more than 30% of revenue in the year ended December 31, 2021. Within the global IT services market, we operate in attractive and growing geographic markets, mainly France, Spain, Belgium and Portugal, where growth is mainly driven by structural digital trends, including digital penetration of new business areas, increased outsourcing and external IT expenditure, the boost in digitalization led by COVID-19 and the increased complexity of systems and software required to maintain legacy IT infrastructure. We are a long-term partner of large, blue-chip IT customers and a one-stop shop for fast-growing mid-market customers, which we serve through our regional footprint and local delivery networks. Large companies accounted for more than 90% of our revenue from our top 100 customers for the year ended December 31, 2021. We maintain long-term relationships with many of these customers. More than half of our top ten customers have been with us for more than ten years and revenue generated from our top ten customers grew at a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 4% over the same period. We estimate that recurring and highly repeatable revenue accounted for approximately 71% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020, translating into a strong demand backlog and revenue visibility. We believe that our business has a differentiated growth platform which is demonstrated by our historic performance, driven by our diverse value proposition and efficient execution capabilities. We are also an established consolidation platform, in particular through the acquisition and integration of more than 25 companies since 2016. In successfully scaling-up our business, we have benefitted from the experience of our CEO, Vincent Rouaix, and CFO, Cyril Malher, and we currently benefit from the support and expertise of Bain Capital, who has been our majority shareholder since July 2022. Among other advantages, this has allowed us to maintain our strong track record of attracting and retaining best-in-class talent, which are at the heart of innovation in our business. Over five decades, we have grown organically and through acquisitions to become one of the leading providers of IT services in Europe. As such, we intend to strategically position ourselves in key markets such as the French and Spanish markets and aim to capture the expected structural digital transformation and rise in demand for IT services. We also aim to continue leveraging our market expansion track record to push significant growth initiatives throughout our business, including pursuing new growth opportunities, markets and business models. Furthermore, we intend to maintain and consolidate our leadership position in our core IT activities and in our various industry verticals, while continuing the service portfolio transformation ----- towards our Consulting and Business Solutions activities. As the IT services market remains highly fragmented, we seek to further strengthen our position and broaden our product portfolio, capabilities and geographic presence by continuing to consolidate smaller players. As one of the largest multi-local players in the fragmented IT services market, we have the resources and expertise, including a deep knowledge of legacy IT infrastructures, to act as a true partner to our customers in their digital transformation. Multi-local providers like us generally benefit from regional footprints and high customer proximity in several countries. We see focused investments in talent and vendor partnerships as an opportunity to accelerate the shift of our revenue mix towards digital services and solutions, with expected corresponding uplift in organic revenue growth and margin. In addition, we seek to continue leveraging our diversified operating platform and realizing economies of scale to grow our profitability and improve our margins. We believe that we have the potential to close the gap between our profit margin levels and our peers’ through several identified, tangible levers, including streamlining our organization, optimizing our subcontracting process, increasing the flexibility of our cost structure. Our competitive advantages, operating model and the attractive underlying fundamentals of the IT services market in which we operate, have enabled us to deliver a strong financial performance, with our revenue increasing at a CAGR of 17.9% over the two years ended December 31, 2021 and organic revenue growth of 4.9% for the year ended December 31, 2021.

Subsection Title: Our Competitive Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Large and attractive underlying markets with secular growth drivers
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the global IT services market, which has historically grown in line with or faster than GDP in each of the key countries in which we operate—France, Spain, Belgium and Portugal, which collectively accounted for 89% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022—with periods of accelerated growth that have been largely driven by technology transitions and related digital transformation trends. These attractive and growing markets collectively grew, according to the Market Report, at a CAGR of approximately 4.3% from approximately €42 billion in revenue in 2016 to approximately €48 billion in 2019 and, after a brief contraction to approximately €45 billion in 2020, were expected to grow at an estimated CAGR of approximately 5.6% in the period 2020-2025, reaching approximately €59 billion in 2025. See “Industry.” We believe that the growth in the IT services market is and will continue to be mainly driven by structural digitalization trends, including (i) the rising penetration of digital technologies in new business areas and the continued proliferation of new applications and data, prompting companies to adopt larger IT budgets and require continued support; (ii) an increase in IT outsourcing and external IT expenditure due to the need for flexible IT resources, higher service quality, cost savings and better overall end-user engagement; (iii) the boost in digitalization sparked by COVID-19, including acceleration of e-commerce and the adoption of work-from-home tools, which we expect to be permanent; and (iv) the increased complexity of systems and software required to maintain legacy IT infrastructure. In addition, France, Spain, Belgium and Portugal remain relatively underpenetrated, with IT services expenditure representing 1.4%, 1.5%, 1.8% and 1.2% of GDP, respectively, in 2019, compared to more than 2.0% in the United Kingdom and the United States in the same period. We believe that this will create several attractive opportunities for future growth in our key geographic areas. Our market opportunity is also underpinned by increased potential for digitalization across all our key industry verticals, which we believe creates significant headroom for future growth. For instance, legacy infrastructure accounted for approximately 85% of total IT infrastructure in the Public Sector and for approximately 68% of total IT infrastructure in the Financial Services industry in 2020, which is broadly consistent with legacy infrastructure in the French and Spanish IT services markets, which represented 65% of the total IT infrastructure in such markets in the same period. This highlights our key markets’ potential to grow as customers continue to transition to digital models and shift away from legacy IT infrastructures. Our key geographic areas also exhibit significant barriers to entry for new and global competitors, which is expected to provide us with opportunities to grow both operating revenue and margins. These markets are characterized by multi-regional providers like us with difficult-to-replicate characteristics, such as local and long-term relationships with customers, strong knowledge of customers’ IT infrastructures solutions that are deeply entrenched within and are mission-critical for customers, particularly in the Public Sector and Healthcare, Financial Services and EUC industry verticals, regional footprints and local delivery networks and deep knowledge of local markets and complex regulatory dynamics. With respect to international competitors, these significant barriers, together with our proven ability to reduce costs via nearshoring, are ----- reflected by the fact that low-cost Indian operators (who play a key role in various IT services markets) have a limited presence in France and are virtually absent in Spain, two of our key markets.

Subsection Title: Our Competitive Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Scaled multi-country IT services platform with leadership in key markets and attractive proposition for large and mid-market customers
Subsubsection Text: We operate a highly diversified business that provides multiple services across key geographic areas and industry verticals, with a strong local presence, complemented by our growing nearshore capabilities through our 21 global service centers. We believe this makes us a long-term partner of large, blue-chip IT customers and a one-stop shop for fast-growing mid-market customers, who we serve through our regional footprint and local delivery networks. We are a leader in each of the key markets in which we operate, ranking among the top five overall and top two multi-local IT service providers in France, Spain, Belgium and Portugal (based on application implementation services revenue in 2021). Our defensible, attractive market positioning today has been built over several decades through gradual expansion across key geographic areas and industry verticals and building robust and long term relationships with large and mid-market customers. For large customers (including Orange, Airbus, Société Générale, EDF and BNP Paribas), we position ourselves as part of a core panel of three to five lead IT service providers. We differentiate our offering to such customers by being more flexible and responsive than large global IT service providers, and are often more price competitive. For midmarket customers (including Eolane, Euskaltel, ICA and IKKS), we position ourselves as a full-service IT service provider that can be a strategic partner for customers through their digitalization journey or that lack in-house IT expertise. We differentiate ourselves by offering such customers a combination of broad technical capabilities paired with a local footprint. The attractiveness of our offering to customers is illustrated by the fact that we scored above our IT services peers in several key purchasing criteria (“KPCs”), ranking in the top three in the five most important KPCs, including ranking first on price, relationship and flexibility with scores of 4.1, 3.9 and 4.2 (out of 5), respectively (based on customer surveys of medium-to-large companies in France and Spain).

Subsection Title: Our Competitive Strengths
Subsubsection Title: Comprehensive suite of offerings complemented by a differentiated IP portfolio, growing digital capabilities and strong vendor relationships
Subsubsection Text: We are an end-to-end IT service provider, with comprehensive offerings that are strategically diversified by activity, industry vertical and technology. We do this by providing various services and solutions across the entire value chain, organized around our seven activities as shown in the graphic below. _Source: Company information._ We believe that our comprehensive suite of services and solutions is a key differentiating factor of our business, increasing customer satisfaction and retention, while contributing to our diversified revenue base. The charts below illustrate our revenue by activity, industry vertical, type and contract type for December 2021. -----

Subsection Title: Revenue by activity Revenue by industry vertical** **Revenue by type** **Revenue by contract type
Subsubsection Title: Stable and diverse customer base, with long-term relationships driving more predictable, recurring and repeatable revenue streams
Subsubsection Text: Our customer base of over 10,000 customers is very broad and includes a mix of large and growing blue-chip customers and mid-market customers. We are one of the preferred suppliers for many European blue-chip companies, which have significant digitalization and legacy transformation needs and require IT service providers like us that have at-scale delivery capabilities. On the other hand, mid-market customers require a combination of broad technical capabilities, flexibility and a local footprint. ----- Our customers value our consistent quality, the breadth of our IT services and solutions that are tailored to their needs, our understanding of local market characteristics and our comprehensive suite of offerings. We believe that these factors, along with our active management of relationships with our customers, contribute to our consistently high customer satisfaction rates (approximately 90% in France in the year ended December 31, 2021 according to customer satisfaction surveys that we perform at the end of projects on a continuous basis), which we believe contributes to our increasing contract renewal rates (calculated on the basis of the total value of existing contracts rolled forward in any given year), which in France have been at or above 90% since 2019 and at 95% for the year ended December 31, 2021, and the longevity of our customer relationships (almost all of our top ten customers from 2012 were still within our top 16 customers in 2021). We have been serving more than half of our top ten customers for more than ten years, with some relationships dating back to 1995, and our revenue from our top ten customers has grown at a CAGR of approximately 4% over the past ten years, with eight out of ten customers generating higher absolute revenue in 2021 and a relatively similar operating margin over that same period. At the same time, we benefit from low customer concentration and significant customer diversification across our industry verticals. In 2021, our top customer, top ten customers and top 35 customers accounted for 2.7%, 17.5% and 35.3% of our revenue, respectively. We believe that this diversity increases our resilience to periods of economic uncertainty and other fluctuations in the macroeconomic environment of the countries in which we operate. The chart below shows the increasingly diverse nature of our customer base.

Subsection Title: Revenue by activity Revenue by industry vertical** **Revenue by type** **Revenue by contract type
Subsubsection Text: Consulting Outsourcing 2% 8% SolutionsSoftware8% ApplicationServices36% VAR 9% Infrastructure Services 17% Business Solutions 20% _Source: Company information_ Industry & Services 7% TMT 9% RCG 10% EUC 10% Defence & Security 5% TTS 11% Public Sector & Healthcare 25% Financial Services 22% Digital c.40%+ Software Solutions 8% VAR 12% Outsourcing 14% Project Build 16% Time & Material 29% System Integration, App Mgmt and Other 21% Non-Digital 60% The breadth of our services and solutions gives us exposure to the industry verticals shown in the chart above, with no industry vertical representing more than 30 % of our revenue in 2021. Our services and solutions include both those that are tailored to specific industry verticals and those that are transversal in nature, _i.e., those that span industry verticals by catering to common problems, including for example, our activity,_ time and content management solutions. For example, in our Public Sector and Healthcare industry vertical, we have tailored and refined our services and solutions for over 40 years to become a privileged partner to more than 3,000 public organizations, (i) providing consulting services focused on digital and open government models, digital education, reengineering and automation of public procurement processes and property management adoption, (ii) improving the citizen experience with a public/social CRM, citizen and transparency portals, and open data platforms and (iii) shaping smart territories with our intelligent city solutions. In the Financial Services industry vertical, we provide innovative offerings including (i) IT services relating to funds administration, payments and settlements solutions, regulatory compliance, risk management and credit management, (ii) compliance solutions to insurance customers with over €14.0 billion in assets managed, helping them monitor approximately 14 million property and casualty contracts, which cover over 8 million individuals and (iii) instant payments and cash management evolution and integration to help expand digital payments usage. In addition to these services, we offer powerful proprietary IP Software Solutions for Public Sector customers, which differentiates our offering in areas such as finance, HR, school transport, intelligent and collaborative territories, social protection, taxation and management of urban planning and housing, emergency medical services, fire services and emergency management. We believe that our business benefits from a relatively high proportion of our operating revenue being generated by sales of Software Solutions based on our own proprietary software or other IP. In 2021, sales from our Software Solutions accounted for 8% of our total revenue. We believe that, in addition to generating recurring revenue and increasing operational leverage, IP-rich software solutions tend to strengthen customer relationships and support strong customer retention, which can enable cross-selling and up-selling of additional services and software, and enhance margins. We have also been investing in strengthening and growing our digital capabilities to cater to the increasing demand for such services and solutions, with digital services and solutions across our services and solutions accounting for approximately 40% of our total contract value for the year ended December 31, 2020. Some of our digital services and solutions include advisory in digital transformation, digital customer experience customization, digital workplace transformation, contract modernization, cloud migration, virtualization and maintenance, data analytics, cybersecurity solutions, and robotic process automation. Finally, we are a long-standing partner of market leading software and cloud vendors for workplace solutions (including Red Hat, Oracle and ServiceNow), data center and multi-cloud providers (including AWS, Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure) and network and security providers (including Palo Alto Networks). For instance, we benefit from a relationship with SAP spanning over 20 years, resulting in approximately 2,300 accreditations and 350 certifications. These strong vendor relationships allow us to provide our customers with the best solution to suit their needs.

Subsection Title: As a % of total revenue (�m) Other clients 1,015 2,219
Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Long-term track record of resilient top-line growth and cash generation, with prudent financial leverage policy
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our business has a differentiated growth platform which is demonstrated by the historic performance driven by our diverse value proposition and efficient execution capabilities. These have been key factors to our above-market growth over the years. By leveraging our resilient and flexible business model through economic downturns, we have demonstrated our ability to maintain profitability while expanding our business through a combination of organic and acquisition-led growth. ----- The following graphics show the evolution of our organic and reported revenue, margins and cash flow conversion over time, demonstrating our ability to produce above-market revenue growth, both organically and inorganically, while achieving stable margins and with improving cash flow conversion in the long term. _Source: Company information_ (1) Organic and Pro Forma Revenues are both rebased to 100, based on 2011 figures; (2) Adjusted for 3SI and Kidiliz contracts ramp down impact. Impact was known at the moment of the acquisition and factored in the acquisition price; (3) Before pro forma adjustments. Pre-IFRS 16 prior to 2019, post-IFRS 16 otherwise; (4) Defined as: (Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure, less depreciation of right of use assets associated with IFRS 16 leases, which we consider as a proxy for IFRS 16 lease payments) divided by (Adjusted EBITDA less depreciation of right of use assets associated with IFRS 16 leases), expressed as a percentage. We have historically maintained margin discipline, suggesting experience and multiple strategies to deal with cost inflation via pass-through to customers (especially in high growth areas), better cost optimization (reallocation of staff across customers and projects, use nearshoring or freelance) and productivity improvements (employment of lean industrialization techniques). We believe that the upwards evolution of our revenue, margins and cash flow conversion over time are mainly driven by our strong structural foundation and highly attractive underlying business model. We increased our operating margin as a percentage of revenue from 6.3% in 2019 to 7.4% in 2021, due to our strong recovery following the COVID-19 pandemic, notably in relation to our activity ratio. Our operating margin as a percentage of revenue further improved to 7.6% in the twelve months ended June 30, 2022, as a result of certain efficiency measures that we are in the process of implementing. In addition to a well-diversified revenue base and an attractive mix of blue-chip and mid-market customers, we have benefited from stable profit margins in recent years, driven by various efficiency measures targeting our portfolio mix and contributing to growth in our direct margin. Furthermore, our asset-light business model has further enhanced cash flow conversion, which increased from 56.8% in 2016 to 77.5% in 2021. Our capital expenditure level is also relatively low, representing 2.3%, 1.9% and 2.0% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Our financial policy is to maintain strong cash flow conversion, with a target of at least 70%, in the medium term. While we believe we will be able to accomplish this, our ability to do so will depend on various factors, many of which are not within our control. Therefore, we cannot assure you that we will be able to achieve any such results in the future.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Attractive consolidation platform with a track record of creating value through integration
Subsubsection Text: We are an established consolidation platform in a highly fragmented IT services market, with a strong track record of successfully acquiring and integrating more than 25 companies since 2016, which has allowed us to expand our product offering and geographic reach, generate significant cross-selling opportunities within our existing customer base and realize synergies. In part thanks to our acquisition strategy, we generated €2.3 billion in revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022 and have generated approximately €1.0 billion of additional revenue from companies that we have acquired since 2016 (calculated by aggregating ----- revenue contribution of each acquired company solely in the year of their respective acquisition, on a _pro forma basis as if the acquisition was completed on January 1 of the relevant financial year) in the year of_ their respective acquisition. We constantly evaluate opportunities for prudent, highly-targeted and strategic bolt-on acquisitions, focused on the expansion of both of our services and solutions portfolio and geographic reach. As part of our expansion of our offerings, our acquisitions include Cognitis, a banking services and consulting specialist, IVS, a public sector software specialist, Addstones, a corporate and investment bank specialist, Itn, Inservio and i2s, insurance software and services experts, Novulys, a Microsoft CRM specialist, Projixi Europe, an automation specialist, and Ilex International, a cybersecurity software provider. As part of our geographic expansion, our acquisitions include IECISA, Efron and Gesfor, which allowed us to significantly expand our business in Spain and LatAm, Realdolmen, which allowed us to expand in the BeLux market, Impaq, which allowed us to enter the Polish market with high-tech nearshoring capabilities, and Do IT Wise, which allowed us to capitalize on the success of ServiceNow and further expand our service center capabilities. In addition, in Africa, we acquired Somafor, which allowed us to enter the Ivory Coast market, Archos Technology and Capital Consulting, which allowed us to consolidate our leading position in Morocco, Cynapsys, which allowed us to enter the Tunisian market and increase our offshore shared service center capacities and which we capitalized on by acquiring HLi Consulting in 2021. We are experienced in integrating assets and driving cost efficiencies and cross-selling synergies, as demonstrated by the seamless integration and success of our acquired companies. For example, in relation to IECISA, which we acquired in 2020, we have already exceeded our initial objectives and delivered more than €20 million of savings by improving billables and optimizing the costs of certain non-billables, such as property, plant and equipment, general and administrative expenses and subcontracting expense. We have developed a disciplined and clear approach to our M&A strategy, targeting specialized IT services providers, while expanding our geographic footprint and maintaining our local approach.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Experienced leadership team and strong focus on talent development that have positioned us for profitable growth
Subsubsection Text: Our business is supported by our highly-experienced management team, which is widely recognized in the IT services market and has successfully scaled-up and positioned us across various geographies, taking us from a local player to one of the leading IT services providers in Europe. Our senior managers include Vincent Rouaix, who has been our CEO since 2009 and Cyril Malher, who has been our CFO since 2009, each of whom has over 20 years of experience in the IT services market. In addition to our CEO and CFO, the rest of our management team has an average experience of ten years in the IT services market. Under their management, our business is well-positioned to deliver strong growth and successfully implement our growth and transformation strategy. We also have a strong and proven track record of attracting and retaining best-in-class talent, which are at the heart of innovation in our business. As of June 30, 2022, we had more than 27,000 FTEs, the majority of whom are consultants and direct employees, with 4,100 subcontractors, 946 freelancers, dedicated research teams of 150 professionals and a pool of 300 engineers focused on innovation. We are always looking for ways to help our talent with their training and professional development, with more than 10,000 employees and consultants trained, accredited and certified in 2021 by our long-term partners, such as Google and Microsoft. In part due to our strong focus on talent development and focus on innovation, a significant portion of our FTEs remain with us for a long term, with approximately 40% of our FTEs having worked for us for five years or more, and the average tenure of our FTEs for the year ended December 31, 2021 being approximately seven years. We believe that our strong focus on talent development and investment in innovation sets us apart from our competitors. From the year ended December 31, 2019, to the year ended December 31, 2021, we invested a total of approximately €167 million in R&D. Such investments and our large number of long-serving and well-trained FTEs provide a significant barrier to entry into the market for new competitors, who would need to invest a significant amount of time and money to gain such a workforce and similarly innovate. Such barriers to entry also help us maintain profitability while we pursue growth. In addition, we benefit from the expertise, business relationships and knowledge of Bain Capital, who has been our majority shareholder since July 2022. Since its inception in 1984, Bain Capital and its affiliates have completed over 650 transactions and have made investments in more than 350 companies in a broad range of industries, including consumer/retail, financial and business services, healthcare, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Bain Capital has specialized knowledge of the IT services market in Europe, due to its ownership of Engineering—Ingegneria Informatica S.p.A., a leading IT services provider in Italy. ----- Bain Capital also has a long track record of partnering with management teams of technology and digital services companies to accelerate growth. The firm’s technology investments include Brillio, Genpact, Waystar, Viewpoint, Blue Coat, BMC Software and QuEST Global Services, amongst many others.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Text: ~35% **+7% ~56% 2016 2021 _Source: Company information_ Our loyal and sticky customer base provides us with high level of revenue predictability and visibility, both through contractually recurring business and highly repeatable business. A large portion of our customer contracts are long-term in nature, leading to recurring revenue. For example, the length of our project-based contracts across our customer base in France is on average greater than three years. In addition, a significant portion of our revenue, such as certain “time and material” contracts and revenue from our Value-Added Reselling activity, which while not contractually recurring, in our experience are repeatable in nature. We estimate that recurring and highly repeatable revenue accounted for approximately 70% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. As of January 2022, we estimate that approximately 71% of our 2022 yearly budget was covered through amounts expected to be realized in connection with projects in our weighted pipeline, time and material (“T&M”) contracts for the next three months and oral commitments. This amount increased from approximately 67% in 2021, which we believe reflects our strong demand backlog and gives us a good level of revenue visibility, barring significant changes in the macroeconomic backdrop which could impact our weighted pipeline in particular. We also believe our high customer satisfaction, the long-term nature of our customer relationships and the breadth and quality of our services and solutions present important cross-selling opportunities, particularly as we pursue our strategy of growing revenue from digital services and solutions, along with our Business Services and Consulting activities which we view as activities with higher added value and greater revenue growth potential.

Subsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Pursue growth and consolidate our positioning as a leading IT services and solutions provider in key markets
Subsubsection Text: We are in the core panel of IT services and solutions providers for blue-chip corporates and a strategic partner to mid-market companies in the markets in which we operate. Over five decades, we have grown organically and through acquisitions to become one of the leading providers of IT services, software and digital platforms in Europe, with operations in 29 countries across Europe, Latin America, North America, the Middle East, Asia and Africa. In particular, we have established a leading market position in each of our mature and stable markets, such as France, Iberia and BeLux, which we will continue to capitalize on. We also have a robust presence in growing markets, such as Eastern Europe, Africa and LatAm, which helps us diversify our revenue mix. The global IT services market has grown consistently at or above GDP over the long term and we are currently in a period of acceleration due to the digital and cloud transitions. We believe our geographies and industry verticals are relatively underpenetrated. For example, the IT services expenditure as a percentage of GDP in 2019 was at 1.4% in France and 1.5% in Spain, with these countries still being relatively early in the shift to cloud-based services and solutions. We believe this indicates a forward growth trajectory for these markets as both private and public sector customers continue to increase their IT investments to remain competitive and fill the technology gap that currently exists in comparison with other main EU countries. The French and Spanish IT services markets are expected to resume their growth trajectories at a CAGR of 5.5% and 6.9%, respectively, for the 2021-2025 period. See “Industry.” Through our strategic position in these and other key markets, we aim to benefit from the expected structural digital transformation and rise in demand for IT services. We also aim to maintain and consolidate our leadership position in our core activities (such as Application Services and Business Solutions), as well as in our various industry verticals (such as Public Sector and Healthcare and Financial Services), while continuing our service portfolio transformation towards our Business Solutions and Consulting activities. We believe that expanding and cross-selling services will help us continue to be an IT services and solutions provider of choice and a strategic partner for our key customers.

Subsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Accelerate the shift of our revenue mix towards digital services and solutions to accelerate business growth and profitability
Subsubsection Text: In line with market trends, we have been investing in strengthening our digital capabilities with approximately 40% of our total contract value deriving from digital services and solutions in 2020, with a goal to increase that percentage to approximately 60% in the coming years. Our customers increasingly allocate a significant portion of their budgets to cloud-based applications, digital infrastructure, cybersecurity, automation and data analytics, which are key drivers of our digital-led growth. As a result, meeting our customers’ increasing needs in the digital space has become a key focus for us and an area where we intend to generate revenue growth. We have the resources and expertise, including a deep knowledge of legacy IT infrastructures, to accompany our customers in their digital transformation journey. We believe this is particularly valued by customers in our key industry verticals (Financial Services and Public Sector and Healthcare) where a smooth transition is crucial given the mission critical nature of their processes and the high cost of failure due to their highly regulated nature. We also see focused investments in talent and vendor partnerships as an opportunity to accelerate the shift of our revenue mix towards digital services and solutions, with corresponding uplift in organic revenue growth and margin, and believe this is an approach followed successfully by other competitors. We intend to build on our leadership position in our core IT activities to be a leading digital services provider, and we believe our existing customer base and our global delivery model based on proximity to the customer provide a robust base to achieve this. Digital projects we have undertaken for customers include the cloud migration of the technical base of BNP Paribas’s electronic payment system, the redesign and migration of the customer-facing website of BNP Insurance, the migration of corporate customer front-end applications to DevOps and cloud for Orange, the redesign of data warehousing to Google Cloud hosting for Orange, the automation of the process of closing current accounts and passbook accounts for Orange, the cloud migration ----- of databases and management of data APIs for Société Générale and the automation of back-office processes as part of retail bank convergence project within Société Générale. Furthermore, we are a long-standing partner of market leading software and cloud vendors for workplace solutions (including Red Hat, Oracle and ServiceNow), data center and multi-cloud providers (including AWS, Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure) and network and security providers (including Palo Alto Networks). For instance, we benefit from a relationship with SAP spanning over 20 years, resulting in approximately 2,300 accreditations and 350 certifications. We seek to keep and reinforce our long-standing partnerships with these global software and cloud players as our customers’ needs increasingly shift to digital solutions.

Subsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Continue to pursue growth initiatives and opportunities in the large and growing upper mid-market segment
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue leveraging our market expansion track record to push significant growth initiatives throughout our business. One of our key initiatives continues to be increasing the proportion of revenue generated by our Business Solutions and Consulting activities as we view these as areas with higher added value and greater revenue growth potential in light of digitalization trends. To pursue additional growth opportunities, we intend to further scale our platform in new geographies and focus on the development of our industry vertical-focused offerings. As one of the largest multi-local players in fragmented IT services markets where scale increasingly matters, we believe that the trend among our customers to consolidate to key partners will benefit large IT service providers (such as ourselves), who can absorb a large portion of IT expenditure from recurring customers. We also seek to capture growth in the upper mid-market segment, leveraging its shift to digital and cloud. This represents a particularly attractive opportunity for us, given our strong presence in the mid-market segment and the fact that there is less competition for such mid-market customers than for larger companies. To adapt our services and solutions to such companies, we intend to continue delivering a comprehensive offering tailored to address these customers’ needs through our broad technical capabilities and local footprint, which we believe gives us a structural advantage against potential competitors by being one of the “one-stop shops” within our industry.

Subsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Further enhance profitability through identified levers
Subsubsection Text: We seek to continue leveraging our diversified operating platform and realizing economies of scale to grow our profitability and improve our margins. We see significant potential to improve our profitability when comparing ourselves to some of our peers (our Adjusted EBITDA margin was 10.5% in 2021, which was below the (non-weighted) average of our peers in the French mid-cap market (12.7%), regional providers (14.5%), digital competitors (17.7%) and global IT players (19.8%) (adjusted from public figures to exclude (i) expenses linked to share-based payments and (ii) other operating income and expenses)), we believe that we have the potential to close this gap through several identified, tangible levers. We intend to streamline our organization by simplifying our processes, nearshoring our back-office and increasing capacity utilization. We also intend to optimize our subcontracting process by improving our relationships and increasing synergies with our subcontractors and internalizing longer-tenure subcontractors. We also seek to increase the flexibility of our cost structure by improving our processes in connection with selling, general and administrative expenses by providing local and tailored services and solutions to targeted and underpenetrated markets. Furthermore, we plan on focusing on the lean industrialization and automation of our processes, leading to more efficient delivery, reduced costs and timely execution of our projects. In addition, we seek to realize more effective synergies from future acquisitions, and to realize the full potential of businesses we have already acquired, particularly IECISA, a Spanish technology consulting company with strong market positions in Spain, Portugal and LatAm.

Subsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Title: Continue making targeted and opportunistic acquisitions to expand our portfolio, capabilities and geographic presence
Subsubsection Text: The IT services market remains highly fragmented and we intend to further strengthen our position and broaden our product portfolio, capabilities and geographic presence by continuing to consolidate smaller players. We have been one of the most active consolidation platforms in the IT services markets in which we operate, successfully acquiring and integrating more than 25 companies since 2016. We have developed a disciplined and systematic approach to acquisition activity, targeting best-in-class specialized IT players with a focus on increasing our capabilities in high-growth areas and consolidating our positions across our industry verticals. We pursue acquisitions that we believe are supported by a strong business case of value creation, ----- provide business continuity and limit disruption to profitability. We believe that this continued focus on acquiring and integrating specialized providers of IT services will allow us to further cross-sell acquired services and solutions into our broad customer base, attract and retain talented employees and strengthen our R&D capabilities. Our future acquisition strategy will focus on attractive and accretive add-ons to complement our envisaged organic growth and increase our scale and synergies, in addition to high margin capabilities to our portfolio, reinforcing our existing footprint and expanding into new territories and further developing our offering and access to strategic assets and partnerships.

Subsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Text: We aim to continue strengthening our position across our activities, industry verticals and geographic areas by implementing the key strategies set forth below.

Subsection Title: The Transactions
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition
Subsubsection Text: On April 22, 2022, the Issuer, as buyer, and Mannai Corporation QPSC (the “Seller”), as seller, entered into a share purchase agreement (the “Acquisition Agreement”), pursuant to which, on July 20, 2022 (the “Acquisition Completion Date”), the Issuer purchased from the Seller 99.83% of the share capital of the Company. In addition, the Issuer purchased free shares of the Company that were issued on July 20, 2022 and allocated to employees of the Company. As a result, the Issuer holds 99.90% of the share capital of the Company, with the remaining 0.10% of share capital held by senior management of the Company. We refer to the acquisition of the Company pursuant to the Acquisition Agreement and the acquisition of the free shares from employees of Inetum as the “Acquisition.” The consideration paid to consummate the Acquisition (including the repayment of certain borrowings of the Company and its subsidiaries, but excluding current and non-current IFRS 16 lease liabilities and other current financial liabilities) was €1,631.4 million.

Subsection Title: The Transactions
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition Financing
Subsubsection Text: On or about the Acquisition Completion Date, the Issuer incurred €1,132.7 million under the Existing Senior Term Loan, and the Sponsors indirectly funded investments in the Issuer in the form of a combination of cash contributions for equity and subordinated shareholder debt in an aggregate amount of approximately €568.3 million (the “Shareholder Funding”). The proceeds of the Existing Senior Term Loan, the Shareholder Funding and cash on balance sheet were used to finance the Acquisition consideration and to fund cash on balance sheet, and were or will be used to pay fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. We refer to the Existing Senior Term Loan, the Shareholder Funding and, in each case, the use of proceeds thereof as the “Acquisition Financing.” The estimated sources and uses of the funds necessary to pay the Acquisition consideration, fund cash to balance sheet and pay fees, costs and expenses in connection with the Transactions are shown in the table below.

Subsubsection Title: The Individual Investors’ Investment
Subsubsection Text: On the Acquisition Completion Date, certain individual investors, including our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, entered into a Securityholders’ Agreement to invest into Holdco, the indirect parent of the Issuer. It is expected that certain other individual investors, who were shareholders of the Company on the Acquisition Completion Date, will invest in Holdco and accede to the Securityholders’ Agreement in the third quarter of the year ending December 31, 2022, for a total of 2.7% of the share capital of Holdco (the “Individual Investors’ Investment”).

Subsubsection Text: The gross proceeds of the Offering will be used, together with borrowings under the New Senior Term Loan, to partially repay the Existing Senior Term Loan.

We refer to the Acquisition Financing, the Offering, the New Senior Term Loan and the use of proceeds thereof, collectively, as the “Financing Transactions.” We refer to the Acquisition, the Individual Investors’ Investment and the Financing Transactions, together, as the “Transactions.”

Subsection Title: Our Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Title: Bain Capital
Subsubsection Text: Since its inception in 1984, Bain Capital and its affiliates have completed over 650 transactions and have made investments in more than 350 companies in a broad range of industries, including consumer/retail, financial and business services, healthcare, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Bain Capital Private Equity’s global team of more than 250 investment professionals creates value for its portfolio companies through its global platform and depth of expertise, managing approximately $160 billion of assets in total and leveraging the firm’s shared platform to capture opportunities in strategic areas of focus. Bain Capital has investors from across the world that include sovereign wealth funds, public pension funds, foundations, insurance companies, family offices, high-net-worth individuals and funds of funds. The firm has a strong track record of investments in the IT and tech-enabled services industries, including its recent investments in Engineering, Genpact, Brillio, Quest and Kantar. Headquartered in Boston, Bain Capital and its affiliates have offices in Chicago, Dublin, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, London, Luxembourg, Madrid, Melbourne, Mumbai, Munich, New York, Palo Alto, San Francisco, Seoul, Shanghai, Sydney and Tokyo.

Subsection Title: Our Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Title: NB Renaissance
Subsubsection Text: NB Renaissance is an investment firm with a focus on companies with a high growth potential primarily headquartered in Italy. NB Renaissance currently manages over €2.3 billion in assets and is invested in 13 companies with an aggregate turnover of approximately €6 billion. NB Renaissance was formed in 2015 from the strategic partnership in private equity in Italy between Intesa Sanpaolo, Italy’s largest bank, and Neuberger Berman (“NB”). NB, founded in 1939, is a private, independent, employee-owned investment manager. As of June 30, 2022, NB had $418 billion in client assets, including approximately $120 billion in alternative assets (mainly private equity), operations in 25 countries and over 2,500 employees.

Subsection Title: Our Principal Shareholders
Subsubsection Title: The Issuer
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations, material assets, other than the shares it holds in the Company and its receivables under the Company Proceeds Loan, or material liabilities, other than those incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions, including indebtedness incurred in connection with the Transactions. -----

Subsection Title: Trading Update
Subsubsection Text: _The information below is estimated and forward-looking in nature, is based on a number of assumptions and estimates as of the date of this Offering Memorandum that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change, has not been audited or reviewed by our independent statutory auditor, is based on our management accounts and relies on management judgment. In particular, the information below assumes no significant changes to the macroeconomic environment will occur during the relevant periods. Although we believe this information to be reasonable, our actual results may vary from this information and such variations could be material, As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information. Furthermore, we make no representation and give no warranty regarding this information and make no undertaking to publish or report any potential changes or updates to this information. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance._ We estimate that our revenue for the year ending December 31, 2022, will be in the range of €2.3 billion to €2.4 billion, compared to €2.2 billion in the year ended December 31, 2021. We currently aim for organic revenue growth over the medium term broadly in line with historical performance, with a slight acceleration over the years. We expect this growth to be achieved mainly through (i) an increased demand in our key markets for all activities in all geographic areas, with moderately faster growth in geographic areas outside of France, and (ii) a shift in our business mix towards activities with higher revenue growth potential, such as Business Solutions and Consulting, and an increase in our digital offerings. In addition, we estimate our operating margin (% of revenue) will be in the range of 8% for the year ending December 31, 2022, compared to 7.4% for the year ended December 31, 2021. We estimate Adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of €250 to €270 million for the year ending December 31, 2022, compared to €233.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. We aim to continue to increase margin and profitability primarily through (i) an improvement of our activity ratio and the industrialization and automation of our processes as well as (ii) our cost savings initiatives, including streamlining our organization, optimizing our subcontracting process, increasing the flexibility of our cost structure by improving our processes in connection with selling, general and administrative expenses. Based on preliminary results, derived from our unaudited management accounts and other information currently available, we estimate that revenue grew in July and August 2022 by 10.9% as compared with the same months in 2021, increasing from €314.2 million to €348.5 million, in spite of there being one less working day in both France and Iberia in these months as compared to the same months in 2021. We believe that our revenue mix in July and August 2022 included comparatively more revenue from our VAR activity, which accounted for approximately €41 million of revenue during the period, representing growth of 27% as compared to July and August 2021. Growth in revenue from our VAR activity came principally from Spain, followed by Belgium. We estimate that organic growth for July and August 2022 was approximately 8.3% (after agency charges) and believe that the overall EBITDA for July and August 2022 will be in line with that of the same months in 2021. _This preliminary information is based on internal management accounts and has been prepared by our management. While this preliminary information has been prepared in accordance with IFRS (subject to certain exceptions and adjustments), this preliminary information has not been audited, reviewed or verified and no procedures have been completed by our external auditors with respect thereto and is not comparable with the corresponding financial information set forth elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. It is not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the relevant periods as of and ended July 30 and August 31, 2022, and you should not place any reliance thereon. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our business, financial position and results of operation._ -----

Please see “Description of the Notes— _Withholding Taxes.”_ Tax Redemption . . . . . . . . . . . .** In the event the Issuer would become obligated to pay certain additional amounts as a result of certain changes in tax laws, the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the applicable redemption date. Please see “Description of the _Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain events of a change of control, the Issuer will be required to make an offer to repurchase the Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of their aggregate principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of repurchase. See “Description of the Notes— _Change of Control.”_ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture contains covenants that restrict the ability of the Issuer and its subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness; - make certain restricted payments and investments; - transfer or sell assets; - enter into transactions with affiliates; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions; - issue or sell share capital of certain of our subsidiaries; - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments to us; ----- - impair the security interests in the Collateral; and - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as the Notes achieve investment grade ratings. - rank pari passu in right of payment with all of that Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is not subordinated in right of payment to its Note Guarantee, including obligations in respect of the Senior Facilities Agreement; - rank senior in right of payment to all of that Guarantor’s future indebtedness that is subordinated in right of payment to its Note Guarantee; - rank effectively senior to any existing and future unsecured indebtedness of that Guarantor, to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Note Guarantees; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of that Guarantor (including obligations to trade creditors) that is secured by property or assets that do not constitute Collateral, to the extent of the value of the property and assets securing such obligations or indebtedness; - be structurally subordinated to any indebtedness or other obligations of that Guarantor’s subsidiaries (including obligations to trade creditors) that do not guarantee the Notes; and - be subject to the limitations described in “Limitations on Validity _and Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ Security: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, on the Issue Date, the Notes will be secured by first-priority security interests (collectively, the “Issue Date Collateral”): (i) in respect of the Issuer, in its shares in the Company, its structural intra-group receivables owed to it by the Company (including under the Company Proceeds Loan) and its material bank accounts located in France; and (ii) in respect of Midco, in its shares in the Issuer and its structural intra-group receivables owed to it by the Issuer. (1) We define Acquisition Adjusted Revenue as revenue, adjusted as though the Acquired Companies had been acquired as of January 1, 2019, instead of the actual dates on which the acquisitions occurred or were deemed to have occurred for accounting purposes. (2) We define Acquisition Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA, further adjusted as though the Acquired Companies had been acquired as of January 1, 2019, instead of the actual dates on which the acquisitions occurred or were deemed to have occurred for accounting purposes. (3) We define organic revenue growth as the percentage growth in Group revenue between two periods whereby: (i) for the periods 2011-2012, 2012-2013, 2013-2014, 2014-2015, and 2015-2016, the revenues used for the calculation are the reported revenues for the two periods, as adjusted, for the subsequent period, (a) to exclude the revenue contribution of any entity acquired in that period and (b) to exclude the revenue contribution of entities acquired in the prior period to the extent of the corresponding period prior to acquisition;, (ii) for the periods 2016-2017, 2017-2018 and 2018-2019, the revenue used for the calculation is our reported revenue, as adjusted to (a) include the revenue contribution of entities acquired in the year ended December 31, 2016 (on a pro forma basis as if the acquisitions were completed on January 1, 2016) and (b) exclude the revenue contribution of entities acquired on or after January 1, 2017; and (iii) for the period 2019-2020 and 2020-2021, the revenue used for the calculation is our reported revenue, as adjusted to include (a) the revenue contribution of IECISA on a pro forma basis, as if the acquisition was completed on January 1, 2019 and (b) exclude the revenue contribution of all other entities acquired on or after January 1, 2019. (4) We define Adjusted EBITDA as net consolidated income before provisions for depreciation on working capital and risks, income tax expense, other financial income (expenses), cost of gross debt, income from cash and cash equivalents, other operating income and expenses, gains (losses) on disposals, restructuring costs, amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions and amortization (other than goodwill). ----- We believe Adjusted EBITDA is a useful metric for investors to understand our results of operations and profitability because it permits investors to evaluate our recurring profitability from underlying operating activities. Our presentation of Adjusted EBITDA may be different from the presentation used by other companies and therefore comparability may be limited. Adjusted EBITDA is a Non-IFRS Measure and the term Adjusted EBITDA is not defined under IFRS or any other generally accepted accounting principles. Consequently, the use of Adjusted EBITDA has certain limitations. Adjusted EBITDA is not a measure of net income, operating income, operating performance or liquidity presented in accordance with IFRS. When assessing our operating performance, you should not consider these measures in isolation or as substitutes for our net income, operating income or any other operating performance or liquidity measure that is calculated in accordance with IFRS. See “Presentation of Financial and _Other Information—Non-IFRS Measures.”_ The following table sets forth the reconciliation from net consolidated income to Adjusted EBITDA for the periods indicated.

Section Title: SUMMARY HISTORICAL AND CERTAIN OTHER FINANCIAL DATA
Subsubsection Text: The following tables present our summary consolidated financial information and other data of the Company as of the dates and for each of the periods indicated. The summary consolidated financial information are derived from the Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS and included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The other financial and operating data shown below are derived from the Group’s accounting records or management reporting systems and were not included in the Financial Statements. In our audited consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2021, the comparative financial information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 was restated to reflect the completion of the purchase price allocation to goodwill and net identifiable assets acquired in relation to the acquisition of IECISA, which we acquired on April 24, 2020. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of certain critical accounting estimates. It also requires the board of directors to exercise its judgment in the process of applying accounting policies. The areas involving a higher degree of judgment or complexity, or areas where assumptions and estimates are significant to our financial statements, are disclosed in the Financial Statements. See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Critical Accounting _Policies and Use of Estimates—Critical accounting policies.”_ In making an investment decision, you must rely upon your own examination of the terms of the Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. You should consult your own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP and how those differences could affect the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Macroeconomic, Political and Social Environment
Subsubsection Title: Macroeconomic downturns and inflationary cycles may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in a dynamic environment that is rapidly shifting due to innovation in technology, evolving and increasing global regulation, information proliferation and a generation of new users. While we believe that we operate in attractive markets, our performance depends in large part on the financial health and strength of our customers, which in turn is dependent on the general economies of the countries in which they operate. Our activities are sensitive to macroeconomic conditions in the markets in which we operate, including particular downturns and inflationary cycles. In particular, demand for our services and solutions depends principally on investments in platforms that combine technology and specialized proprietary content and on the consumption of these platforms by private companies and government bodies. A downturn in economic conditions resulting in rising interest rates, inflation or unemployment, or more generally resulting in a deterioration of the economic situation in the markets in which we operate, could have a material adverse impact on us, our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, any deterioration in economic conditions may affect customer spending, which may also have negative effects on our financial performance. Certain of our contracts with customers may provide for fixed pricing rates for the services and solutions to be provided, a cap on pricing or other terms which we negotiate based on our assumptions regarding our customers’required scope of services, costs that will be incurred to fulfill the scope and operational efficiencies we expect to achieve and other estimates. As a result, while we seek to pass on our costs to our customers, this may not be feasible in all situations. These assumptions and estimates may prove to be inaccurate, particularly if operating costs continue to rise in the current inflationary environment.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Macroeconomic, Political and Social Environment
Subsubsection Title: We are vulnerable to fluctuations and deteriorations in the economic conditions in the industry verticals we serve.
Subsubsection Text: The demand for our services and solutions is dependent on the health of the respective industry verticals we serve. Any negative trend in any industry vertical in which we operate could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition. For example, we are dependent on the Financial Services and Public Sector and Healthcare industry verticals, which represented 49.7% of our revenue in the twelve months ended June 30, 2022, which are often subject to heightened regulatory scrutiny, consolidation, increasing capital requirements, lower transaction volumes in certain markets and asset classes and relatively low overall anticipated market growth. This complex regulatory environment often leads to periods of reductions in costs and reduced supplier spending in the industry, although it simultaneously increases compliance and risk-management concerns, which may benefit our business. However, we cannot assure you that this will continue to be the case in the future.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Macroeconomic, Political and Social Environment
Subsubsection Title: Unfavorable conditions in the capital and credit markets and political uncertainty may adversely affect business conditions and our access to credit needed to maintain and grow our business.
Subsubsection Text: Disruptions in the global capital and credit markets as a result of economic downturns, economic uncertainty, regulatory changes, financial institution failures or other factors could adversely affect our ability to access ----- the liquidity we need to make investments in our services or to otherwise maintain our business and pursue our strategy. For example, if the financial institutions that have extended credit commitments to us, or from whom we seek credit commitments in the future, were to be adversely affected by conditions in the capital and credit markets, they might be unable to fund borrowings under such credit commitments, which could have an adverse impact on our financial condition and our ability to borrow funds, if needed, for capital expenditure, working capital, acquisitions and other corporate purposes. Unfavorable market conditions could also make it difficult for our customers to obtain the financing they need for their projects on reasonable terms, which may reduce demand for our services and solutions or may hinder our customers’ ability to meet their payment obligations to us, increasing losses on bad debt. Delinquencies and credit losses generally can be expected to increase during economic slowdowns or recessions. See “—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Any _delay or failure in payment for our services by customers who represent a large percentage of our trade receivables balance could adversely affect our business. Additionally, an increase in our trade receivable and in our provisions for bad debt, may negatively affect our working capital and lead us to experience liquidity constraints.” Our_ third-party providers may also be adversely impacted by unfavorable capital and credit markets, causing disruptions to our business operations. Political uncertainty may also negatively impact the capital and credit markets. For example, changes in foreign policy or regulatory requirements, trade restrictions or sanctions, higher tariffs and changes to existing, or the imposition of additional, regulations relating to the import or export of products. In particular, global markets are experiencing volatility and disruption following the escalation of geopolitical tensions and the start of the military conflict between Russia and Ukraine. On February 24, 2022, a full-scale military invasion of Ukraine by Russian troops occurred, leading to sanctions and other penalties being levied by the United States, European Union and other countries against Russia, Belarus, the Crimea Region of Ukraine, the so-called Donetsk People’s Republic, and the so-called Luhansk People’s Republic, including, but not limited to, agreement to remove certain Russian financial institutions from the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) payment system. Additional sanctions and penalties have since been implemented, with further measures having been proposed and/or threatened. Although the length and long-term impact of the ongoing military conflict is highly unpredictable, the conflict in Ukraine has led and could continue to lead to market disruptions, including significant volatility in commodity prices, credit and capital markets, severe inflation, as well as supply chain interruptions for some of our third-party suppliers. We have no activities or operations in Russia, Belarus or Ukraine. However, if the conflict intensifies or expands beyond Ukraine, it could have an adverse impact on our business. In addition, political uncertainty could also increase currency exchange fluctuations and volatility. Our main functional currency and reporting currency (for over 90% of our revenue and expenses) is the euro. However, we offer our services and solutions in various countries and, as a result, may be subject to some translation risk. The expansion of our international activities, including through our recent acquisitions, may increase our exposure to these currency exchange fluctuations. For more information, see “Management’s Discussion _and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosure about Market and Financial Risks—Exchange rate risk.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Macroeconomic, Political and Social Environment
Subsubsection Title: Market perceptions concerning the instability of the euro, the potential reintroduction of individual currencies within the Eurozone or the potential dissolution of the euro entirely, could negatively impact our business or our ability to refinance our liabilities.
Subsubsection Text: Economic and political events in recent years affecting European economies have raised a number of questions regarding the stability and overall standing of the European Monetary Union. Credit risk in these countries and in other Eurozone countries could have a negative impact on our business. Concerns also remain regarding the overall stability of the euro and the suitability of the euro as a single currency given the diverse economic and political circumstances in individual euro Member States. In addition, continued hostilities in the Middle East and tensions in North Africa and Eastern Europe and other world events could adversely affect the economies of the European Union and those of other countries. Future developments are dependent upon a number of political and economic factors, including the effectiveness of measures by the European Commission and Member States to address debt burdens of certain countries in Europe, the overall stability of the Eurozone, the influx of refugees in certain European countries and the rise of populism in Europe. In addition, political repercussions of responses to the COVID-19 pandemic by European Union institutions as well as by other countries in the European Union could have complex and hard-to-predict consequences for the future, including inflation, a destabilization of the European Union or its institutions or a slow-down or reversal of European integration. See “—The impact of COVID-19 and related risks could materially affect our ----- _business, results of operations and financial condition” and “—Unfavorable conditions in the capital and credit markets and political uncertainty may adversely affect business conditions and our access to credit needed to maintain and grow our business.”_ The departure or risk of departure from the euro by one or more Eurozone countries or the abandonment of the euro as a currency, could have major negative effects on our existing contractual relations with our customers, and could adversely affect the economy in France, Iberia and BeLux, which represented 41.2%, 35.2% and 14.0%, respectively, of our revenue in the twelve months ended June 30, 2022. Any of these developments could affect our ability to refinance our liabilities and have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. The potentially severe impact of these events on Europe and the global financial system could also have a negative impact on the value and marketability of the Notes. On June 23, 2016, the United Kingdom held a referendum on the United Kingdom’s membership within the European Union, the result of which favored the exit of the United Kingdom from the European Union (“Brexit”). Following such referendum and the enactment of legislation by the government of the United Kingdom, the United Kingdom formally withdrew from the European Union and ratified a trade and cooperation agreement governing its future relationship with the European Union. The agreement, which was ratified by the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union on April 28, 2021 and applies permanently since May 1, 2021, addresses trade, economic arrangements, law enforcement, judicial cooperation and a governance framework including procedures for dispute resolution, among others. Because the agreement merely sets forth a framework in many respects and will require complex additional bilateral negotiations between the United Kingdom and the European Union as both parties continue to work on the rules for implementation, significant political and economic uncertainty remains about how the precise terms of the relationship between the parties will differ from the terms before withdrawal. These developments, or the perception that any related developments could occur, have had and may continue to have a material adverse effect on global economic conditions and financial markets, and could significantly reduce global market liquidity and restrict the ability of key market participants to operate in certain financial markets. Since we rely on access to the financial markets in order to refinance our debt liabilities and gain access to new financing, ongoing political uncertainty and any worsening of the economic environment may reduce our ability to refinance our existing and future liabilities or gain access to new financing, in each case on favorable terms or at all.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Macroeconomic, Political and Social Environment
Subsubsection Title: The impact of COVID-19 and related risks could materially affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Significant outbreaks of contagious diseases or other illnesses may result in a widespread health crisis that could adversely affect the economies and financial markets of many countries, leading to substantial declines in customer purchasing power and resulting in an economic downturn that could affect demand for our products, our ability to collect against existing trade receivables and our operating results. The outbreak and continued spread of the COVID-19 virus and variants thereof (the “COVID-19 pandemic”), and the measures taken to attempt to contain and mitigate its effects, including stay-at-home, business closure and other restrictive orders, and the resulting changes in customer behavior, have impacted and may continue to impact our workforce and operations, and those of our customers. This led to a slowdown in business investment and may lead to a drop in activity for our business and prevent us from achieving our goals, particularly as we were unevenly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic across our geographies, with France being the most impacted country where our revenue decreased by 8.3% between the year ended December 31, 2019 and the year ended December 31, 2020. However, the strong reduction in infections and deaths recorded in recent months, facilitated by the successful outcome of the vaccination campaign, has allowed the reopening of many sectors severely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and is gradually bringing the economy closer to pre-pandemic levels. According to the Banque de France, the recovery of the French economy in 2022 as the COVID-19 pandemic draws to a close remains solid. However, this projected recovery may be negatively impacted by deteriorating general economic conditions due to, among other things, rising inflation, tightening monetary policies and pressures on public finances, all of which may be exacerbated by geopolitical threats, including the current conflict in Ukraine. See “—Unfavorable conditions in the capital and credit markets and _political uncertainty may adversely affect business conditions and our access to credit needed to maintain and grow our business.” The degree to which the COVID-19 pandemic impacts our business, results of operations_ and financial condition will depend on developments beyond our control. A resurgence in infections in certain areas of the world may result in the implementation of new restrictions and while vaccination campaigns against COVID-19 are progressing, there can be no assurance on if and ----- when the population will be fully immunized, including as a result of new strains of the virus which may be characterized by higher transmission rates. Therefore, it remains unclear if or when the COVID-19 pandemic will cease and whether previously lifted measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19 may be reinstated.
