Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: by Geographic Area:
Subsubsection Text: France . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ 925.5 849.0 906.7 452.8 488.0 Iberia . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ 253.5 678.1 814.3 412.1 402.5 BeLux . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ 293.5 294.8 321.8 161.0 159.4 LatAm . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ 43.9 58.8 83.4 37.1 71.2 Other . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ._ 79.0 85.2 92.9 45.4 56.7 _Customer Retention Rate and Recurring Revenue_ We have historically generated a significant proportion of our revenue from sources that we consider to be recurring and from customers with whom we have developed and maintained stable, long-term, strategic relationships. This is evidenced by our high customer satisfaction rates (approximately 90% in France in the year ended December 31, 2021 according to customer satisfaction surveys that we perform at the end of projects on a continuous basis), which we believe contributes to our increasing contract renewal rates (calculated on the basis of the total value of existing contracts rolled forward in any given year), which in France have been at or above 90% since 2019 and was 95% in the year ended December 31, 2021, and the longevity of our customer relationships (almost all of our top ten customers from 2012 were still within our top 16 customers in 2021). ----- We consider revenue to be recurring if we expect to generate such revenue in one or more of the following years, either based on our track record with the customer, such as revenue generated by existing customers seeking new services or solutions and from long-term agreements with customers for whom we have implemented proprietary or customized solutions or pursuant to specific contractual arrangements, as is the case with our system integration, application management, outsourcing and software contracts. See “Business—Customers—Customer Contracts.” As a further example of the loyalty of our customer base, each of our top ten customers have been with us for more than ten years and revenue generated from these customers grew at a CAGR of 4% in the same period. In the year ended December 31, 2021, our top ten customers generated 18.5% of our revenue. We believe that the loyalty of our customers is due to their satisfaction with the quality of our services and solutions, our deep knowledge of complex IT systems and our customers’ businesses and the high costs required to switch IT service providers. Our loyal customer base has also become increasingly diverse, considerably reducing our customer concentration, with our top 35 customers representing 55.6% of our revenue in 2016 and 35.3% of our revenue in 2021. In particular, many of our services and solutions are highly customized and deeply integrated into our customers’ IT systems, as a result of which our replacement would be a complicated, time-consuming and expensive process. We also typically benefit from strong demand backlog at the beginning of the year, which further contributes to revenue visibility. As of January 2022, we estimated that approximately 71% of our 2022 yearly budget was covered through amounts expected to be realized in connection with projects in our weighted pipeline, T&M contracts for the next three months and oral commitments. This amount increased from approximately 67% in 2021, which we believe reflects strong demand backlog and gives us a good level of revenue visibility, barring significant changes in the macroeconomic backdrop which could impact our weighted pipeline in particular. _DSO and Trade Receivables Without Contracts Assets and Advances and Deposits Paid For Orders_ We generally issue invoices for the services we offer to our customers at the time of delivery on a monthly basis, such as for time and material contracts. For fixed price contracts, customers often make a down payment at the time of the execution of the contract and make subsequent payments according to a payment schedule and milestone delivery. While we believe our typical payment terms are consistent with those of our peers, from time to time, in the ordinary course of business, we carry significant accounts receivable on our balance sheet from customers that generate a large portion of our revenue. The lengths of payment cycles for services rendered vary across our different industry verticals as well as the type of customer we serve. Our DSO for the year ended December 31, 2021 was 41 days, as compared to 43 days for the year ended December 31, 2020, 51 days for the year ended December 31, 2019 and 58 days as of June 30, 2022, in each case in terms of invoiced revenue. Further, our average DSOs generally declined across our historical perimeter in France, Portugal and Belgium during 2020, despite the COVID-19 pandemic. DSOs vary across our geographic areas and tend to be the lowest in BeLux, the highest in Africa and otherwise relatively similar to each other across the other countries in which we operate. During the six months ended June 30, 2022, we experienced a significant delay in invoicing, due to the rollout of our new ERP system (SAP), which led to an additional approximate €50 million of working capital outflow in France as of June 30, 2022. Trade receivables without contracts assets and advances and deposits paid for orders vary across our geographic areas and amounted to €370.9 in the year ended December 31, 2021 (of which 43.0% were incurred in France, 37.0% were incurred in Iberia, 6.8% were incurred in BeLux, 4.5% were incurred in LatAm and 8.7% were incurred in our Other countries), as compared with €335.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 (of which 39.6% were incurred in France, 41.6% were incurred in Iberia, 4.2% were incurred in BeLux, 5.0% were incurred in LatAm and 9.5% were incurred in our Other countries). In addition, we engage regularly in the sale of receivables on the basis of non-recourse factoring to manage our working capital during peak periods, as is customary in our industry. With the sale of the trade receivables for non-recourse factoring, the factoring company assumes substantially all risks in connection with the transferred receivables. Following the completion of the Transactions, we intend to rely primarily on our operating cash flow, as well as our Revolving Credit Facility and the factoring of receivables to satisfy our working capital and other liquidity needs. _Seasonality_ We have limited seasonality with respect to our revenue throughout the year. However, our operating margin is typically higher in the second half of the year. This seasonality effect is mostly driven by (i) an improvement in our activity ratio (which is calculated as the ratio of days worked during the relevant period to the number of Potential Days. Potential Days corresponds to the number of Working Days, multiplied by the number of ----- Billable FTEs, excluding vacation days and certain other days of inactivity) due to progressively increasing demand, which is in turn driven by the typical timing for customer decisions that impact IT expenditure, (ii) the release of project and bonus provisions at the end of the year, which reflects the larger number of projects that are concluded in the second half of the year and (iii) the contribution of license revenue in the second half of the year, which reflects the fact that we conclude more projects that generate license revenue in the second half of the year, for the reasons described above. Our working capital levels typically peak in the summer months and in September and October, with lower points in June and December of each year, in connection with payments of invoices by our customers and following typical invoicing patterns. _Acquisitions_ Value-accretive acquisitions of attractive IT services and solutions assets have been a significant driver of growth in our operations, breadth of services and solutions offerings, geographic scale, revenue and EBITDA. Since January 1, 2019, we have completed 14 acquisitions, including our acquisition of IECISA in 2020, which allowed us to significantly expand our operations in Iberia. We completed six acquisitions in 2019, one acquisition in 2020, three acquisitions in 2021 and four acquisitions in the six months ended June 30, 2022 (collectively, the “Acquired Companies”), in each case excluding transactions in which we only increased our stake in previously consolidated companies. Due to the changes in our scope of consolidation as a consequence of each of such acquisitions, our results of operations in the periods under review are not entirely comparable. The table below shows the acquisitions we have completed since 2019, noting the principal country of operation for each Acquired Company. **2019** **2020** **2021** **2022** Capital Consulting Bridgeo IECISA Ilex International JCommerce Hutobee (Morocco) (Cameroun) (Iberia) (France) (Poland) (France) Archos Technology Hundred Projixi Europe EditInfo-IT Do IT Wise (Morocco) (Peru) (France) (Morocco) (Bulgaria) SIS I2S HLi Consulting (France) (Iberia/Africa) (Morocco/Tunisia) Historically, we have funded our acquisitions primarily with cash from operations and debt. In the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, and the six months ended June 30, 2022, we spent €31.8 million, €269.2 million, €17.2 million and €49.5 million, respectively, on acquisition consideration. We believe that the acquisitions we made in the periods under review have generated synergies for our business and have also contributed to our organic growth by generating cross-selling and up-selling opportunities. After each acquisition, we review both our portfolio of offers and potential customers to identify potential for synergies. Among our portfolio of offers, Business Solutions and Software Solutions are usually the areas where we can most readily find synergies. When an acquisition exposes us to a new country, we assess the opportunities that may be possible with subsidiaries of our top customers. Once an acquired business is fully integrated in our business, we aim to increase its volumes of operations by leveraging our global and local platforms. In the future, we intend to continue to grow our business through disciplined strategic bolt-on acquisitions of specialized IT services providers in order to add complementary technology to our portfolio, as well as to enlarge our customer base and expand internationally. See “Business—Our Strategies—Continue _making targeted and opportunistic acquisitions to expand our portfolio, capabilities and geographic presence.”_ See also “—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations and Financial Condition— _Acquisitions” below for an explanation of how acquisitions during the periods under review have affected the_ comparability of our results across these periods. _Investments in R&D, Innovation and Capital Expenditure_ To maintain our competitive position, we test our innovative services and solutions on a continuous basis in order to enhance our offering in ways that we believe are or will be of interest to the market and existing and potential customers. We invested approximately €50.0 million, €58.0 million and €59.0 million in R&D in the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively: €24.7 million, €27.2 million and €27.7 million, respectively of this R&D expense was capitalized. The remaining portion was recognized as an expense under staff costs, less any research tax credits (notably, in our case, the French government’s R&D tax credit). We are currently involved in research projects in the following key areas, which span our industry verticals: digital industry, smart transportation, digital and physical security, smart city and smart government solutions, ----- energy, waste management, 5G, digital media, cloud, Big Data, blockchain and AI. In 2021, we focused our efforts on the following themes: AI to serve our customers’ businesses, AI for operations (AI Ops), AI for development (AI Dev), virtual and augmented reality, the value and intelligence of massive data, IoT, cybersecurity, blockchain and new tools for modelling and developing new applications and services. Our ability to continue to compete and to maintain and grow our business is dependent on the success of our investments in R&D and innovation, which depends in turn on our ability to attract and retain qualified personnel and leadership. Our capital expenditure for the periods under review primarily related to investments in intangible assets and capitalized R&D, in connection with our Software Solutions activity. We incurred €36.2 million, €38.0 million and €45.2 million of capital expenditure in the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively, representing 2.3%, 1.9% and 2.0% of our revenue in the same periods, respectively. For further information, see “—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Capital Expenditure.” _Cost Structure, Cost Saving Initiatives and Synergies_ Our cost structure primarily comprises personnel expenses. Nearly 90% of our workforce consists of billable consultants. In particular, staff costs represented on average 62% of our total costs included in our operating margin in the years 2019, 2020 and 2021. To further support our resilient business model and increase our margins and/or lower our costs, during the periods under review we have taken actions to: - manage our activity ratio and/or lower our selling, general and administrative costs, resulting in the incurrence of €11.5 million, €15.9 million and €16.0 million per year of restructuring costs (excluding acquisitions) in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively, mainly in France, Iberia and Belgium; - implement cost saving initiatives and synergies following acquisitions, most notably following the IECISA acquisition in 2020; and - purchase, through establishing a Group purchasing department and achieving procurement synergies in IT capital expenditure, car fleet and VAR sourcing, and relocation, through rightsizing our real estate footprint primarily by reducing our office rental stock, notably in Paris where we have closed or are in the process of closing six of our ten offices following increased remote working after the COVID-19 pandemic. Going forward, we intend to implement a cost savings plan with the objective of reaching €20 million per year of cost savings within the next 18 months, which is focused on streamlining our organization, optimizing our subcontracting process, increasing the flexibility of our cost structure by improving our processes in connection with selling, general and administrative expenses. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to _Accounting Standards and Financial Information—We may not achieve the anticipated benefits of our cost savings initiatives.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations and Financial Condition
Subsubsection Text: _The Transactions_ The Financial Statements have not been adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes to the income statements, statements of financial position or cash flow statements that might occur as a result of purchase accounting adjustments to be applied as a result of the Transactions. However, the Issuer will account for the Acquisition using the acquisition method of accounting under IFRS and will apply purchase accounting adjustments in connection with the Acquisition to the financial statements for accounting periods subsequent to the Acquisition Closing Date. The application of purchase accounting could result in different carrying values for existing assets and liabilities and we may add additional assets to our statement of financial position, which may include intangible assets, such as goodwill, brand name, customer relationships, leasehold rights and software. We may also recognize different amortization and depreciation expenses. Due to these and other potential adjustments, our future financial statements could be materially different once the adjustments are made and may not be comparable to the Financial Statements that are included in this Offering Memorandum. Furthermore, we will incur a substantial amount of indebtedness as a result of the Transactions. As of June 30, 2022, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, we would have had total net debt in an aggregate amount of €1,121.2 million, consisting of the Notes, the Senior Facilities and lease liabilities. See “Capitalization”and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” In addition, on or about the date of this Offering Memorandum, we will have €200.0 million available for drawing under the Revolving Credit Facility, which is ----- expected to be undrawn on the Issue Date. Our indebtedness may limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and industry and the emergence of new business opportunities, since a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations will be dedicated to meeting debt services requirements, and this may place us at a competitive disadvantage, as some of our competitors have lower leverage levels than we do and thus may be able to react to such changes and opportunities more quickly. _Acquisitions_ The historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is affected by the acquisitions that we have made, which have changed our scope of consolidation and this may make it more difficult for investors to evaluate the historical performance of our business. Accordingly, our historical results are not, and results for future periods will not be, directly comparable to past periods because of the acquisition activity that we have undertaken. Subsidiaries are consolidated as from the date of acquisition, which corresponds to the date on which the Group took control of them and until control ceases. In accordance with the purchase method of accounting, the identifiable assets and liabilities assumed from the acquired entity are recorded at fair value on the date of acquisition and may be adjusted during the 12 months following such date. _Reclassification of LatAm Results of Operations_ During the periods under review and up to December 31, 2021, our results of operations from our branches in LatAm (which were mainly serving the Public Sector and Healthcare industry vertical), were recorded in our statutory accounts within the Iberia segment and were subsequently reclassified into the LatAm segment without reconciliation to prior periods. Additionally, our results of operations from our activities in LatAm are affected by large but infrequent projects, which may lead to variations in our results year-on-year, whereas our results in Iberia tend to be consistent and reflect the nature of demand in more mature markets, such as Spain and Portugal. Accordingly, our historical results are not, and results for future periods following December 31, 2021 will not be, directly comparable to past periods.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Items
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Revenue refers to revenue from sales of our services and solutions. In particular, this refers to technical assistance, consulting and systems integration, invoiced services, sales of software and hardware, maintenance services and transactions where we act as agent. See “—Critical Accounting Policies and Use of Estimates— _Revenue recognition policy.” Staff costs_ Staff costs refers to direct personnel costs relating to our FTEs and consultants, such as wages and salaries, social security costs, employee profit sharing, profit-sharing costs and retirement benefit plans. _Operating expenses_ Operating expenses primarily refers to direct and indirect costs, comprising: - subcontracting costs; - cost of intangible assets, expensed R&D costs, cost of materials, consumables, supplies and goods, which mainly comprise the cost of external purchases of hardware and software for resale; - cost of services, which mainly comprises costs directly related to the services rendered to our customers, as well as indirect services and consultancy costs related to management (such as sales, marketing, legal, administrative, maintenance and IT costs); - costs relating to use of third-party assets, which mainly comprises lease and rental expense for our facilities and equipment; - amortization, depreciation and write-downs, which mainly comprises amortization of intangible fixed assets, depreciation of tangible fixed assets, other write-downs of fixed assets and writedowns of current receivables and liquid funds; and - certain other operating costs, such as membership fees and commercial costs. ----- _Non-income taxes_ Non-income taxes consist of taxes other than current and deferred income taxes (e.g., CVAE and property tax). Taxes for any relevant period are estimated taking into account the result for the period as well as the applicable laws and regulations, and represent the best management estimate of the tax charge. _Amortization (other than goodwill)_ Amortization refers to depreciation of property, plant and equipment, amortization of intangible assets (other than goodwill), as well as depreciation and amortization resulting from the adoption of IFRS 16. _Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions_ Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions refers to amortization allocated within the framework of the allocation of goodwill in the context of business combinations, mainly relating to customer relationships. _Restructuring costs_ Restructuring costs refers to costs incurred as part of our restructuring activities, such as indemnities and severance costs. _Other operating income and expenses_ Other operating income and expenses refers to non-recurring costs associated with transactions, disputes, tax/social litigation and other expenses.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue Revenue increased by €0.1 billion, or 6.3%, from €1.1 billion for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €1.2 billion for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was principally driven by growth across all of our geographic areas. In particular, growth increased organically in France by 6.7%, in Iberia by 10.8% (supported by strong performances across our services offering and VAR), in LatAm by 10.1% and in BeLux by 1.8%. Growth also increased in our Other countries driven by both organic revenue growth across our sub-regions and our acquisitions of JCommerce and Do IT Wise.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Geographic Area Mix of Revenue
Subsubsection Text: _France_ France accounted for €452.8 million and €488.0 million, or 41%, of our total revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Revenue in France increased over the period as a result of recovery of the business across our activities from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and higher activity levels as compared to 2021 due to strong customer demand, especially in Application Services across the industry verticals we serve and Business Solutions. Our Software Solutions activity also supported revenue in France, as did our acquisition of Ilex International. _Iberia_ Iberia accounted for €412.1 million and €402.5 million, or 37% and 34%, of our total revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Excluding the impact of our acquisition of IECISA, revenue in Iberia was €388 million in the six months ended June 30, 2021, as compared to €402 million in the same period in 2022, reflecting the impact of the reclassification of our LatAm branches and significant growth in services. _BeLux_ BeLux accounted for €161.0 million and €159.4 million, or 15% and 14%, of our total revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Revenue in BeLux decreased over the period as a result of constraints on resource availability, partially offset by a slight increase in our VAR activity during the period under review. ----- _LatAm_ LatAm accounted for €37.1 million and €71.2 million, or 3% and 6%, of our total revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Excluding the impact of our acquisition of IECISA, revenue in LatAm grew from €61.2 million to €71.2 million, an increase of 16% over the same period. Revenue in LatAm increased significantly over the period as a result of contracts signed in Mexico in the six months ended June 30, 2022 (as compared to in the six months ended June 30, 2021, which was a slower period) coupled with expansion in Peru where we had new opportunities with both existing and new customers. _Other_ Our Other countries accounted for €45.4 million and €56.7 million, or 4.1% and 4.8%, of our total revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2022, respectively. Revenue in our Other countries increased over the period as a result of our ability to leverage skilled personnel who command competitive market prices, particularly in Eastern European countries, such as Poland. We also experienced the beginning of a recovery in activity in our African operations. Staff costs Staff costs increased by €54.2 million, or 8.7%, from €619.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €674.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was principally driven by the increase in headcount due to the acquisitions completed during the six months ended June 30, 2022. Operating expenses Operating expenses increased slightly by €2.7 million, or 0.7%, from €378.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €380.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was principally driven by an increase in travel expenses and the cost of insurance. Non-income taxes Non-income taxes increased slightly by €0.9 million, or 9.5%, from €9.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €10.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Amortization (other than goodwill) Amortization (other than goodwill) increased slightly by €1.9 million, or 5.9%, from €32.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €34.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Other underlying operating income and expenses Other underlying operating income and expenses decreased slightly by €0.3 million, from €2.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €1.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Operating margin Operating margin increased by €9.3 million, or 13.3%, from €70.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €79.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was principally driven by revenue growth (as discussed above), gross margin improvement and acquisitions. _France_ France accounted for €849.0 million and €906.7 million, or 43% and 41%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Revenue in France increased over the period as a result of recovery of the business across our activities from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, higher ----- activity levels as compared to 2020 (although still below 2019 levels) in spite of reduced headcount, and the integration of Projixy. Our Business Solutions, Software Solutions and Consulting activities performed particularly well in 2021, bolstered by several contracts and improvements in average selling prices. In Application Services, our largest activity in France, revenue increased by 9.0%, or €30.4 million, from December 31, 2020 to December 31, 2021, driven by improved activity ratio, combined with improvement in our average selling prices, with such improvements being well spread out across our activities, particularly in Financial Services and Public Sector and Healthcare. In our Business Solutions activity, revenue grew by 11.4%, or €11.8 million, supported by strong performance across all our offerings and improved activity ratio and higher average selling prices. In our Infrastructure Applications activity, growth was limited, with revenue growing 4.1%, or €10.0 million, from December 31, 2020 to December 31, 2021, with resilience in this activity being driven by the long-term nature of contracts, supported by improvements in our activity ratio and increases in our average selling prices, particularly in regards to customers in our Financial Services activity who are exposed to the insurance sector. In our Outsourcing activity, revenue decreased by 14.4%, or €4.0 million, driven by the end of contracts with Thales and Kidiliz. In our Software Solutions activity, revenue grew by 10.1%, or €12.8 million, driven by activity in relation to licenses and maintenance, as well as an improved activity ratio. _Iberia_ Iberia accounted for €678.1 million and €814.3 million, or 34% and 37%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Revenue in Iberia increased over the period as a result of continued cross-selling with, and the full integration of, IECISA. _BeLux_ BeLux accounted for €294.8 million and €321.8 million, or 15%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Revenue in BeLux increased over the period as a result of continuous growth across all activities, with increasing strength in digitalization and cloud offerings. Additionally, revenue grew in Belgium in our Application Services and Infrastructure Services activities, which was driven by an improvement in our activity ratio and a higher average selling price. From December 31, 2020 to December 31, 2021, revenue in BeLux increased organically by 9.4%, or €26.6 million, driven by performance in Belgium, particularly in our Application Services and Infrastructure activities, supported by business with Corylut, which is a key customer in both activities. Our Software Solutions activity in Belgium also benefited from improved activity ratio and higher average selling prices. _LatAm_ LatAm accounted for €58.8 million and €83.4 million, or 3% and 4%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Revenue in LatAm increased over the period as a result of strong performance in Mexico, Colombia and Peru, which offset the ongoing impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic in other countries in LatAm. _Other_ Our Other countries accounted for €85.2 million and €92.8 million, or 4% in each case, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, respectively. In the year ended December 31, 2021, revenue in our Other countries increased organically by 8.9% or €7.6 million, supported by performance in Eastern Europe, particularly in Romania and Poland, driven by our relationships with Rolls Royce, Nokia, Renault and Société Générale and where our number of FTEs grew and our activity ratio and average selling prices increased. This was partially offset by a slight decline in Africa over the same period, with Morocco underperforming as compared to historic levels and with our Application Services, Infrastructure Services and Software Solutions activities lacking new business and experiencing changes to planned projects. ----- Staff costs Staff costs increased by €123.5 million, or 11.3%, from €1.1 billion for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €1.2 billion for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was principally driven by the increase in headcount due to the acquisitions completed in the year ended December 31, 2021. Operating expenses Operating expenses increased by €89.3 million, or 13.4%, from €664.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €753.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was principally driven by the impact of acquisitions, significant subcontractors hires in some geographic areas, leading to additional recruitment and insurance fees. Non-income taxes Non-income taxes increased slightly by €0.6 million, or 3.2%, from €17.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €18.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Amortization (other than goodwill) Amortization (other than goodwill) stayed largely consistent throughout the periods under review, increasing by €1.0 million, or 1.4%, from €66.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €67.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Other underlying operating income and expenses Other underlying operating income and expenses increased by €2.1 million, from €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €2.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Operating margin Operating margin increased by €40.9 million, or 33.1%, from €123.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €164.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was principally driven by revenue growth (as discussed above), gross margin improvement and acquisitions. _France_ France accounted for €925.5 million and €849.0 million, or 58% and 43% (decrease in proportion mainly due to the IECISA acquisition), of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Revenue in France decreased over the period as a result of a decrease in our Application Services activity (our largest activity in France), relating to certain of our blue-chip customers facing new protocols and implementing new cost savings measures (particularly among our Financial Services customers) and a decrease in our Outsourcing activity, due in large part to the termination of our Kidiliz contract, which is currently the subject of a dispute. These revenue decreases were partially offset by a resilient average selling price and strong revenue generation in our Infrastructure Services and Software Solutions activities, which were more resilient during the COVID-19 pandemic and where we were able to offer wider ranges of recurring services to some of our small- and medium-sized enterprise (SME) customers, notably relating to digitalization and the transition to remote working in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. In France, in our Application Services, Infrastructure Services and Outsourcing activities, we experienced an overall decrease in revenue due to the impact of COVID-19, with Application Services being particularly impacted by the effects of the pandemic on our Financial Services and our TTS customers, including airlines and rental car businesses. Revenue in our Outsourcing activity also decreased, as the result of certain customer contracts coming to an end, coupled with the impact of COVID-19 on our customers’ business needs. Revenue in our Infrastructure Services activity were more resilient, due to the long-term nature of many of our projects in this activity. _Iberia_ Iberia accounted for €253.5 million and €678.1 million, or 16% and 34%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Revenue in Iberia increased over the period as a result of our acquisition of IECISA, where we benefited from cross-selling and up-selling with IECISA, the recruitment of over 500 new billable FTEs, a context of broadly stable average selling price and cost-base streamlining as we realized synergies from the acquisition of IECISA. Revenue in Iberia is largely oriented towards our services offerings, of which our Outsourcing and Software Solutions activities performed particularly well in 2020, due to the revenue contribution from our largest customer, the expansion of our customer base among Financial Services customers and in our Software Solutions activity. Our VAR offering also performed well due to SME and public sector investment in remote working infrastructure. Excluding the IECISA Acquisition, revenue increased by €18.6 million over the period. In Iberia, in our Application Services, Infrastructure Services and Outsourcing activities, we experienced steady growth, thanks to the resilience of our TMT customers and our Public Sector and Healthcare customers to the effects of the pandemic. _BeLux_ BeLux accounted for €293.5 million and €294.8 million, or 18% and 15%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Growth in BeLux revenue in 2020 was driven primarily by the strength of our offering to, and expertise with, large, public sector customers and performance in our Infrastructure Services, Business Solutions and VAR activities in Belgium for our robust portfolio of SME customers, which offset a decline in revenue in Luxembourg, due to declines in our VAR activity. _LatAm_ LatAm accounted for €43.9 million and €58.8 million, or 3% of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Revenue in LatAm is driven largely by demand from large projects with our Public Sector and Healthcare and TMT customers. ----- _Other_ Our Other countries accounted for €79.0 million and €85.2 million, or 4.3%, of our total revenue in the years ended December 31, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Revenue in our Other countries increased over the period as a result of growth in Africa (particularly in Morocco, as well as from the acquisitions of I2S in Angola and Capital Consulting in Morocco), as well as by strong performance in Poland and Romania: in Poland, growth was supported by revenue from a large automotive industry customer and, in Romania, activity levels increased significantly in 2020. Staff costs Staff costs increased by €87.9 million, or 8.7%, from €1.0 billion for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €1.1 billion for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by an increase in wages and salaries of increasing headcount. Operating expenses Operating expenses increased by €239.1 million, or 56.2%, from €425.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €664.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by the IECISA acquisition, the workforce of which included many subcontractors. Non-income taxes Non-income taxes increased by €3.5 million, or 24.4%, from €14.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €17.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by wagebased taxes and is in line with the increase in wages. Amortization (other than goodwill) Amortization (other than goodwill) increased by €13.9 million, or 26.5%, from €52.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €66.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by the IECISA contribution, which was split between non-IFRS amortization of intangible and tangible assets. Other underlying operating income and expenses Other underlying operating income and expenses decreased significantly by €3.0 million, from €3.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Operating margin Operating margin increased by €23.2 million, or 23.1%, from €100.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €123.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by revenue growth (as discussed above) largely due to the contribution of IECISA, which contributed €33.2 million to operating margin for the year ended December 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Geographic Area Mix of Operating Margin
Subsubsection Text: _France_ Operating margin from France increased slightly by €0.5 million, or 1.75%, from €28.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €29.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Profit expansion in the period translated into this slight increase of €0.5 million due to increased R&D amortization. Additionally, our French activity ratio in the six months ended June 30, 2022 helped to offset the impact of certain government grants that were received in the six months ended June 30, 2021, which were not renewed in the same period in 2022. The key contributors to operating margin improvements for the six months ended June 30, 2022 were our Application Services and Business Solutions activities. _Iberia_ Operating margin from Iberia increased by €6.9 million, or 33.3%, from €20.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €27.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase resulted from ----- improvements in Spain in our services offering, further savings at the direct margin level, a more optimized activity ratio thanks to growth and internal restructuring initiatives, a higher contribution from our VAR activity and tighter control over operating expenses in connection with the implementation of restructuring plans following our acquisition of IECISA _BeLux_ Operating margin from BeLux decreased by €7.5 million, or 43.8%, from €17.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €9.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, as a result of reduced resources (both employees and subcontractors, due to higher turnover and more sick time taken) available for Application Services, along with lower demand in our Infrastructure Services activity. While VAR revenue increased, its contribution to operating margin decreased due to changes in mix (favoring software over hardware, due to shortages in the latter), while operating expenses were comparatively lower in the six months ended June 30, 2021, due to hiring delays. _LatAm_ Operating margin from LatAm increased by €7.0 million from €1.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €8.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, in part due to performance in Mexico, where certain IECISA contracts were relatively low-margin. _Other_ Operating margin from our Other countries increased significantly by €2.4 million from €1.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €4.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, in line with higher revenue in Eastern Europe including the contribution of JCommerce and reflecting the beginning of a recovery in Africa. Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions decreased slightly by €0.1 million, or 1.8%, from €4.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €4.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Restructuring costs Restructuring costs stayed largely consistent throughout the period under review, decreasing by €0.9 million, or 7.8%, from €11.5 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €10.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Restructuring costs during the six months ended June 30, 2022 consisted of a restructuring cost of €6.0 million in France (principally in relation to billables) and €3.2 million in Spain (principally in relation to billables and operating expenses). Gains (losses) on disposals Gains on disposals decreased from €2,000 for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €49,000 of losses for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Other operating income and expenses Other operating expenses stayed largely consistent throughout the periods under review, decreasing by €0.1 million, or 2.1%, from €5.0 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €4.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Operating profit Due to the factors described above, operating profit increased significantly by €10.4 million, or 21.4%, from €48.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €59.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Cost of net debt Cost of net debt decreased by €2.6 million, or 20.5%, from a loss of €12.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to a loss of €10.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This decrease was principally driven by reducing interest expense as a result of margin ratchet improvement, in connection with a better leverage ratio at the end of 2021. ----- Other financial income (expenses) Other financial income increased by €2.7 million, from an expense of €2.2 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to an income of €0.4 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was principally driven by favorable foreign exchange rate fluctuations. Income tax expense Income tax expense increased by €2.5 million, or 19.7%, from €12.7 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €15.2 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, in line with our profits before taxes. Net consolidated income Net consolidated income increased significantly by €13.2 million, or 62.6%, from €21.1 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to €34.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, driven by the factors described above. _Year ended December 31, 2021 compared to year ended December 31, 2020_ The table below sets out the results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020. _France_ Operating margin from France increased significantly by €25.5 million, or 58.3%, from €43.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €69.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, as a result of an increasing share of maintenance revenue from our Software Solutions activity and an improvement in activity ratio due to a return to historical levels following the easing of the COVID-19 pandemic, while our operating expenses were relatively stable, although impacted by higher bonuses. Operating margin improvement by activity and key drivers are as follows: - In our Application Services and Infrastructure Services activities, operating margin increased by €17.6 million and €3.7 million, respectively, from December 31, 2020 to December 31, 2021, in each case mostly driven by improved revenue and gross margin, due in turn to improved activity ratio and stable direct margin, slightly offset by increased operating expenses. - In our Business Solutions activity, operating margin increased by €5.8 million, driven by improved revenue and gross margin, due in turn to improved activity ratio and supported by stable direct margin, while operating expenses increased slightly over the period. - In our Outsourcing activity, operating margin decreased by €1.1 million from December 31, 2020 to December 31, 2021, driven by decreases in revenue and gross margin, due in turn to changes in projects which negatively impacted direct margin, while operating expenses decreased over the period. - In our Software Solutions activity, operating margin increased by €6.3 million, driven by improved revenue and gross margin in regards to both licenses and maintenance, while operating expenses increased slightly over the period. _Iberia_ Operating margin from Iberia increased by €10 million, or 21.4%, from €46.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €56.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, as a result of the integration ----- of IECISA and the implementation of synergies. Operating margin improvement in Iberia between the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021 was driven largely by the ongoing effects of the IECISA acquisition in Spain, reflecting savings initiatives, savings on subcontractor costs and other incremental savings and bottom-line growth driven by revenue growth and average selling price improvement, which were partially offset by additional management fees over the period. In Portugal, operating margin was supported by the strength of our various services offerings and, in particular, Cleva (an insurance software solution), which drove revenue, license business and average selling price improvement, which were partially offset by lower performances in our SAP business, due to a lack of new business. _BeLux_ Operating margin from BeLux increased by €4.8 million, or 21%, from €22.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €27.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. While revenue in our Application Services and Infrastructure services activities increased, gross and direct margin remained stable over the period. The increase in operating margin was partially offset by significantly higher operating expenses in connection with sales and marketing to catch up on recruitment, travel and marketing activities. Operating margin improvement between the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021 in BeLux was driven primarily by activity in Belgium, particularly in our Application Services and Infrastructure Services activities, where direct margin and gross margin remained stable and activity ratio improved slightly. Our Software Solutions and Business Solutions activities also benefited from improved operating margin, while operating expenses was significantly higher in the period, primarily due to increased sales and marketing costs from delated recruiting efforts connected to the COVID-19 pandemic and travel expenses, as discussed above. _LatAm_ Operating margin from LatAm (after giving effect to the reclassification of IECISA branches) increased by €1.2 million, or 37.0%, from €3.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €4.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, as a result of strong performance in Mexico, Colombia and Peru, which offset the ongoing impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic in other countries in LatAm. _Other_ Operating margin from our Other countries decreased slightly by €0.6 million, or 8.1%, from €7.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €6.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, as a result of declines in Africa over the period, with Morocco underperforming as compared to historic levels and experiencing changes to planned projects, which were not completely offset by higher direct margins in our Eastern European operations (in particular in Romania and Poland) as well as Switzerland, due to improvements to delivery, customer mix and average selling price, while operating expenses increased slightly. Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions increased by €1.7 million, or 22.9%, from €7.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €9.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was driven principally by purchase price allocation in connection with the acquisition of IECISA. Restructuring costs Restructuring costs stayed largely consistent throughout the period under review, increasing by €0.1 million, or 0.6%, from €15.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €16.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Gains (losses) on disposals Gains on disposals decreased from €1.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €2,000 for the year ended December 31, 2021. Other operating income and expenses Other operating expenses decreased significantly by €14.7 million, or 53.2%, from €27.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €12.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was driven ----- principally by a significant depreciation of Kidiliz’s trade receivables associated with the termination of the Kidiliz contract, which is currently the subject of a dispute, amounting to €13.9 million. Operating profit Due to the factors described above, operating profit increased significantly by €52.3 million, or 70.9%, from €73.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €126.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Cost of net debt Cost of net debt decreased by €1.8 million, or 6.7%, from a loss of €26.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to a loss of €24.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was driven principally by reducing interest expense as a result of margin ratchet improvements, in connection with a better leverage ratio at the end of 2020 and June 2021. Other financial income (expenses) Other financial expenses increased significantly by €3.6 million, from €0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €3.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was principally driven by favorable foreign exchange rate fluctuations. Income tax expense Income tax expense decreased slightly by €1.1 million, or 3.9%, from €29.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €28.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The reduction is mainly due to a decrease in the CVAE tax, pursuant to changed policy by the French government. Net consolidated income Net consolidated income increased significantly by €51.6 million, from €18.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €69.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, driven by the factors described above. _Year ended December 31, 2020 compared to year ended December 31, 2019_ The table below sets out the results of operations for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2019. _France_ Operating margin from France decreased by €16.2 million, or 27.1%, from €59.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €43.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 due to the decline in revenue (as discussed above). Gross margins slightly decreased primarily due to a percentage point drop in our activity ratio in France, which was partly offset by government subsidies for partial unemployment and reduced expenses in the COVID-19 context. Our average selling price in France was broadly stable and not significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. _Iberia_ Operating margin from Iberia grew significantly by €32.4 million from €14.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €46.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, due to the contribution of IECISA, which contributed €32.0 million to operating margin. Excluding the IECISA acquisition, operating margin increased by 2.8% over the period. The increase in operating margin was driven by the stabilization of the average selling price and the cost-base streamlining with IECISA. ----- _BeLux_ Operating margin from BeLux grew by €8.3 million, or 57.2%, from €14.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €22.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, in line with activity and against a stable direct margin. _LatAm_ Operating margin from LatAm decreased by €0.5 million, or 14.4%, from €3.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €3.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, as a result of lower results in Brazil and Mexico, which were only partially offset by growth in Peru. _Other_ Operating margin from our Other countries decreased slightly by €0.8 million, from €8.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, to €7.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions Amortization of intangibles identified on acquisitions almost doubled, from €3.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €7.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by the impact of the IECISA acquisition. Restructuring costs Restructuring costs increased significantly by €4.5 million, or 39.0%, from €11.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €15.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by the costs associated with the IECISA acquisition. Gains (losses) on disposals Gains on disposals increased significantly by €1.1 million, from €0.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €1.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by the termination of certain activity in Spain. Other operating income and expenses Other operating expenses increased significantly by €27.1 million, from €0.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €27.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by costs associated with the IECISA acquisition (€7.5 million) and the exceptional depreciation associated with the termination of the Kidiliz contract, which is currently the subject of a dispute (€13.9 million). Operating profit Due to the factors described above, operating profit decreased by €11.0 million, or 13.0%, from €84.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €73.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Cost of net debt Cost of net debt increased significantly by €10.7 million, or 69.4%, from a loss of €15.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to a loss of €26.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by an increase in interest expense as a result of the new borrowings that we undertook in connection with the IECISA acquisition. Other financial income (expenses) Other financial expenses decreased significantly by €1.2 million, or 87.6%, from €1.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €173,000 for the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was principally driven by favorable foreign exchange rate fluctuations in LatAm. Income tax expense Income tax expense increased by €4.7 million, or 19.1%, from €24.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €29.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was principally driven by the contribution of IECISA. ----- Net consolidated income Net consolidated income decreased significantly by €25.2 million, or 57.9%, from €43.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €18.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, driven by the factors described above.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue Revenue increased by €253.1 million, or 12.9%, from €2.0 billion for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €2.2 billion for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase results primarily from the IECISA acquisition, as well as from the integration of Ilex International and Projixy, while organic revenue growth was 4.9% over the same period, across all our geographic areas except Africa, particularly driven by the development of our services offering in Iberia, LatAm and BeLux, and across all of our activities, particularly our Business Solutions, VAR (notably in BeLux) and Infrastructure Services activities, as well as due to expansion of our offering following the acquisition of IECISA and to recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue Revenue increased significantly by €370.6 million, or 23.2%, from €1.6 billion for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €2.0 billion for the year ended December 31, 2020, largely due to the contribution of IECISA, which ----- contributed €422.1 million to revenue for the year ended December 31, 2020. We experienced lower activity in France due to the negative impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, largely in our Application Services activity among our Financial Services and Industries customers, which was partially offset by performance in our Outsourcing, Infrastructure Services and Software Solutions activities, which are, overall, more digitalized activities, supported by strong recurring revenue from SME and public sector customers, as well as French government subsidies. Organic growth between the year ended December 31, 2019 and December 31, 2020 was limited at 2.4%, as we were impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, which had differing impacts across the geographic areas in which we operate, with revenue in France decreasing overall, Iberia being relatively stable, BeLux and our Other countries continuing to grow.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: _Overview_ Historically, the principal sources of our liquidity have been cash flow from operating activities, bank credit lines and bonds. We have also engaged in the sale of receivables on a non-recourse basis in order to support our working capital and liquidity needs. Typically, receivables factored through non-recourse factoring transactions are written off from our financial statements upon their transfer, as all risks and benefits of the factored receivables are irrevocably transferred to the transferee. As at June 30, 2022, the amount of nonrecourse factored receivables excluded from our financial statements was €142.8 million. Following the completion of the Transactions, we intend to rely primarily on our operating cash flow, as well as our Revolving Credit Facility and the factoring of receivables to satisfy our working capital and other liquidity needs. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.” Historically, our principal uses of cash have been, and we expect that our principal uses of cash following the Transactions will be, to meet debt service requirements, provide working capital and fund capital expenditure. We believe that the current cash flow from operating activities, the Revolving Credit Facility and our nonrecourse factoring will provide us with sufficient liquidity to meet current working capital needs. _Cash flows_ The table below sets forth a summary of our consolidated statements of cash flows as of and for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021 and for the six-month periods ended June 30, 2021 and 2022.

This increase of change in working capital is due to the SAP implementation which led to a delay in invoicing and therefore in the collection of trade receivables, the impact of which amounted to approximately €50 million and which we expect to collect in the second half of 2022. Net cash from operating activities decreased by €88.6 million, from an inflow of €236.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to an inflow of €147.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was mainly attributable to the fluctuation in change in working capital requirements for operations, from €117.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to negative €34.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This fluctuation is the result of, among others, €45.9 million in advance payments received from IECISA’s former shareholders, a decrease of €50 million under our non-recourse factoring arrangements, and some delayed social charges in connection with COVID-19 of €19.8 million. Net cash from operating activities increased by €37.2 million from an inflow of €199.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to an inflow of €236.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. This increase was mainly attributable to a positive fluctuation in change in working capital requirements for operations of €35.3 million, from €82.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to €117.8 million for the year ended ----- December 31, 2020, as well as to a decrease in consolidated net income before income from discontinued operations of €22.3 million, from €43.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2019, to €21.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. Net cash flow from / (used in) investing activities Net cash flow used in investing activities increased by €42.0 million, from an outflow of €30.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, to an outflow of €72.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to the impact of acquisitions completed in each period. At the end of June 2022, the group acquired four entities (EditInfo-IT, JCommerce, Do IT Wise and Hutobee), leading to an outflow of €43.0 million, as compared to one acquisition (Projixi Europe) for €6.7 million in the 2021 comparable period. Net cash flow used in investing activities decreased by €242.9 million, or 79.1%, from an outflow of €307.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to an outflow of €64.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to the acquisition of IECISA, which involved a disbursement net of cash acquired amounting to €241.9 million. In 2021, the impact of entities acquired (Ilex International, Projixi Europe and HLi Consulting) amounted to €13.6 million. Net cash flow used in investing activities increased by €237.7 million, from an outflow of €69.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, to an outflow of €307.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to the impact of the IECISA acquisition, which led to an outflow of €269.2 million of net cash compared to €31.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. Net cash flow from / (used in) financing activities Net cash flow from financing activities decreased by €1.4 million, from an outflow of €50.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021 to an outflow of €48.9 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to repayments of lease contracts and interest payments. Net cash flow used in financing activities decreased by €355.4 million, from an inflow of €256.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to an outflow of €98.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to decreases in new borrowings, from €538.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €1.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, which were partly offset by decreases in repayment of borrowings, from €227.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020 to €49.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Net cash flow from financing activities increased by €345.6 million, from an outflow of €89.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to an inflow of €256.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to increases in new borrowings in the form of a loan to finance the acquisition of IECISA and bond debt, from €36.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €538.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, which were partly offset by increases in repayment of borrowings, from €59.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 to €227.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Capital Expenditure
Subsubsection Text: Capital expenditure consists of disbursements as a result of acquisition of intangible assets and disbursements from acquisition of property, plant and equipment. We mainly use our capital expenditure to finance our R&D activities which represent most of our disbursements for the acquisition of intangible assets. Our disbursements for the acquisition of property, plant and equipment encompass purchases of IT equipment, installation, fittings and other tangible assets.
