Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Capital expenditure increased by €1.6 million, or 7.3%, from €21.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021, of which €14.6 million was from disbursements as a result of acquisition of intangible assets, to €23.4 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022, of which €15.4 million was from disbursements as a ----- result of acquisition of intangible assets. This increase was primarily due to the R&D activity of Ilex International, which we acquired in 2021. Capital expenditure increased by €7.2 million, or 18.9%, from €38.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, of which €27.9 million was from disbursements as a result of acquisition of intangible assets, to €45.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, of which €30.8 million was from disbursements as a result of acquisition of intangible assets. This increase was primarily due to costs related to the implementation of SAP during the year ended December 31, 2021. Capital expenditure increased by €1.8 million, or 5.0%, from €36.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, of which €27.7 million was from disbursements as a result of acquisition of intangible assets, to €38.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, of which €27.8 million was from disbursements as a result of acquisition of intangible assets. This slightly increase was primarily due to the purchase of intangible assets during the year ended December 31, 2020. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we expect our capital expenditure for the year ending December 31, 2022 to amount to approximately €50 million, and that our capital expenditure as a percentage of revenue will remain in line with historical levels over the medium term.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: Commitments which are not recognized on the balance sheet are obligations with third parties arising from legal agreements with certain obligatory effects which have not been executed by either of the parties. They include commitments of a certain amount and execution (such as purchase and sale forwards) and commitments, the execution of which is certain but not the amounts. Such commitments are shown at their nominal amounts in accordance with the related supporting documentation. As part of the contracts that we have with our customers, we are required, at the formal request of customers, to take out bank guarantees with regard to commitments made in customer contracts. These guarantees represented €139.5 million as of June 30, 2022, as compared to €117.0 million as of December 31, 2021, €84.8 million as of December 31, 2020 and €12.1 million as of December 31, 2019. We have also engaged in the sale of receivables on a non-recourse basis in order to support our working capital and liquidity needs. Typically, receivables factored through non-recourse factoring transactions are written off from our financial statements upon their transfer, as all risks and benefits of the factored receivables are irrevocably transferred to the transferee. As of June 30, 2022, the amount of non-recourse factored receivables excluded from our financial statements was €142.8 million. Off-balance sheet arrangements relating to our financing activities include contractual limitations to our dividends and investments and compliance with certain financial criteria and ratios, as set out in certain of our debt agreements. For more information, please refer to the notes in our Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Qualitative and Quantitative Disclosure about Market and Financial Risks
Subsubsection Text: _Overview_ In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to exchange rate risk, credit risk, liquidity risk and interest rate risk. Our operating and financial policies are aimed at minimizing potential effects on our financial performance by improving our economic results and net financial position. This discussion does not address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk _Factors.” Exchange rate risk_ Our currency risk in respect of commercial transactions is not hedged, as most of our transactions are made within the euro zone, in euros. Outside of the euro zone, our revenue is generated in the currency of the relevant operating charges and few intercompany operating transactions are denominated in currencies other than the euro, thereby limiting exposure to foreign-exchange fluctuations. However, in light of current fluctuations in the exchange rate of the euro to other currencies, our exposure may currently be higher than it has in the past, including in the periods under review. The impact on our results for the year ended December 31, 2021 of a uniformly negative one centime change in the euro would total approximately €1 million. ----- _Credit risk_ Our credit risk mainly relates to trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents. Our exposure to credit risk is largely limited to failures of third parties, with a maximum exposure equal to the book value of the relevant instrument. The risk associated with trade receivables is assessed based on an analysis of receivables due and not impaired, which are continuously monitored. Regarding receivables transferred to our non-recourse factoring arrangements, insurance has been taken out to cover the risk of non-payment. _Liquidity risk_ Liquidity risk is the risk associated with the ability to meet commitments arising from financial liabilities. We have short and long-term debt. Prudent management of the liquidity risk arising from normal operations requires the maintenance of an adequate level of cash and the availability of funds obtainable through an adequate number of appropriately-sized credit lines. We further mitigate liquidity risk by ensuring that we have access to different sources of financing with different banking institutions and that there are no significant concentrations of liquidity risk on the side of both financial assets and the sources of financing. We also use non-recourse factoring arrangements and bank overdraft facilities to mitigate this risk. The medium to long-term debt structure used to finance our acquisitions and the availability of commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility and other long-term bank debt enable us to optimize the sources and application of funds and support us in developing our business. _Interest rate risk_ Our exposure to interest risk mainly derives from the volatility of financial charges in relation to debt, expressed at a variable rate. Fluctuations in market interest rates may affect our results, indirectly affecting costs and returns of financing and investment transactions. After completion of the Transactions, we will continue to be exposed to interest rate risk in connection with the Senior Facilities. The strategy that we follow for this type of risk mitigation is one that aims at mitigating interest rate risk while optimizing debt cost. Our main objective when managing this risk is to minimize the cost of debt, while guarding against fluctuations in interest rates. As such, we intend to hedge, within certain limits, an increase in the 3-month EURIBOR rate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies and Use of Estimates
Subsubsection Text: _Critical accounting policies_ The preparation of financial statements requires our management to apply accounting principles and methods which, in certain circumstances, are based on difficult and subjective assessments and estimates based on historical experience and assumptions that are considered reasonable from time to time and realistic according to the relative circumstances. The application of these estimates and assumptions affects the amounts reported in the Financial Statements and other information provided in this Offering Memorandum. The final results of the Financial Statement items for which such estimates and assumptions have been used may differ from those reported in the Financial Statements due to the uncertainty that characterizes the assumptions and conditions on which the estimates are based. The areas that require more subjectivity on the part of management in preparing the estimates, and for which a change in the conditions underlying the assumptions used could have a significant impact on the financial data, include the measurement of retirement benefit plans, testing of goodwill for impairment, provisions for liabilities and charges and the recoverability of deferred tax assets, each of which are described further below. _Measurement of retirement benefit plans_ Estimates are required in the accounting for defined benefit pension plans, including establishing discount rates, rates of increase in salaries and pensions in payment, inflation and mortality assumptions. These estimates are made by management based on the advice of qualified advisors. Details of the assumptions used and the sensitivity of the benefit obligation to these assumptions are set out in Note 4.3 (Retirement Benefit _Plans) to the financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 that are included elsewhere_ in this Offering Memorandum. _Testing of goodwill for impairment_ In accordance with IFRS, we assess whether goodwill has been impaired each year, or more frequently when there is an indication that it may have been impaired. The recoverable amount of the cash generating units has been calculated based on calculations of the value in use. These calculations require the use of estimates. ----- _Provisions for liabilities and charges_ Provisions for liabilities and charges are recognized to cover specific liabilities that are certain or probable, but whose amount or due date is unknown at the reporting date. Specifically, provisions for liabilities relate to specific liabilities whose occurrence is probable and amount estimated, while provisions for charges relate to specific liabilities, whose occurrence is certain and amount or due date estimated, that arise from obligations already taken on at the reporting date but which will be paid in subsequent years. Accruals to provisions for liabilities and charges are primarily recognized in the profit and loss account section to which the transaction relates, privileging the classification of costs by nature. The amount of the accruals to the provisions is based on the best estimate of costs, including the legal expenses, at each reporting date and is not discounted. Moreover, in estimating accruals to provisions for charges, we may consider the related time horizon, if a reasonable estimate of the amount required to settle the obligation and its due date is possible and the latter is so far into the future that the obligation’s present value and estimated liability will be considerably different at that settlement date. If the measurement of the accruals gives a range of values, the accrual represents the best possible estimate between the upper and lower thresholds of the range. The provisions are subsequently used directly and solely for those costs and liabilities for which they were originally set up. If they are not sufficient or are redundant, the shortfall or surplus is recognized in the profit and loss account in line with the original accrual. _Recoverability of deferred tax assets_ The recoverability of deferred tax assets is subject to the achievement of sufficiently large future taxable profits for the absorption of the aforementioned tax losses or to the competition of the deferred taxation connected to the other deferred tax assets. Significant management judgments are required to determine the amount of deferred tax assets that can be recognized in the financial statements based on the timing and amount of future taxable income. In particular, it should be noted that deferred tax assets have been recorded on past tax losses for the portion estimated recoverable against future taxable income shown in our updated strategic plans, also as a consequence of the fact that the tax losses may be carried forward indefinitely. _Revenue recognition policy_ We recognize revenue as follows: Technical assistance, consulting and systems integration billed at cost plus Revenue arising from these services is recognized as and when the services are rendered. Revenue is determined by reference to the contractually agreed price and to billable chargeable hours spent on the job. Invoices to be raised or deferred income are recognized when billing is out of phase with the stage of completion. Services invoiced for a fixed amount Revenue arising from these services is recognized by reference to the stage of completion based on costs incurred to date and costs that will be incurred subsequently. When it is probable that costs will exceed revenue, the expected loss is recognized immediately. Invoices to be raised or deferred income are recognized when billing is out of phase with the stage of completion. Systems integration associated with sales of software packages and hardware In general, the turnover of the two services is recognized separately. The part of the income relating to the software packages and materials is recorded during the delivery to the customer (transfer of control). The revenue of the integration service is recognized over time, based on costs incurred and costs remaining to be incurred. However, for license sales including a so-called complex integration, the software / hardware and integration constitute a single service. The corresponding overall income is recorded based on the costs incurred and the costs still to come. Sales of software and hardware For sales of software packages and hardware made independently of any service, the turnover is recognized when the control is transferred to the customer. Maintenance The turnover relating to these services is recorded on a pro rata basis over the duration of the contract. Transactions carried out as an agent When we act as an agent, the revenue relating to the transaction is not recognized. Only the margin achieved from such transactions is recorded under “Revenue.” -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations for the periods set forth below. This discussion should be read together with, and is qualified in its entirety by reference to, the Financial Statements that are included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The following discussion should also be read in conjunction with “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Summary Historical and Certain Other Financial Data.” The discussion in this section may contain forward-looking statements that reflect our plans, estimates and beliefs and involve significant risks and uncertainties. Our actual results could differ materially from those discussed in these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause or contribute to these differences include, but are not limited to, those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, particularly under “Risk Factors,” “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Forward-Looking Statements.” This section contains various Non-IFRS Measures, which are not prepared or presented in accordance with IFRS. Such measures may not accurately reflect our performance, liquidity or our ability to incur debt, have limitations as analytical tools, and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit, net profit, cash flow from operating activities or any other performance measures derived from or prepared or presented in accordance with IFRS, SEC requirements or any other generally accepted accounting principles. For more information, see “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Measures” and “Summary Historical and Certain Other Financial Data.” As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer is a holding company with no revenue-generating activities of its own, and no business operations or material assets, other than the shares it holds in the Company and its receivables under the Company Proceeds Loan, or material liabilities, other than those incurred in connection with its incorporation and the Transactions, including indebtedness incurred in connection with the Transactions. As a result, no financial information of the Issuer is included in this Offering Memorandum, except for certain limited “as adjusted” financial data presented on a consolidated basis as adjusted to reflect certain effects of the Transactions. All historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the Company and its consolidated subsidiaries. Accordingly, unless otherwise stated, all references to “we,” “us,” “our” or the “Group” in respect of historical financial information in this Offering Memorandum are to the Company and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis. In the future, we expect to report our financial results in respect of periods beginning with the year ending December 31, 2022 at the level of Lux Topco in accordance with IFRS. Lux Topco is a holding company with no revenue-generating activities of its own, no business operations, no material assets, other than the shares it holds in the Issuer, or material liabilities._

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Title: By Activity
Subsubsection Text: The IT services market can be broadly categorized into the following activities, which may vary from similarlynamed activities carried out by us: “Consulting”: This refers to general advisory covering business and technology strategy and operations. The Consulting activity is structured around two types of consulting: (a) strategy and management consulting and (b) digital and innovation consulting focused on digital transformation (our primary focus). The latter includes projects specifically designed for CIOs and CxOs (including in expertise areas such as cybersecurity, data/AI, process automation and cloud computing). In 2019, within our key markets, the Consulting activity accounted for approximately €7.0 billion in revenue. Despite a contraction due to the COVID-19 pandemic to an estimated €6.6 billion in 2021, growth in revenue is expected to resume at an estimated 8.8% CAGR during the period from 2021 to 2025, faster than pre-pandemic levels. Growth in Consulting is expected to be generated from customers’ need for upstream support, complexity management and digital transformation, led by both IT departments and business areas; “Application Services”: This consists of build-and-run activities, ranging from planning, specification and design to custom software development, packaged software implementation, integration of applications, all the way to maintenance and enhancement of existing applications. In 2019, within our key markets, the Application Services activity accounted for approximately €18.5 billion in revenue. After a brief contraction to an estimated €18.4 billion in 2021, revenue are forecasted to rebound strongly and grow at a CAGR of 8.3% during the period from 2021 to 2025. Growth is expected to be driven by customers’demand for build activities around new digital solutions and their transition to cloud-supported infrastructure; “Infrastructure Services”: This includes workplace support services such as field services, services desk, hardware maintenance, cloud services, cybersecurity and related activities. Infrastructure Services also encompass customization, integration of infrastructure products, and infrastructure managed services, such as data center outsourcing, hosting and management. Services can be catered to both public and private cloud-based environments. In 2019, within our key markets, the Infrastructure Services activity accounted for approximately €17.8 billion in revenue, and briefly contracted to an estimated €17.3 billion in 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. While forecasted growth is not expected to be as substantial as Consulting, the Infrastructure Services market is still expected to grow at a moderate pace at an estimated CAGR of 3.8% for the period from 2021 to 2025, mainly driven by infrastructure managed services; and ----- “Other”: This includes network services and hardware support. As of 2019, within our key markets, the revenue from the Other activities were approximately €4.3 billion. After a brief contraction to an estimated €4.0 billion in 2021, revenue is forecasted to grow at a CAGR of 1.3% for the period from 2021 to 2025.

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Title: By Geography
Subsubsection Text: Our key geographic markets are described below: France:_ France is our largest market, accounting for €941.9 million, or 41.2% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022. In 2019, the size of the IT services market in France was approximately €25.9 billion. Despite revenue being negatively impacted during the COVID-19 pandemic to reach an estimated €25.3 billion in 2021, the French IT services market is expected to resume its growth trajectory and record a CAGR of 5.5% for the period from 2021 to 2025 to reach an estimated size of approximately €31.3 billion. This growth is mainly expected to stem from the development of new high value-added services (such as cybersecurity, AI and cognitive systems) and cloud offerings. Financial Services and Public Healthcare are the leading industry verticals, accounting for approximately 45% of the French IT services market. Spain:_ Spain is our second largest, accounting for €666.0 million, or 29.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022. In 2019, the size of the IT services market in Spain was approximately €13.6 billion. While this market is less resilient in comparison to France, it is expected to rebound faster after downturns. After a brief contraction to an estimated €12.8 billion in 2021, the Spanish IT services market is expected to rebound strongly and record a CAGR of 6.9% for the period from 2021 to 2025 to reach an estimated size of €16.7 billion. Consulting and Application Services activities are expected to drive the majority of growth in the Spanish IT services market. Belgium:_ Belgium is a large and mature market, accounting for €298.7 million, or 13.1%, of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022. In 2019, the size of the IT services market in Belgium was approximately €6.5 billion. Not only has the market shown the strongest resiliency during the COVID-19 pandemic, rebounding to an estimated €6.5 billion in 2021, but it is also forecasted to grow at a solid CAGR of 7.0% for the period from 2021 to 2025 to reach an estimated size of €8.5 billion. Growth is expected to be predominately driven by an increase in IT expenditure and in the share of outsourced IT projects by Belgian companies. Portugal:_ Portugal is a maturing market that is growing faster than our other key markets, accounting for €138.8 million, or 6.1% of our revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022. In 2019 and 2021, the size of the IT services market in Portugal was estimated to be approximately €1.6 billion. While this market is less resilient in comparison to the ones in France, Spain and Belgium, it is expected to grow at a CAGR of 7.4% for the period from 2021 to 2025 after a brief contraction from 2019 to 2020, a faster pace than our other key markets, mainly driven by the market catching up on digitalization.

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: Enterprises and other organizations of all sizes and across all industries and sectors have been undergoing a digital transformation, with COVID-19 further accelerating this trend. Full-fledged digital transformations have led to a significant increase in IT expenditure globally. From customer-facing activities to internal reorganization processes, enterprises and other organizations are allocating an increasing portion of their related expenditure to the deployment of core digital technologies (e.g., cloud, AI, cybersecurity) as well as to the modernization of their underlying technology stack, legacy systems and infrastructure. As a result, IT has become mission critical for enterprises, capturing significant mindshare at the board level and shifting responsibilities from the CIOs (Chief Information Officers) to CxOs (Chief Experience Officers), and of increasing importance for other organizations, including public sector entities, as part of delivering their services and performing their mandates. Demand for independent, third-party digital transformation service providers like Inetum is underpinned by the increasing complexity of digital technology solutions, lack of skilled resources and a focus on cost-effectiveness. Our customers’ tech and IT architecture is becoming increasingly complex and requires additional support to design and interoperate both legacy systems and new digital solutions. With an acute shortage of skilled resources at their disposal, our customers increasingly rely on us for all their digital transformation needs. Along the same lines, our customers face ever growing pressure to allocate limited IT resources and drive cost efficiencies while optimizing investments and operating costs. In response, digital transformation service providers have adapted their business models by acquiring new capabilities, expanding their portfolio and industrializing their delivery system. They are bolstering internal capabilities through (i) “acqui-hiring” (i.e., purchasing companies in order to acquire their employees), especially with respect to next-gen technologies such as cloud, cybersecurity, CX, and RPA; (ii) venturing upstream into Consulting to support end-to-end digital transformation and to enable downstream business origination through CxOs; and (iii) industrializing and automating their operating models through shared service centers with service and quality commitments. We believe that the key countries in which we operate, France, Spain, Belgium and Portugal, from which we derived 89% of revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022, are large and ripe for digitalization. The IT services market in these key geographic markets is expected to grow from an estimated size of €46.1 billion in 2021 to €58.7 billion in 2025, which represents a CAGR of 6.2%, with most of the growth stemming from Application Services and Consulting activities. We offer our customers a broad set of IT services and solutions spanning the entire value chain, both upstream and downstream of the IT lifecycle. Our key activities include Consulting, Infrastructure Services and Application Services. The Consulting activity is upstream within the pre-design phase, whilst Application Services and Infrastructure Services span the entire value chain from build to run activities. We also offer proprietary software solutions and distribute hardware and software products, which are covered in subsequent sections. The following charts illustrate the split of the IT services market in our key markets, by geographic market and by activity segments. ----- _IT services market in our key markets by geography and activity segments, 2016-2025E Source: Company information and estimates._

Subsection Title: Key Market Growth Drivers
Subsubsection Title: IT services market through the cycles
Subsubsection Text: Over the past 25 years, the IT services market has grown consistently globally at or above the year-on-year global GDP growth rate, with periods of acceleration, mainly driven by technology transition. As set forth in the graph below, the global IT services market has broadly grown by 3 – 5% per year over the long term, even during periods of economic disruptions. While growth in IT services slowed globally after the global financial crisis, it rebounded at the start of 2015 and has accelerated since 2021. This new phase of growth is spurred by digital and cloud transformation trends. The increasing complexity and mission-critical nature of IT services, alongside increased reliance on IT services providers for all digitalization needs have greatly added to the underlying resilience in performance through economic cycles and downturns. ----- _Global IT services market ($ billion) (1996–2021) Sources: Bain Capital analysis, with use of IMF and World Bank data._ As shown below, IT services expenditure within our key markets as a percentage of GDP is lower compared to the other major European countries as well as the United States, indicating a degree of structural underpenetration in such markets. For instance, countries such as France and Spain had IT services expenditure as a percentage of GDP at 1.4% and 1.5% in 2019, respectively. This would suggest that these countries are still relatively at the early stages of their shift to cloud-based services and solutions. We believe this underpenetration is an indicator of a forward growth trajectory as both private and public sector customers continue to increase their IT investments to remain competitive and fill the technology gap that currently exists in comparison with other major economies. We believe the runway for the current wave of growth within our key markets is long, with most CIOs projecting the market to stabilize at higher growth levels in the future. _IT services expenditure as % of GDP, 2019_ 2.9% 2.1% 1.9% 1.8% 1.8% 1.8% 1.6% 1.5% 1.4% 1.2% 1.0% UK US Finland NetherlandsDenmark Belgium Sweden Spain France Portugal Italy _Source: Company, Bain Capital, analysis using IMF data._

Subsection Title: Key Market Growth Drivers
Subsubsection Title: Structural Growth Drivers
Subsubsection Text: _End to end digitalization across all markets and industry verticals_ Digitalization is transforming organizations’ operating models, affecting daily business operations as well as internal and external stakeholder interactions. This transformation is enhancing productivity and increasing the competitiveness of enterprises, governments, and mid-market customers. The COVID-19 pandemic has been a catalyst of this phenomenon and has accelerated trends such as e-commerce penetration, work from home and outsourcing cost initiatives. As set forth in the charts below, investments in legacy IT services are fairly stable, accounting for roughly two-thirds of the revenue within the IT services market (including IaaS and business consulting) in 2020. However, digital transformation-related services in France and Spain are forecasted to continue growing at a double-digit rate to account for an estimated 49% and 60% of the total IT services market (including IaaS and business consulting), respectively, confirming the trend towards digitalization away from legacy. -----

Subsection Title: None of the above
Subsubsection Text: |and US, % of total workloads|Col2|Col3|Col4|Col5|Col6|Col7|Col8|Col9| |---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---| |||||||||| |60%||||8%||9%||23%| |||||||||| |53%|||12%||7%||28%|| |||||||||| |41%|7%|10%||42%||||| |||||||||| 9% On-premise Co-location Managed hosting Public cloud 37% 28% 21% 19% We believe that IT services and solutions lie at the heart of the increasing digital world we live in and that laying out the adequate IT architecture has become a strategic imperative for technology driven organizations. To thrive and ensure agile delivery models, organizations are strongly incentivized to invest in their technology infrastructure and offerings. Investment in IT services should be deployed in response to evolving customer needs, boost development pace and delivery times, as well as move existing infrastructure to the cloud. This trend is expected to create lasting opportunities for IT services providers as most public and private organizations are still in the first phase of this transformation. _Increasing complexity_ The IT architecture constitutes the backbone of organizations’ business operations (processes and functions), business applications and databases and the equipment and services that run the applications. Traditional product development was driven largely by hardware considerations. With the surge of digital applications, today’s tech-enabled products depend on the successful integration of multiple hardware and software components, which makes their development a multidimensional and highly complex process. Integrations can be difficult and unpredictable due to the complexity and intricate nature of software IT infrastructure. Acquired technologies are typically developed independently and may not have been designed to integrate existing products. Such difficulties are compounded when products involved are well established, as compatibility with the existing base of installed products must be preserved. -----

Subsection Title: Focus on Our Key Markets
Subsubsection Title: France
Subsubsection Text: _France’s IT services market evolution (€ billion) (2016 – 2025)_ France is our biggest market with a total IT services market size of €25.9 billion in 2019. France has demonstrated solid historical growth with a CAGR of 3.4% for the period from 2016 to 2019, primarily driven by consulting services growing on the back of an increasingly complex IT architecture and digital innovation and transformation. Digital accounted for 35% of the IT services market size (including IaaS and business consulting) in 2020, recorded strong growth of 16% per year for the period from 2016 to 2020, and contributed to 72% of overall IT expenditure growth during such period. The French IT services market resumed growth in 2021 and is expected to keep growing at approximately 5 – 6% per year until 2025, supported by the Financial Services and Public Healthcare industry verticals that are expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.0% and 5.6%, respectively during the period from 2021 to 2025. The growth is substantiated by the French Government’s recovery plan which aims at digitizing both public administrations and SMEs through upskilling digital capabilities and investments in digital tools and capabilities. The forecast anticipates stronger growth rates for Consulting and Application Services activities (8.3% and 8.1%, respectively, for the period from 2021 to 2025). The growth in the Consulting activity is expected to be due to the continuation of digital transformation projects, while the growth in the Application Services is expected to be driven by growth in both the application managed services (commercial and custom applications managed services) and application implementation during the same period. On the other hand, revenue from the Infrastructure Services activity is expected to recover from the COVID-19 impact at a slower pace, with a forecasted CAGR of 2.3% during the period from 2021 to 2025.

Subsection Title: Focus on Our Key Markets
Subsubsection Title: Spain
Subsubsection Text: _Spain’s IT services market evolution (€ billion) (2016 – 2025)_ Spain’s IT services market has historically been the fastest growing of our key markets, recording a CAGR of 6.2% for the period from 2016 to 2019 to reach a market size of approximately €13.6 billion market in 2019. Growth has been fueled by the Consulting and Application Services activities, which have grown at a CAGR ----- of 9.8% and 6.5%, respectively, during the same period, and accounted for 15% and 38% of our revenue in 2019. Similar to France, digital accounted for 35% of the IT services market size (including IaaS and business consulting) in 2020 and grew at a CAGR of 12% for the period from 2016 to 2020. The Spanish IT services market, which is forecasted to grow at a CAGR of 6.9% during the period from 2021 to 2025, shares similar characteristics with the French market, where the Financial Services and Public Healthcare industry verticals are expected to remain the largest industry verticals and are forecasted to grow at a CAGR of 7.2% and 6.8% from 2021 to 2025, respectively. From an activity standpoint, Consulting and Application Services activities are expected to drive the Spanish IT services market in the next years. Together, they accounted for an estimated 53% of the IT services market and are forecasted to grow at a CAGR of 9.2% and 8.5% from 2021 to 2025, respectively. Growth in the Consulting activity is expected to be predominantly driven by digital transformation projects of big and mid-size companies across industry verticals. On the other hand, Application Services activity growth is expected to be fueled by custom and commercial applications to support the modernization of legacy infrastructure.

Subsection Title: Focus on Our Key Markets
Subsubsection Title: Belgium
Subsubsection Text: _Belgium’s IT services market evolution (€ billion) (2016 – 2025)_ Belgium is our third largest key market, with a total IT services market size of €6.5 billion in 2019, having grown at a CAGR of 4.4% over the period from 2016 to 2019. The market has demonstrated stronger resilience than France and Spain during the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenue expected to fully recover in 2021 after the 2020 dip caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Belgium shares similar growth attributes to the French and Spanish markets. Consulting and Application Services activities constitute the main growth drivers of the IT services market, supported by the need for digital transformation projects for mid-market and large companies across industry verticals. In addition, Financial Services, Public Healthcare, and TMT having been resilient during the COVID-19 pandemic, and are expected to continue growing in the future, aided by a €575.0 million Belgian recovery plan that puts digital transformation at the center of its priorities. From an activity standpoint, the Consulting activity is expected to experience the strongest growth at a CAGR of 8.9% for the period from 2021 to 2025, exceeding historical growth levels, with the Application Services activity also expected to grow at a CAGR of 8.9% during the same period, largely driven by commercial and customer applications, partly due to the “API-zation” of companies.

Subsection Title: Focus on Our Key Markets
Subsubsection Title: Portugal
Subsubsection Text: The Portuguese IT services market had total revenue of approximately €1.6 billion in 2019 and 2021. Portugal is less resilient and, as a result, sees greater swings in revenue during periods of upturn and downturn. While the IT services market recorded a CAGR of 5.1% over 2016 to 2019, it also contracted by 6.8% from 2019 to 2020. After an expected recovery in 2021, the IT services market is forecasted to grow at a CAGR of 7.4% during the period from 2021 to 2025, mainly driven by the market catching-up on digitalization. The Consulting activity accounted for an estimated 30% of the revenue from the Portuguese IT services market in 2021, approximately twice the proportion as in our other key markets, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 9.8% during the period from 2021 to 2025. This growth is expected to be due to numerous service ----- centers in need of management consulting projects to ensure adequate strategy run and implementation. Financial Services and Public Sector and Healthcare are the two largest industry verticals representing an estimated 46% of revenue in the IT services market, broadly in line with our other key markets.

Subsection Title: Focus on Our Key Markets
Subsubsection Title: Other Key IT Services and Solutions
Subsubsection Text: Beyond Consulting, Application Services and Infrastructure Services, we also have, among others, our Software Solutions and Value-Added Reselling activities. A brief description of the French enterprise Software Solutions market and the Value-Added Reselling activity is provided below. _French enterprise Software Solutions market_ The software solutions activity covers activities from design, distribution to maintenance of software packages for enterprises and other organizations. The market for software solutions can be categorized into Infrastructure and Applications Software. Infrastructure Software is designed for IT professionals to run and manage the performance of IT resources. Applications Software is split in two categories—Horizontal Software that are typically industry-agnostic and targeted to a wide audience of business users and functions such as human resources, sales and accounting and, Vertical Specific Software (VSS) that are industryspecific and cover core and non-core business processes with limited replicability across industries. We mostly address the VSS market. _French enterprise software solutions market (€ billion) (2016 – 2020) CAGR 16A-19A CAGR 16A-20A_ **+8.1%** **+5.7%** 3.9 3.9 **+4.4% 3.7 5.9 5.7 **+7.3% 4.3 4.8 5.2 **+5.1%** 5.0 5.2 5.5 6.1 6.1 2016A 2017A 2018A 2019A 2020A Infrastructure applications Horizontal applications Vertical specific software In France, as of 2019, revenue from the software solutions market was approximately €16.4 billion, having grown at a CAGR of 8.1% during the period from 2016 to 2019, roughly in line with global trends. The COVID-19 pandemic has moderately impacted the market, with revenue decreasing by 1.5% from 2019 to 2020. In this regard, the software solutions market is more resilient compared to our other activities, as software faces greater exposure to the acceleration of digitalization efforts as increased software rollout is required to support remote working, e-learning, telehealth, and other essential digital services. While all categories of the software solutions market grew at healthy rates from 2016 to 2019, horizontal applications grew at faster rates, driven by more overall equipment, higher adoption of SaaS solutions, and move from custom specific to commercial off-the-shelf solutions. The VSS category, which we mostly address, had estimated revenue of €4.4 billion in 2020, representing approximately 27% of the total software solutions market. The Financial Services and Public Sector and Healthcare industry verticals were the largest VSS sub-categories and delivered sustained growth during the period from 2016 to 2020. The market for French VSS is expected to accelerate during the period from 2021 to 2025 and is forecasted to grow at CAGR of 10.4% to reach an estimated size of €7.2 billion. All the key industry verticals sub-categories are expected to show significant growth, but at varying levels. Financial Services, Public Healthcare and Retail Consumer Good are expected to experience some of the highest growth rates, with forecasted CAGRs of 10.6%, 11.9% and 12.7%, respectively, during the period from 2021 to 2025. While the growth in Public Healthcare-specific software is expected to be driven by digitalization efforts, Financial Services-specific software growth is expected to stem from the need for standardized solutions in business processes and from the increasing development of fit-for-purpose solutions. The graph below sets forth the progression of the French VSS market by industry vertical from 2016 to 2025. |+8.1% 3.9 3.9 3.7 4.3 4.8 5.2 5.0 5.2 5.5|4.4|Col3|4.4|Col5| |---|---|---|---|---| ||5.9||5.7|| ||6.1||6.1|| ----- _French VSS market by industry vertical (€ billion) (2016 – 2025) CAGR 16A-19A CAGR 16A-19A_ 0.4 2016A 2019A 2020A 2021E 2025E Financial Services Public - Healthcare Energy - Utilities TMT Transport Retail - Consumer Good Wholesale Trade The expansion of the French software market is supported by the rise in off-the-shelf market applications, which entail the shift away from custom, in-house built solutions. This shift is justified by high upfront development costs, potential for mutualization and reliability of market solutions. Concurrently, enterprises are moving from on-premises software to SaaS, which has become a market standard for new solutions. In addition, continuous innovation around digital solutions, coupled with new go-to-market strategies through development of market partnerships, are creating new business opportunities around SMACS, especially analytics and artificial intelligence offerings. _Value-Added Reselling (VAR)_ VAR represents an upselling opportunity for IT services providers and consists of various valuable services to end-customers. VAR includes distribution activities for both hardware and software, including training, personalization, and installation: - Distribution of software and hardware products, intermediating software publishers and hardware equipment manufacturers to end-customers. Value-Added Resellers often have structured partnerships with manufacturers, ensuring higher trust from customers and guarantee of better access to services (e.g., technical support); - Advice on hardware and software packaging to meet customers’ needs and on technical ecosystem; - Personalization and installation: VAR can take care of software configurations but also create product bundles (e.g., combination of vertical-specific software and hardware along with turnkey hardware and installed software solutions); and - Training customers to understand the functionality behind the IT architecture. Value-Added Resellers act as key intermediaries between manufacturers and end-customers. On one hand, manufacturers enjoy an increased customer base reach at a lower search cost given the scattered SME market. On the other hand, Value-Added Resellers represent a one-stop-shop with both material and procurement installation. The revenue model varies depending on the type of service sold (e.g., one-off margins applied in the event of a products sale, recurring commission fee on software subscriptions and additional revenue coming from extra services such as support or training).

Subsection Title: Competitive Landscape, Key Purchasing Criteria and Barriers to Entry
Subsubsection Title: Key Differentiators
Subsubsection Text: The chart below shows the results of a proprietary survey conducted in 2021 for medium and large size companies in France and Spain with respect to certain key performance criteria with respect to both our customers and non-customers. ----- _KPC comparison against peers, (%) (2021) Source: Market Report, Company analysis, Proprietary survey (KPC)._ In both France and Spain, we believe that we stand out in terms of our flexibility, customer proximity and price criteria, which provide a clear competitive edge for mid-market customers and a strong “value for money”positioning for large customers. While technical capabilities are considered in line with market average for large companies in France, they fall slightly lower than the average in some sectors in Spain where global majors have the upper hand. For mid-market companies in Spain, we believe we are perceived to possess deep technical and delivery capabilities. This combination of broad technical capabilities and local footprint gives us a structural advantage over both global majors and smaller local providers. On the one hand, we are nimbler and customer-centric while offering the full suite of IT services like global majors. On the other hand, we also guarantee high quality of service alongside deep sector expertise, unlike smaller providers in the market. We believe that the combination of these characteristics represents a significant barrier to entry for foreign competitors. The chart above shows the market share of each type of IT services providers in key European markets in 2019. As illustrated in the graph below, low-cost Indian operators (which play a key role in some IT services markets) have a limited presence in France and are virtually absent in Spain, which are two of our key markets. As a result, this limits competitive pressure from Indian operators in markets that are otherwise fairly fragmented across global, local, mid-tier and other operators. In addition, multi-local providers have some of the highest market share in key markets, similar to local branches of major global IT providers, demonstrating our strong competitive positioning across our key geographic markets. _Market share by type of provider, (%) (2019) Source: Company and Bain Capital analysis._ In addition to the market-specific attributes listed above, our competitiveness is driven by three internal levers, which are in line with industry best practices. Firstly, we are gradually transitioning to a vertical sales ----- organization, offering sectorial expertise and increased relevance to customers and potentially leading to increased wins and further upselling (especially in France and in the Financial Services industry vertical). This transition is in line with global majors’ organizational structure set up. Secondly, we are improving our performance in talent attraction with further room for improvement to recruit top experts and program managers, while retention is on par with best performers. Finally, we have strong established partnerships with major editors and global software providers (for example, SAP, Sage, Microsoft, Salesforce and Oracle). This not only testifies to our reputation in delivery solutions, but it also allows us to provide specialized vertical integrated solutions, enabling market share gain and differentiation.

Subsection Title: Competitive Landscape, Key Purchasing Criteria and Barriers to Entry
Subsubsection Text: The IT services competitive landscape is highly fragmented, with the top 15 companies representing approximately 50% of total revenue of the IT services market in France and Spain. Four archetypes of providers compete in the IT services market, and they are divided based on providers’ footprint, value chain positioning and technological know-how: - Global majors represent global IT services providers with worldwide footprint and deep capabilities across most industry verticals and technologies. Global majors possess the largest portfolio of capabilities on the market with a wide array of product and service offerings. Key global majors include Accenture, Capgemini, Atos and IBM; ----- - Multi-local generalists represent generalist IT services providers with regional footprint and higher customer proximity and intimacy. Multi-local generalists include Sopra, Indra, NTT Data and us; - Local providers are characterized by local footprint and integrated activities with focus on costs and efficiencies. Examples of local providers include Ayesa, Infotel, NRB and Neurones; and - Vertical or Functional specialists are local or international providers with a focus on a specific industry or technology (e.g., cybersecurity), usually with higher digital maturity. Specialists are good M&A candidates as they typically fill a gap in the portfolio of service offerings. Key providers in the space include Devoteam, HR Path and Cloudreach. We are positioned as a multi-local generalist, competing against global majors and other providers within the IT services market. Nevertheless, we do not have the same positioning on main IT activities. While global majors enjoy the largest portfolio of capabilities, multi-local generalists like us benefit from a strong foothold and customer intimacy in key geographies. Global majors have a multinational footprint with exposure to multiple businesses. They also enjoy higher levels of performance, with approximately 13% (non-weighted) average adjusted operating margin in 2019, compared to approximately 7% for multi-local generalists. This performance premium is driven by a favorable business mix coupled with higher average daily rates (ADR); in addition to industrialized delivery capabilities with cost advantage in offshore location and scale effect optimization (e.g., better leverage of global pyramid). Market shares are relatively stable organically, with substantial changes only explained by M&A activity such as the acquisition of Galitt in 2017 by Sopra Steria, or the acquisition of Silvio and Sutter Mills by Accenture in 2019. These dynamics grant us with a relatively protected market structure. Furthermore, our key markets is characterized by unique attributes, which constitute significant barriers to entry for potential foreign competitors: - Customer proximity and intimacy, which allows IT services providers to be responsive to their customers’ needs. We have approximately 40 sites in France and are present in the 12 largest cities; - Strong historical relationships with local customers, in addition to the complexities and high costs normally associated with switching existing IT services providers. Inetum is one-stop shop for fast-growing mid-market customers; - Deep knowledge of local market dynamics, regulatory dynamics and providers’ ecosystems; - Language barriers in each of the countries in which we operate represent an important advantage to domestic providers vis-à-vis foreign competitors; and - Deeply entrenched and mission-critical offerings for regulated and technical customer organizations, especially in the energy and healthcare sectors.

The application implementation market is mostly dominated by key global majors and multi-local generalists. The top 15 providers account for approximately 73%, 64% and 66% of 2021 total revenue from this market in France, Belgium and Spain, respectively. Among these, the top five providers in France, Belgium and Spain account for approximately 49%, 34% and 45%, respectively, of total revenue in 2021. In 2021, within each of our key markets, we were ranked within the top five in revenue in the application implementation services market, coming ahead of global leaders such as IBM, CGI and Microsoft. -----

16-20 20-25 16-20 20-25 2016 2020 2025E Legacy Digital _Note: IT services market includes IaaS and business consulting_ 2016 2020 2025E Legacy Digital Digitalization is driven by the growth of core digital technologies, which are transforming customer interactions and internal ways of working. SMACS (Social, Mobile, Analytics, Cloud, Security) have a key area of growth. For example, in the French IT services market (including IaaS and business consulting), revenue from SMACS grew at a CAGR of 15.6% from 2015 to 2019. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic impacting the French market negatively in 2020, SMACS demonstrated strong resiliency by growing during the same period. Each of the SMACS areas are described below: (i) _Social:_ This represents social networks and internal communication channels, disrupting traditional models of workplace by connecting people and enabling them to work collaboratively. Examples include the implementation of collaborative solutions such as Zoom and Microsoft Teams, spurred by the trend towards working from home. (ii) Mobility: This refers to mobile applications allowing users to connect anytime and anywhere to traditional services. Mobile applications cover custom mobile apps with strong user interfaces across various verticals and functions. Examples include but are not limited to banking apps, insurance apps and data synchronization platforms. (iii) Analytics: This refers to big data analytics for businesses, which gives the ability to process, extract and use knowledge from data sources such as social media sites, GPS-based tracking systems, point of sale equipment and Machine Learning. Google Analytics is a primary example that enables users to measure advertising ROI and track website traffic, amongst other functions. (iv) Cloud: This encompasses cloud computing services such as Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS), Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS), Software-as-a-Service (SaaS), and Network-as-a-Service (NaaS). Cloud can be public or hybrid (public and private cloud servers mix). Cloud IT services offerings include moving legacy infrastructure to the cloud, re-platforming, and integration of cloud native SaaS solutions. AWS, Microsoft Azure and Google Cloud are primary examples of cloud computing platforms that provide distributed computing processing capacity and software tools. Cloud is the key contributor within SMACS, for example, with a market size of €6.7 billion in 2020 in France (approximately 45% of the French SMACS estimated revenue). (v) _Security:_ This refers to cybersecurity and its integration within organizations’ operating models to protect against digital attacks. Cybersecurity is now essential to data and privacy protection. Examples of IT services offerings include testing capabilities, access and identity management implementation, as well as personal data protection. Palo Alto Networks and Fortinet are good examples of leading cybersecurity solution providers. Legacy projects still represent approximately 65% of the total IT services market (including IaaS and business consulting) in France and Spain. In some industry verticals, the share of legacy technology and applications is quite high. For example, the share of legacy technology and applications in the Spanish public sector was estimated to be approximately 85% in 2020. In addition, revenue from the Financial Services industry vertical in the IT services market in our key markets is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.6% from 2021 to 2025, and the Public—Healthcare industry vertical is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.2% during the same period. This highlights our key markets’ potential to grow as industry verticals continue to transform and achieve greater digital maturity. _Increased IT outsourcing across all geographies Internal vs. External IT services expenditure in our key geographies (€ billion; %) (2016 – 2019)_ **60% 55%55% 50%50% < 10%< 10%** Middle office Back officeMiddle office Back office OverallOverall OSSOSS Non-OSSNon-OSS Core systemCore systysysysyyysyyysysyyysysysysysysysysyysysyyssssssss em ProcessProcess _France_ 37.4 39.4 37% 34% 63% 66% 2016 2019 **60% 55%55% 50%50% < 10%< 10%** _Spain_ 20.0 17.2 32% **+3.3% 34% 66% 68% **+6.2% 2016 2019 External Internal _Belgium_ 8.7 7.7 26% 25% 74% 75% 2016 2019 CAGR 16-19 _Portugal_ 2.7 2.4 42% 41% 58% 59% 2016 2019 _Note: Internal services includes internal IT staff_ Traditionally, companies have outsourced their business processes mainly to achieve cost savings efficiencies. In recent years, outsourcing has further evolved to encompass more sophisticated IT services offerings because of customers’ greater demand for digital products and services. While overall IT expenditure is growing in our key geographies, the share of external expenditure is growing slightly faster than the share of internal expenditure in these same geographies. For example, during the period from 2016 to 2019, the share of IT services which were outsourced externally in France and Spain increased from 63% and 66% to reach 66% and 68%, respectively. Four main drivers are fueling this transformation: (i) _Cost base variabilization:_ the pooling of resources within industrialized service centers. (ii) Quality requirements: beyond cost improvement, the need for commitment to service quality levels and overall end-user engagement, with a focus on managed services offerings. (iii) Delivery risk reduction: the need to access rare skilled resources to handle new tech-intensive demands contributing to the growth of industrialized and highly productive delivery models for IT services providers (e.g., managed services and cross-shoring (offshoring for cost efficiency, re-shoring or nearshoring for customer proximity and further responsiveness)). ----- (iv) IT department role switch: as businesses’ back-end operations increase in complexity, the role of the IT department has moved from that of a solution provider to one of pilot and architect supervising outsourced operations. _Permanent COVID-19 impact_ The COVID-19 pandemic has permanently altered the way businesses and society operate. According to a study conducted by a consulting company, the pandemic propelled society five years forward in consumer and business digital adoption. Effectively, remote working and virtual meetings are expected to remain part of the working culture (albeit being used less intensely than at the pandemic’s peak), digital transformations have accelerated and the adoption of automation and AI has increased. According to a survey in the EU and US at the end of 2020 conducted by a market-leading consultancy, approximately 52% of survey respondents anticipate a permanent increase in the use of collaboration tools solutions, such as voice, video, messaging and project management tools. This is followed by 46% and 37% of respondents expecting such an increase in network security and capacity, and identification and access management, respectively. With the rise of the digital transition and the adoption of new solutions, the need for move-to-cloud services has significantly increased. The share of location of application workloads on public cloud in the US and the US is forecasted to reach 42% in 2023, up from 23% in 2018. _Expected permanent increase in IT Solutions and expected location of application workloads_

Subsubsection Title: Stable and diverse customer base, with long-term relationships driving more predictable, recurring and repeatable revenue streams
Subsubsection Text: Our customer base of over 10,000 customers is very broad and includes a mix of large and growing blue-chip customers and mid-market customers. We are one of the preferred suppliers for many European blue-chip companies, which have significant digitalization and legacy transformation needs and require IT service providers like us that have at-scale delivery capabilities. On the other hand, mid-market customers require a combination of broad technical capabilities, flexibility and a local footprint. Our customers value our consistent quality, the breadth of our IT services and solutions that are tailored to their needs, our understanding of local market characteristics and our comprehensive suite of offerings. We believe that these factors, along with our active management of relationships with our customers, contribute to our consistently high customer satisfaction rates (approximately 90% in France in the year ended December 31, 2021 according to customer satisfaction surveys that we perform at the end of projects on a continuous basis), which we believe contributes to our increasing contract renewal rates (calculated on the basis of the total value of existing contracts rolled forward in any given year), which in France have been at or above 90% since 2019 and at 95% for the year ended December 31, 2021, and the longevity of our customer relationships (almost all of our top ten customers from 2012 were still within our top 16 customers in 2021). We have been serving more than half of our top ten customers for more than ten years, with some relationships dating back to 1995, and our revenue from our top ten customers has grown at a CAGR of approximately 4% ----- over the past ten years, with eight out of ten customers generating higher absolute revenue in 2021 and a relatively similar operating margin over that same period. At the same time, we benefit from low customer concentration and significant customer diversification across our industry verticals. In 2021, our top customer, top ten customers and top 35 customers accounted for 2.7%, 17.5% and 35.3% of our revenue, respectively. We believe that this diversity increases our resilience to periods of economic uncertainty and other fluctuations in the macroeconomic environment of the countries in which we operate. The chart below shows the increasingly diverse nature of our customer base.

Subsubsection Text: Consulting Outsourcing 2% 8% SolutionsSoftware8% ApplicationServices36% VAR 9% Infrastructure Services 17% Business Solutions 20% _Source: Company information_ Industry & Services 7% TMT 9% RCG 10% EUC 10% Defence & Security 5% TTS 11% Public Sector & Healthcare 25% Financial Services 22% Digital c.40%+ Software Solutions 8% VAR 12% Outsourcing 14% Project Build 16% Time & Material 29% System Integration, App Mgmt and Other 21% Non-Digital 60% ----- The breadth of our services and solutions gives us exposure to the industry verticals shown in the chart above, with no industry vertical representing more than 30 % of our revenue in 2021. Our services and solutions include both those that are tailored to specific industry verticals and those that are transversal in nature, _i.e., those that span industry verticals by catering to common problems, including for example, our activity,_ time and content management solutions. For example, in our Public Sector and Healthcare industry vertical, we have tailored and refined our services and solutions for over 40 years to become a privileged partner to more than 3,000 public organizations, (i) providing consulting services focused on digital and open government models, digital education, re-engineering and automation of public procurement processes and property management adoption, (ii) improving the citizen experience with a public/social CRM, citizen and transparency portals, and open data platforms and (iii) shaping smart territories with our intelligent city solutions. In the Financial Services industry vertical, we provide innovative offerings including (i) IT services relating to funds administration, payments and settlements solutions, regulatory compliance, risk management and credit management, (ii) compliance solutions to insurance customers with over €14.0 billion in assets managed, helping them monitor approximately 14 million property and casualty contracts, which cover over 8 million individuals and (iii) instant payments and cash management evolution and integration to help expand digital payments usage. In addition to these services, we offer powerful proprietary IP Software Solutions for Public Sector customers, which differentiates our offering in areas such as finance, HR, school transport, intelligent and collaborative territories, social protection, taxation and management of urban planning and housing, emergency medical services, fire services and emergency management. We believe that our business benefits from a relatively high proportion of our operating revenue being generated by sales of Software Solutions based on our own proprietary software or other IP. In 2021, sales from our Software Solutions accounted for 8% of our total revenue. We believe that, in addition to generating recurring revenue and increasing operational leverage, IP-rich software solutions tend to strengthen customer relationships and support strong customer retention, which can enable cross-selling and up-selling of additional services and software, and enhance margins. We have also been investing in strengthening and growing our digital capabilities to cater to the increasing demand for such services and solutions, with digital services and solutions across our services and solutions accounting for approximately 40% of our total contract value for the year ended December 31, 2020. Some of our digital services and solutions include advisory in digital transformation, digital customer experience customization, digital workplace transformation, contract modernization, cloud migration, virtualization and maintenance, data analytics, cybersecurity solutions, and robotic process automation. Finally, we are a long-standing partner of market leading software and cloud vendors for workplace solutions (including Red Hat, Oracle and ServiceNow), data center and multi-cloud providers (including AWS, Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure) and network and security providers (including Palo Alto Networks). For instance, we benefit from a relationship with SAP spanning over 20 years, resulting in approximately 2,300 accreditations and 350 certifications. These strong vendor relationships allow us to provide our customers with the best solution to suit their needs.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Long-term track record of resilient top-line growth and cash generation, with prudent financial leverage policy
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our business has a differentiated growth platform which is demonstrated by the historic performance driven by our diverse value proposition and efficient execution capabilities. These have been key factors to our above-market growth over the years. By leveraging our resilient and flexible business model through economic downturns, we have demonstrated our ability to maintain profitability while expanding our business through a combination of organic and acquisition-led growth. The following graphics show the evolution of our organic and reported revenue, margins and cash flow conversion over time, demonstrating our ability to produce above-market revenue growth, both organically and inorganically, while achieving stable margins and with improving cash flow conversion in the long term. ----- _Source: Company information_ (1) Organic and Pro Forma Revenues are both rebased to 100, based on 2011 figures; (2) Adjusted for 3SI and Kidiliz contracts ramp down impact. Impact was known at the moment of the acquisition and factored in the acquisition price; (3) Before pro forma adjustments. Pre-IFRS 16 prior to 2019, post-IFRS 16 otherwise; (4) Defined as: (Adjusted EBITDA less capital expenditure, less depreciation of right of use assets associated with IFRS 16 leases, which we consider as a proxy for IFRS 16 lease payments) divided by (Adjusted EBITDA less depreciation of right of use assets associated with IFRS 16 leases), expressed as a percentage. We have historically maintained margin discipline, suggesting experience and multiple strategies to deal with cost inflation via pass-through to customers (especially in high growth areas), better cost optimization (reallocation of staff across customers and projects, use nearshoring or freelance) and productivity improvements (employment of lean industrialization techniques). We believe that the upwards evolution of our revenue, margins and cash flow conversion over time are mainly driven by our strong structural foundation and highly attractive underlying business model. We increased our operating margin as a percentage of revenue from 6.3% in 2019 to 7.4% in 2021, due to our strong recovery following the COVID-19 pandemic, notably in relation to our activity ratio. Our operating margin as a percentage of revenue further improved to 7.6% in the twelve months ended June 30, 2022, as a result of certain efficiency measures that we are in the process of implementing. In addition to a well-diversified revenue base and an attractive mix of blue-chip and mid-market customers, we have benefited from stable profit margins in recent years, driven by various efficiency measures targeting our portfolio mix and contributing to growth in our direct margin. Furthermore, our asset-light business model has further enhanced cash flow conversion, which increased from 56.8% in 2016 to 77.5% in 2021. Our capital expenditure level is also relatively low, representing 2.3%, 1.9% and 2.0% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. Our financial policy is to maintain strong cash flow conversion, with a target of at least 70%, in the medium term. While we believe we will be able to accomplish this, our ability to do so will depend on various factors, many of which are not within our control. Therefore, we cannot assure you that we will be able to achieve any such results in the future.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Attractive consolidation platform with a track record of creating value through integration
Subsubsection Text: We are an established consolidation platform in a highly fragmented IT services market, with a strong track record of successfully acquiring and integrating more than 25 companies since 2016, which has allowed us to expand our product offering and geographic reach, generate significant cross-selling opportunities within our existing customer base and realize synergies. In part thanks to our acquisition strategy, we generated €2.3 billion in revenue for the twelve months ended June 30, 2022 and have generated approximately €1.0 billion of additional revenue from companies that we have acquired since 2016 (calculated by aggregating revenue contribution of each acquired company solely in the year of their respective acquisition, on a _pro forma basis as if the acquisition was completed on January 1 of the relevant financial year) in the year of_ their respective acquisition. ----- We constantly evaluate opportunities for prudent, highly-targeted and strategic bolt-on acquisitions, focused on the expansion of both of our services and solutions portfolio and geographic reach. As part of our expansion of our offerings, our acquisitions include Cognitis, a banking services and consulting specialist, IVS, a public sector software specialist, Addstones, a corporate and investment bank specialist, Itn, Inservio and i2s, insurance software and services experts, Novulys, a Microsoft CRM specialist, Projixi Europe, an automation specialist, and Ilex International, a cybersecurity software provider. As part of our geographic expansion, our acquisitions include IECISA, Efron and Gesfor, which allowed us to significantly expand our business in Spain and LatAm, Realdolmen, which allowed us to expand in the BeLux market, Impaq, which allowed us to enter the Polish market with high-tech nearshoring capabilities, and Do IT Wise, which allowed us to capitalize on the success of ServiceNow and further expand our service center capabilities. In addition, in Africa, we acquired Somafor, which allowed us to enter the Ivory Coast market, Archos Technology and Capital Consulting, which allowed us to consolidate our leading position in Morocco, Cynapsys, which allowed us to enter the Tunisian market and increase our offshore shared service center capacities and which we capitalized on by acquiring HLi Consulting in 2021. We are experienced in integrating assets and driving cost efficiencies and cross-selling synergies, as demonstrated by the seamless integration and success of our acquired companies. For example, in relation to IECISA, which we acquired in 2020, we have already exceeded our initial objectives and delivered more than €20 million of savings by improving billables and optimizing the costs of certain non-billables, such as property, plant and equipment, general and administrative expenses and subcontracting expense. We have developed a disciplined and clear approach to our M&A strategy, targeting specialized IT services providers, while expanding our geographic footprint and maintaining our local approach.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Experienced leadership team and strong focus on talent development that have positioned us for profitable growth
Subsubsection Text: Our business is supported by our highly-experienced management team, which is widely recognized in the IT services market and has successfully scaled-up and positioned us across various geographies, taking us from a local player to one of the leading IT services providers in Europe. Our senior managers include Vincent Rouaix, who has been our CEO since 2009 and Cyril Malher, who has been our CFO since 2009, each of whom has over 20 years of experience in the IT services market. In addition to our CEO and CFO, the rest of our management team has an average experience of ten years in the IT services market. Under their management, our business is well-positioned to deliver strong growth and successfully implement our growth and transformation strategy. We also have a strong and proven track record of attracting and retaining best-in-class talent, which are at the heart of innovation in our business. As of June 30, 2022, we had more than 27,000 FTEs, the majority of whom are consultants and direct employees, with 4,100 subcontractors, 946 freelancers, dedicated research teams of 150 professionals and a pool of 300 engineers focused on innovation. We are always looking for ways to help our talent with their training and professional development, with more than 10,000 employees and consultants trained, accredited and certified in 2021 by our long-term partners, such as Google and Microsoft. In part due to our strong focus on talent development and focus on innovation, a significant portion of our FTEs remain with us for a long term, with approximately 40% of our FTEs having worked for us for five years or more, and the average tenure of our FTEs for the year ended December 31, 2021 being approximately seven years. We believe that our strong focus on talent development and investment in innovation sets us apart from our competitors. From the year ended December 31, 2019, to the year ended December 31, 2021, we invested a total of approximately €167 million in R&D. Such investments and our large number of long-serving and well-trained FTEs provide a significant barrier to entry into the market for new competitors, who would need to invest a significant amount of time and money to gain such a workforce and similarly innovate. Such barriers to entry also help us maintain profitability while we pursue growth. In addition, we benefit from the expertise, business relationships and knowledge of Bain Capital, who has been our majority shareholder since July 2022. Since its inception in 1984, Bain Capital and its affiliates have completed over 650 transactions and have made investments in more than 350 companies in a broad range of industries, including consumer/retail, financial and business services, healthcare, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Bain Capital has specialized knowledge of the IT services market in Europe, due to its ownership of Engineering—Ingegneria Informatica S.p.A., a leading IT services provider in Italy. Bain Capital also has a long track record of partnering with management teams of technology and digital services companies to accelerate growth. The firm’s technology investments include Brillio, Genpact, Waystar, Viewpoint, Blue Coat, BMC Software and QuEST Global Services, amongst many others. -----

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Our Strategy
Subsubsection Text: We aim to continue strengthening our position across our activities, industry verticals and geographic areas by implementing the key strategies set forth below.

Subsection Title: Top 35
Subsubsection Title: Pursue growth and consolidate our positioning as a leading IT services and solutions provider in key markets
Subsubsection Text: We are in the core panel of IT services and solutions providers for blue-chip corporates and a strategic partner to mid-market companies in the markets in which we operate. Over five decades, we have grown organically and through acquisitions to become one of the leading providers of IT services, software and digital platforms in Europe, with operations in 29 countries across Europe, Latin America, North America, the Middle East, Asia and Africa. In particular, we have established a leading market position in each of our mature and stable markets, such as France, Iberia and BeLux, which we will continue to capitalize on. We also have a robust presence in growing markets, such as Eastern Europe, Africa and LatAm, which helps us diversify our revenue mix. The global IT services market has grown consistently at or above GDP over the long term and we are currently in a period of acceleration due to the digital and cloud transitions. We believe our geographies and industry verticals are relatively underpenetrated.
