We also facilitate remote working by providing our employees with key remote working tools and equipment, which has greatly reduced the number of employees commuting to work as well as paper consumption. We also comply with applicable regulations concerning the responsible use of energy and the sustainable use of transportation. In addition, we have launched our Green Project, which focuses on the development of practices and solutions that have a positive impact on our planet and its occupants. It consists of three parts: (i) our green IT practices and solutions, (ii) our IT for green offers and (iii) the implementation of an internal approach to digital sobriety including regular awareness-raising among our employees. Through our Green Project, we are developing a solution for an energy supplier in Africa to replace generators with solar micro power plants (solutions to manage electricity supply in urban and rural economic clusters by installing clean energy micro power plants). In parallel, we are working on the implementation of a meter-to-cash solution for the monetization of energy services (prepaid offers). We also participate in the European research and innovation program for the promotion of community energy self-sufficiency in urban areas. Interconnect, funded by the European H2020, involves 50 European entities from eleven countries and aims at developing solutions to connect and converge digital homes and buildings to the electrical grid.

Subsection Title: Employees
Subsubsection Text: The following table sets forth the average number of FTEs by function for the years ended December 31, 2019, 2020 and 2021 and for the six months ended June 30, 2022. Additionally, as of June 30, 2022, we employed 4,100 subcontractors and 946 freelancers.

Subsection Title: Six months Year ended December 31,** **ended June 30, 2019** **2020** **2021** **2022

Subsubsection Text: Our relationships with the majority of our employees in France are subject to collective bargaining agreements. In general, the collective bargaining agreements include terms that regulate remuneration, minimum salary, salary complements, extra time, benefits, bonuses and partial disability. In addition, an economic and social unit (unité économique et sociale) exists between us and Inetum Software France pursuant ----- to a collective agreement dated March 21, 2001, which gave rise to the implementation of several committees (one central economic and social committee (comité social et économique central), eight establishment social and economic committees (comité social et économique d’établissement), one central health and safety commission (commission centrale santé, sécurité et conditions de travail) and eight health and safety commissions (commission santé, sécurité et conditions de travail)). Trade unions and work councils are active at all our premises. We have entered into a company-wide collective agreement with trade unions active in our company regulating annual performance bonuses and employee social security. We have also entered into a further company-wide collective agreement regulating remuneration and health insurance of executives. We consider our relations with employees, trade unions and work councils to be good and we have not experienced any significant labor issues in the past three years. We hired over 4,500 new employees and trained and certified more than 10,000 employees in 2021. Our hiring and training policy focuses on attracting and retaining top talent. Over the last five years, the average tenure of our employees has been approximately seven years. We also value diversity: creating a workplace that values the contributions of all genders, cultures and abilities is a key consideration in the development of our human resources policy. In partnership with Pôle Emploi, we also aim to include people in our workforce who are often excluded from employment. We are aiming to increase our hiring of young employees (persons under 26 when they are hired by us), having already increased these hires between December 2019 and December 2021, with a further 30% increase targeted over the next 6 years. Finally, we are aiming to increase the total number of women vice presidents in our organization, having increased their representation modestly between December 2020 and the present, with a further 30% increase targeted over the next 6 years.

Subsection Title: Pensions
Subsubsection Text: We have mostly defined contribution pension plans and, to a lesser extent, defined benefit contribution pension plans (in Belgium only), as well as post-employment arrangements (such as retirement indemnities and termination indemnities) for our current and former employees as required by applicable law. Postemployment benefits mainly concern end-of-career indemnities in France. The level of contribution is dependent upon, among other things, the level of employee participation and salaries in each country. Other than increases in contributions required by law and the evolution of the interest rates, which may affect the amount of the retirement or termination indemnities, we do not expect significant pension liabilities going forward. Provisions for retirement indemnities amounted to €58.8 million as of June 30, 2022.

Subsection Title: Insurance
Subsubsection Text: As an integral part of our risk management program, we maintain insurance coverage for property damage, professional indemnity, general third party liability, directors’ and officers’ liability and employers’ liability as well as cybersecurity and GDPR liability. Insurance cover for these risks is provided through a combination of self-insured deductibles and annual aggregates. Our insurance coverage is reviewed on an annual basis. We believe the levels of risks insured, risks retained and the limits of insurance indemnity are broadly in line with similar companies in the same industry.

Subsection Title: Legal Proceedings
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are involved or implicated in claims and legal proceedings that arise in the ordinary course of business, such as disputes with our customers and suppliers, authorities or business partners, labor law disputes and disputes relating to intellectual property, among others. These disputes can entail amounts that are material for the operation of our business and which may not be covered in full or all by our insurance. We are currently involved in a number of disputes brought against us by customers in the context of projects that have been terminated by one of the parties. These disputes generally lead to legal proceedings, with the relevant court generally determining the split of responsibility between the parties. As of June 30, 2022, we had made provisions for disputes amounting to €2.0 million. For more information, see “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We are subject to the _risk of litigation, tax and regulatory investigations, quality audits by our customers and other claims.”_ -----

Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT Board of Directors
Subsubsection Text: The Group is managed by the board of directors of Holdco (the “Board”). Pursuant to the Shareholders’ Agreement, the Board is currently composed of eight members and includes one member appointed by NB Renaissance. The Board oversees the conduct of the Group’s business, including delegations of the Board’s authority to senior management, and also establishes committees to ensure oversight of the Group’s operations. The Board meets at least four times per year.

Subsection Title: Name** **Age** **Position
Subsubsection Title: Consultative Committees
Subsubsection Text: The committees below are formed by, and report to, the Board. The committees may invite any person (either employees of the Group or other persons) competent in relation to the subjects discussed.

Subsection Title: Name** **Age** **Position
Subsubsection Title: People Committee
Subsubsection Text: The People Committee provides strategic input and direction to attract, retain and develop people in a high performing, diverse, equitable and inclusive organization. The committee meets at least four times a year.

Subsection Title: Name** **Age** **Position
Subsubsection Title: Audit and Risk Committee
Subsubsection Text: The Audit and Risk Committee is in charge of managing the risk and control environment of the Group. It reviews the Group’s finance and accounting practices and ensures compliance with internal control procedures. The committee meets at least four times a year and is currently composed of five members.

Subsection Title: Name** **Age** **Position
Subsubsection Text: Vincent Rouaix 63 Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Matthias Boyer Chammard 42 Director Stuart Gent 50 Director Charles Megaw 52 Director Giovanni Camera 39 Director Harry Simpson 33 Director Bridget van Kralingen 59 Director Pietro Galli 59 Director The following are brief biographical descriptions of the members of the Board mentioned above. _Vincent Rouaix—Mr. Rouaix is the Chairman of the Board. He spent his entire career in international service_ groups. Prior to joining Inetum, he worked for Logispace and Cognicase, where he occupied several positions, including Chairman and CEO of Logispace and Executive Vice President and Managing Director Europe of Cognicase. He also created and developed the Adelior group with the support of investment funds. Following the takeover of the Adelior group by Inetum, he was appointed director in 2006 and promoted as managing director in 2009. He graduated from the École Supérieure des Travaux Publics. _Matthias Boyer Chammard—Mr. Boyer Chammard is a Managing Director in both the Technology Financial_ and Business Services vertical and the Industrial vertical, and a member of the Bain European Private Equity team. He joined Bain Capital Private Equity in 2011 and leads its activities in France. Previously, Mr. Boyer Chammard was a Principal at Boston Consulting Group’s Paris office and a member of the Energy and the Industrial Goods Practices from 2003 to 2011. He was also a lecturer in Energy and Environment at Science Po Paris. Mr. Boyer Chammard holds a Master of Public Administration from Harvard University and a Master of Science from École Polytechnique. _Stuart Gent—Mr. Gent is a Managing Director and Co-Head of the European Private Equity team, where he_ also leads the Portfolio Group. He joined Bain Capital Private Equity in 2007 and has extensive experience in the Technology, Financial & Business Services vertical and the Industrials vertical. Prior to joining Bain Capital Private Equity, Mr. Gent was Managing Director of Avis UK and a member of the Avis Europe Executive Board, where he was responsible for their UK business. Mr. Gent was also a Partner at Bain & Company, where he focused on business transformation. Mr. Gent received a bachelor of science from Bristol University. _Charles Megaw—Dr. Megaw is a Managing Director, and a member of the Portfolio Group for European_ Private Equity at Bain Capital Private Equity. He joined Bain Capital Private Equity in 2007 and has worked on investments in technology, financial and business services, healthcare, industrials and retail. Previously, he was a Partner at Bain & Company where he consulted in a range of retail, consumer and industrial businesses for strategy and performance improvement in Europe and South Africa. Dr. Megaw holds a PhD from the University of Cambridge in Development Economics. He also holds a Masters in Geography from the University of Cambridge. _Giovanni Camera—Mr. Camera is a member of Bain Capital’s European Private Equity team, and is also a_ principal in the Technology, Financial & Business Services vertical. Prior to joining Bain Capital Private Equity in 2012, Mr. Camera was an associate at JP Morgan from 2010 to 2012 TMT M&A/Advisory team, an investment analyst at the International Finance Corporation from 2009 to 2010, and an analyst at JP Morgan from 2007 to 2009. Mr. Camera holds a Masters in finance and a bachelor of science in business administration from Bocconi University in Milan. _Harry Simpson—Mr. Simpson joined Bain Capital Private Equity in 2016. He is a Vice President in the_ Technology Financial & Business Services vertical and member of the European Private Equity team. Prior to joining Bain Capital, Mr. Simpson worked at CDC Group in London on growth equity investments across ----- Africa and South Asia. Previously, he was a consultant at McKinsey & Company in their London office, working primarily on strategy and M&A projects across a number of industries. Mr. Simpson received a Masters in Manufacturing Engineering from the University of Cambridge. _Bridget van Kralingen—Mrs. van Kralingen is a senior advisor to Bain Capital Private Equity. Until_ December 2021, she was a senior Vice President at IBM where she ran the firm’s Consulting division, then its Industry software division, and was ultimately responsible for all go to market, global operations and revenue of IBM. Previously, she was a managing partner at Deloitte, responsible for its US Financial Services consulting business. Mrs. van Kralingen holds a Masters of Commerce degree from the University of South Africa and a Bachelors of Commerce degree from the University of Witwatersrand. _Pietro Galli—Mr. Galli is an Operating Partner of NB Renaissance. Previously, he was General Manager of_ Expo Milan 2015 and a Senior Partner at Bain & Company where he led Bain & Company’s investments in the TMT practice. Mr. Galli graduated from the University of Genoa cum laude in Business Administration. Vincent Rouaix 63 Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Cyril Malher 58 Chief Financial Officer The following are brief biographical descriptions of the members of senior management, to the extent not provided above: _Cyril Malher—Mr. Malher has served as the Chief Financial Officer of the Group since 2009 after ten years_ of previous experience as the Chief Financial Officer of French multinational companies Ingenico and Oberthur Card Systems. He began his career as a financial auditor at Arthur Anderson and holds an MBA from the ESCEM (École Supérieure de Commerce et de Management). We are not aware of any conflicts of interest between any duties or private interests of any member of our Board or senior management and those duties they owe to us.

Subsection Title: Senior Management
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the senior management of the Company consists of the following persons:

Subsection Title: The Individual Investors’ Investment
Subsubsection Text: On the Acquisition Completion Date, certain individual investors, including our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, entered into a Securityholders’ Agreement to invest into Holdco, the indirect parent of the Issuer. It is expected that other individual investors will adhere to the Securityholders’ Agreement in the third quarter of the year ending December 31, 2022, for a total of 2.7% of the share capital of Holdco. See “Summary Corporate and Financing Structure” and “Summary—The _Transactions.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Bain Capital
Subsubsection Text: Since its inception in 1984, Bain Capital and its affiliates have completed over 650 transactions and have made investments in more than 350 companies in a broad range of industries, including consumer/retail, financial and business services, healthcare, industrials, and technology, media and telecommunications. Bain Capital Private Equity’s global team of more than 250 investment professionals creates value for its portfolio companies through its global platform and depth of expertise, managing approximately $160 billion of assets in total and leveraging the firm’s shared platform to capture opportunities in strategic areas of focus. Bain Capital has investors from across the world that include sovereign wealth funds, public pension funds, foundations, insurance companies, family offices, high-net-worth individuals and funds of funds. The firm has a strong track record of investments in the IT and tech-enabled services industries, including its recent investments in Engineering, Genpact, Brillio, Quest and Kantar. Headquartered in Boston, Bain Capital and its affiliates have offices in Chicago, Dublin, Guangzhou, Hong Kong, London, Luxembourg, Madrid, Melbourne, Mumbai, Munich, New York, Palo Alto, San Francisco, Seoul, Shanghai, Sydney and Tokyo.

Subsection Title: NB Renaissance
Subsubsection Text: NB Renaissance is an investment firm with a focus on companies with a high growth potential primarily headquartered in Italy. NB Renaissance currently manages over €2.3 billion in assets and is invested in 13 companies with an aggregate turnover of approximately €6 billion. NB Renaissance was formed in 2015 from the strategic partnership in private equity in Italy between Intesa Sanpaolo, Italy’s largest bank, and Neuberger Berman (“NB”). NB, founded in 1939, is a private, independent, employee-owned investment manager. As of June 30, 2022, NB had $418 billion in client assets, including approximately $120 billion in alternative assets (mainly private equity), operations in 25 countries and over 2,500 employees.

Subsection Title: Shareholders Agreement
Subsubsection Text: The Sponsors have entered into a shareholders’ agreement on July 18, 2022 (the “Shareholders’ Agreement”) regulating the affairs of Lux Topco and Holdco and their investment in the Group, among others things, including governance rights in relation to Lux Topco and Holdco as well as certain matters which require the consent of NB Renaissance. The Shareholders’Agreement provides for certain pre-emptive rights on issues of new securities of Lux Topco (subject to customary exclusions), as well as certain restrictions on transfers of the securities of Lux Topco (subject to limited permitted transfers) in the first five years of the term of the Shareholders’ Agreement. After the expiry of the first five years of the term: (i) Bain Capital will have a right of first offer in the event another securityholder decides to dispose of any of its Lux Topco securities; and (ii) NB Renaissance will receive tag-along rights to participate in a transfer of securities by Bain Capital, other than certain specified transfers. The Shareholders’ Agreement also includes a drag-along right entitling Bain Capital to require NB Renaissance to transfer all of its securities upon a transfer of all of Bain Capital’s securities in Lux Topco at any time following the fifth anniversary of the Shareholders’ Agreement, subject to certain conditions. Decisions of the boards Lux Topco and Holdco will be taken by a majority of the votes cast by the members who are present and voting or represented during such meeting, provided that at least one representative of Bain Capital has voted in favor of any such decision. The Shareholders’ Agreement also includes a number of reserved matters which require both securityholders’ approval. These reserved matters will be reduced if NB Renaissance ceases to hold at least 5.0% in Lux Topco. -----

After giving effect to the Individual Investors’ Investment, Bain Capital will beneficially own approximately 80.9% and NB Renaissance will beneficially own approximately 16.4%, with the remaining 2.7% to be beneficially-owned by management and certain co-investors, in each case, of the share capital of the Issuer. See “Summary—The Transactions.”

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Transaction Services Agreement
Subsubsection Text: On July 25, 2022, Midco entered into a Transaction Services Agreement with the Sponsors pursuant to which the Sponsors will continue to provide advice, analysis and assistance on transactions in consideration for the payment of an aggregate fee equivalent to one percent of the value of the relevant transaction.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Consulting Services Agreement
Subsubsection Text: On July 25, 2022, Midco entered into a Consulting Services Agreement pursuant to which the Sponsors will continue to provide the Group with ongoing business consultancy services unrelated to specific transactions for the payment of fees up to a maximum of €6.25 million for the first two years, €5.0 million for the third year and €3.75 million for the remainder of the term, up to a maximum of €15.0 million.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Agreements with the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
Subsubsection Text: The Group is also party to a non-compete agreement and a consulting services agreement with the Chief Executive Officer. -----

Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS Senior Facilities Agreement

Subsubsection Text: principal amount of €1,132.74 million (the “Original Facility B”) and (ii) a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of €200.0 million (the “Original RCF”). The Original Facility B was provided in connection with the Acquisition, refinancing or otherwise discharging of certain indebtedness of the Company and its subsidiaries and the other transactions contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement and other documents ancillary to or entered into in connection therewith (in each case including the financing or refinancing thereof) (the “Original Transaction”). It is intended that (i) a portion of the Original Facility B will be refinanced by the Notes and a new senior term loan facility in principal amount of €432.7 million (“Facility A”) (the “Facility B Refinancing”) and (ii) in connection with the Facility B Refinancing, the Original Senior Facilities Agreement will be amended and restated under an amendment and restatement agreement (“ARA”) to establish Facility A and to reflect the Facility B Refinancing (the Original Senior Facilities Agreement as amended and restated, the “Senior

The Senior Facilities Agreement is expected to provide for (i) following the Facility B Refinancing, a reduced term loan Facility B in principal amount of €350.0 million (“Facility B”); (ii) Facility A and (iii) a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of €200.0 million (the “New RCF”). Subsection Title: Senior Secured Facilities” and, together with the Senior Credit Facilities, the “Senior Secured Facilities”).
Subsubsection Title: Borrowers, Currencies and Utilizations
Subsubsection Text: The Original Facility B was utilized in full by the Issuer on July 20, 2022 (the “Closing Date”). Facility A may be utilized by the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of that facility (the “Term Facility Borrowers”). The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries which enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement as borrowers of such facility or otherwise accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers (the “RCF Borrowers”), in EUR, GBP, or USD and certain other currencies readily available in the relevant interbank market and freely convertible into EUR (subject to obtaining the consent of all the relevant lenders participating in the relevant utilization) by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of letters of credit and ancillary facilities (on a bilateral and/or fronted basis).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Facilities” and, together with the Senior Credit Facilities, the “Senior Secured Facilities”).
Subsubsection Title: Purpose
Subsubsection Text: All amounts borrowed under the Original Facility B have been applied directly or indirectly, in or towards (including by way of on-lending to, or investment in, any other member of the Senior Secured Group (as defined below)) financing or refinancing: (i) the consideration paid or payable in connection with the Acquisition and/or any other document ancillary to or entered into in connection with the Sale and Purchase Agreement (including any purchase price adjustments); (ii) the payment of certain costs relating to the Acquisition and all other fees, costs, expenses, taxes and other amounts incurred or payable by any member of the Senior Secured Group (including the Company and its subsidiaries) in connection with the Acquisition, ----- the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents, the Original Transaction and/or the repayment, refinancing, discharge and/or close-out of any existing indebtedness made available to or guaranteed or secured by any member of the Company and its subsidiaries; (iii) the repayment, refinancing, discharge and/or close-out of the existing debt of the Company and its subsidiaries (including back-stopping or providing cash cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees or ancillary, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any breakage costs, close-out costs, redemption premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such repayment, refinancing, discharge and/or close-out; (iv) any other payments identified in or for any other purpose contemplated by the tax structure memorandum or the funds flow statement (if any) relating to the Original Transaction that was delivered to the relevant agent pursuant to the Original Senior Facilities Agreement (the “Funds Flow Statement”) or otherwise arising in connection with the Original Transaction; (v) any other related amounts, including fees, costs, taxes and expenses; and/or (vi) the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured Group (including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash over-funding). All amounts borrowed under Facility A will be applied directly or indirectly, in or towards refinancing the Original Facility B. Amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility may be applied directly or indirectly, in or towards financing or refinancing: (i) the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Senior Secured Group including, without limitation, the financing or refinancing of capital expenditure, the Transactions, any permitted acquisitions, the payment of certain costs relating to the Acquisition, investments and joint ventures, operational restructurings and reorganization requirements of the Senior Secured Group, financing or refinancing indebtedness of the Senior Secured Group or any acquisition target (including to backstop or provide cash cover in respect of any existing ancillary facilities, guarantees, indemnities, letters of credit, revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements), any fees (including any additional original issue discount payable in respect of the Original Facility B), costs, taxes, expenses and other liabilities incurred or payable by any member of the Senior Secured Group in connection with the Acquisition, the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents, the Transactions and/or the repayment, refinancing, discharge and/or close-out; (ii) any purpose permitted for the Original Facility B and/or (iii) cash over-funding on the Issue Date and financing any other payments identified in, or for any other purpose contemplated by, the tax structure memorandum or the funds flow statement or otherwise arising in connection with the Transactions, in each case, together with related fees, costs and expenses (and including, for the avoidance of doubt, as cash over-funding).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Facilities” and, together with the Senior Credit Facilities, the “Senior Secured Facilities”).
Subsubsection Title: Availability of the RCF
Subsubsection Text: The Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized from (and including) the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement to (and including) the date falling one month prior to the maturity date of the Revolving Credit Facility.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Senior Secured Facilities” and, together with the Senior Credit Facilities, the “Senior Secured Facilities”).
Subsubsection Title: Interest and Fees
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the Senior Credit Facilities will initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to the applicable floating rate (being the applicable EURIBOR for loans in Euro, Term SOFR for loans in USD and SONIA for loans in Sterling, and other applicable rates for other currencies) plus an applicable margin, which in each case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of consolidated senior secured net debt to Consolidated EBITDA (as defined in the section entitled “Description of the Notes”) (the “Senior Secured

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Net Leverage Ratio”).
Subsubsection Title: Repayments
Subsubsection Text: The loans made under the Original Facility B will be repaid in full on the date that is seven years from the Closing Date. On and from the Issue Date, any loans made under Facility B will be repaid in full on the date that is six years from the Issue Date. Subject to the Maturity Extension Option (as defined below), any loans made under Facility A will be repaid in full on the date that is five years from the Issue Date. The Issuer has the option to elect to extend the maturity of Facility A on one occasion by one year (the “Maturity Extension Option”), provided that (amongst other things): (i) the Issuer has given notice (the “Election Notice”) to the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement of such election (the “Extension

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Net Leverage Ratio”).
Subsubsection Text: If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under Facility A, Facility B or the Revolving Credit Facility (as applicable). Zero floors will also apply (i) to SONIA (in respect of loans denominated in Sterling) and (ii) Term SOFR (in respect of loans denominated in USD). The interest margin applicable to each Senior Credit Facility will be subject to a capped adjustment by reference to achievement against the Senior Secured Group’s sustainability key performance indicator (“KPI”) targets relating to (1) % reduction of CO2 emissions; (2) % increase in hiring of young employees; (3) % increase of women appointed Vice President; and (4) % increase to the share of purchase costs paid to IT suppliers audited by EcoVadis or another independent rating provider selected by the Senior Secured Group as against total purchase costs paid to IT suppliers. The KPI targets shall be tested for the financial year ending December 31, 2022 and each subsequent financial year, tested annually by reference to the Senior Secured Group’s sustainability report in respect of the previous financial year, such that the margin shall be reduced by a certain percentage for each KPI target met in the previous financial year (by a maximum of 5bps if all four KPI targets are met) or increased by a certain percentage for each KPI target not met in the previous ----- financial year (by a maximum of 5bps if no KPI target is met). Where two KPI targets are met and two KPI targets are not met, the margin will not be adjusted. In the event of any acquisition or disposal the fair market value of which (as determined in good faith by the Issuer) exceeds 10% of the aggregated assets of the Senior Secured Group, the Issuer will either (at the Issuer’s election, in respect of each such acquisition or disposal) (i) recalculate the applicable levels for any relevant KPI target to take into account the acquisition or disposal or (ii) (in the case of an acquisition only) exclude the impact of such acquisition when reporting the KPIs for each financial year. In relation to any permitted acquisition, the Issuer may elect to exclude the relevant acquired person or asset from the calculation of the KPIs for the financial year in which such acquisition occurs and/or the immediately following financial year. The calculation of the KPI targets and any recalculation or amendments to the KPI targets will be reported in a sustainability report and such report will be independently audited by either the Senior Secured Group’s (or the Issuer’s) auditors or any other independent external third party appointed by the Senior Secured Group or the Issuer on a limited assurance basis. A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Revolving Credit Facility from the Closing Date to the end of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the Revolving Credit Facility. Such commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears (provided that the Issuer may elect that accrued commitment fee shall instead be paid on each Quarter Date or the last date of each Interest Period applicable to Facility B), on the last day of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility and on the date the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which the relevant lender cancels its commitment. Any letter of credit issued under the Revolving Credit Facility shall be subject to such issuing bank and fronting fees as may be agreed between the Issuer and the applicable issuing bank and a letter of credit fee equal to the margin that would have been applicable to a cash drawing under the Revolving Credit Facility in the applicable currency. Default interest will be calculated as an additional one per cent. per annum on the defaulted amount.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS

Subsubsection Title: Voluntary and Mandatory Prepayment
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement will permit voluntary prepayments to be made (subject to de minimis amounts) and will require mandatory prepayment in full or in part in certain circumstances, including: - from certain net cash proceeds received by the Issuer and any of its restricted subsidiaries (together the “Senior Secured Group”) from certain asset disposals, to the extent not otherwise applied for a permitted purpose and required to be applied in prepayment of the Senior Secured Facilities and subject to a _de minimis amount and other customary carve outs substantially similar to the Notes as described in the_ section entitled “Description of the Notes”; - unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Issuer shall apply (in each case in such proportions as the Issuer elects (in its sole discretion)) towards the prepayment or cancellation (as applicable) of any or all of the Senior Secured Facilities (or any available commitments in respect of any term loans thereunder), any other senior secured indebtedness of the Senior Secured Group (or any available or undrawn commitments in respect of any senior secured indebtedness of the Senior Secured Group) (or, if such prepayment would comply with the limitation on restricted payments under the Senior Facilities Agreement, any other permitted indebtedness), for each financial year (commencing with the first full financial year following the Closing Date), a percentage of excess cash flow in the event that excess cash flow exceeds a minimum threshold amount (subject to certain adjustments based on anticipated debt service, distributions to be paid to minority shareholders and certain other expenses, restricted payments, debt repayments, acquisitions, investments, disposals, restructuring costs, group initiatives and capital expenditures in the relevant financial years committed or designated to be undertaken in the next 24 months being deducted after applying the applicable percentage(s)), which percentage decreases as the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio decreases (an “Excess Cash Flow

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Election”) on a date falling no earlier than the fourth anniversary of the Issue Date but no later than five
Subsubsection Text: Business Days before the applicable maturity date; and (ii) no Event of Default has occurred and is continuing on the date of the Election Notice. If the Maturity Extension Option is exercised, Facility A shall amortize such that (i) on the fifth anniversary of the Issue Date, 10% of the aggregate outstanding principal amount of Facility A shall be due and payable as at such date; and (ii) the remaining outstanding loans under Facility A not repaid prior to such date shall be repaid on the extended maturity date. In respect of the Revolving Credit Facility, each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to an ability to roll over cash drawings, subject to the satisfaction of certain customary conditions. All outstanding amounts under the Original RCF will be repaid on the termination date of the Original RCF, being the date falling six and a half years from the Closing Date. On and from the Issue Date, the New RCF will be repaid on the termination date of the New RCF, being the date falling five years and eleven months from the Issue Date. Amounts repaid by the relevant borrowers on loans made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be reborrowed, subject to certain customary conditions. In respect of the letters of credit, each will be repaid on the termination date of the relevant Revolving Credit Facility (or such earlier date in accordance with the Senior Facilities Agreement), provided that if any letter of credit has an expiry date ending on or after the termination date applicable to the applicable Revolving Credit Facility, on such termination date each letter of credit shall be repaid unless the relevant issuing bank agrees ----- that such letter of credit shall continue as between that issuing bank and the relevant member of the Senior Secured Group on a bilateral basis and not as part of or under the documentation for the Senior Secured Facilities.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS

Subsubsection Title: Guarantees and Security
Subsubsection Text: _Guarantor Coverage Test and Material Subsidiaries_ The Senior Secured Facilities will be guaranteed by each borrower of the Senior Secured Facilities (the “Borrowers”) and the Guarantors (together, the “Senior Secured Obligors”). Subject to agreed security principles in the Senior Facilities Agreement, the following security was granted as a condition precedent to the availability of the Original Facility B: (a) Midco granted a limited recourse (i) share pledge in respect of its shares in the capital of the Issuer and (ii) pledge agreement in respect of any structural intercompany receivables owed to Midco (as lender) by the Issuer (as borrower); and (b) the Issuer granted a bank account pledge agreement pledging its material bank accounts in France (without control over use and freely operational prior to acceleration). Within 1 day following the Closing Date, the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement were also secured by: (i) a share pledge granted by the Issuer over its shares in the capital of the Company and (ii) a pledge agreement granted by the Issuer pledging any structural intercompany receivables owed to the Issuer (as lender) by the Company. Within 120 days from (and excluding) the Issue Date, subject to the agreed security principles in the Senior Facilities Agreement, the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement will be secured by (A) share pledges over shares in the capital of Inetum Software France, Inetum Realdolmen Belgium and Inetum Espana (together with the Company, the “Post-Closing Guarantors”), (B) pledge agreements in respect of any structural intercompany receivables owed by the Post-Closing Guarantors and (C) with respect to any Post-Closing Guarantors which become borrowers under Facility A and/or Facility B, security over the material bank accounts located in the relevant Post-Closing Guarantors’ jurisdiction of incorporation (subject to customary exclusions, including in respect of accounts that form part of a cash pooling arrangement (or similar or equivalent arrangement) or that are used in conjunction with any factoring, securitization or other receivables financing arrangement). Subject to certain adjustments, exceptions and agreed security principles in the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Issuer is required to ensure that members of the Senior Secured Group incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction (i) that generate at least 80% of Consolidated EBITDA of the Senior Secured Group within certain agreed jurisdictions (“Guarantor Jurisdictions”), namely, France, Spain and Belgium, the jurisdiction of incorporation of any borrower (but only in relation to that borrower) and any other jurisdiction agreed between the Issuer and the lenders (the “Guarantor Coverage Test”) or (ii) that are wholly owned and individually generate more than 5% of Consolidated EBITDA of the Senior Secured Group (a “Material

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Prepayment”); and
Subsubsection Text: - upon the occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement which follows terms substantially similar to the Notes as described in the section entitled “Description of the Notes”), at the Issuer’s option, unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders, either (i) each lender and issuing bank shall be entitled to require prepayment of outstanding amounts and cancellation of its commitments within a prescribed time period or (ii) all outstanding undrawn commitments of each lender shall be immediately cancelled and outstanding drawn commitments shall become due and payable together with accrued interest and other amounts accrued or owing to each lender. A change of control shall include: (i) any person or group of related persons (other than one or more permitted holders) becoming the beneficial owner of more than 50% of the total voting power of the voting stock of the Issuer (other than in connection with a transaction or series of transactions in which the Issuer shall become the wholly owned subsidiary of a Parent Entity (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) so long as no person or group other than a permitted holder, holds more than 50 per cent of the total voting power of the voting stock of such Parent Entity); (ii) Midco ceasing to directly own 100% of the total issued share capital of the Issuer (or any successor entity as a result of certain mergers permitted under the Senior Facilities Agreement) other than pursuant to any rollover of shares, equity or other interests of a rollover investor or member of management holding stock in connection with the Acquisition or any permitted acquisition provided any such rollover is completed within 5 days; or (iii) on a sale, lease, transfer, conveyance or other disposition (other than by way of merger, amalgamation, consolidation or other business combination transaction), in one or a series of related transactions, of all or substantially all of the assets of the Senior Secured Group taken as a whole to a person, other than a restricted subsidiary or one or more permitted holders, in each case, subject to certain exceptions. The Revolving Credit Facility shall not be entitled to any mandatory prepayment proceeds (other than a mandatory prepayment as a result of a Change of Control or illegality). In the event that it becomes unlawful for any lender to perform its obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the borrower shall repay that lender’s participation in the utilizations made to that borrower to the extent necessary to comply with applicable laws on the last day of the interest period for each utilization occurring after the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement has notified the Issuer (or if earlier, the date specified by the lender in the illegality notice). Any available commitments of such lender will be immediately reduced and cancelled to the extent necessary to comply with applicable laws. A lender becoming a sanctioned ----- entity shall not (by virtue of becoming such sanctioned entity alone) trigger any mandatory prepayment under the Senior Facilities Agreement. If a lender waives its right (such right shall be at the Issuer’s request only) to receive its share of any prepayment of the Senior Secured Facilities (“Waived Amounts”), such Waived Amounts may (at the Issuer’s option) be retained by the Senior Secured Group for any purposes not prohibited by the Senior Facilities Agreement (including restricted payments), may be offered to any lender(s) selected by the Issuer which did not decline such prepayment (apportioned between such lenders in the Issuer’s sole discretion, if applicable) or applied in prepayment of any other permitted indebtedness.

Subsubsection Title: Representations and Warranties
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain representations and warranties (subject to certain agreed qualifications and with certain representations being repeated), including: (i) status, (ii) binding obligations, (iii) non-conflict with other obligations, (iv) power and authority, (v) validity and admissibility in evidence, (vi) governing law and enforcement, (vii) filing and stamp taxes, (viii) information memorandum, management case and reports, (ix) financial statements, (x) no litigation, (xi) taxation and (xii) pari passu ranking. Certain representations and warranties shall be made on the Closing Date and will be repeated on the date of each utilization, on the first day of each interest period and at certain other times.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS

Subsubsection Title: Springing Financial Covenant
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement contains a springing senior secured net leverage financial covenant (“Financial Covenant”) solely for the benefit of the lenders participating in the Revolving Credit Facility and any applicable Incremental Senior Secured Facilities (together the “Financial Covenant Facilities”), set at a flat ratio whereby the Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio as set out in the relevant compliance certificate delivered to the agent under Senior Facilities Agreement shall not exceed 8.35:1. The Financial Covenant will be on a last twelve months (“LTM”) basis as at each financial quarter date on or after the first testing date, being June 30, 2023 (such first testing date and each subsequent testing date, a “Test

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Subsidiary”), in each case, are guarantors under the Senior Facilities Agreement within 120 days of the Issue
Subsubsection Text: Date and thereafter on an ongoing basis within 120 days of the date on which the annual financial statements of the Issuer (or other applicable financial reporting entity) are required to be delivered to the agent under the Senior Facilities Agreement. As part of the guarantor accession process, subject to the agreed security principles in the Senior Facilities Agreement, security shall be granted over: (a) the shares of each acceding guarantor and any Material Subsidiary incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction to the extent its shareholder is incorporated in Guarantor Jurisdiction; (b) any structural intercompany receivables owed by each acceding guarantor and any Material Subsidiary incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction to the extent they are owed to an entity that is incorporated in Guarantor Jurisdiction; and (c) with respect to any acceding guarantors which become borrowers under Facility A and/or Facility B (“Acceding Borrowers”), material bank accounts held by the Acceding Borrower located in its jurisdiction of incorporation (subject to customary exclusions, including in respect of accounts that form part of a cash pooling arrangement (or similar or equivalent arrangement) or that are used in conjunction with any factoring, securitization or other receivables financing arrangement). _Release of Guarantees and Security_ In addition to the circumstances described below under “—Intercreditor Agreement—Distressed Disposals” and “—Intercreditor Agreement—Non-distressed Disposals,” the Issuer may, subject to certain conditions, ----- request the release of a guarantor from its guarantee under the Senior Facilities Agreement if (i) such guarantor is the subject of a third-party disposal or other permitted activity under the Senior Facilities Agreement pursuant to which such guarantor will cease to be a member of the Senior Secured Group, (ii) on a pro forma basis taking into account such release, the Guarantor Coverage Test will continue to be satisfied, (iii) such guarantor is not required to be a guarantor pursuant to the agreed security principles, (iv) the lenders whose commitments under the Senior Facilities Agreement aggregate 50.1% or more of the total commitments under such facilities consent to such release; or (v) the resignation of that guarantor is contemplated by the tax structure memorandum or the Intercreditor Agreement (as defined below). Upon the effectiveness of a release pursuant to the foregoing sentence, the applicable guarantor would have no further obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement, including any obligations to grant Security in any Collateral owned by such guarantor. The provision and the terms of the security and guarantees set forth above will in all cases be subject to certain limitations and are at all times and in all cases subject to the requirements of applicable law and the other matters set forth in the Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Facilities Agreement.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Date”), provided that the Senior Secured Group will only be required to test the Financial Covenant if as of
Subsubsection Text: 11.59p.m. (or such other time as is specified by the Issuer) (in London) on a Test Date, the amount of: (a) all loans under the Financial Covenant Facilities (excluding: (i) loans to fund any original issue discount or flex-related payments, costs and expenses with respect to the Original Facility B or Facility B (as applicable) and any Incremental Senior Secured Facility which is a term facility; (ii) loans made on or prior to the Closing Date; (iii) loans used to fund any acquisitions, capital expenditure or other investments (and, in each case, any rollover loan in respect thereof)) and (iv) (for the avoidance of doubt) any amounts drawn under the Revolving Credit Facility by way of ancillary facilities and letters of credit (or bank guarantees); minus (b) any cash and cash equivalent investments of the Senior Secured Group, exceeding 40% of the aggregate of: (i) the total commitments of the Revolving Credit Facility as at the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement; and (ii) the aggregate of all commitments under any Incremental Senior Secured Facility which is a revolving facility established after the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement, (disregarding, in each case, any reduction in such commitments following the establishment thereof) (the “Test Condition”). The Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio is based on the definitions and adjustments in the Senior Facilities Agreement, which may differ from similar definitions in the Indenture and the equivalent definitions described in this Offering Memorandum. The Senior Facilities Agreement contains an equity cure provision enabling the Issuer to cure or prevent breaches of the Financial Covenant (an “Equity Cure”) by the contribution from its shareholders or any other person to the Senior Secured Group of additional equity, assets and/or subordinated loans (“Cure Amount”) to (i) increase the Consolidated EBITDA under the Senior Facilities Agreement, (“EBITDA Cure”), (ii) decrease consolidated senior secured net debt as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement (“Net Debt

Subsubsection Title: General Undertakings
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants, information undertakings and related definitions (with, in each case, certain adjustments), including (i) limitations on indebtedness; (ii) limitations on restricted payments; (iii) limitations on liens (which includes the ability to designate certain credit facilities and/or hedging obligations secured on the Collateral as Super Senior Liabilities (as defined in the section entitled “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”) if, prior to such designation, Facility A and Facility B have been refinanced in full (ignoring any participation (x) of a lender which has been rolled over in a refinancing (or otherwise) of Facility A or Facility B and/or (y) in respect of which a lender has declined prepayment) and the original Revolving Credit Facility (to the extent not fully and finally discharged) has been designated as Super Senior Liabilities (as defined in the section entitled “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”)); (iv) limitations on sale of assets and subsidiary stock; (v) limitations on affiliate transactions; (vi) designation of restricted and unrestricted subsidiaries (vii) merger and consolidation undertakings with respect to (x) the Issuer and (y) the guarantors of the Senior Secured Facilities; and (viii) additional intercreditor agreements. In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement also requires the Issuer and certain of its restricted subsidiaries to observe certain other customary positive and negative covenants, subject to certain exceptions and grace periods, including covenants relating to: (i) authorizations and consents; (ii) compliance with laws; (iii) pari passu ranking; (iv) taxes; (v) centre of main interests; (vi) guarantees and security; (vii) further assurance; (viii) anti-corruption law and sanctions; (ix) ratings; and (x) certain post-closing undertakings (including granting the post-Closing Date security described above). The Senior Facilities Agreement also requires the Issuer to comply with certain customary information undertakings, including delivery of financial statements, sustainability reports and accompanying compliance certificates, provided that the obligation to deliver financial information and/or sustainability reports may differ from similar requirements in the Indenture and as described in this Offering Memorandum. It is intended that certain agreed covenants and other provisions of the Senior Facilities Agreement will fall away upon the satisfaction of certain release conditions, being (i) (with permanent effect) the occurrence of a listing of any member of the Senior Secured Group or a holding company which does not constitute a Change of Control and in respect of which the Senior Secured Group’s Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio does not exceed 4.25:1; and (ii) (while the release condition remains satisfied) the Issuer or any holding company of the Issuer having a long-term corporate credit rating equal to or higher than BBB-, Baa3 or BBB- (as applicable) ----- or higher according to any two of Fitch Ratings, Inc., Moody’s Investors Service, Inc. or Standard & Poor’s Investors Ratings Services or, in each case, any of its successors or assigns that is a nationally recognized statistical rating organization.

Subsection Title: Cure”), or (iii) prepay loans under a Financial Covenant Facility (“Prepayment Cure”) so that the Test
Subsubsection Title: Events of Default
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement provides for substantially the same events of default as under the Notes. In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to customary materiality qualifications, thresholds, grace periods, and excluded matters including (i) breach of the financial covenant, provided that (A) in the event of such breach, only the Super Majority Revolving Facility Lenders may exercise acceleration rights as a result of such breach and (B) if the Super Majority Revolving Facility Lenders have exercised such acceleration rights as a result of such breach, the remaining lenders shall have a right of cross-acceleration; (ii) misrepresentation; (iii) invalidity and unlawfulness of the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents; and (iv) material failure to comply with the Intercreditor Agreement.

Subsubsection Title: Governing Law
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it, are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in accordance with English law although the restrictive covenants, events of default and related definitions scheduled to the Senior Facilities Agreement will be interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact that the Senior Facilities Agreement is governed by English law).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Cure”), or (iii) prepay loans under a Financial Covenant Facility (“Prepayment Cure”) so that the Test
Subsubsection Text: Condition is no longer satisfied. An EBITDA Cure may be exercised on no more than five occasions during the term of the Senior Facilities Agreement and no more than two EBITDA Cures may be made in any three ----- consecutive relevant periods. Any such Equity Cure must be exercised prior to the date falling 20 Business Days after the date on which the compliance certificate is required to be delivered. There shall be no obligation to use any Cure Amount (other than with respect to a Prepayment Cure) in prepayment of the Senior Secured Facilities. There shall be no cap on the amount of any cure and over-cures are permitted. If the Financial Covenant has been breached, but is complied with when tested on any subsequent Test Date or is otherwise not required to be tested due to the Test Condition not being met on any subsequent date, then, the prior breach of such Financial Covenant or any event of default arising therefrom shall be deemed cured unless the requisite super majority of the lenders under any relevant Revolving Credit Facility (the “Super Majority Revolving Facility Lenders”) have exercised their acceleration rights to declare all or part of the loans under that Revolving Credit Facility to be immediately due and payable. The Issuer may elect to recalculate the Test Condition or Financial Covenant for any period at any time based upon any financial statements (including the latest internally available financial information for an LTM period) and, if (taking into account such recalculation) the Test Condition is not met or the Financial Covenant is complied with at such time (due to prepayments of the Revolving Credit Facility, cash or cash equivalents on balance sheet or otherwise), the Financial Covenant shall be deemed complied with and any prior breach of such Financial Covenant or any Event of Default arising therefrom shall be deemed cured. For any such calculation, the Issuer may give pro forma effect to all applicable transactions (and permitted adjustments to any Applicable Metric (being any financial covenant or financial ratio or incurrence-based permission, test, basket, or threshold, whether any default, event of default or other relevant breach of the Senior Secured Facilities financing documents has occurred, is continuing or would result or any other metric, condition or permission) in connection therewith) for which the applicable transaction date has occurred following the end of the applicable period or any subsequent relevant period as if such applicable transaction had been consummated on the first day of such applicable period or relevant period (as applicable).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Intercreditor Agreement
Subsubsection Title: General
Subsubsection Text: To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, the Issuer and the Trustee are party to and certain Guarantors will accede to an Intercreditor Agreement with, among others, the agent, arrangers and lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Security Agent. By accepting a Note, holders of the Notes will be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the relationship of certain of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Issuer, the Guarantors and any other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Debtor or Third Party Security Provider (as defined below), when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or Third Party Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions and provisions related to the enforcement of shared security. The following description is a summary of certain provisions contained in the Intercreditor Agreement. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety, and we urge you to read that document because it, and not the description that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes and of the Trustees. Capitalized terms used but not defined herein have the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement. For the purposes of this description: “Senior Secured Group” shall mean the Issuer and each of its restricted subsidiaries from time to time. References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include the Notes and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued by or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) has been made available to or by a member of the Senior Secured Group which are designated by the Issuer under the Intercreditor Agreement as Senior Secured Notes. The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term “Company” to refer to the Issuer and “Senior Secured Notes

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Liabilities” to refer to all present and future moneys, debts and liabilities under the Senior Secured Notes and
Subsubsection Text: certain other indebtedness of the Issuer, save for certain amounts payable to a Senior Secured Notes Trustee or any adviser, receiver, delegate, attorney, agent or appointee under the documents relating to the Senior Secured Notes Liabilities. For the purposes of this description only: “Debt Documents” means the Intercreditor Agreement and the documents creating or evidencing the Cash Management Facility Liabilities, the Hedging Liabilities, the Second Lien Liabilities, the Senior Secured ----- Liabilities, any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan Liabilities, the Topco Liabilities, the Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities, the unsecured liabilities of any unsecured creditors who are party to the Intercreditor Agreement, the Subordinated Liabilities and the Intra-Group Liabilities (each as defined in this description) and any other document designated as such by the Security Agent and the Issuer. “Designation Date” means the first date that the Issuer designates any liabilities as Super Senior Liabilities in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement. “Finance Documents” means the Senior Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Senior Secured Notes, Second Lien Facility Agreement, the indenture in respect of any Second Lien Notes, any facility documentation documenting any Topco Facility, any indenture in respect of any Topco Notes and any document designated by the Issuer as an unsecured finance document under and in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement. “Priority Secured Parties” means the Secured Parties other than the Topco Creditors. “Secured Creditors” means the Senior Secured Creditors, Second Lien Creditors and the Topco Creditors (each as defined below). “Secured Debt Documents”means (a) where such term is used in a Transaction Security document (other than any Transaction Security document creating or expressing to create Topco Shared Security), the Transaction Security Secured Debt Documents; and (b) in any other case (including, for the avoidance of doubt, any Transaction Security document creating or expressing to create Topco Shared Security), the Topco Shared Security Secured Debt Documents, provided that where such term is used in a Transaction Security document creating or expressing to create both Topco Shared Security and other Transaction Security that is not Topco Shared Security, such term shall mean Transaction Security Secured Debt Documents or Topco Shared Security Secured Debt Documents, as applicable. “Secured Obligations” means (i) in the case of Transaction Security other than Topco Shared Security, all liabilities and all other present and future obligations at any time due, owing or incurred by any member of the Senior Secured Group and by each Debtor and any Third Party Security Provider to any Secured Party (other than a Topco Creditor) under the Secured Debt Documents (other than the Topco Finance Documents) (including to the Security Agent under any parallel debt), both actual and contingent and whether incurred solely or jointly and as principal or surety or in any other capacity (the “Transaction Security Secured

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Obligations”) and (ii) in the case of Topco Shared Security, the Topco Shared Security Secured Obligations
Subsubsection Title: Ranking and Priority
Subsubsection Text: _Priority of Debts_ The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities owed by the Issuer and each other debtor under the Intercreditor Agreement (together, the “Debtors”) (other than any member of the Senior Secured Group or an affiliate thereof which is designated as a Topco Borrower under the Intercreditor Agreement by the Issuer (and which, for the avoidance of doubt, includes Midco) (a “Topco Borrower”)) to the Secured Parties and (in respect of Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities only) the Topco Borrowers (or a Topco Investor (in respect of any Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities only)) shall rank in right of priority and payment in the following order and are postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows: (i) first, liabilities owed to (i) the lenders, issuing banks and ancillary lenders in relation to the Senior Facilities Agreement or any future senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior Secured

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: Obligations”) and (ii) in the case of Topco Shared Security, the Topco Shared Security Secured Obligations
Subsubsection Text: (as defined below). “Secured Parties” means, where such term is used in a Transaction Security document (other than any document creating or expressing to create Topco Shared Security), the Security Agent, each of the agents (other than the Topco Agent or Topco Notes Trustee), any receiver or delegate, the arrangers (other than the Topco Arrangers) and the Secured Creditors (other than the Topco Creditors) from time to time but, in the case of each agent, arranger or any Secured Creditor, only if, it (or in the case of any noteholders, the relevant notes trustee) is a party to the Intercreditor Agreement or has acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement, in the appropriate capacity (the “Transaction Security Secured Parties”); and (ii) in any other case (including, for the avoidance of doubt, any Transaction Security document creating or expressing to create Topco Shared Security), the Security Agent, each of the agents, any receiver or delegate, the arrangers and the Secured Creditors from time to time but, in the case of each agent, arranger or any Secured Creditor only if, it (or in the case of any noteholders, the relevant notes trustee) is a party to the Intercreditor Agreement or has acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement, in the appropriate capacity (the “Topco Shared Security Secured Parties”), provided that where such term is used in a Transaction Security Document creating or expressing to create both Topco Shared Security and other Transaction Security that is not Topco Shared Security, such term shall mean Topco Shared Security Secured Parties or a Transaction Security Secured Parties, as applicable. “Soulte”means, in relation to any appropriation by, or attribution to, the Secured Parties of any assets subject to Transaction Security and/ or Topco Independent Transaction Security (“Charged Property”) as a result of the enforcement of any French security document occurring by way of appropriation (including pursuant to a pacte commissoire or any similar enforcement mechanism) or judicial foreclosure of any French security document, the amount by which the value of the Charged Property appropriated or foreclosed pursuant to such security enforcement exceeds the amount of obligations secured by that French security which is discharged as a result of that security enforcement being carried out. ----- “Third Party Security Provider” means Midco and any other person that has provided Transaction Security (including Topco Shared Security) but is not a Debtor in respect of any direct borrowing or guarantee liabilities of the applicable Secured Obligations to which that Transaction Security relates and which is designated by the Issuer (in its discretion) by written notice to each agent that is a party to the Intercreditor Agreement at such time. “Topco Independent Obligor” means each Topco Borrower or any member of the Senior Secured Group that directly holds shares in a Topco Borrower or any such person that is not a member of the Senior Secured Group which is designated as such by the Issuer (in its discretion). “Topco Independent Transaction Security”refers to security (other than Transaction Security) which in relation to a Topco Independent Obligor (i) is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties) in respect of the Topco Independent Secured Obligations (as defined below); (ii) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties), is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of (x) all the Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties); (y) in respect of security documents governed by French law, the Security Agent as “agent des sûretés” (security agent) acting in its name for the benefit of the other Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties) or (z) (other than in respect of security documents governed by French law) under a parallel debt and/or joint and several creditorship or similar structure for the benefit of all the Topco Secured Parties (or a class of Topco Secured Parties), in each case, in respect of the Topco Independent Secured Obligations. In the case of a Topco Independent Obligor which is a member of the Senior Secured Group and a direct shareholder of a Topco Borrower, such security shall be (i) limited to shares in and receivables owed to it by the relevant Topco Borrower which are not required to be subject to the Transaction Security pursuant to the Finance Documents and (ii) granted on a limited recourse basis. Topco Independent Transaction Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of each Topco Independent Obligor to the Topco Secured Parties under the Topco Finance Documents (including to the Security agent under a parallel debt) both actual and contingent and whether incurred solely or jointly and as principal or surety or in any other capacity (for the avoidance of doubt, other than to the extent that such security extends to any asset subject to Transaction Security (as defined below) at the time such security is granted) (the “Topco Independent Secured Obligations”). “Topco Shared Security” refers to security at any time which is created, or expressed to be created, over any of the following: (i) the shares in the Issuer held by any direct shareholder of the Issuer and (ii) all receivables owed by the Issuer to a Topco Investor (as defined below), Subordinated Creditor (as defined below) or other holding company or shareholder of the Issuer (including any Topco Proceeds Loan and the Topco Proceeds Loan Liabilities, as applicable) (iii) the shares in any Topco Borrower which is a member of the Senior Secured Group, (iv) all receivables owed by a member of the Senior Secured Group under any Topco Proceeds Loan (or, in the case of a Topco Borrower which is a member of the Senior Secured Group, any Senior Secured Notes Proceeds Loan), and (v), any other assets not falling within limbs (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv) of this paragraph of a Topco Borrower and (to the extent that the Issuer has confirmed to the Security Agent that the granting of such security in favor of the Topco Shared Security Secured Obligations is not prohibited by the terms of any applicable prior ranking financing agreements) any other member of the Senior Secured Group, in each case designated as Topco Shared Security by the Issuer (in its discretion) in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or if such trustee arrangements are not legally possible, in favor of (x) all the Secured Parties (or class of Secured Parties), (y) in respect of security documents governed by French law, the Security Agent as “agent des sûretés” (security agent) acting in its name for the benefit of the other Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) or (z) (other than in respect of security documents governed by French law) in favor of the Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure). Topco Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of the Senior Secured Group and each Topco Borrower that is not a member of the Senior Secured Group and each of its Subsidiaries other than Unrestricted Subsidiaries (as defined in the documents governing the relevant Topco Notes or Topco Facility (as the case may be)) (the “Topco Group”), each Debtor and any Third Party Security Provider to the Secured Parties under the Secured Debt Documents (including to the Security agent under a parallel debt) both actual and contingent and whether incurred solely or jointly and as principal or surety or in any other capacity (the “Topco Shared Security Secured Obligations”). “Topco Shared Security Secured Debt Documents” means the documents relating to the Senior Secured Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities, Topco Liabilities and Hedging Liabilities and any other document designated as such by the Security Agent and the Issuer. ----- “Transaction Security” refers to security (from the Senior Secured Group, any Third Party Security Provider and Topco Shared Security (but excluding, for the avoidance of doubt, Topco Independent Transaction Security)) in each case which, to the extent legally possible and subject to any Agreed Security Principles (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement (i) is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the other Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) in respect of the applicable Secured Obligations; or (ii) in the case of any jurisdiction in which effective security cannot be granted in favor of the Security Agent as agent or trustee for the Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties), is created, or expressed to be created, in favor of (x) all the Secured Parties (or class of Secured Parties), (y) in respect of security documents governed by French law, the Security Agent as “agent des sûretés” (security agent) acting in its name for the benefit of the other Secured Parties (or a class of Secured Parties) or (z) (other than in respect of security documents governed by French law) in favor of the Security Agent under a parallel debt or similar structure. Transaction Security which is not Topco Shared Security shall secure all liabilities and present and future obligations of the Debtors and Third Party Security Providers to the Secured Parties (other than the creditors under the Topco Liabilities (as defined below) (the “Topco Secured Parties”)) under the Secured Debt Documents (other than the finance documents relating to the Topco Liabilities (the “Topco Finance Documents”)). Transaction Security which is Topco Shared Security shall secure the Topco Shared Security Secured Obligations. “Transaction Security Secured Debt Documents” means the documents relating to the Senior Secured Liabilities, Second Lien Liabilities and Hedging Liabilities and any other document designated as such by the Security Agent and the Issuer. On the Issue Date, the Notes and the Note Guarantees thereunder will be Senior Secured Notes Liabilities for the purposes of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Designation Date will not have occurred. On the Issue Date, no Cash Management Facility Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Topco Notes Liabilities, Second Lien Lender Liabilities or Second Lien Notes Liabilities will be outstanding. Such liabilities (and liabilities in respect of other New Debt Financings) may only be incurred and/or designated if not prohibited under the terms of the Debt Documents, including, without limitation, the covenants applicable to the Notes described under “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.”
