A legal act performed by a debtor (including, without limitation, an agreement pursuant to which such debtor guarantees the performance of the obligations of a third party or agrees to provide or provides security for any of such debtor’s or a third party’s obligations, enters into additional agreements benefiting from existing security or any other legal act having similar effect) can be challenged in, or outside of, the context of the insolvency proceedings of the relevant debtor by the creditors’representative (mandataire _judiciaire), the court-appointed commissioner in charge of overseeing the implementation of the safeguard or_ reorganization plan (commissaire à l’exécution du plan), or by any of the creditors of the relevant debtor outside the insolvency proceedings or any creditor who was prejudiced in its means of recovery as a consequence of the act in or outside insolvency proceedings. Any such legal act may be declared unenforceable against all the creditors of the relevant debtor (if the claim was lodged by the creditors’ representative (mandataire judiciaire) or the court-appointed commissioner in charge of overseeing the implementation of the safeguard or reorganization plan (commissaire à l’exécution du plan)) or the concerned creditor (if the claim was lodged by such creditor) if: (i) the debtor performed such act without an obligation to do so; (ii) the relevant creditor or (in the case of a claim lodged by the creditors’ representative (mandataire judiciaire) or the ----- court-appointed commissioner in charge of overseeing the implementation of the safeguard or reorganization plan (commissaire à l’exécution du plan)) any creditor was prejudiced in its means of recovery as a consequence of the act; and (iii) at the time the legal act was performed, both the debtor and the counterparty to the transaction knew or should have known that one or more of such debtor’s creditors (existing or future) would be prejudiced in their means of recovery (where the legal act was entered into for no consideration (à titre _gratuit), no such knowledge of the counterparty is necessary). If a court found that the issuance of the Notes,_ the grant of the security interests in the Collateral, or the granting of a Note Guarantee involved a fraudulent conveyance that did not qualify for any defense under applicable law, then the issuance of the Notes, the granting of the security interests in the Collateral or the granting of such Note Guarantee could be (i) declared unenforceable against all the creditors if the claim was lodged by the creditors’ representative (mandataire _judiciaire) or the court-appointed commissioner in charge of overseeing the implementation of the safeguard_ or reorganization plan (commissaire à l’exécution du plan) or (ii) declared unenforceable against the creditor who lodged the claim in relation to the relevant act. As a result of such successful challenges, holders of the Notes may not enjoy the benefit of the Notes, the Note Guarantees or the security interests in the Collateral and the value of any consideration that holders of the Notes received with respect to the Notes, the security interests in the Collateral or the Note Guarantees could also be subject to recovery from the holders of the Notes and, possibly, from subsequent transferees. In addition, under such circumstances, holders of the Notes might be held liable for any damages incurred by prejudiced creditors of the Issuer or the Guarantors as a result of the fraudulent conveyance.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: of Creditors Test”). If a party voting against a draft plan argues the judgment does not satisfy the Best
Subsubsection Title: Recognition of intercreditor arrangements by French courts
Subsubsection Text: There is no law or published decision of the French courts of appeal or of the French Supreme Court (Cour _de cassation) on the validity or enforceability of the obligations of an agreement such as the Intercreditor_ Agreement, except for Articles L. 626-30 and L. 628-7 of the French Commercial Code pursuant to which, in the context of safeguard or judicial reorganization proceedings, the court-appointed administrator, while constituting the classes shall comply with the provisions of subordination agreements between creditors that were entered into prior to the commencement of the safeguard, accelerated safeguard or judicial reorganization proceedings, provided that such subordination agreements have been brought to his attention within the required deadline. As a consequence, except to the extent referred to above (which, as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, has received no judicial interpretation), we cannot rule out that a French court would not give effect to certain provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: of Creditors Test”). If a party voting against a draft plan argues the judgment does not satisfy the Best
Subsubsection Title: Priority of a pledge over a securities account
Subsubsection Text: A pledge over the shares of a stock company (société par actions) governed by French law is a pledge over the relevant securities account (nantissement de compte de titres financiers) in which the shares of such company which are held by the grantor are credited. In France, no lien searches are available for security interests which are not registered, such as pledges over securities accounts (nantissements de comptes de titres financiers). As a result, no assurance can be given on the priority of a pledge over a securities account in which the shares of such a company are credited.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: of Creditors Test”). If a party voting against a draft plan argues the judgment does not satisfy the Best
Subsubsection Title: Priority of a pledge over the bank accounts and receivables
Subsubsection Text: Certain of the pledges over bank accounts and receivables are governed by French law. In France, no lien searches are available for security interests, which are not registered, such as pledges over bank accounts and receivables. As a result, no assurance can be given on the priority of the pledges over the relevant bank accounts or receivables of a debtor.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: of Creditors Test”). If a party voting against a draft plan argues the judgment does not satisfy the Best
Subsubsection Title: Assumption as to the enforceability of the second-ranking pledges over the bank accounts
Subsubsection Text: Although French law does not expressly prohibit the grantor of a pledge over a bank account from granting a second-ranking pledge over the same bank account, this structure has not been tested before the French courts and no assurance can be given that such second-ranking pledges would be upheld if tested.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: of Creditors Test”). If a party voting against a draft plan argues the judgment does not satisfy the Best
Subsubsection Title: Limitations on guarantees
Subsubsection Text: The liabilities and obligations of any Guarantor organized under the laws of France (a “French Guarantor”) are subject to: - certain exceptions, including to the extent of any obligations which, if incurred, would constitute prohibited financial assistance within the meaning of Article L. 225-216 of the French Commercial Code or ----- infringement of the provisions of Articles L. 241-3, L. 242-6 or L. 244-1 of the French Commercial Code or any other law or regulations having the same effect, as interpreted by French courts; and - French corporate benefit rules. Under French financial assistance rules, a company incorporated as a société anonyme or a société par actions _simplifiée is prohibited from guaranteeing indebtedness of another company that is used, directly or indirectly,_ for the purpose of its acquisition. French law requires that, when a French company grants a guarantee of third-party obligations, the guarantee must be in the corporate purposes and in the corporate interests of the guarantor company. Under French corporate benefit rules, a guarantor must receive an actual and adequate benefit from the transaction involving the granting by it of the guarantee, taken as a whole. A court could declare any guarantee unenforceable and, if payment had already been made under the relevant guarantee, require that the recipient return the payment to the relevant guarantor, if it found that these criteria were not fulfilled. Existence of corporate benefit is a factual matter which must be determined on a case-by-case basis. French case law has recognized that certain intragroup transactions (including upstream guarantees), can be in the corporate interest of the guarantor, in particular where the four following criteria are fulfilled: - the existence of a genuine group of companies operating under a common strategy working towards a common objective and the guarantee and the transaction to which it relates must be entered into in the common economic intent of the group as a whole and the liability under the guarantee should be commensurate of such group benefit; - the risk assumed by a French guarantor must be proportionate to the benefit; - the French guarantor must receive an actual and adequate benefit, consideration or advantage from the transaction involving the granting by it of the guarantee which is commensurate to such group benefit; and - the obligations of the French guarantor under the guarantee must not exceed its financial capability. The existence of a real and adequate benefit to the guarantor and whether the amounts guaranteed are commensurate with the benefit received are matters of fact as to which French case law provides no clear guidance. Each of the Note Guarantees by the French Guarantors and the amounts recoverable thereunder will be limited to the maximum amount that can be guaranteed by a particular Guarantor without rendering its Note Guarantee voidable or otherwise ineffective under applicable law. Accordingly, the Note Guarantee of any French Guarantor will be limited to the aggregate amount of the Notes proceeds on-lent, directly or indirectly, to such French Guarantor or any of its subsidiaries or pursuant to any other intercompany loans or similar arrangements and outstanding on the date a payment is requested to be made by such French Guarantor under its Note Guarantee. Any payment made by such French Guarantor under its Note Guarantee will reduce the maximum amount of its Note Guarantee. Any payment made by such French Guarantor under its Note Guarantee in respect of the obligations of any other obligor shall reduce pro tanto the outstanding amount of the intercompany loans due by such French Guarantor or its subsidiaries under the intercompany loan arrangements referred to above. By virtue of this limitation, a French Guarantor’s obligation under its Note Guarantee could be significantly less than amounts payable with respect to the Notes, or a French Guarantor may have effectively no obligation under its Note Guarantees. In addition, if a French Guarantor receives, in return for issuing the guarantee, an economic return that is less than the economic benefit such French Guarantor would obtain in a transaction entered into on an arm’s length basis, the difference between the actual economic benefit and that in a comparable arm’s length transaction could be taxable under certain circumstances.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: of Creditors Test”). If a party voting against a draft plan argues the judgment does not satisfy the Best
Subsubsection Text: Interest of Creditors Test, the court will determine the value of the company on a going concern basis; - where applicable, any new financing is necessary to implement the plan and does not excessively affect the interests of the affected parties. The court may refuse to approve the plan if it does not offer a reasonable prospect of avoiding the debtor’s insolvency or of ensuring the viability of the business. The court must check that the interests of all creditors are “sufficiently protected.” The judgement adopting the plan renders the plan enforceable against all (including the affected parties who did not vote or voted against the adoption of the plan). As for plans adopted through a standard consultation, if the plan provides for a share capital increase, the shareholders may pay up their subscription to such share capital increase by way of a set-off against their admitted claims against the debtor (as such claims may be reduced according to the provisions of the plan). If the plan is not approved by the required majority of each class of affected parties, it may be approved (arrêté) by the court at the request of the debtor or the court-appointed administrator with the agreement of the debtor and be imposed on the parties that voted against the draft plan (Cross-Class Cram-Down), where the plan meets the following conditions: - the plan complies with the conditions for the adoption of the plan by the court mentioned above; - the plan has been approved by: - a majority of the classes of affected parties entitled to vote, including at least one class of secured creditors or a class ranking higher than the class of unsecured creditors; or, if such condition is not met, - by at least one of the classes of affected parties entitled to vote, other than a class of Equity Holders or any other class which, after determination of the value of the debtor as a going concern, it may reasonably be assumed it would not be entitled to any payment, if the order of priority of creditors for the distribution of the assets in liquidation proceedings or of the sale plan (plan de cession) were applied; - the claims of a dissenting class of affected creditors shall be paid in full (by identical or equivalent means) if a more junior class receives any distribution or keeps any interest under the restructuring plan (the “absolute priority rule”) (the court may decide to waive this condition under certain conditions); - under the safeguard plan, no class of affected parties may receive or retain more than the total amount of its claims or interests; - in the case of one or more dissenting classes of Equity Holders: - the formation of classes of affected parties was compulsory regarding the thresholds met by the debtor (i.e., 250 employees and a net turnover of €20 million or with a net turnover of at least €40 million at the group level); - it may reasonably be assumed, after determination of the value of the debtor as a going concern, that the dissenting classes of Equity Holders would not be entitled to any payment or retain any interest if the order of priority of creditors for the distribution of the assets in liquidation proceedings or of the sale plan (plan de cession) were applied; - if the draft plan provides for a share capital increase subscribed in cash or by way of set off, the shares to be issued are offered in preference to the existing shareholders, in proportion to the part of the share capital represented by their shares; ----- - the plan does not provide for the sale of all or part of the rights of the dissenting class or classes of Equity Holders. The decision of the court shall constitute approval of the changes to the shareholding structure or to the rights of the Equity Holders or to the articles of association provided for in the plan. The court may appoint an agent to carry out the acts necessary for the implementation of these amendments. As for plans adopted through a standard consultation, if the court adopts a safeguard plan, it can set up a time-period (which cannot exceed the duration of the plan) during which the assets that it deems to be essential to the continuation of the business of the debtor may not be disposed of without the court’s consent. At the latest within ten days from the vote of the classes on the draft plan, any affected party having voted against the draft plan and considering that: - the best interest test criterion has not been met; or - the condition relating to the adoption of the draft plan by at least one of the classes of affected parties entitled to vote (other than a class of Equity Holders or any other class which, after determining the value of the debtor as a going concern, it is reasonable to assume would not be entitled to any payment if the order of payment in a judicial liquidation was applied (whether in the event of a piecemeal sale or, a courtordered sale plan)) has not been met; or - in the event of a cross class-cram-down on Equity Holders, the condition relating to the debtor’s value criterion has not been met (i.e., it is reasonable to assume, after determining the value of the debtor as a going concern, that the Equity Holders of the dissenting class or classes would not be entitled to any payment or retain any interest if the order of payment applicable in a judicial liquidation was applied (whether in the event of a piecemeal sale or, of a court-ordered sale plan)), may petition the court to dispute the same. Following a hearing and after receiving the public prosecutor’s opinion, the court will, in the same decision, determine the value of the debtor (in respect of which the court is entitled to order the appointment of an expert) and rule on compliance with the aforementioned conditions and on the adoption of the plan. The decision made by the court regarding the adoption of the plan may be appealed under the ordinary procedure within 10 days from its notification (or of its communication if the appeal was lodged by the State prosecutor). The decision of the court of appeal may be challenged before the French Supreme Court. In case of failure to adopt the plan in safeguard proceedings, the alternatives are either the termination of these proceedings or the conversion into judicial reorganization proceedings. The imposition of an alternative plan and payment terms is not possible. _Specific case—creditors that are public institutions:_ Public creditors (financial administrations, social security and unemployment insurance organizations) may agree to grant debt write-offs under conditions that are similar to those that would be granted under normal market conditions by a private economic operator placed in a similar position. Public creditors may also decide to enter into subordination agreements for liens or mortgages, or relinquish these security interests. Public creditors are consulted under specific conditions, within the framework of a local administrative committee (Commission des Chefs de Services Financiers). The tax authorities may grant relief from all direct taxes. As regards indirect taxes, relief may only be granted for default interest, adjustments, penalties or fines.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Spain
Subsubsection Title: Spanish Insolvency Law
Subsubsection Text: Law 16/2022 amends Royal Legislative Decree 1/2020 of 5 May approving the consolidated text of the Spanish insolvency law (as amended from time to time, the “Spanish Insolvency Law”), which was enacted to restate ----- and improve the previous legal framework governing insolvency in Spain, with the aim of implementing the restructuring framework required by Directive (EU) 2019/1023 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 on preventive restructuring frameworks, on discharge of debt and disqualifications, and on measures to increase the efficiency of procedures concerning restructuring, insolvency and discharge of debt, and amending Directive (EU) 2017/1132 (Directive on restructuring and insolvency) (the “EU Insolvency Directive”), as well as otherwise significantly amending the previous insolvency law. The Spanish Insolvency Law will enter into force 20 calendar days after its publication in the Official Gazzette (Boletín Oficial del Estado) on September 6, 2022 and will apply to insolvency proceedings commenced after its entry into force. Insolvency proceedings already commenced before such date will still be governed by Royal Legislative Decree 1/2020 of 5 May, with a number of certain exceptions set forth in the Spanish Insolvency Law. The Spanish Insolvency Law seeks to overcome some limitations of the existing Spanish pre-insolvency and insolvency system, such as (i) the limited use of pre-insolvency proceedings in comparison with other European countries, (ii) the excessive duration of insolvency proceedings due to the high work-load of Spanish commercial courts and (iii) the tendency of Spanish companies to only file for insolvency when their financial situation is critical and therefore the high number of insolvency proceedings ending up in liquidation. In addition, due to the health crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, on March 14, 2020, the Spanish government declared a state of emergency (estado de alarma) in Spain lasting until June 21, 2020. Since March 14, 2020, the Spanish government has enacted certain Royal Decree-Laws that temporarily amend certain provisions of the Spanish insolvency regime, as described below. Likewise, future changes to, and amendments or restatements of the Spanish Insolvency Law cannot be ruled out either. The Spanish government has also approved several extraordinary resolutions, including Royal Decree Law 34/2020, of November 17, on urgent measures to support business solvency and the energy sector, and on tax-related measures (Real Decreto-ley 34/2020, de 17 de noviembre, de medidas urgentes de apoyo a la solvencia _empresarial y al sector energético, y en materia tributaria) and Act 3/2020, of September 18, adopting_ procedural and organizational measures to confront COVID-19 in the area of the administration of justice (Ley 3/2020, de 18 de septiembre, de medidas procesales y organizativas para hacer frente al COVID-19 en el _ámbito de la Administración de Justicia) (“Act 3/2020”) as amended under Royal Decree-Law 5/2021 of_ March 12 on urgent measures to support business solvency in response to the COVID-19 pandemic (Real _Decreto-ley 5/2021, de 12 de marzo, de medidas extraordinarias de apoyo a la solvencia empresarial en respuesta a la pandemia de la COVID-19) and Royal Decree-Law 27/2021, under which it extends certain financial_ measures to support the recovery of businesses (Real Decreto-ley 27/2021, de 23 de noviembre, por el que se _prorrogan determinadas medidas económicas para apoyar la recuperación), which have introduced several_ temporary and extraordinary measures affecting pre-insolvency and insolvency proceedings. _Concept and petition for insolvency_ As a rule, if any Spanish Guarantor becomes insolvent, insolvency proceedings can be initiated in Spain and will be governed by Spanish law. The Spanish Insolvency Law regulates court insolvency proceedings. In Spain, full-blown insolvency proceedings (insolvency), referred to as “concurso de acreedores” apply to all natural persons and legal entities (save for limited exceptions specifically contemplated in the Spanish Insolvency Law, such as public entities). These proceedings may lead either to the restructuring of the business or to the liquidation of the debtor’s assets. Spanish insolvency laws may not be as favorable to creditors’ interests as the laws of the United States, the United Kingdom or other jurisdictions to which you may be familiar with. Below is a brief description of certain aspects of Spanish insolvency laws. In Spain, insolvency proceedings are only triggered when the debtor is in a situation of current insolvency (insolvencia actual) or imminent insolvency (insolvencia inminente). Under the Spanish Insolvency Law, a debtor is insolvent when it can no longer regularly meet its payment obligations in a timely and regular manner (current insolvency), or when it is aware that it will be unable to meet its payment obligations within a three-month period (imminent insolvency). Insolvency proceedings are available as a type of legal protection that a debtor may request to avoid the attachment of its assets by its creditors. A petition for current insolvency may be initiated by (i) the debtor, in the case of a company, by decision of the management body (voluntary insolvency) (concurso voluntario); (ii) any of its creditors, provided that the creditor requesting the insolvency of a debtor did not acquire the credit within six months before filing the ----- petition for insolvency, through inter vivos acts, on a singular basis and once the credit has matured (mandatory insolvency) (concurso necesario); or (iii) certain other interested third parties (also mandatory insolvency) (concurso necesario). However, only the debtor is entitled to file a petition for insolvency on the basis of its imminent insolvency (and in that case, it is not compulsory). The Spanish Insolvency Law provides that insolvency proceedings conclude following either (i) a court confirmation of full compliance with all the obligations set forth in an agreement between the creditors and the debtor (the “Company Voluntary Agreement,” or the “CVA”), or (ii) the liquidation of the debtor’s estate. Insolvency proceedings can also conclude, among others, (iii) at any moment, once it is verified that there are insufficient assets to pay post-insolvency credits; (iv) at any moment, once it is verified that all of the credits have been paid, or the situation of insolvency no longer exists; or (v) once it is verified that all of the creditors have waived their credit rights. _Voluntary insolvency_ Insolvency is generally considered voluntary (concurso voluntario) if filed by the insolvent debtor. The debtor must file a petition for insolvency within two months after it becomes aware, or should have become aware, of its insolvency situation. It is presumed that the debtor becomes aware of its insolvency, unless otherwise proved, if any of the circumstances that qualify as the basis for a petition for mandatory insolvency occur (as explained in the section on mandatory insolvency below). In the event of failure to file a petition for insolvency within the statutory two-month period, the directors may be held liable for the unpaid claims or the damages arising from the delay. Despite the above, this general rule obliging debtors to file for insolvency within the two-month period does not apply if the debtor notifies the relevant court that it has commenced negotiations with its creditors to obtain support for a Restructuring Plan (as defined below), by means of the communication that is foreseen under Article 585 of the Spanish Insolvency Law (the “Creditor Negotiations Notice”). _Pre-insolvency_ Pursuant to Article 585 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, a Creditor Negotiation Notice may be communicated to the competent court by any debtor in the event of: (i) current insolvency (insolvencia actual); (ii) imminent insolvency (insolvencia inminente); or (iii) “likelihood of insolvency” (probabilidad de insolvencia). The Spanish Insolvency Law has introduced the concept of “likelihood of insolvency” (probabilidad de _insolvencia), defined as the situation in which it is objectively foreseeable that the debtor will be unable to_ regularly fulfil its payment obligations that fall due in the next two years unless it enters into a Restructuring Plan with its creditors. In addition to being able to start negotiating with its creditors with a view to entering into a Restructuring Plan at any time during this period when insolvency is likely, the debtor will also be able to file for pre-insolvency in court, in which case it will inform the court that it is trying to negotiate a Restructuring Plan with its creditors. If the debtor files a Creditor Negotiations Notice with the relevant court, the debtor is granted a grace period of three months and one more month to file for insolvency. Such grace period of three months could be extended if, no later than at the end of the initial three-month grace period, either the debtor, or creditors holding more than 50% of the debts that the Restructuring Plan may affect at that time (net of any credits that would qualify as subordinated claims in an insolvency situation), request the court for a three-month extension, provided the so-called “restructuring expert”, if one is appointed by the relevant Court, issues a favourable report supporting the request. During the three-month period of the Creditor Negotiations Notice (or six in case it has been extended), enforcement actions are stayed, subject to the following: - As a general rule, neither judicial nor extrajudicial enforcement proceedings may be initiated to seize or attach assets or rights that the debtor requires to continue its professional or business activities (the so-called “necessary assets”). Previously initiated enforcement proceedings over assets or rights that the debtor requires to continue its professional or business activities will also be stayed. It is not always easy to determine when an asset is necessary to operate the business and the courts will decide on a case-by-case basis. Courts normally take a flexible approach and consider elements such as cash or credit rights as assets that are necessary to continue to run the business. However, creditors may challenge the court clerk’s asset qualification, which the court will hear. Shares/quota shares held by an insolvent debtor in another company whose only activity is the holding of a material asset and servicing the financing provided in connection with the acquisition of that asset are not considered an asset necessary for the debtor’s business activity as ----- long as the foreclosure of the relevant security interest granted over those shares/quota shares does not cause the termination or amendment of the insolvent debtor’s contracts with the subsidiary allowing the insolvent debtor to exploit that asset. - At the debtor’s request, the court may extend these stays in relation to one or several creditors or class of creditors in respect of other assets or rights, even if they are not deemed as “necessary assets”, if doing so could help to bring the negotiations to a satisfactory conclusion, provided the restructuring expert, if one has been appointed, issues a favourable report supporting of the request. The court decision on this suspension may be challenged by a remedy (recurso de reposición), exclusively. - Subject to the above, enforcing security in rem over “necessary assets” may be initiated but will be automatically stayed. However, neither financial collateral governed by Spanish Royal Decree-Law 5/2005, applicable to financial collateral (“RDL 5/2005”), nor security interests located in another Member State (other than Denmark) should be affected by this suspension. The prevention or suspension of enforcement procedures does not apply to public credit rights (créditos de _derecho público). However, if the enforcement proceeding affects assets or rights that the debtor requires to_ continue its professional or business activities, once initiated, it may be suspended only at the stage of disposal by the judge hearing the case. In the event of an out-of-court enforcement (ejecución extrajudicial), the suspension may be ordered by the judge before whom the Creditors Negotiations Notice has been filed, exclusively at the stage of disposal. This protection will cease once 3 months have elapsed since the filing of the Creditor Negotiations Notice. The Creditor Negotiations Notice can also protect guarantees and security granted by other group companies to the extent certain requirements are met (i.e., when requested by the debtor, proving that the enforcement of the guarantee or security may cause the insolvency of the guarantor and of the debtor itself). Additionally, subject to certain exceptions, ipso facto clauses are banned. The mere submission of the Creditor Negotiations Notice does not affect bilateral agreements with outstanding reciprocal obligations (executory agreements) at that time. Once a period of three months from the Creditor Negotiation Notice has elapsed, the debtor which has not reached a Restructuring Plan shall request the declaration of insolvency within the following month, unless the debtor is not in a current state of insolvency (insolvencia actual). While the effects of the Creditor Negotiation Notice are in force, the insolvency request filed by the debtor may be suspended by the judge at the request of the restructuring expert, if one has been appointed, or of the creditors who, at the time of the request, represent more than 50% of the liabilities that could be affected by the Restructuring Plan. The application must show that the creditors have submitted a Restructuring Plan that is likely to be approved. While the effects of the Creditor Negotiation Notice are in force, the legal duty to resolve the dissolution due to losses that reduce the net worth to an amount lower than half of the share capital will be suspended. _“Pre-pack”_ The Spanish Insolvency Law also foresees certain amendments to the sale of business units regime. In particular, pursuant to Article 224 bis of the Spanish Insolvency Act, the debtor may file, together with the request of the declaration of insolvency, a binding written proposal from a creditor or from a third party for the acquisition of one or more business units. _Mandatory insolvency_ Insolvency is considered necessary (concurso necesario) if filed (among others, such as personally liable shareholders) by a third-party creditor and, in certain cases, by the insolvency mediator (mediador concursal). Under article 2.4 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, a creditor can seek a debtor’s declaration of insolvency if (i) that creditor can prove that the debtor has failed to attach any assets—or sufficient assets—to pay the amount owed; or (ii) that creditor proves before the court a final previous judicial or administrative declaration of insolvency; (iii) there is a generalized default on payments by the debtor; (iv) there is a seizure of assets affecting or comprising the generality of the debtor’s assets; (v) there is a misplacement, “fire sale” or ruinous liquidation of the debtor’s assets; or (vi) there is a generalized default on certain tax, social security and employment obligations during the applicable statutory period (three months) prior to filing the relevant insolvency request. On receipt of an insolvency petition by a creditor, the court may order provisional interim ----- measures to protect the assets of a debtor and may request a guarantee from the petitioning creditor requesting the adoption of those measures to cover damages caused by the preliminary protective measures. The relevant debtor may oppose the mandatory insolvency petition, and will have to prove that it is not insolvent, unless the creditor’s insolvency petition is based on: (i) evidence of a previous final judicial or administrative declaration of insolvency; (ii) the failure to seize sufficient assets of the debtor to pay the amounts owed; or (iii) the seizure of assets affecting or comprising the generality of that debtor’s assets, where the insolvency court will hand down an order declaring the opening of the insolvency proceedings without hearing the debtor. In this case, the insolvency court will then summon the parties to a hearing and will finally issue a court ruling either dismissing the application filed by the creditor or declaring the debtor’s insolvency. _Request of coordinated insolvency_ The insolvency of a company that forms part of a group of companies, including the parent company, does not automatically lead to the insolvency of the remaining companies of the group. As stated above, a company is insolvent when it cannot regularly meet its payment obligations as they fall due. This analysis is conducted individually at each company level. However, creditors may apply for a coordinated insolvency declaration of two or more of its debtors (acumulación de concursos) if (i) the assets are commingled, or (ii) the debtors form part of the same group of companies. Therefore, the request for the coordinated insolvency of two or more legal entities can only be filed by a common creditor of the relevant companies and each of the affected companies must be separately insolvent. Coordinated insolvency may also be requested by the companies themselves provided that they form part of the same group. As to ongoing insolvency proceedings, any of the insolvent debtors or the insolvency trustee, as the case may be, can apply for the procedural coordination under certain circumstances (particularly, if the insolvent debtors form part of the same group of companies). Moreover, creditors may apply for the procedural coordination of the insolvency proceedings of two or more of their debtors already declared insolvent if (i) the assets are commingled, or (ii) they belong to the same group of companies, provided that a petition has not been submitted by any of the insolvent debtors or by the insolvency trustee pursuant to article 41 of the Spanish Insolvency Law. It is important to note that coordinated insolvency proceedings do not entail substantive consolidation. As a result, a “group insolvency” does not generally lead to a commingling of the debtors’ assets and creditors of that group. This means that the creditors of one company of the group will not have recourse against other companies of the same group (except where cross-guarantees exist, in which case such a financial claim will be subordinated). The current system that the Spanish Insolvency Law provides for is basically a procedure aimed at making the insolvency proceedings as time and cost-efficient as possible. However, exceptionally, for the purpose of drafting the insolvency report, which only the insolvency trustee can do, assets and liabilities held between the insolvent companies may be consolidated if the estates and liabilities are commingled to avoid unjustified cost and delay. _Enforcement and termination in a pre-insolvency scenario_ The obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees of the Spanish Guarantor will not necessarily be enforced in accordance with their respective terms in every circumstance, as this enforcement is subject to, _inter alia, the nature of the remedies available in the Spanish courts, the acceptance by the court of jurisdiction,_ the discretion of the courts, the power of the courts to stay proceedings, the provisions of Spanish law on civil procedure (Ley 1/2000, de 7 de enero, de Enjuiciamento Civil) (the “Spanish Law on Civil Procedure”) regarding remedies and enforcement measures available under Spanish law, the provisions of the Spanish Insolvency Law, and other principles of law of general application. In this regard, note the following: - Spanish law does not specifically recognize the concept of an indemnity. Articles 1,152 et seq. of the Spanish Civil Code (Código Civil) establishes that any penalty (cláusula penal) agreed by the parties in an agreement will substitute damages (indemnización de daños) and the payment of interest (abono de intereses) in an event of breach, unless otherwise agreed. Spanish courts may modify the penalty agreed between the relevant parties on an equitable basis if the debtor has partially or irregularly performed its obligations, ----- unless the penalty (liquidated damages) was aimed at that partial performance (and the liquidated damages clause is not disproportionate under fairness standards). There is some doubt as to the enforceability in Spain of punitive damages. - Where obligations are to be performed in a jurisdiction outside Spain, they may not be enforceable in Spain if that performance would be illegal under the laws of the applicable jurisdiction. - Spanish law precludes the validity and performance of contractual obligations from being left at the discretion of one of the contracting parties. Therefore, Spanish courts may refuse to uphold and enforce terms and conditions of an agreement giving discretionary authority to one of the contracting parties. - Spanish law, as applied by the Spanish Supreme Court, precludes an agreement from being terminated on the basis of a breach of obligations, undertakings or covenants if the basis for termination is not a breach of an obligation considered material in view of the particular circumstances (which could be the case in the event of termination on the grounds of cross default or cross acceleration), or which are merely ancillary or complementary to the main undertakings foreseen under the relevant agreement (such as payment obligations under financing agreements), and allows Spanish courts not to enforce any such termination. - Under Spanish law, acts carried out in accordance with the terms of a legal provision when these acts seek a result that is forbidden by or contrary to law will be deemed to have been executed in circumvention of law (fraude de ley) and the provisions whose application was intended to be avoided will apply. - A Spanish court may award damages if the specific performance of an obligation is considered impracticable. - A voluntary waiver of statutory rights would not be valid if it were contrary to public order or detrimental to a third party. Furthermore, under Spanish law, the waiver of future rights that do not yet exist or of which there is a mere expectation could be considered null unless ratified upon the rights arising and being perfected. - A Spanish court may modify the obligations deriving from the contracts in the terms it deems necessary to restore the balance between the obligations (or even declare them unenforceable) if unexpected and exceptional circumstances arise that were unforeseeable when the contracts were executed, which would not have been explicitly or implicitly assumed and entail a drastic change in the consideration or the reciprocal obligations assumed in the contracts, to such an extent that a Spanish court would consider strict compliance with the obligations assumed by this party in the contracts as nearly impracticable or extremely burdensome. In fact, there have been cases where Spanish first instance courts (ruling no. 1/2021 of the Court of First Instance no. 20 of Barcelona (8 January 2021); and ruling no. 155/2020 of the Court of First Instance no. 60 of Madrid (30 April 2021) (although the latter precautionary measures were subsequently lifted by the High Court of Appeals of Madrid (Audiencia Provincial de Madrid) upon challenge by the creditors affected by the measure)) have granted injunctive relief (medidas cautelares) applying the “rebus sic stantibus” (“hardship”) doctrine to stop the enforcement of guarantees, even first demand guarantees, when the health crisis situation caused by COVID-19 has upset the balance between the contracting parties, making performance by one to the other unduly burdensome. - Under Spanish procedural law, rules regarding the burden of proof in judicial proceedings cannot be modified by agreement of the parties and, consequently, any provision of the contracts whereby decisions, certificates, notifications, opinions or the like issued by the parties are considered conclusive evidence in the absence of a manifest error would not be upheld by a Spanish court. - Any document that is not in Spanish must be accompanied by an official sworn translation into Spanish for it to be admissible by a Spanish court or authority. - Under Spanish law, powers of attorney, appointments and authorizations are generally revocable by the grantor (irrespective of whether they are said to be revocable or irrevocable) provided that the revocation is in good faith. However, this general rule would not prevail when the powers of attorney, appointments or authorizations are a necessary consequence of the underlying relationship between the grantor and the beneficiary and that revocation is aimed at frustrating the purpose for which those powers were granted. - Finance or security document provisions relating to application of enforcement proceedings might not be enforceable if they contravene any mandatory provisions under Spanish law. - The choice of New York law in the Notes will not restrict the application of the Spanish “overriding mandatory provisions,” as defined in article 9.1 of Regulation (EC) No 593/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council of June 17, 2008, on the law applicable to contractual obligations (Rome I). Furthermore, Spanish courts may refuse to apply a provision of the chosen law if that application is ----- manifestly incompatible with Spanish public policy. Spanish courts may also give effect to the overriding mandatory provisions of the law of the country in which the obligations arising from the contract have been performed or must be performed. - The exclusive jurisdiction of the Spanish courts includes matters relating to the incorporation, validity, nullification and dissolution of companies or legal entities domiciled in Spain, and any decisions and resolutions of their governing bodies; the validity or nullity of any recording in a Spanish registry; and the recognition and enforcement of any judgment or arbitration award in Spain that has been obtained in a foreign country. _Certain effects of insolvency declaration Effects on the debtor_ As a rule, and subject to certain exceptions, the debtor in a voluntary insolvency retains its powers to manage and dispose of its business but is subject to the intervention (intervención) of the insolvency trustee (administrador concursal), who is appointed by the court. In the case of mandatory insolvency, as a rule, the debtor’s management will be replaced (sustitución) by the insolvency trustee. However, the court has the power to modify this general regime subject to the specific circumstances of the case. Also, at the insolvency trustee’s request, the court has the power to swap the intervention regime for a suspension regime or vice versa. Actions carried out by the debtor that breach any required supervision of the bankruptcy authorities may be declared null and void. Subject to certain exceptions linked to the maintenance and conservation of the debtor’s estate, the debtor cannot sell or create security over its rights and assets without the court’s authorization until the approval of a CVA (convenio de acreedores) or the opening of the liquidation phase. _Effects on contracts_ Under articles 156-158 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, all clauses in contracts with reciprocal obligations that allow a party to terminate, stay or modify an agreement based solely on the other party’s declaration of insolvency or the opening of the liquidation phase are deemed as not included in the agreement and, therefore, unenforceable, except if expressly permitted by specific laws (i.e., agency laws or RDL 5/2005, as defined under it). A declaration of insolvency does not impair the effectiveness of contracts with reciprocal obligations pending performance by both the insolvent party and the counterparty, which remain in full force and effect, and the obligations of the insolvent debtor will be fulfilled against the insolvent estate as post-insolvency credits/ estate claims (con cargo a la masa). However, if there has been a breach of an agreement by either party after it has been declared insolvent, the court can terminate any such contracts at the request of the non-breaching party of the agreement or declare that the agreement remains in force because it is beneficial for the insolvency proceedings (mantenimiento del contrato en interés del concurso), in which case the non-insolvent party is entitled to seek specific performance against the insolvent estate and the claims stemming from that agreement will be considered a post-insolvency credit/estate claims. Likewise, even in the event of non-breach by the counterparty of its obligations under such an agreement after the debtor’s declaration of insolvency, the insolvency trustee (together with the insolvent debtor or at its sole discretion if the insolvent debtor’s powers to manage and dispose of its business have been conferred on the insolvency trustee, as provided above) may ask the insolvency court to resolve the termination of the agreement (on the grounds of it being beneficial for the insolvency proceedings (resolución del contrato en _interés del concurso)). The termination of these contracts may result in the insolvent debtor having to return—_ and indemnify damages to—its counterpart against the insolvent estate. If the insolvent debtor, the insolvency trustee and the counterparty agree on the termination of the agreement and its effects, the insolvency court will approve the parties’agreement; otherwise, if the insolvency court upholds termination, it will also establish the damages claim to be received by the non-breaching party due to the termination of the agreement. Moreover, the declaration of insolvency determines that interest accrual is suspended, except in cases where, (i) under recent case law from the Spanish Supreme Court and Article 152 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, ordinary/legal interest is secured with an in rem right (so long as it is included as a contingent claim in the proof of claims), in which case interest accrues up to the value of the security (9/10 of the collateral fair value minus senior claims in a CVA scenario) (i.e., default interest is stayed following the insolvency declaration); and (ii) wage credits are in favor of employees, accruing the legal interest set forth in the corresponding State Budget Act (Ley de Presupuestos del Estado). ----- _Effects on enforcement proceedings_ As a rule, unsecured creditors’ enforcement rights are suspended on the court declaration of insolvency (with the exception of certain actions conducted by public authorities that do not concern assets necessary for the continuation of the debtor’s commercial or professional activity). Also, once the insolvency proceedings are declared open, singular, judicial or extrajudicial enforcements may not be initiated, nor may administrative or tax demands for payment to be collected coercively against the debtor’s assets be continued. The enforcement of any security over certain assets or rights necessary for the continuation of the debtor’s commercial or professional activity may not be commenced and the procedures already initiated before the declaration of insolvency will be suspended for one year. Enforcement will be suspended even if at the time of declaration of insolvency the notices announcing the public auction have been published. - Enforcement of security over certain assets necessary to continue the insolvent company’s commercial or professional activity (in rem security interests) is prohibited until the earlier of (i) the conclusion of a composition agreement (convenio de acreedores), provided that the composition agreement does not affect that right; or (ii) one year from the date the insolvency was declared without the opening of the liquidation phase. Secured creditors will also be allowed to commence or resume enforcement proceedings after one year from the commencement of the liquidation phase (to the extent the relevant collateral is not sold therein). - Enforcement proceedings conducted before other courts or notary publics will be stayed within this oneyear period unless the insolvency court declares that the collateral is not necessary for the continuation of the debtor’s commercial or professional activity. When it comes to determining which of the debtor’s assets or rights are used for its professional or business activities, Spanish courts have generally given a broad interpretation and will likely include most of the debtor’s assets and rights (such as cash or credit rights) as assets that are necessary to continue to run the debtor’s business. However, shares/quota shares held by an insolvent debtor in another company whose only activity is the holding of a material asset and servicing the financing provided in connection with the acquisition of that asset are not considered an asset necessary for the debtor’s business activity as long as the foreclosure of the relevant security interest granted over those shares/quota shares does not cause the termination or amendment of the insolvent debtor’s contracts with the subsidiary allowing the insolvent debtor to exploit that asset. The above regime does not affect financial collateral foreseen under RDL 5/2005 (the Spanish law implementing the EU Financial Collateral Directive), which will still be enforceable, or collateral located in another EU member state at the time of the declaration of insolvency. If the collateral is located in a non-EU state at the time of the declaration of insolvency, the automatic stay (if any) and, in general, the effects of the insolvency will be governed by the insolvency law of the state where the collateral is located. Under articles 44, 52 et seq. and 142 et seq. of the Spanish Insolvency Law, to protect the interests of the debtor and creditors, the jurisdiction of the court dealing with the insolvency proceedings is extended to handle any enforcement proceedings or interim measures affecting the debtor’s assets (whether based upon civil, labor or administrative law). As a rule, insolvency proceedings are not compatible with other enforcement proceedings that may affect the insolvent estate (excluding enforcement proceedings with regard to financial collateral (as defined in RDL 5/2005) or collateral located in an EU state other the Spain or, subject to local law, a third state). When compatible, to protect the interests of the debtor and creditors, the Spanish Insolvency Law extends the jurisdiction of the court dealing with insolvency proceedings, which is then legally authorized to handle any enforcement proceedings or interim measures affecting the debtor’s assets (whether based upon civil, labor, or administrative law). Finally, prospective investors should also note that enforcement of any security interests will be subject to the provisions of Spanish Law on Civil Procedure and the Spanish Insolvency Law (where applicable), which may delay the enforcement. _Ranking of claims (priority rules)_ The court decision issued by the competent insolvency court declaring the opening of insolvency proceedings for a particular debtor (auto de declaración de concurso) must specifically request creditors to (i) declare any debts owed to them within one month from the day after the publication of the insolvency proceedings in the ----- Official Gazette of the Spanish State (Boletín Oficial del Estado), and (ii) provide the insolvency trustee with the relevant documentation to justify those credits. Based on the documentation provided by the creditors and documentation held by the debtor, the court insolvency trustee will draw up a list of acknowledged creditors/claims and classify them according to the categories established in the Spanish Insolvency Law, which are summarized below. Under the Spanish Insolvency Law, claims are classified into two groups: - Post-insolvency credits/estate claims (créditos contra la masa): article 242 of the Spanish Insolvency Law sets out the so-called “estate claims,” which are pre-deductible (when they become due) claims from the estate (excluding any assets of the insolvent debtor subject to in rem security). Debt against the insolvent estate includes, among others (but not limited to), (i) certain amounts of the employee payroll; (ii) costs and expenses of the insolvency proceedings; (iii) certain amounts arising from services provided by the insolvent debtor under reciprocal contracts and outstanding obligations that are declared to remain in force after the declaration of insolvency, as well as obligations to return and indemnify damages in cases of voluntary termination or breach by the insolvent debtor; (iv) claims deriving from the exercise of a clawback action within the insolvency proceedings concerning bilateral contracts (except in cases of bad faith); (v) certain amounts arising from obligations created by law or tort liability of the insolvent debtor after the declaration of insolvency and until its conclusion; (vi) certain debts incurred by the debtor following the declaration of insolvency; (vii) insolvency trustee’s fees; (viii) in case of liquidation, the financing granted to the debtor under a CVA, excluding funds lent by persons closely related to the debtor through a share capital increase, loan or analogous transaction; and (ix) 50% of the interim or new financing lent under a Restructuring Plan entered into in compliance with the requirements set forth in articles 635 et seq. of the Spanish Insolvency Law, as long as the claims affected by the approved Restructuring Plan amount to at least 51% of the debtor’s total liabilities (in case the funds are granted by persons closely related to the debtor, the Restructuring Plan must affect over 60% of the total liabilities of the debtor, excluding the relevant claims held by the persons closely related to debtor). These post-insolvency claims are deemed “super-senior” in the sense that they are not subject to ranking or acknowledgement and, as a default rule, must be paid as and when they fall due; therefore, these claims are given preference over all others, except for proceeds from collateral subject to special privilege claims (as described below). - Insolvency claims (créditos concursales), which are classified as follows: - Special privilege claims (créditos con privilegio especial): Creditors benefiting from special privileges, representing security over certain assets (in rem security) up to the amount of the value of their security, provided that such security is listed in the creditors’ list (in this regard, the value of a security will be limited to the reasonable value of the secured asset determined in accordance with the rules set out in articles 273 et seq. of the Spanish Insolvency Law minus senior claims). The part of the claim exceeding the value of their security will be classified according to the nature of the claim. These claims benefiting from special privileges may entail separate proceedings, but are subject to certain restrictions derived from a waiting period that may last up to one year and certain additional limitations set forth in the Spanish Insolvency Law. As a rule, secured creditors are not subject to the CVA, except if they give their express support by voting in favor of the CVA and if certain majorities have been reached among secured creditors (see “Conclusion of insolvency—Settlement”). In the event of liquidation, they are the first to collect payment against the assets on which they are secured up to the value of the security. However, the insolvency trustee has the option of stopping the enforcement of the securities and paying these claims as administrative expenses under specific payment rules. The receiver can sell the secured assets during the insolvency proceedings to a third party or to the creditor holding the special privilege debt that is secured by the asset, in each case, subject to certain conditions. The pledged assets might be sold either with the charge or free of the security, by applying the sale proceeds (in the proportion allocated to the secured assets) towards the payment of special privilege debts, subject to the consent of the special privilege creditor in certain scenarios. In the context of the sale of business units that include secured assets, it must be noted that the consent of special privilege creditors is not required when the security is not released and the buyer is subrogated in the debtor’s position. If the sale proceeds applied to satisfy the special privilege debt are lower than the value of the security, the consent of special privilege creditors with collateral included within the business unit sale is required. 75% of the special privilege debts affected by the sale can cram down holdouts. Also, in the context of the insolvency proceedings of a Spanish Guarantor, it must be noted that the insolvency receiver can sell business units to a third party, excluding its creditors from ----- the transfer (barring certain exceptions regulated by law), resulting in a loss of value of the pledge granted over the shares of the Spanish Guarantor. - General privilege claims (créditos con privilegio general): Creditors benefiting from a general privilege, including, among others (but not limited to), (i) specific labor claims and specific claims brought by public entities or authorities; (ii) 50% of the claims held by the creditor that filed for the debtor’s insolvency (net of any credits that would qualify as subordinated claims); and (iii) 50% of the interim or new money lent under a Restructuring Plan entered into in compliance with the requirements set forth in articles 635 et seq. of the Spanish Insolvency Law, as long as the claims affected by the approved Plan amount to at least 51% of the debtor’s total liabilities (in case the funds are granted by persons closely related to the debtor, the Restructuring Plan must affect over 60% of the total liabilities of the debtor, excluding the relevant claims held by the persons closely related to debtor). Similar to secured claims, these general privilege claims are not subject to the CVA unless creditors holding claims benefiting from general privileges representing at least 65% (or 75% depending on the workout measures envisaged under the CVA) of the total value of claims benefiting from general privileges of the same class vote in favor of that CVA. In the event of liquidation, they are the first after secured creditors to collect payment against assets other than those secured by a secured claim, in accordance with the ranking established under the Spanish Insolvency Law. - Ordinary claims (créditos ordinarios): Ordinary creditors are those having claims that are not classified as subordinated or privileged claims. They are paid pro rata once the estate claims and the general and special privilege claims have been paid. For a CVA to be deemed approved by either simple majority, 50% or 65% of the ordinary creditors (depending on the workout measures envisaged under the CVA) of the total value of ordinary claims must vote in favor of that CVA. - Subordinated claims (créditos subordinados): Subordinated claims is a category of claims that includes, among others (but not limited to), (i) credits notified late (outside the specific one-month period mentioned above); (ii) credits that are contractually subordinated with regard to all other credits of the debtor; (iii) credits relating to unpaid interest claims (including default interest, regardless of whether they are secured), except for credits secured with an in rem right up to the value of the security interest (if they have been included as a contingent claim in the proof of claims to be sent to the insolvency receiver); (iv) fines; and (v) certain claims of creditors that are “closely related parties”to the insolvent debtor. In the case of legal entities, the following are considered “closely related parties” (personas _especialmente relacionadas): (i) shareholders with unlimited liability (if the shareholders are natural_ persons, this would include any party closely related to these shareholders, as described in this document); (ii) limited liability shareholders holding, directly or indirectly, 10% or more of the insolvent company’s share capital (or 5% if the company is listed or has securities listed in a secondary official market) at the time the credit is generated; (iii) directors (de iure, de facto or shadow directors), insolvency liquidators, shadow directors and those holding general powers of attorney on behalf of the insolvent company (including individuals that have held these positions during the two years before the declaration of insolvency); and (iv) companies pertaining to the same group as the debtor and their respective shareholders, provided those shareholders meet the minimum shareholding requirements specified in (ii) above (i.e., 10% or 5% if the company is listed). Furthermore, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, assignees or awardees of claims belonging to any of the persons mentioned in this paragraph are presumed to be parties closely related to the insolvent debtor if the acquisition has taken place within two years before the insolvency proceedings are declared open. Additionally, “closely related parties”, are not entitled to vote on a Restructuring Plan. Despite the above, creditors that have directly or indirectly capitalized their credit rights under a Restructuring Plan entered into in compliance with articles 635 et seq of the Spanish Insolvency Law (and even those appointed as directors) will not be considered closely related to the debtor, in respect of credits against the debtor, as a result of the financing granted under such Restructuring Plan. Claims related to accrued and unpaid interest, unless and to the extent they are secured by an in rem right, are also subordinated. Moreover, those creditors will not be considered shadow directors because of the debtor’s obligations under the viability plan, unless it is proved that they occupy this role. Subordinated creditors are second-level creditors. They do not have voting rights under the CVA but are subject to its terms, being paid once the ordinary claims have been satisfied under the CVA. Thus, subordinated creditors have limited chances of collecting payment according to the ranking established in the Spanish Insolvency Law. ----- As an exception to the subordination regime, new financing granted to the debtor under a Restructuring Plan regulated under articles 635 et seq of the Spanish Insolvency Law, which also contemplates a capitalization of credit rights before granting new financing, will not be classified as a subordinated claim under article 281 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, provided that the requirements set out in article 283 of the Spanish Insolvency Law are met. This is an incentive to promote the refinancing and capitalization of credit rights. The claims of the beneficiaries of the Note Guarantees provided by the Spanish Guarantor could be classified as “contingent” (non-crystallized) claims and it may occur that no amounts are recognized (and that the beneficiaries have no voting rights) until and when a default occurs and the guarantee is validly enforced, resulting in an amount due and payable. _Winding up due to losses sustained in 2020 and 2021_ Act 3/2020, of September 18 (in force from September 20, 2020), established that, for the purposes of the events resulting in a company having to wind up due to the losses specified under article 363.1 e) of the Spanish Companies Act, losses attributable to the 2020 and 2021 financial results will not be taken into account. However, if the 2022 financial results show that the company must be wound up because the losses reduce the company’s net worth to an amount lower than half of its share capital, the administrators must call a general shareholders meeting either to dissolve the company or remedy the wind-up situation. _No termination effect_ The general principle of “no termination effect” is established so that all agreements remain effective at the time of insolvency. Therefore, the declaration of insolvency does not impair the existence of contracts entered into by the debtor, which remain in force. Contractual arrangements establishing the termination of a contract with reciprocal obligations or entitling the relevant creditor to terminate it in the event of the debtor’s declaration of insolvency, or both, are unenforceable. As a rule, a declaration of insolvency does not alter the general contractual rules on termination, but under the Spanish Insolvency Law, if a judge decides to remedy an eventual default of the insolvent party by reinstating an agreement, any outstanding amounts and further payments under the agreement will be postinsolvency claims. To safeguard the insolvent party’s interests, the court may also terminate an agreement with compensation for damages to achieve the best outcome from the insolvency proceedings. There are specific rules for employment agreements, mainly affecting collective dismissals, which are dealt with by insolvency judges. See the section on “Effects on contracts” above for further information. _Set-off_ The Spanish Insolvency Law generally prohibits the insolvent company’s credits and debts from being set off once it has been declared insolvent, although set-offs fulfilling the operating requirements before the declaration of insolvency may still apply. However, a particular creditor may exercise a set-off against the insolvent company if allowed under the law governing the reciprocal credit right of the insolvent company in insolvency scenarios. Also, a set-off as part of a master netting agreement is also permitted provided that it complies with the requirements of RDL 5/2005. Set-off is also allowed in connection with credits arising from the same legal relationship. _Hardening periods_ There is no clawback date by operation of law. Therefore, no prior transactions will automatically become void as a result of initiating the insolvency proceedings, but rather the insolvency trustee (or creditors that have asked the insolvency trustee to initiate proceedings due to the latter’s inaction) must expressly challenge any transactions considered detrimental to the insolvent debtor’s estate. Under the Spanish Insolvency Law, particularly article 226, once insolvency has been declared, only transactions that could be considered damaging (perjudiciales) to the insolvent debtor’s estate (i.e., causing “damages to property”) during the two years before the date on which the insolvency is filed may be challenged, even if there was no fraudulent intent. Transactions taking place earlier than two years before the filing for insolvency may be rescinded subject to certain actions set out in the Spanish Civil Code (i.e., fraudulent conveyance, which has a four-year look-back period). The same clawback grounds apply in relation to any detrimental actions carried out within two years preceding the pre-insolvency filing, as well as those carried out since that date up to the declaration of insolvency, even ----- if there has been no fraudulent intent, as long as: (i) a Restructuring Plan has not been passed or, when passed, has not been approved by the court; and (ii) the insolvency is declared within a year of the end of the pre-insolvency period. The Spanish Insolvency Law does not define the meaning of “damages to property” In any case, “damages” does not refer to the parties’ intention, but to the effects of the transaction on the debtor’s interest resulting in damages to the insolvent debtor’s estate or unequal treatment among creditors, triggering the insolvency proceedings (par conditio creditorum). The Spanish Insolvency Law specifies several “irrebuttable presumptions”(iuris et de iure)—namely free disposals (for no consideration) and prepayment or cancellation of the company’s claims or obligations prior to them becoming due and where the due dates of the relevant claims or payment obligations fall after the date of declaration of insolvency—except if those obligations are secured by an in rem security, in which case the transactions would be subject to a rebuttable presumption of “damages to property,” as explained below. Likewise, the Spanish Insolvency Law determines certain actions deemed to cause “damages to property” affecting the insolvent company, but which are “rebuttable presumptions”(iuris tantum), meaning they may be contested by the counterparty—namely, disposals in favor of closely related parties (as described above), the granting of security to secure previously existing obligations or in respect of new obligations replacing existing ones, and the payment or other acts to terminate obligations being secured by an in rem security and that mature after the date of declaration of insolvency. Ordinary transactions carried out in the debtor’s ordinary course of business cannot be rescinded provided that they are carried out at arm’s length. Consequently, if these acts have been performed by the relevant debtor, they may be rescinded if they were carried out during the two-year hardening period and are considered detrimental to that debtor’s estate. Particularly, judges have considered payments made by an insolvent company before a declaration of insolvency to be detrimental, determining that in some situations, a debtor could not be compelled to repay its obligations at the time of payment because it was already unable to regularly pay debts as they became due. Guarantees granted by a Spanish company in favor of a third party to secure other group companies’ debt may be subject to clawback on the basis that those guarantees could be considered detrimental to the guarantor’s estate if the guarantor cannot prove that there was a tangible and identifiable corporate benefit for the guarantor to grant the guarantee (beyond an abstract group interest or a general indication of belonging to the same group of companies, or so-called “group interest”). Whether the granting of an upstream guarantee by the guarantor is detrimental to the guarantor’s estate is a factual matter that needs to be proved on a case-by-case basis (with the beneficiary of the guarantee bearing the burden of proof). Case law has sustained that when the parties had envisaged the creation of the security at the time of granting the financing, if there is a solid business reason to delay the constitution of the security, damage would not exist. In this sense, the ruling handed down by Commercial Court no. 1 of Oviedo, dated February 18, 2010 (AC 2010\525), indicated that “to ascertain whether a security is contextual to the creation or cause of the claim, _it must be verified whether the transactions that gave rise to granting the claim and the security were conceived by the parties simultaneously, thus reducing any importance given to potential temporary delays in technically granting the security.”_ If a court resolution rescinds a prejudicial act, the parties involved will be required to return their reciprocal consideration with any accrued revenue or interest (in the case of bilateral contracts; otherwise, only the non-insolvent party is obliged to return this consideration). These claims are generally regarded as estate claims unless the relevant creditor acts in bad faith, in which case its claims will be subordinated. In any case, under article 16 of the EU Insolvency Regulation and article 730 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, acts and transactions governed by laws other than Spanish law will not be subject to clawback actions if those acts or transactions cannot be rescinded or challenged by any means or on any grounds (not only in insolvency scenarios) under laws applicable outside of Spain. Procedurally, there is no safe harbor against a lawsuit being filed and lenders being served to appear before Spanish courts, but the lawsuit should be dismissed on the merits if lenders prove that the act or transaction at issue is (i) subject to foreign law, and (ii) unavoidable due to the circumstances under that foreign law. No insolvency clawback action will apply to Restructuring Plans, or to any transactions, acts and payments accomplished or any guarantees instituted in the performance of these refinancing agreements, provided that they comply with the requirements set out below in the section on “Cramdown effects of certain refinancing _agreements.”_ ----- _Restructuring Plans_ The so-called restructuring plans are those aimed at modifying the composition, conditions or structure of the debtor’s assets and liabilities, or its equity, including transfers of assets, productive units or the entire business, as well as any necessary operational changes, or a combination of these elements (a “Restructuring

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Spain
Subsubsection Text: No later than 120 days following the Issue Date, one of the Guarantors will be, and other Guarantors may from time to time be, organized under the laws of Spain (the “Spanish Guarantors”). The following is a brief description of certain aspects of insolvency law in Spain and of the limitations applicable to the Note Guarantees and security interests in the Collateral provided by the Spanish Guarantors.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Plan”).
Subsubsection Title: Conclusion of insolvency
Subsubsection Text: _Settlement_ Once the debtor’s assets and liabilities have been identified, the Spanish Insolvency Law encourages creditors to reach a CVA to restructure the payment of the insolvency debts. The CVA may be proposed either by the debtor or by the creditors, and it should set forth how, when and up to what amount creditors are to be paid. Once executed, the CVA must be honored by the debtor and respected by the creditors. ----- The CVA must contain proposals for write offs and stays. Article 317 of Spanish Insolvency Law provides that it may also contain alternative or additional proposals for all creditors or for certain classes of creditors (except for public entities), including conversion of debt into shares, into profit participating loans, convertible bonds or subordinated debt, or any financial instrument different from the original debt. It may also include proposals for allocation of all assets or of certain assets to a specific person with a commitment from the acquirer to continue the activity and to pay off the debt as determined in the CVA. The Spanish Insolvency Law has also incorporated Article 317 bis, by virtue of which the CVA may include the merger, spin-off or global assignment of assets or liabilities of the insolvent company. In this case, the CVA shall also be signed by the duly authorized representatives of the companies which will be a party to such structural amendments. The proposals in the CVA must include a payment schedule and a viability plan.
