For a CVA to be deemed approved by the creditors, the following majorities must be met at the creditors’ meeting: (a) If the CVA contains write offs equal to or less than 50% of the amount of the claims; stays on the payment of principal, interest or any other outstanding amount for a period not exceeding five years; or, in the case of creditors other than those related to the public administration or employment matters, the conversion of debt into profit participating loans (préstamos participativos) over the same period, at least 50% of votes representing the unsecured claims (ordinary credits) must be in favor of that CVA. However, a simple majority will be sufficient when the CVA consists of (i) full payment of ordinary or unsecured claims within a period not exceeding three years, or (ii) immediate repayment of outstanding ordinary unsecured claims applying a write off of less than 20%. (b) If the CVA contains stays of between five and ten years; write offs of more than 50% of the amount of the claims and, in the case of creditors other than those related to the public administration or employment matters, the conversion of debt into profit participating loans over the same period and any other proposal permitted under the Spanish Insolvency Law, 65% of votes representing the unsecured claims (ordinary credits) must be in favor of the CVA. The holders of subordinated credits and creditors considered closely related to the debtor are not entitled to vote. Although, in principle, privileged creditors are not subject to an approved CVA (unless they have expressly voted in its favor), the effects of an approved CVA can be extended to privileged creditors provided that the relevant CVA has been approved by the following majorities of creditors within the corresponding category of creditors (labor creditors, public law creditors, financial creditors or others): (c) If the CVA contains a write off (or debt discharges) equal to or less than 50% of the amount of the claims, stays for a period no longer than five years, or conversion of debt into profit participating loans, also for a period not exceeding five years, at least 60% of privileged creditors’ votes must be in favor of the CVA. If the CVA contains a write off of more than 50% of the claim, stays (for a period between five and ten years), conversion of debt into profit participating loans also for a period between five and ten years, and any other proposal permitted under the Spanish Insolvency Law, at least 75% of privileged creditors’ votes must be in favor of the CVA. _Liquidation_ Liquidation will occur if the CVA is not approved, or at the debtor’s request at any time. The debtor must file a petition for liquidation if, after a CVA has been approved, it becomes aware that it is no longer able to meet the payment commitments and obligations undertaken after the approval of the CVA. In this case, the company will face dissolution and the directors (in the event of voluntary insolvency) will be removed. Deferred credits will compulsorily fall due and credits consisting of other benefits will be converted into cash credits. The court, upon commencement of the liquidation phase or at a later stage, with prior hearing to, or report by, the insolvency trustee in a 10 calendar days period, will determine the special liquidation rules the court deems appropriate or modify those already established. This special liquidation rules cannot provide for the liquidation to take more than one year, nor require specific court approval before selling the assets and rights of the debtor. The court may modify or terminate these ----- special liquidation rules at any time, either ex officio, at the insolvency trustee’s request, or at certain creditor’s request (subject to certain thresholds). In the absence of special liquidation rules approved by the court, certain subsidiary rules set forth in the Spanish Insolvency Law will apply. The insolvency trustee is required to report quarterly on the liquidation and has one year to complete it. _Termination of the insolvency proceedings_ Article 465.5 of the Spanish Insolvency Law also foresees the termination of the insolvency proceedings at any stage when it is proved that all credits have been paid, or that all creditors have been entirely satisfied by other means. Finally, it must be noted that article 465.7 of the Spanish Insolvency Law foresees the termination of the insolvency proceedings at any time when there are not enough assets to pay post-insolvency debt, as long as the requirements set out in article 473 of the Spanish Insolvency Law are met, namely no future clawback actions are envisaged, no actions claiming third-party liability are brought, and the court does not qualify the insolvency as culpable (concurso culpable). The Spanish Insolvency Law also includes certain amendments in connection with the qualification of the insolvency as culpable (concurso culpable). In particular, pursuant to Article 449 of the Spanish Insolvency Law, the creditors who had previously submitted allegations for the qualification of the insolvency as culpable (concurso culpable) and also represent at least 5% of the total liabilities or which are holders of claims over one million euro may request the qualification of the insolvency as culpable (concurso culpable) by submitting a reasoned and documented report. _Fraudulent conveyance laws_ Under Spanish law, in addition to an insolvency clawback action, the insolvency trustee and any creditor may bring an action to rescind a contract or agreement (acción rescisoria pauliana) against the debtor and the third party to that contract or agreement provided that it was performed or entered into fraudulently and the creditor has no other way of receiving payment of the amounts owed. Although case law is not consistent, it is widely accepted that the following requirements must be met for a creditor to bring an action of this kind: - The debtor owes the creditor an amount under a valid contract and the fraudulent action took place after that debt was created. - The debtor has performed an act that is detrimental to the creditor and beneficial to the third party. - That act was fraudulent. - There is no other legal remedy available to the creditor to seek compensation for the damages suffered. - The debtor’s insolvency, construed as a situation in which the debtor’s estate has decreased significantly, has made it impossible or more difficult to collect the claim. The existence of fraud (which must be proved by the creditor) is one of the essential requirements under Spanish civil law for the action to succeed. Under article 1,297 of the Spanish Civil Code, (i) agreements by virtue of which the debtor transfers assets for no consideration, and (ii) transfers for consideration carried out by parties held liable by a court (sentencia condenatoria) or whose assets have been subject to a writ of attachment (mandamiento de embargo) will be considered fraudulent. The presumption referred to in (i) above is a iuris et de iure presumption (it cannot be rebutted with evidence), unlike the presumption indicated in (ii), which is a iuris tantum presumption (a rebuttable presumption). Under article 1,292 of the Spanish Civil Code, payments of debts not yet due and payable made in insolvency may be also rescinded. If the clawback action were upheld, the third party would be liable for returning the consideration received under the contract. Following that, the creditor would need to carry out the actions necessary to obtain the amount owed by the debtor. If the consideration received by the third party under the contract cannot be returned to the debtor, the third party must indemnify the creditor for the damages. The legal term for bringing a clawback claim is four years. _Applicable jurisdiction_ Under European and Spanish law, the applicable jurisdiction to conduct insolvency proceedings is the one in which the insolvent party has its “center of main interests” (“COMI”). The COMI is presumed to be where ----- the insolvent party conducts the administration of its interests on a regular basis and which may be recognized as such by third parties (although under European Union and Spanish law there is a presumption that a debtor’s COMI is the location of its registered office). Insolvency proceedings conducted by the court of the COMI are considered “the principal insolvency proceedings”and have a universal reach affecting the insolvent party’s worldwide assets, with certain exceptions, such as security interests over assets located outside of Spain. If the COMI is not in Spain, but the insolvent party has a permanent establishment in Spain, Spanish courts will only have jurisdiction over the assets located in Spain (the “territorial insolvency proceedings”). If Spanish courts have jurisdiction, article 261 of the current Spanish Insolvency Law may apply, in which case the claims of the beneficiaries of the guarantee provided by the Spanish Guarantor may be classified as “contingent” claims and it may occur that no amounts are recognized until and when the principal debt becomes due and payable (or, based on some precedents, a default by the principal debtor occurs and the guarantee is validly enforced), and the beneficiaries will not have any voting rights. Special rules may apply if the guarantee is not a first demand or joint and several (solidaria) guarantee, but an ordinary guarantee (fianza) and, therefore, the benefits of preference (excusión), order (orden) and division (división) apply. Please note that other jurisdictions outside the European Union do not require a COMI shift for a Spanish company to file a claim in those jurisdictions (similar to schemes of arrangements in the UK). Yet foreign insolvency proceedings not based on COMI or that do not have a reasonable connection of an equivalent nature under the Spanish Insolvency Law should not be recognized. Also, any creditor could file for nonprincipal insolvency proceedings in Spain.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Plan”).
Subsubsection Title: Limitations on validity and enforcement of the guarantees and security interests granted by Spanish subsidiaries
Subsubsection Text: Under Spanish law, claims may become time barred (five years from the date on which the obligation becomes enforceable being the general term established for obligations in personam under article 1,964 of the Spanish Civil Code, as amended by Act 42/2015, of October 5, 2015), or may be or become subject to the defense of setoff or counterclaim. Also, article 1,851 of the Spanish Civil Code establishes that an extension granted to a debtor by a creditor without the guarantor’s consent extinguishes the guarantee (in the sense that it is limited to the original term, although case law has established exceptions where the extension benefits both the debtor and the guarantor). In general terms, under Spanish law, any guarantee or security interest must guarantee or secure a primary obligation to which it is ancillary. The primary obligation must be clearly identified in the guarantee or security agreement, and the nullity or termination of the primary obligation entails the nullity or termination of the ancillary guarantee or security interest. Consequently, if the primary obligation is terminated, the ancillary guarantee or security interest will also be considered null and void. If the guarantor or security provider is able to prove there are no existing and valid guaranteed or secured obligations, the Spanish courts may consider that the guarantor’s or security provider’s obligations under the relevant guarantee or security agreement are not enforceable. The enforcement of guarantees may be limited since the guarantor may not be required to pay any amount in excess of the amount owed by the principal debtor or under conditions that are less favorable than those applying to the principal debtor. In addition, a guarantee or security interest cannot be enforced in Spain without having validly accelerated (totally or partially, as applicable) the underlying agreements governing the guaranteed or secured obligations, and it could be affected by an amendment, supplement, waiver, repayment, novation or extinction of the secured obligations. Spanish courts may not accept the acceleration (vencimiento anticipado) of an agreement if the default is negligible. To be recognized by the Spanish courts as giving rise to the remedy of acceleration, a default must be material. The decision to accelerate an agreement must be based on objective facts and cannot be left to the sole discretion of one party as this would be forbidden under article 1,256 of the Spanish Civil Code. All acts and transactions performed and carried out by a Spanish company must be in pursuit of and aligned with its corporate benefit and interests. Particularly, directors have a duty to act in the best interest of the Spanish company, although there is no specific Spanish mandatory provision of law requiring an express and direct corporate benefit. The absence of a corporate benefit and interests may constitute grounds to challenge these acts and transactions. When assessing whether directors have acted in the best interest of a Spanish company, only the interest of that Spanish company is taken into account. Accordingly, transactions undertaken for the benefit of the group may not always be considered consistent with the best interest of the Spanish company. In the context of upstream and cross-stream guarantees, the Spanish Supreme Court has ruled that the subsidiary granting the guarantee or security interest to secure the debt of its parent company or other company of its group should receive some kind of consideration or benefit, either directly or indirectly, to compensate the financial burden assumed in the interest of the group. This compensation must ----- (i) be verifiable, even if it is not received at the same time as the delivery of the guarantee or security; (ii) be adequate and proportional to the burden assumed by the relevant company in the interest of its group; and (iii) have an economic value. Furthermore, the action undertaken in the interest of the group must be justified and must not jeopardize the solvency of the subsidiary. _Financial assistance_ Furthermore, the Spanish Guarantor’s obligations under its Notes and Note Guarantees or under any security instrument granted by it cannot extend to an obligation that, if incurred, would constitute a breach of the Spanish financial assistance rules. According to these rules, the Spanish Guarantor’s obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees or any security granted or executed by the Spanish Guarantor: - cannot extend to the proceeds of the Notes being used to acquire shares representing the share capital of the Spanish Guarantor or shares representing the share capital of its direct or indirect parent company, or to refinance a previous debt incurred for the acquisition of shares representing the share capital of the Spanish Guarantor or shares representing the share capital of its direct or indirect parent company; and - will be considered not to be undertaken or incurred by the Spanish Guarantor if it implies unlawful financial assistance as provided under article 150 (for Spanish public limited companies (sociedades anónimas)) or article 143 (for Spanish private limited companies (sociedades de responsabilidad limitada)) of Royal DecreeLaw 1/2010, of July 2 (Ley de Sociedades de Capital) (the “Spanish Companies Act”), in which case all provisions of the guarantee or security will be construed accordingly in the sense that no Note Guarantees or security given by the Spanish Guarantor can provide unlawful financial assistance of this kind. More specifically, Spanish law prohibits financial assistance from being granted to (i) Spanish public limited companies for the acquisition of their own shares or the shares of any direct or indirect parent company, and (ii) Spanish private limited companies, for the acquisition of their own shares and the shares of any member of their corporate group. Therefore, Spanish law governing guarantees or security interests granted or assumed by subsidiaries organized under the laws of Spain does not extend to any payment obligation incurred by the issuer for the purpose of acquiring the shares of the Spanish subsidiary or the shares of its direct or indirect parent company or, as applicable, any member of the group, as the security interest would constitute unlawful financial assistance within the meaning of articles 150 and 143 of the Spanish Companies Act. This limitation may also apply to the refinancing of acquisition debt, although this is widely debated among scholars. Accordingly, any guarantee or security interest granted by a Spanish subsidiary will not apply if the proceeds are used to repay the Issuer’s existing indebtedness and the existing indebtedness was used for the purposes described above. No whitewash procedures are available. Accordingly, the guarantee granted by a Spanish company will be limited by the amount of funds not used for unlawful financial assistance purposes. For the purposes of the paragraphs above, any reference to a Guarantor’s “holding company” or “parent company” means the company that directly or indirectly owns the majority of the Guarantor’s voting rights or that may have a dominant influence on that Guarantor. It will be presumed that one company has a dominant influence on another company when any of the scenarios set out in section 1 of article 42 of the Spanish Commercial Code (Código de Comercio) arise. _Principle of specialty (principio de especialidad) and principle of ancillary nature (principio de accesoriedad)_ One of the guiding principles of Spanish law on security interests is the so-called principle of specialty (principio de especialidad), which means that, as a rule, a security interest can secure only one main obligation and its ancillary obligations such as interest and costs, but not two or more main obligations at the same time. In principle, where two different main obligations are to be secured, two different security interests must be created. No statutory provision of Spanish law regulates the possibility of simultaneously creating a diversity of in rem pledges of equal rank over the same asset or right. In this respect, many scholars believe that the creation of two or more pledges over a certain asset or right is legally possible and that, similarly, those pledges may rank pari passu among themselves. This opinion is based on the fact that Spanish law allows for concurrent and second or subsequent ranking real estate mortgages, even though it should be pointed out that not all scholars agree, and that there is no case law for or against the analogical application of the legal principles concerning mortgages to the ordinary pledge (prenda común). Therefore, there are grounds to sustain the effectiveness of concurrent equal ranking pledges governed by Spanish law, although the competent courts may take a different view, considering these pledges ineffective and not admissible. Furthermore, it is important to note that, unlike other jurisdictions, Spanish law does not specifically regulate the possibility of creating a single global pledge to secure several obligations (a floating charge), although ----- global real estate mortgages are permitted under the Spanish Mortgage Act. Therefore, there are also grounds to sustain the validity of global pledges, despite the competent courts potentially holding a different view. Given the above, any security interest governed by Spanish general civil law (derecho común) may be created to secure several obligations (either one security per obligation or as a global security), but as this is not specifically foreseen and has not been tested by the Spanish courts, a ruling might hold a security of this kind to be void and null. Likewise, another general principle on which Spanish law on security interests is based is the principle of ancillary nature (principio de accesoriedad), by virtue of which a guarantee, pledge or mortgage must secure another obligation to which it is ancillary, which must be clearly identified in the relevant security agreement. Therefore, the security interest follows the underlying obligation in such a way that nullity of the underlying obligation entails the nullity of the security, and termination of the underlying obligation entails termination of the security. If the security providers can prove there are no existing and valid secured obligations, the Spanish courts may consider that the secured obligations under the relevant guarantees or security interests are not enforceable. _Security interests consisting of share pledges_ On the foreclosure of a pledge over the shares of a Spanish company incorporated as a Spanish private limited company, the shareholders and the company (if so provided in the company’s bylaws) will have preemption rights over the shares that are being foreclosed. Also, on the foreclosure of a pledge over the shares of a Spanish company incorporated as a public limited company, (only if so provided in the bylaws), the shareholders and the company whose shares are pledged will have pre-emption rights. This may delay the enforcement process or affect the value of the shares. _Equity requirements_ Under Spanish law, some provisions on capitalization must be taken into account when guarantees are enforced. For example, when the enforcement of the guarantee causes the amount of the relevant Spanish subsidiary net equity (patrimonio neto) to fall below half of its share capital, the Spanish subsidiary will need to be wound up (disolverse), within certain terms provided by law, unless the balance between its net equity and its share capital is restored, and provided that it is not required to declare its insolvency. Under the Spanish Companies Act, Spanish companies (both public limited companies and private limited companies) may issue and guarantee (or provide security for) numbered series of notes and other securities that recognize or create debt, with certain restrictions applicable to private limited companies. _Enforcement of pledges_ The law regulating the enforcement of pledges through auctions organized by notaries as described in the Notary Public Act, of May 28, 1862 (the “Notary Public Act”), was significantly amended by Act 15/2015, of July 2, on voluntary jurisdiction (“Act 15/2015”). There is considerable uncertainty as to this new legal framework because some provisions of the Notary Public Act seem to conflict with laws regarding the enforcement of pledges that were not repealed by Act 15/2015. As a result, certain aspects of these types of auctions are open to interpretation. Given that the amendments to the Notary Public Act brought about by Act 15/2015 entered into force on October 15, 2015, there are no precedents clarifying how Act 15/2015 should be applied. Consequently, the clauses in pledge agreements governing auctions organized by notaries may not be enforceable in accordance with their own terms. If in the course of the foreclosure of a security interest, the pledged assets are allocated to or acquired by the secured creditor, a Spanish court may order the secured creditor to discharge the secured debt fully—as opposed to partially—regardless of any provision to the contrary in the relevant security agreement. _Issuance restrictions_ Under the Spanish Companies Act, Spanish companies (both public limited companies and private limited companies) may issue and guarantee (or provide security for) numbered series of notes and other securities that recognize or create debt, with certain restrictions applicable to private limited companies. In particular, under article 401 of the Spanish Companies Act, the issuance by a Spanish company incorporated as a private limited company is subject to the following restrictions: private limited companies (i) can only issue notes up to an aggregate maximum amount of twice their own equity (recursos propios), unless the issue is secured by a mortgage, a pledge over securities, a public guarantee or a joint and several guarantee from a credit ----- institution; and (ii) are prohibited from issuing or guaranteeing (or providing security for) notes convertible into shares (participaciones sociales). If a court rules that the limitation in point (i) above will also apply to the guarantee or provision for security of notes by Spanish companies organized under the form of private limited companies, the Note Guarantees provided by any Spanish Guarantor incorporated as a limited company will be limited accordingly. Regarding the restrictions applicable to Spanish private limited companies, there is no consistent opinion among scholars and practitioners, or any case law regarding the interpretation of article 401 of the Spanish Companies Act. Under Spanish law, claims may become time barred (five years being the general term established for obligations in personam under article 1,964 of the Spanish Civil Code (Código Civil)) or may be or become subject to the defense of set-off or counterclaim. The terms “enforceable,” “enforceability,” “valid,” “legal,” “binding” and “effective” (or any combination of them) mean that all obligations assumed by the relevant party under the relevant documents may be type enforced by Spanish courts. They do not mean that these obligations will necessarily be enforced in all circumstances in accordance with their terms. Enforcement before the courts will, in any event, be subject to: - the nature of the remedies available in the courts; - Spanish public policy (overriding mandatory provisions); and - the availability of defenses such as (without limitation) setoff (unless validly waived), circumvention of law (fraude de ley), abuse in the exercise of rights (abuso de derecho), misrepresentation, force majeure, unforeseen circumstances, undue influence, duress, abatement and counterclaim. Without notarization of the security documents and provision of originals or enforceable copies (primeras _copias o copias autorizadas con efectos ejecutivos) of the notarial documents together with the lawsuit, the_ secured parties cannot access the executive summary proceedings (juicio ejecutivo) in case of judicial enforcement of the security documents in Spain, and the secured parties must follow the ordinary judicial proceedings (juicio ordinario). See the section on “Enforcement and termination in a pre-insolvency scenario” for other factors that may limit the enforcement of contracts. _Trust under Spanish law_ Spanish law security interests must be granted in favor of each secured party, and each secured party must accept them. As Spanish law does not sanction the concept of security agent or that of trustee, Spanish courts may not recognize either one. Therefore, in cases where an entity acts as security agent or trustee of the actual beneficiaries of the security interest or a guarantee (i.e., the creditors of the secured obligations), that security agent or trustee must be duly empowered for that purpose at the time it takes on that role. Otherwise, the security interest or guarantee will not be validly created in favor of its purported beneficiaries. Particularly, since the noteholders will have no power to accept and enforce the Spanish law security interests securing the Notes except through the security agent or the trustee, whose authority to represent the holders and to enforce the Spanish law security interests in their name and for their benefit is established in documents governed by New York law, there is some uncertainty as to whether a Spanish court would recognize the noteholders as secured parties, and whether obligations to beneficial owners of the Notes not identified as registered holders in a Spanish law security document will be validly secured or whether the security agent would only be able to enforce the guarantees or the security interest in respect of those obligations. These limitations may be overcome if the creditors grant formal powers of attorney in favor of the security agent for the latter to represent them in the enforcement proceedings, although there is no uniform case law on this point. The noteholders, from time to time, will be the beneficial holders of any Spanish law security interests. However, it is envisaged that they will not be parties to the Spanish law security documents executed by the security agent on their behalf and the noteholders will not be entitled to take enforcement actions in respect of those security interests except through the security agent (even if they are the direct beneficiaries of the security interests). Although it could be argued that article 429 of the Spanish Companies Act could apply by analogy, as it basically states that the representative of the syndicate of the noteholders (comisario) may enforce any security interest on behalf of all noteholders under certain circumstances, it cannot be ruled out that if the security ----- agent is to enforce the security interest, it may need to prove that it is duly and expressly empowered for this purpose by means of a power of attorney granted in its favor by each of the secured parties. This must be notarized and, if applicable, bear an apostille of the Hague Convention dated October 5, 1961, or legalized. Therefore, there could be a delay in the enforcement of the Spanish security documents while the security agent obtains these powers and the relevant public deeds are granted. In the absence of the above powers of attorney, the security agent may be unable to enforce the relevant Spanish collateral on behalf of all of the secured creditors (including the noteholders), and there is a risk that the security agent would only be able to enforce the security interest against the debt that it holds individually, and not for the full amount owed to creditors for whom it may be acting as security agent. Further, beneficial holders of the security who have not accepted the security or empowered (by means of notarial and apostilled powers of attorney) the security agent to do so may be treated, from a Spanish law perspective—including without limitation in an insolvency scenario—as unsecured creditors. It is worth noting that there is a risk that the relevant court or notary public before whom a Spanish security interest may be enforced will request the notarization of the documents from which the relevant obligations arise, and the notarization of each of the transfer certificates regarding each transfer of the Notes. Likewise, the validity and enforceability of security interests granted in favor of the secured parties through the security agent, in its capacity as joint and several creditor (acreedor solidario) of the secured parties, has not been tested before the Spanish courts. Moreover, the structure of joint and several creditor is not contemplated under Spanish law in a situation where the joint and several creditor does not hold a portion of the secured obligation itself. As a result, the security agent’s ability to represent the applicable trustee and the noteholders may be challenged. _Parallel debt_ Parallel debt structures have not been tested under Spanish law and we cannot assure that creating a structure of this kind will eliminate or mitigate the risk of unenforceability by the security agent. If any challenge to the validity, perfection or enforceability of the security interests created by the security documents were successful, the noteholders may be unable to enforce the security. Also, under Spanish law, if the relevant obligor enters into insolvency proceedings, the securities or the parallel debt obligation could be challenged by an insolvency administrator, the obligor itself or by other creditors of that obligor under the rules of avoidance or clawback of Spanish insolvency laws and the relevant law on the non-insolvency avoidance or clawback of transactions by the debtor. Likewise, validity and enforceability of security interests granted in favor of the secured parties through the security agent, in its capacity as joint and several creditor (acreedor solidario) of the secured parties, has not been tested before the Spanish courts. Moreover, the structure of joint and several creditor is not contemplated under Spanish law in a situation where the joint and several creditor does not hold a portion of the secured obligation itself. _Corporate benefit in cross-collateral security structures_ The Spanish Guarantor will be creating the Spanish security as security of the Notes issued by a company of the group receiving the financing under the Notes, so it is arguable whether the Spanish Guarantor has obtained a corporate benefit for granting the relevant Note Guarantees or collateral over their assets. Unlike other jurisdictions, the concept of “corporate benefit” is not specifically regulated under the Spanish Companies Act or any other piece of legislation. However, Spanish lower courts, particularly Spanish commercial courts (Juzgados de lo Mercantil) ruling on insolvency matters, have recently declared null or rescinded upstream guarantees by applying the rebuttable presumption of actions detrimental to the estate of an affiliate granting guarantees or security interests in favor of the liabilities incurred by a parent company or other companies of its group for the purposes of article 226 of the Spanish Insolvency Law (i.e., clawback of these actions during the two year hardening period, as described above), when the obligations guaranteed or secured do not directly benefit the Spanish company granting the guarantee or security interest. The Spanish Supreme Court has recently issued several rulings in favor of the validity and enforceability of these guarantees and security interests in cases where it can be proved that there is a direct benefit for the Spanish company, and not only for the group to which it belongs (e.g., if amounts can be borrowed directly by the company granting the guarantee or security interest or indirectly on-lent, or otherwise made available to that company under an intercompany loan agreement, equity contribution or similar arrangement). Other ----- courts have also considered indirect benefits deriving from the enhancement of the financial position of the group to which the company belongs and the granting of parent guarantees, indemnities and comfort letters for which the relevant company obtains the most favorable economic and financial conditions under its contractual relationships with suppliers and other counterparties, in accordance with Spanish case law on the construction of the notion of “compensatory advantage” (ventaja compensatoria), but always focused on the benefit of the Spanish company (not only for the group). However, there is no certainty that further proof of the existence of benefits and compensatory advantages would need to be delivered to the court, the insolvency trustee or the insolvency court in an insolvency scenario where the noteholders’ claims, particularly “special privilege claims,” may be challenged if the insolvency trustee or other creditors allege that the corporate benefit did not exist. _First demand guarantee_ Despite not being specifically regulated under the Spanish Civil Code, the validity and effectiveness of first demand guarantees (garantías a primer requerimiento) have been admitted in several judgments and regulated by the Spanish Supreme Court as a separate guarantee, detached from the underlying agreement the obligations of which are being guaranteed, thus acknowledging the validity of the provision under which the guarantor agrees not to rely on exceptions other than those arising from the guarantee. However, case law has admitted, with certain limitations, that guarantor may object to the guarantee, relying on the exception of fraud, bad faith or abuse of rights (abuso de derecho), in cases where the beneficiary enforces the guarantee in a fraudulent manner or with bad faith. Likewise, case law has also admitted that the guarantor may stay the enforcement by showing there has been no event of default (the guarantor bearing the burden of proof), usually through a declaratory relief filed by the guarantor requesting the stay of the enforcement proceedings. Moreover, recent court precedents have tightened the requirements for a guarantee to be characterized as a first demand guarantee rather than an ordinary guarantee (fianza). Although the above case law and court precedents are related to guarantees contractually governed by Spanish law, some of their findings may be regarded as being part of the Spanish contractual public policy. _Financial collateral arrangements_ RDL 5/2005 implements, among others, provisions related to the special regime for security interests over cash and securities. However, to benefit from the provisions of RDL 5/2005, the parties to the security documents must be those referred to in article 4 (mainly public entities, credit entities and financial institutions in accordance with article 1.5 of Directive 2006/48/EC of June 14, 2006), and the object of the security must consist exclusively of (i) cash, meaning money paid into an account in any currency; (ii) securities and other financial instruments as defined in the Securities Market Act and its implementing regulations, and any other direct or indirect regulations over them (the shares of Spanish companies incorporated as a private limited company would not qualify as securities or financial instruments, and there is an uncertainty as to whether the shares of non-listed companies incorporated as a Spanish public limited company or those represented by titles would qualify as securities or financial instruments to these effects, as we are not aware of this having been tested before Spanish courts); and (iii) credit claims, meaning pecuniary claims arising from an agreement under which a credit institution grants credit in the form of a loan or a credit to an entity (other than or micro or small enterprises, save where the collateral taker or the collateral provider of those credit claims is one of the institutions referred to in article 4.1(d) of RDL 5/2005). Only if a security qualifies as a financial collateral arrangement as provided under RDL 5/2005 can that security be enforced by means of direct appropriation. Otherwise, the security will be enforced through other available procedures, such as judicial proceedings, in accordance with articles 681 to 698 of the Spanish Act on Civil Procedure, or notarial proceedings in accordance with article 1,872 of the Spanish Civil Code. In both cases, the relevant asset is required to be sold by public auction. If the sale price obtained in the public auction exceeds the outstanding secured amount, the amount by which it exceeds the outstanding secured amount must be delivered to the security provider. Judicial or notarial procedures can be very complex and long (as they may be subject to formalities, granting of judicial powers of attorney, waiting periods, legal notice requirements, valuation of assets, material costs and expenses, among others) and the result may differ from what was expected or might not be successful. _Further considerations on certain Spanish security interests_ Under Spanish law, the law governing in rem legal aspects of a pledge is the lex rei sitae (the law where the property is situated). When the pledged asset is a credit right—such as receivables or intercompany loans— the determination of the lex rei sitae is unclear given its lack of physical existence. In these cases, several ----- theories have been construed among Spanish scholars to determine the lex rei sitae (such as the tax residence of debtor of the credit rights being pledged, the pledgor’s tax residence, and the law governing the credit right being pledged). If a judge considers that any of the pledges created over credit rights under the Spanish security documents is governed by Catalan law, the regulations of that autonomous region would govern those pledges instead of Spanish common law, which could affect the validity of those pledges. Also, under Spanish law, the law governing the pledge over shares of a Spanish public limited company the nominative certificates of which are issued is the law of the jurisdiction where those certificates are located. If the certificates were moved to a particular place at the time of or shortly before creating the pledges, and that place had no connection with the security agreement or with the obligations secured under it, a judge could consider that the lex rei sitae is not the place stated in the pledge and may apply a different law to determine the validity and enforceability of the pledge against third parties.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Plan”).
Subsubsection Text: Under the Spanish Insolvency Law, the effects of a Restructuring Plan, as set out in Articles 614 et seq., can be imposed on all types of creditors and claims (subject to specific exceptions), including public creditors (subject to strict requirements), one or multiple classes of creditors and, where applicable, to shareholders. The Restructuring Plan must include a minimum content provided for in Article 633 of the Spanish Insolvency Law and will need to be formalized in a public document (formalizado en instrumento público). In addition, a Restructuring Plan under the Spanish Insolvency Law may contain a great variety of acts and operations, provided these are sufficient and proportionate to ensure the viability of the business and its continuation as a going concern. The debtor and its creditors may agree on a great variety of measures deemed necessary to effectively restructure the debtor’s business, including changes in the composition, conditions or structure of its assets and liabilities, or any part of its capital structure. This could include sales of assets, parts of the business or even the entire business as a going concern, as well as any other necessary operational changes, or a combination of the above. The Restructuring Plan must nevertheless set out, among others, the reasons why it has a “reasonable prospect” (perspectiva razonable) of preventing the insolvency of the debtor and ensuring the viability of its business, including the necessary conditions for its success. The creditors affected by the Restructuring Plan must be gathered into classes, which are envisaged by the parties to the Restructuring Plan. Class formation depends on the existence of a “common interest based on objective criterion” (e.g., insolvency rank). Claims with the same insolvency ranking may be separated into different classes when there are sufficient reasons to justify it. For these purposes, attention shall be paid, in particular, to the financial or non-financial nature of the claim, to the conflict of interest that creditors forming part of different classes may have, or to how the claims will be affected by the Restructuring Plan. The Spanish Insolvency Law allows the debtor or the creditors whose claims represent more than 50% of the total liabilities affected by the approved Plan to accede to a prior judicial confirmation on class formation. Claims secured by assets of the debtor shall constitute a single class, unless the diversity of the encumbered assets or rights justifies their separation into two or more classes. Public credit rights (créditos de derecho público) shall constitute a separate class among the classes of the same insolvency ranking. The Restructuring Plan shall be considered approved by a class of affected creditors if more than two-thirds of the liabilities corresponding to that class has voted in favor. In the event that the class consists of secured claims, the Restructuring Plan shall be deemed approved if three-fourths of the liabilities corresponding to this class have voted in favor. If the Restructuring Plan affects claims which are subject to a syndication agreement, the majorities referred to in the above paragraph will apply (unless a lower majority is set forth in the syndication agreement). The approval of a Restructuring Plan, by itself, shall not affect the agreements with outstanding reciprocal obligations. In particular, contractual clauses establishing the other party’s power to suspend or modify the obligations or the effects of the agreement, as well as the power to terminate the agreement on the mere ground of the filing of the application for approval or its admission for processing, the judicial approval of the plan or any other circumstance analogous or directly related to the above, shall be deemed not to have been put into effect. The agreements which are necessary for the continuity of the debtor’s business or professional activity shall not be suspended, modified, terminated or early terminated merely because the Restructuring Plan entails a change of control of the debtor. During the negotiation of a Restructuring Plan, the debtor may request the amendment or termination of any agreements with outstanding reciprocal obligations when such amendment or termination is necessary for the successful completion of the restructuring and to prevent insolvency. _Cramdown effects of certain Restructuring Plans—Court approval (homologación)_ Court approval (homologación) of the Restructuring Plan shall be necessary in any of the following cases: (i) when it is intended to extend its effects to creditors or classes of creditors who had not voted in favor of the ----- Restructuring Plan or to the shareholders of the debtor; (ii) when it is intended to terminate agreements in the interest of the restructuring; and (iii) when it is intended to protect the interim financing and the new financing provided for in the Restructuring Plan, as well as the acts, operations or businesses carried out in this context against clawback actions. The application for approval of the Restructuring Plan may be filed by the debtor or by any affected creditor who has executed it and shall be signed by both a court agent (procurador) and an attorney (abogado). Court approval of a Restructuring Plan may be sought merely to ring-fence it from potential clawback if the debtor becomes insolvent (i.e., without seeking to cram down dissenting creditors). The court will verify that the relevant majorities required for court approval are met prior to approving the Restructuring Plan. The Restructuring Plan might become binding for both (i) dissenting creditors in classes where a majority has been achieved (i.e., an intra-class cram down); and (ii) creditors in classes where no majority has been achieved (i.e., a cross-class cram down). For a cross-cram down to happen, the Restructuring Plan must meet one of the following two requirements: (i) it must be supported by a simple majority of the classes, provided at least one of those classes is composed of claims that would benefit from a general or special privilege (i.e. secured claims) if the debtor were declared insolvent; or, failing that, (ii) it must be supported by at least one of the classes that is “in the money” (i.e. any class that could, upon a valuation of the debtor as a going concern, be reasonably presumed to receive any payment according to the ranking of liquidation priorities applicable under the Spanish Insolvency Law). The effects of a cross-class cram down are subject to some practical limitations. If the Restructuring Plan affects a class of claims secured by rights in rem, and that class has rejected the Restructuring Plan by a majority of dissenting votes over favorable votes, any secured dissenting creditor of that class will have the right to: (a) enforce the underlying security interest (which will accelerate the underlying secured claim) within a month of the court ruling approving the Restructuring Plan being published in the Public Insolvency Registry. If the proceeds obtained from the enforcement (i) are lower than the security value of the collateral set out in the Restructuring Plan, the creditor will keep those proceeds in full (security value equals the “reasonable value” minus legally preferred claims). Any deficit will remain unsatisfied, or (ii) are higher than the security value collateral set out in the Restructuring Plan, but lower than the original claim, the creditor will keep those proceeds in full. Any excess will be deducted from the amounts that the creditor’s unsecured part of the claim would be entitled to receive pursuant to the Restructuring Plan; or (b) instead, and only if expressly provided in the Restructuring Plan, wait to receive a cash payment for the amount of the secured claim that is covered by the security value of the collateral within no more than 120 days. If payment is not received in a timely manner, the affected creditor will be entitled to enforce the security interest. Pursuant to Article 653 et seq of the Spanish Insolvency Law, a dissenting class subject to a haircut will be allowed to challenge the Restructuring Plan based on, among other, a more junior class (or the equity holders) receiving any payment from—or maintaining any interest in—the debtor under the Restructuring Plan. The Spanish Insolvency Law, however, contains certain exceptions to the absolute-priority rule. Besides the absolute priority rule, Spanish law provides for a number of grounds to challenge the Restructuring Plan, which depend on whether all classes or the shareholders approve the Restructuring Plan. These challenges can be filed once the homologation of the Restructuring Plan is granted by the relevant court, or at an earlier stage, if so requested by the party seeking homologation. _Protection in case of insolvency Protection of interim and new money_ The Spanish Insolvency Law specifically protects the following forms of financing granted by any party (whether they are or not an existing creditor) in the context of a Restructuring Plan: (a) Interim financing: defined as new financing granted to the debtor that is reasonable and immediately needed to (i) ensure that the debtor’s activity continues totally or partially while the Restructuring Plan is being negotiated (and until a court approves it); or (ii) maintain or increase the value of the debtor’s business or business units. ----- (b) New financing: defined as new financing granted to the debtor that is provided for in the Restructuring Plan and is necessary for its implementation. Interim and new financing may benefit from two effects: (a) Protection against clawback: under the same terms as any other actions or transactions resulting from the Restructuring Plan. As a special rule, in order to protect interim or new financing lent by a “specially related party”to the debtor from clawback, the claims affected by the Restructuring Plan (after deducting the claims held by that specially related lender) must represent more than 60% of the debtor’s liabilities. Otherwise, they will be subject to the ordinary clawback regime. (b) Preferential treatment for repayment of interim or new money: in the event of the debtor’s insolvency, 50% of the interim or new financing provided in the framework of a judicially sanctioned Restructuring Plan will be treated as an estate claim (crédito contra la masa). The remaining 50% will be treated as a generally privileged claim (crédito con privilegio general). This preferential treatment will only apply if the claims affected by the Restructuring Plan exceed the minimum thresholds described above with respect to the debtor’s total liabilities (i.e., 51% in general, and 60% if interim or new financing is granted by a “specially related party” to the debtor). _Protection of certain Restructuring Plans against clawback_ Neither Restructuring Plans nor transactions, acts and payments accomplished, or any guarantees created in connection with such Restructuring Plans will be subject to an action to clawback, provided that they comply with the requirements set out below. In order to seek protection against clawback, Restructuring Plans can be judicially sanctioned (homologado) by the commercial court that will be competent to conduct a potential insolvency proceeding, upon request by the debtor or by any creditor having entered into such Restructuring Plans. Anyhow, Restructuring Plans approved according to the Spanish Insolvency Law but not judicially sanctioned are not subject to clawback provisions either. If the Restructuring Plan affects claims that represent at least 51% of the debtor’s total liabilities, the following will not be subject to clawback unless it is proven that they were made with an intent to defraud creditors: - actions and transactions that were “reasonable”and “immediately necessary”for the successful negotiation of the Restructuring Plan, if expressly identified as such in the Restructuring Plan. Any payment of (i) fees or costs in relation to negotiating, signing or confirming the Restructuring Plan; (ii) fees for legal and professional advice with close relationship with the restructuring; (iii) employee salaries for completed works; and (iv) other amounts in the ordinary course of the debtor’s business activity, will be deemed to be protected actions and transactions; - interim and new money, including that provided by specially related parties; and - actions and transactions that are reasonable and immediately necessary to implement the Restructuring Plan. If the Restructuring Plan affects claims that represent less than 51% of the debtor’s total liabilities, the actions and transactions described above may still be subject to clawback, but none of the rebuttable presumptions of detriment explained in section Hardening Periods will apply. Therefore (as long as none of the non-rebuttable presumptions apply), the insolvency trustee or the creditor requesting the clawback will need to evidence the detriment. Judicially sanctioned Restructuring Plans will not be subject to the bankruptcy clawback action, but they may be challenged pursuant to general fraudulent conveyance law.

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Belgium
Subsubsection Title: Insolvency
Subsubsection Text: One of the Guarantors is, and other Guarantors may from time to time be, organized under the laws of Belgium (the “Belgian Guarantors”). To the extent any Belgian Guarantor has its statutory seat (statutaire _zetel/siège social) in Belgium or to the extent that Belgium is the territory in which the center of a Belgian_ Guarantor’s main interests is situated, main insolvency proceedings may be initiated in Belgium. This also applies to any debtor for which Belgium is the territory in which the center of such debtor’s main interests is situated. Such proceedings would then be governed by Belgian law, subject to certain exemptions. In case of a branch in Belgium, the EU Insolvency Regulation and Belgian law also allows secondary bankruptcy proceedings to be opened in Belgium over the assets of companies whose center of main interests is not situated in Belgium. The effects of those secondary bankruptcy proceedings are restricted to the assets situated in Belgium. The following is a brief description of certain aspects of Book XX (“Insolvency of Undertakings”) of the Belgian Code of Economic Law, as inserted by the Act of August 11, 2017 and as amended from time to time (hereafter the “Belgian Insolvency Law”). The Belgian Insolvency Law provides for two main insolvency proceedings: judicial reorganization proceedings (gerechtelijke reorganisatie/réorganisation judiciaire) and bankruptcy proceedings (faillissement/faillite). Note that in addition, Belgian law allows for liquidation in deficit (deficitaire vereffening/liquidation déficitaire). The latter proceedings will not be further discussed. Belgium is currently implementing the EU Restructuring Directive. The implementation will have an impact on the available reorganization proceedings. However, the date of implementation is still uncertain and no official legal texts are available yet. _Judicial reorganization_ A debtor may (and in limited circumstances, its creditors, interested third parties or the public prosecutor) file a petition for judicial reorganization if the continuity of the enterprise is at risk, whether immediately or in the future. If the net assets of the company have fallen under 50% of the company’s registered capital, the continuity of the enterprise is presumed to be at risk. A state of bankruptcy of the debtor does not exclude that a petition for judicial reorganization is filed. As from the filing of the petition with the competent commercial court overseeing the judicial reorganization and for as long as such court has not issued a judgment thereon, the debtor cannot be declared bankrupt (save in case the debtor files a declaration of bankruptcy itself) or wound up by court order. Furthermore, during this period, with limited exceptions, none of the debtor’s assets may be realized by any of its creditors as a result of the enforcement of any security interests that such creditors may hold with respect to such assets. The filing of the petition does not, however, have a suspensory effect if the debtor requested the opening of judicial reorganization proceedings less than six months ago (unless the court decides otherwise). The Belgian Insolvency Law provides that, within a period of 15 days as from the filing of the petition, the court will examine such petition, and within 8 days following such examination and subject to the satisfaction of the filing conditions, the court may decide to open the judicial reorganization procedure, thereby, granting a temporary moratorium to the debtor for a period of maximum six months. At the request of the debtor (or of the judicial administrator in case of a procedure of transfer under judicial authority) and pursuant to the report issued by the delegated judge, the moratorium period can thereafter be extended (once or several times) up to a total maximum period of twelve months as from the judgment opening the judicial reorganization. In exceptional circumstances (such as due to the size of the business, the complexity of the case or the impact of the procedure on employment), and in the interest of the creditors, the court may order an additional extension ----- of the moratorium period for six months. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the special rules that apply when a debtor has already requested and obtained a judicial reorganization procedure in the last 3 years before the new request, are currently suspended but should come into effect again as of 1 April 2023. The granting of the temporary moratorium operates as a stay. No enforcement measures with respect to pre-existing claims (i.e., for debts incurred before the judgment opening the judicial reorganization proceedings) in the moratorium can be continued or initiated against any of the debtor’s moveable and immovable assets from the time that the moratorium is granted until the end of the period, with limited exceptions. During the moratorium, no attachments can be made with regard to pre-existing claims. During the moratorium, the debtor can also not be declared bankrupt, except upon declaration of the debtor itself and, if the debtor is a legal entity, judicial dissolution will not be possible during this period. Conservatory attachments that existed prior to the opening of the judicial reorganization retain their conservatory character, but the court may order their release, provided that such release does not have a material adverse effect on the situation of the creditor concerned. If the date for the forced sale of moveable or immoveable property has already been set, such sale may, under certain conditions, be continued. If receivables are pledged by the debtor in favor of a creditor prior to the opening of the judicial reorganization proceedings, such pledge will not be affected by the moratorium (provided that the receivables are pledged specifically to that creditor from the moment the pledge is created) (note that a pledge of a business or other universality including receivables is not considered as a pledge specifically with respect to receivables), and the holder of such pledged receivables is permitted to take enforcement measures against the estate of the initial counterparty of the debtor (e.g., the debtor’s customers) during the moratorium. A pledge on financial instruments within the meaning of the Belgian Financial Collateral Law of December 15, 2004, as amended (Wet Financiële Zekerheden/Loi sur les Sûretés Financières) (the “Belgian

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Financial Collateral Law”), such as shares in a Belgian Guarantor, can be enforced notwithstanding the
Subsubsection Title: Bankruptcy
Subsubsection Text: Bankruptcy proceedings may be initiated by the debtor, by unpaid creditors or upon the initiative of the Public Prosecutor’s office, by the provisional administrator of the debtor’s assets, by the liquidator of the debtor’s assets or by the liquidator of ‘main insolvency proceedings’ opened in another EU member state (other than Denmark) in accordance with the EU Insolvency Regulation. Once the court ascertains that the requirements for bankruptcy are met, the court will establish a date by which all creditors’ claims must be submitted to the court for verification. Conditions for a bankruptcy order (faillietverklaring/déclaration de faillite) are that the debtor must be in a situation of sustained cessation of payments (op duurzame wijze opgehouden hebben te betalen/cessation de _paiements de manière persistante) and be unable to obtain further credit (wiens krediet geschokt is/ébranlement du crédit). Cessation of payments is generally considered as the inability of the debtor to pay its debts as they_ fall due. Such situation must be persistent and not merely temporary. In bankruptcy, the debtor loses all authority and decision rights concerning the management of the bankrupt business. The bankruptcy receiver (curator/curateur), appointed by the court, becomes responsible for administering the bankruptcy and implements the sale of the debtor’s assets, the distribution of the sale proceeds to creditors and the liquidation of the debtor. The rights of creditors in the process are limited to being informed of the course of the bankruptcy proceedings on a regular basis by the bankruptcy receiver. Creditors may oppose the sale of assets by bringing an action before the court if such sale is detrimental to their rights. Any interested party may request the temporary continued operation of the business if this is not detrimental to the creditors. The bankruptcy receiver may elect to continue the business of the debtor, provided the bankruptcy receiver obtains the authorization of the court and such continuation does not cause any prejudice to the creditors. However, two exceptions apply: - the parties to an agreement may contractually agree that the occurrence of a bankruptcy constitutes an early termination or acceleration event; and - intuitu personae contracts (i.e., contracts whereby the identity of the other party constitutes an essential element upon the signing of the contract) are automatically terminated as of the bankruptcy judgment since the debtor is no longer responsible for the management of the company. Parties can however agree to continue to perform under such contracts. The bankruptcy receiver must decide whether or not to temporarily continue performance under ongoing contracts (i.e., contracts existing before the bankruptcy order) or whether to terminate ongoing contracts unilateral if such termination is required for administrating the bankrupt estate. Such decisions will not impair any rights in rem of third parties that are enforceable against the estate. The counterparty to an ongoing contract may summon the bankruptcy receiver to take a decision within 15 days. If no extension of the 15 days term is agreed upon or if the bankruptcy receiver does not take any decision, the ongoing contract is presumed to be terminated after the expiration of the 15 days term. If the bankruptcy receiver decides not to continue the performance of an ongoing contract or if an ongoing contract is terminated due to the expiration of the fifteen days term, the counterparty to that agreement may make a claim for damages in the bankruptcy and/or seek a court order to have the relevant contract dissolved. The counterparty may not seek injunctive relief or require specific performance of the contract. ----- As a general rule, the enforcement rights of individual creditors are suspended upon the rendering of the court order opening bankruptcy proceedings, and after such order is made, only the bankruptcy receiver may proceed against the debtor and liquidate its assets. However, such suspension does not apply to a pledge on financial instruments or cash held on account, falling with the scope of the Belgian Financial Collateral Law. Further exceptions exist with regard to estate credits (boedelschulden/dettes de la masse). For creditors with claims secured by movable assets (other than financial collateral), such suspension would normally be limited until the filing of the first report of claims. At the request of the bankruptcy receiver, the suspension period may be extended for up to one year as from the bankruptcy judgment. Such extension requires a specific order of the court which can only be made if the further suspension will allow for a realization of the assets in the interest of all creditors without prejudicing the secured creditors and provided that those secured creditors have been given the opportunity to be heard by the court. However, a pledge on financial instruments or cash held on accounts can be enforced during the suspension period. For creditors with claims secured by immovable assets, the intervention of the bankruptcy receiver is necessary to pursue the sale of the assets, subject to certain exceptions. The bankruptcy receiver will do so upon an order of the court, given either at its request or at the request of a mortgagee. A first-ranking mortgagee will generally be entitled to pursue the enforcement of its mortgage as soon as the first report of claims has been filed. The court may suspend such enforcement for a period of not more than one year from the date of the bankruptcy if the suspension will allow for a realization of the assets without prejudicing the mortgagee provided that the mortgagee has been given the opportunity to be heard by the court. If a security interest, such as a pledge, has been granted over assets that, at the time of opening of an insolvency proceeding, are located in another EU Member State, the rights the creditor has under such security shall, in accordance with the EU Insolvency Regulation, not be affected by the opening of such insolvency proceedings. As from the date of the bankruptcy judgment, no further interest accrues against the bankrupt debtor on its unsecured debt, or debts secured by a general privilege, such as tax administration or social security debts. The debts of the bankrupt estate generally will be ranked as to priority on the basis of complex rules. The following is a general overview of such rules: - Estate debt: Costs and indebtedness incurred by the bankruptcy receiver during the bankruptcy proceedings, the so-called “estate debts,” have a senior priority. In addition, if the bankruptcy receiver has contributed to the realization and enforcement of secured assets, such costs will be paid to the bankruptcy receiver in priority out of the proceeds of the realized assets before distributing the remainder to the secured creditors. - Security interests: Creditors that hold a security interest have a priority right over the secured asset (whether by means of appropriation of the asset or on the proceeds upon realization). - Privileges: Creditors may have a particular privilege on certain or all assets (e.g., tax claims, claims for social security premiums, etc.). Privileges on specific assets rank before privileges on all assets of the debtor. Certain privileges prevail over the security interests. - Pari passu: Once all estate debts and creditors having the benefit of security interests and privileges have been satisfied, the proceeds of the remaining assets will be distributed by the bankruptcy receiver among the unsecured creditors (and secured/privileged creditors if the security/privilege did not allow such creditors to be paid in full) who rank pari passu (unless a creditor agreed to be subordinated). - Subordinated creditors will receive the remainder (if any).

Section Title: LIMITATIONS ON VALIDITY AND ENFORCEABILITY OF THE NOTE GUARANTEES AND THE SECURITY INTERESTS AND CERTAIN INSOLVENCY LAW CONSIDERATIONS
Subsection Title: Financial Collateral Law”), such as shares in a Belgian Guarantor, can be enforced notwithstanding the
Subsubsection Title: Limitations on enforcement of the Notes and the Note Guarantees
Subsubsection Text: The grant of a guarantee by a Belgian company for the obligations of another group company must fall within the grantor’s legal and corporate object and be for the own corporate benefit of the granting company and comply with any applicable financial assistance rules. If the granting of a guarantee or the creation of a security interest does not fall within the grantor’s corporate object as described in its articles of association, then such guarantee or security interest could, upon certain conditions, be held null and void. Corporate benefit is not a well-defined concept under Belgian law and its interpretation is left to the courts and legal authors. The corporate benefit rules and their application in the context of granting guarantees or ----- security interests for the benefit of a group company are not clearly established under Belgian law and there is only limited case law on this issue. The assessment of whether or not the grant of a guarantee or the creation of a security interest is in each of the Belgian guarantor’s own corporate interest, is largely dependent on factual considerations and is to be determined on a case-by-case basis by the board of directors or director(s) of each of the Belgian guarantors at the time of the granting of the guarantees or the security interests, in anticipation of their enforcement and to be reviewed ultimately on a case-by-case basis at the time of the enforcement by the competent courts. Consideration has to be given to any direct and/or indirect benefit that such Belgian guarantor would derive from the transaction; this is particularly relevant for upstream or cross-stream guarantees. It is generally considered by legal scholars that at least the following principles apply to such evaluation: (i) the risk taken by the Belgian guarantor in issuing the guarantee must be proportional to the direct and/or indirect benefit derived from the transaction; and (ii) the financial support granted by the Belgian guarantor should not exceed its financial capabilities. Belgian case law does not offer clear guidelines on when a group transaction is within the individual group member’s corporate benefit and when the aforementioned conditions are met. The responsibility for such assessment lies with the board of directors or director(s) of the Belgian guarantors. The corporate benefit justification by the company’s board of directors will be subject to only a “marginal review” by the courts; in insolvency situations, however, the courts can be expected to take a more critical view. If the corporate benefit requirement is not met, the board of directors or director(s) of the Belgian guarantor may be held liable (i) by the company for negligence in the management of the company and (ii) by third parties in tort and under criminal law in certain specific circumstances, i.e., where the specific facts can be qualified as “abuse of company goods”(misbruik van vennootschapsgoederen/abus de biens sociaux). Moreover, the guarantee or security interest could be declared null and void and, under certain circumstances, the creditor that benefits from the guarantee or security interest may also be held liable on the basis of the principles of tort liability. Alternatively, the guarantee or security interest could be reduced to an amount corresponding to the corporate benefit and, under certain circumstances, the creditor could be held liable on the basis of the principles of tort liability for any guarantee or security interest amount in excess of such amount. These rules have however seldom been tested under Belgian law, and there is only limited case law on this issue. In order to enable Belgian subsidiaries to grant a guarantee or security interest for liabilities of a direct or indirect parent or sister company without the risk of violating Belgian rules on corporate benefit, it is standard market practice for indentures, credit agreements, security documents and guarantees to contain so-called “limitation language” in relation to subsidiaries incorporated or established in Belgium. Accordingly, the Indenture (or the accession document in relation thereto) will contain limitation language on the basis of which the total maximum guarantee liabilities of certain Belgian guarantors (in case of an upstream or cross stream guarantee) under the Indenture will be limited. Including such limitation language is, however, not conclusive in determining or upholding the corporate benefit. _Financial assistance_ Any guarantee or security interest granted by a Belgian Guarantor which constitutes a breach of the provisions on financial assistance as defined by article 5:152 or 7:227 of the Belgian Code of Companies and Associations, whichever is applicable, might not be enforceable. Any guarantee or security interest granted by a Belgian Guarantor shall therefore not include and shall not extend to cover any payment obligation in respect of the proceeds of the Notes used to fund, directly or indirectly, the acquisition of shares of such Belgian Guarantor to the extent that by assuming such obligation the Belgian Guarantor would be deemed to be providing prohibited financial assistance to the acquisition of its own shares or capital participations, as prohibited under Article 5:152 or 7:227 of the Belgian Code of Companies and Associations dated March 23, 2019, as amended from time to time. Therefore, such payment obligations shall be excluded from the guarantee or security interest granted by a Belgian Guarantor. _Hardening periods and fraudulent transfer_ In the event that bankruptcy proceedings are governed by Belgian law, certain transactions may be declared ineffective against third parties if concluded or performed by the debtor during the so-called “hardening period” (verdachte periode/période suspecte). The hardening period is the period from the date of cessation of payments up to the declaration of bankruptcy. In principle, the cessation of payments (which constitutes a condition to declare a debtor ----- bankrupt) is deemed to have occurred as of the date of the bankruptcy order, and accordingly there is in principle no hardening period. However, the court issuing the bankruptcy order may determine, based on serious and objective indications, that the cessation of payments occurred on an earlier date. Such earlier date may not be earlier than six months before the date of the bankruptcy order, except in the case where the bankruptcy order relates to a company that was dissolved more than six months before the date of the bankruptcy order in circumstances suggesting an intent to defraud its creditors, in which case the date of cessation of payments may be determined as being the date of such decision to dissolve the company and there would be a hardening period from that date of cessation of payments up to the declaration of bankruptcy. The transactions entered into or performed during the hardening period which may be declared ineffective against third parties and are unenforceable against the bankruptcy receiver include, among others, (i) gratuitous transactions or transactions entered into at an undervalue or on extremely beneficial terms for the counterparty, (ii) payments for debts which are not yet due, and (iii) payments other than in cash for debts due, and (iv) new security interests provided for pre-existing debts. The legal provisions with regards to the judicial reorganization proceedings provide for a number of exceptions. The Belgian bankruptcy receiver may request the court to declare payments of a Belgian Guarantor during the hardening period for debts due ineffective against third parties provided that it can be proven that the creditor concerned was aware of the cessation of payment of the company. If the guarantee or security interest granted by a Belgian Guarantor were successfully held ineffective (based on the above), noteholders would cease to have any claim in respect thereof and would be under an obligation to repay any amounts received pursuant to such guarantee or the realization of such security interest. Regardless of fraudulent intent, registration of a security interest after cessation of payments can also be declared ineffective, when more than 15 days have passed in between the date of the deed and the date of registration. The bankruptcy receiver may also obtain a court ruling that a transaction or payment is not enforceable against the bankrupt’s estate, regardless when such transaction or payment took place, if such transaction or payment was effected with the fraudulent intent to adversely affect the creditors’ rights. Furthermore, even in the absence of bankruptcy proceedings, a third party creditor may obtain a court ruling that an act or transaction (such as a guarantee) is not enforceable against it if it can establish that the challenged act or transaction was effected with the fraudulent intent to adversely affect its position as an existing creditor (actio pauliana). _Recognition and enforcement_ The granting of security interests over movable or immovable, tangible or intangible, assets may be subject to validity and/or enforceability conditions. The breach of or failure to perform any of such conditions may render such security interests invalid or unenforceable. The foreclosure of security interests may be subject to formalities (e.g., judicial or non-judicial consent or, for movable assets not governed by the Belgian Financial Collateral Law (such as receivables), prior notification to the pledgor) and may be time consuming in the event that the foreclosure takes place under judicial control or in the event of a legal dispute, in which case any interested party may request a judge at any moment in time to intervene, and such request would suspend the foreclosure. Courts may condition the enforcement of a security interest and/or guarantee upon the evidence that the creditor has a final and undisputed claim triggering the foreclosure of the security interest and/or guarantee.
