2.** **Significant events: Gfi Group becomes INETUM A NEW IDENTITY IN THE IMAGE OF WHAT WE HAVE BECOME AND OUR AMBITIONS
Subsubsection Text: A historical pioneer in the sector, the Group has grown while retaining its entrepreneurial culture and the daring of its beginnings. Gfi has grown in line with societal, economic and technological changes. After 10 years of growth, we mark our entry into a new era and harmonize our identity at the international level. On October 1, 2020, we become Inetum, Positive digital flow. Our new identity is unveiled in front of all of our employees, across the world, during a live digital event and in multiplex in our different areas. As of January 2021, following this dynamic, the Group’s parent company and its subsidiaries will change their corporate names and now mainstream the name Inetum into their respective corporate names With a new name and a new identity, our ambition is to embody what we have become: an integrated and international group with 27,000 talents in 26 countries with considerably enhanced capacities, to always act as close as possible and in proximity to our customers. In the era of digital post-transformation where change is continuous, movement ceaseless, we assert ourselves as the ESN that helps its clients get the most out of digital flow.

Subsection Title: Iecisa acquisition
Subsubsection Text: After having received the agreement of all the competent competition authorities, the Group acquires through its subsidiary Grupo Corporativo Gfi Informatica acquires on April 24, 2020 100% of the capital of Informática El Corte Inglés Group (IECISA) specializing in technology consulting with projects with high added value, particularly in the field of digital transformation. In addition, IECISA also brings its multisectoral expertise on other key themes, such as Industry 4.0, Cybersecurity, Intelligent Workplace and ERP (SAP). Thus, this merger will allow the two Groups to combine their expertise, access new markets and enhance their respective advisory and service offerings. This acquisition also involved the maintenance of a framework agreement concluded between El cortes Inglés and Iecisa. This commercial agreement on services provides, over a period of 5 years, a guaranteed minimum income for Iecisa.

Subsection Title: 3.** **Covid-19 Pandemic (continued) Impact on activity
Subsubsection Text: While protecting its employees, the systems put in place by the Group have ensured the continuity of services for all customers through recourse to teleworking. Thus, the Group quickly deployed its communication and collaboration technologies to enable remote work for its customers. During fiscal year 2020, the Group was unevenly affected by the crisis. Indeed, despite a relatively marked impact of the crisis in France, some countries such as Belgium, Spain and Romania continued their organic growth, which amounted to 4.9%, 4.8% and 22%. The operating margin, although stable at Group level (i.e. 6.3% of consolidated sales), experienced a slight increase in international scope of around +1 point compared to 2019 on a like-for-like basis. However, some countries are recording significant progress, such as Belgium and Portugal, whose operating margins. increased by +3 points to reach 7.7% and 8.6% respectively of their turnover.

Subsection Title: Employee protection
Subsubsection Text: From February 2020, a crisis unit was set up to take the necessary measures to protect the health and safety of employees and to continue operations. At the start of confinement (March 17, 2020), the clear majority of employees (productive and nonproductive) were teleworking with suitable equipment. In France, more than 82% of productive employees and more than 98% of non-productive employees have fully adopted homework. The measures implemented during containment can be summarized as follows: - Collaborative communication space to maintain proximity between employees; - Constant support from the IT department to respond to numerous requests; -----

Subsection Title: 3.** **Covid-19 Pandemic (continued)
Subsubsection Text: - Daily meetings of managers to communicate the measures to be taken, listen to and respond to the difficulties encountered; - Opening of a listening unit to support employees; - Permanent interaction with general services to allow employees to return to the site after confinement: orders for masks and hydro alcoholic gel, reinforced cleaning of premises, verification of ventilation systems, reinforced marking and display. - Following the confinement (May 11, 2020), several prevention plans (7 successive versions) were adopted with the dual objective of protecting employees and continuing the Group’s activities. These plans focused on the following elements, among others: - Supply of hydro alcoholic gel and masks, reinforced cleaning of sites and adaptation of signage within establishments to indicate the directions of movement and the instructions to be observed; - Verification of the conditions for resuming activity of each customer welcoming our employees; - Organization of teleworking for employees in vulnerable situations and for those wishing to do so. Since October 30, 2020, teleworking is once again the norm; - Negotiation and conclusion of an amendment to the teleworking agreement with a view to its deployment; - Training program for managers on remote management considering the sustainability of teleworking situations.

Subsection Title: Effect on consolidated financial statements
Subsubsection Text: - Accounting for costs induced by Covid-19 As recommended by the financial markets authority (AMF) and accounting standards in France (ANC), all costs incurred because of Covid-19 have been recognized in operating margin. These include the costs incurred to allow employees to continue their professional activities by teleworking and the costs incurred for the purchase of masks, gels, etc. - Subsidies received from the state and deferral of payment of social charges The partial activity measures put in place because of the pandemic have enabled the Group to benefit from government aid. These compensatory allowances received, 11.6 million euros, have been recorded as a reduction in personnel costs. In addition, still as part of the support measures, the Group has benefited in France from a deferral of the payment of social charges, the amount of which amounts to approximately 19.8 million euros. - Estimates of accounting methods The accounting assumptions used by the Group for the preparation of the annual accounts have been revised to consider the impact of the pandemic. These include the valuation methods of provisions for customer depreciation, goodwill, rental contracts (assets and debts recognized under the application of IFRS 16) and the recoverability of deferred taxes. active. Trade receivables:** The analyzes of customer risks and the good collectability of trade receivables during fiscal year 2020 did not lead the Group to recognize statistical provisions as recommended by IFRS 9. Goodwill.** The Group considered that the consequences of this health crisis represent an indication of impairment losses. Thus, impairment tests were carried out to ensure that the recoverable values of the cashgenerating units are not lower than their net book values. In addition, the discount rates used consider the additional premium related to Covid-19. Lease contracts.** The rent payment arrangements granted by lessors due to the Covid-19 pandemic did not significantly impact the value of debt and assets recognized under lease contracts. Assessment of deferred tax assets.** The analysis of the recoverability of deferred tax assets relating to tax losses was tested on the basis of new assumptions. This analysis leads the Group not to question the future consumption of these deferred tax assets recognized. -----

Subsection Title: 3.** **Covid-19 Pandemic (continued) Distribution of dividends
Subsubsection Text: Due to the pandemic and the acquisition of Iecisa, the General Meeting of April 24, 2020 approves the proposal of the Board of Directors held on the same date not to distribute dividends for the 2019 financial year. -----

Subsection Title: Standards, amendments and interpretations of mandatory application as at 1st January 2020
Subsubsection Text: The amendments and interpretations binding on January 1[st], 2021 and mentioned below have no significant impact on the consolidated accounts: - Amendment to IFRS 4, IAS 39 and IFRS 7: “Reform of benchmark interest rates”; - Amendment to IFRS 16: “Covid 19—Rent reduction”. The amendments and interpretations binding on January 1st, 2020 and mentioned below have no significant impact on the consolidated accounts: - Amendment to IFRS 3: “Definition of an activity”; - Amendment to IAS 1 and IAS 8 “Modification of the definition of the term “significant”; - Amendment to IFRS 9, IAS 39 and IFRS 7: “Reform of benchmark interest rates”; - Amendment to IFRS 16: “Covid 19—Rent reduction”.

Subsection Title: Standards, amendments and interpretations published and not applied early
Subsubsection Text: The Group has chosen not to apply early the texts published by the IASB and adopted or not by the European Union. These are mainly amendments to standards: IAS 1—Classification of liabilities as current or noncurrent, IFRS 3—Reference to the conceptual framework and IFRS 16—Leases—Lease incentives. The internal process for determining the potential impact of standards and interpretations on the Group’s consolidated financial statements is ongoing. The Group believes that at this stage of the analysis, the impact of the application of these standards cannot be known with sufficient accuracy. Subsection Title: Standards, amendments and interpretations of mandatory application as at 1[st]** **January 2019
Subsubsection Text: Except IFRS15 and 9, the amendments and interpretations of mandatory application as at January 1, 2019 and mentioned below have no significant impact on the consolidated financial statements: - Amendment IFRS 9—Prepayment features with negative compensation; - Amendment IAS 28—Long-term Interests in Associates and Joint Ventures; - Amendment IAS 19—Plan Amendment, Curtailment or Settlement; - IFRS 23—Uncertainty over Income Tax Treatments;

Subsection Title: Application IFRS 16—Leases
Subsubsection Text: Mandatory from January 1, 2019, IFRS 16 introduces a unique lease accounting model for tenants. The lessee has the obligation to recognise on his assets a “right of use” representing his right to use the underlying asset and his liabilities a debt representative of his obligation to pay rents. The Group has chosen to apply the standard to all leases falling within the scope of application, and this, retrospectively, by recording the cumulative effect of the 1st application in equity in the consolidated reserves, consequently the 2018 financial statements have not been restated. During 2018, the Group conducted an internal project that identified the number of leases that fall within the scope of the standard. These contracts concern real estate leases, vehicles and other tangible assets. In accordance with the standard, low value contracts with a residual maturity of less than 12 months have been excluded.

Subsection Title: Valuation of the right to use the assets and the rental debt
Subsubsection Text: The valuation of the present value of these assets and the associated debt was calculated on the basis of incremental borrowing rate according to the nature of the asset, the duration and the geographical area. The rental period corresponds to the non-cancellable period of each contract including the optional periods which are reasonably certain to be exercised.

Subsection Title: Impacts on financial statements
Subsubsection Text: The impact on equity at 1 January 2019 amounts to 2.7 million euros net of tax. Assets recognised on the balance sheet have a net value of 88 million euros and the corresponding debt amounts to 91.2 million euros. At the level of the income statement, the cancellation of the rental charge leads to the recognition of an amortization expense of 27.1 million euros and an interest expense of 2.2 million euros. -----

Subsubsection Text: The consolidated financial statements incorporate the financial statements of Inetum and its subsidiaries. Subsidiaries are consolidated as from the date of acquisition, which corresponds to the date on which the Group took control of them and until such time as control ceases. Control is achieved when Gfi Informatique has the power to govern the financial and operating policies of an entity so as to obtain benefits from its activities. Intercompany transactions are eliminated on consolidation. Valuation methods applied by Group companies are aligned with those used by the Group. Minority interests represent the share of the profit or loss and the share of the net assets that do not accrue to the equity holders of the parent company. Minority interests are identified separately in the income statement. In the balance sheet, minority interests in the net assets of consolidated subsidiaries are identified separately from the interests attributable to the equity holders of the parent company. -----

Subsection Title: FOREIGN CURRENCY TRANSLATION METHODS Conversion of the financial statements in foreign currency
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s consolidated financial statements are prepared in euros. The operating currency of each Group entity is the currency of the economic environment in which the entity operates. All the assets and liabilities of consolidated entities whose functional currency is not the euro are converted at year-end into euros, which is the Group’s reporting currency. Income and expense items are converted at the average exchange rates for the past financial year. Resulting exchange rate differences and those arising from the application of closing exchange rates to the subsidiaries’opening equity are recognised under “Translation _reserve in consolidated equity”._ Exchange rate differences from converting net investment in foreign subsidiaries are recorded under equity. When a foreign entity is sold, these exchange rate differences are incorporated in the income statement as part of the profit or loss from the sale.

Subsection Title: Conversion of foreign currency transactions
Subsubsection Text: Transactions in currencies other than the entity’s functional currency are recorded at the rates of exchange prevailing on the dates of the transactions. At each balance sheet date, monetary items denominated in foreign currencies are retranslated at the rates prevailing on the balance sheet date. All exchange differences are recognised to profit or loss except for exchange differences on items that, in substance, form part of the net investment in foreign operations that are recognised directly to equity.

Subsection Title: 2.2. CHANGE IN THE CONSOLIDATED SCOPE Business combinations ACQUISITION OF SIS
Subsubsection Text: The group, via its subsidiary Gfi Progiciels, acquired on February 27, 2019 the French company SIS, European leader in emergency information systems and alert processing intended for Civil Security (Firefighters / SDIS and SAMUs). This acquisition is a real opportunity because the Group will strengthen its portfolio of solutions. The company has been included in the consolidation scope since March 1, 2019.

Assets linked to the Group’s normal operating cycle, assets held for sale within 12 months of the balance sheet date and available cash and marketable securities are reported under current assets. All other assets are reported under non-current assets. Liabilities falling due within the Group’s normal operating cycle or within 12 months of the balance sheet date are reported under current liabilities. Assets linked to the Group’s normal operating cycle, assets held for sale within 12 months of the balance sheet date and available cash and marketable securities are reported under current assets. Subsection Title: 2.2. CHANGE IN THE CONSOLIDATED SCOPE Business combinations
Subsubsection Text: Business combinations are accounted for using the purchase method. In accordance with this method, the identifiable assets and liabilities assumed from the acquired entity are recorded at fair value on the date of acquisition and may be adjusted during the 12 months following this date. Costs related to the acquisition are excluded from the consideration transferred and are expensed when incurred. Business combinations are accounted for using the purchase method. In accordance with this method, the identifiable assets and liabilities assumed from the acquired entity are recorded at fair value on the date of acquisition and may be adjusted during the 12 months following this date. Costs related to the acquisition are excluded from the consideration transferred and are expensed when incurred. -----

Subsection Title: 4.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 2** **Consolidation scope (continued) IECISA ACQUISITION
Subsubsection Text: After having received the agreement of all the competent competition authorities, the Group acquires on April 24, 2020 through its subsidiary Grupo Corporativo Gfi Informatica,100% of the capital of Informática El Corte Inglés Group (IECISA). The Iecisa Group, whose full-year turnover represents around 600 million euros, specializes in technology consulting with projects with high added value, particularly in the field of digital transformation. In addition, IECISA also brings its multisectoral expertise on other key themes, such as Industry 4.0, Cybersecurity, Intelligent Workplace and ERP (SAP). Thus, this merger will allow the two Groups to combine their expertise, access new markets and enhance their respective advisory and service offerings. This acquisition also involved the maintenance of a framework agreement concluded between El cortes Inglés and Iecisa. This commercial agreement on services provides, over a period of 5 years, a guaranteed minimum income for Iecisa. The Iecisa Group is integrated as of May 1st, 2020.

On March 5, 2021, the Group acquired the company Projixi Europe, whose activity is focused on expertise in automation and Cloud Computing. Projixi is an expert on the factors of competitiveness for organizations, such as the automation of business processes for activities with low added value, or the orchestration of processes for better efficiency and fluidity in the mastery of tasks, which has become an answer to the multichannel environment of many companies. The company is also recognized for the contribution of its solutions -----

On August 3, 2021, Inetum Software France, subsidiary of Inetum SA, acquired 100% of the capital of Ilex International, the leading French publisher of IAM (Identity and Access Management) software. Ilex International has been able to develop strong and extensive expertise for more than 30 years in the security of information systems by forging partnerships with a majority of major accounts as well as many ETIs. By supporting its clients from many sectors of activity such as banking and insurance, defence, health, media,energy, and distribution, Ilex International now offers its IAM solutions to more than 14 million users in France and around the international. The company has been integrated since August 1, 2021.

Subsection Title: Changes in ownership interests and merger
Subsubsection Text: During the first half of 2021, the Group acquired the shares of minority shareholders of Transformation Business Success et Brand New day consulting, thus bringing its stake to 100% of the capital and voting rights of these companies. Following these minority share buybacks; these entities were the subject of a mergerabsorption.

Inetum Holding Maroc, subsidiary of the Group, acquired in December 2021 the HLI Group. Through this acquisition, the Group acquired 75.5% of the capital and voting rights of HLI Services and HLI consulting Tunisia and 87.5% of the capital and voting rights of HLI Morocco. HLi Consulting has been able to develop for more than 18 years a strong and extensive technological expertise in consulting and integration of solutions customer relationship management, in particular the CRM Dynamics solution, by supporting its customers from many sectors of activity such as banking, insurance, automotive, pharmaceutical and education. Today, HLi Consulting in Tunisia and Morocco is a key player in the implementation of digital solutions focused on customer relations in Africa. The Group has been integrated since December 2021.

Subsubsection Text: Revenue arising from these services is recognized by reference to the stage of completion based on costs incurred to date and costs that will be incurred subsequently. When it is probable that costs will exceed revenue, the expected loss is recognized immediately. Invoices to be raised or deferred income are recognized when billing is out of phase with the stage of completion. Revenue arising from these services is recognized by reference to the stage of completion based on costs incurred to date and costs that will be incurred subsequently. Subsubsection Text: In general, the turnover of the two services is recognized separately. RETIREMENT BENEFIT PLANS DEFINED BENEFIT PLANS** These plans relate to post-employment benefits and are characterized by an obligation on the part of the employer to its employees. In this regard, the Group recognizes a debt corresponding to the present value of estimated future payments by retaining internal and external parameters. The valuation of the Group’s commitments under these plans are valued annually by independent actuaries using the “projected unit credit” method. Per this method, each period of service gives rise to the recognition of an additional unit of benefit rights and each of these units is assessed separately to obtain the final obligation. This method is also based on considering hypotheses of mortality, staff turnover and projection of future salaries. The commitments calculated in this way are discounted based on the interest rates on long-term bonds of first-class issuers. Expenses related to these plans are recognized in the income statement based on contributions paid or due for the year in which the related services were rendered by the beneficiaries. Any revisions to the calculation assumptions (actuarial assumptions or the effect of experience—differences between the actuarial projection and the reality at the date of preparation of the consolidated accounts) generate actuarial gains and losses. These actuarial differences are recognized, during the period in which they arise, in equity under the heading “Gains and losses recorded in equity”. For the Group, post-employment benefits mainly concern end-of-career indemnities in France. In accordance with the revised IAS 19 standard, legal and contractual indemnities are provisioned for each of the employees present per their theoretical length of service on the day of their retirement. These commitments are determined with an initial assumption at the initiative of the employee in 100% of cases and consider the following elements: - Average turnover rate is determined by entity on the basis of resignations observed over a period of 3 years - Average rate of social charges applied: 47%; - Average salary increase rate of is calculated by age and category; - INSEE 2015 – 2017 mortality tables by sex; - Discount rate at 0.78% (versus 0.54% at the end of 2020) and an estimated duration of the plan of 11.2 years. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 5** **Operating profit (continued) FREE SHARES
Subsubsection Text: Performance shares are granted to certain employees and to the corporate officer subject to attendance and performance conditions unrelated to the market. The shares are subject, on the date of grant, to a valuation corresponding to the fair value of the benefit granted to the employee. Thus, they are valued, on the one hand, based on the value of the share determined by an actuary per the “discounted cash flows” method, and on the other hand, by considering the potential number of shares that may be awarded. The potential number of shares is determined based on the presence of the beneficiaries and on the estimates of achievement of the performance conditions provided for in the plans. The charge is recognized, on a straight-line basis, in “Other operating income and expenses” over the vesting period of the rights in exchange for equity. In addition, at the end of each closing, it is subject to a reassessment by management to consider the new estimates related to compliance with the conditions of presence and performance.

Costs related to business combination transactions are recognized as expenses in the year in which they are incurred. ----- Costs related to business combination transactions are recognized as expenses in the year in which they are incurred.

(1,714) (970) **(565)** **(4,546) FREE SHARES** The Boards of Directors dated March 29, 2019 and June 07, 2019, using the power given to them by the General Meetings ordinary and extraordinary shareholders on June 8, 2018 and June 07, 2019, decided to allocate free shares to certain employees and the Chief executive officer of the company’s shares in the form of so-called plans. - “2019 Tier 1 and Tier 2 performance free share plan” reserved for employees and corporate officers, ie 808,817 shares free and, - “CEO 2019 free share plan” for the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Company, ie 300,000 shares free. The shares will be acquired by the beneficiaries at the end of the vesting period and subject to compliance with the conditions of presence and performance. Given the excessively restrictive performance conditions of the 2019 Tier 1 and Tier 2 performance share allocation plan, the Nomination and Remuneration Committee recommended, at its meeting of February 24, 2020, not to proceed with the free allocation actions of this plan and this, by express renunciation of the beneficiaries. Thus, the Board of Directors of February 24, 2020 taking act of the express renunciation of all the beneficiaries cancels the 2019 Tier 1 / Tier 2 performance share allocation plan in order to replace it with three new plans with performance objectives more suited to -----

Subsection Title: NOTE 6** **Financing and financial instruments 6.1. DEBT LOANS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s borrowings include bonds and bank loans. When they are initially recognized, borrowings are measured at their fair value to which are charged the transaction costs which are directly attributable to them on the issuance of the liability. Loan issuance costs are amortized as financial charges over the life of the loan using the effective interest rate method. In the event of early repayment, the residual value of loan issuance costs is recognized as an expense in the year in which the repayment is made.

Subsection Title: NOTE 6** **Financing and financial instruments 6.1. SIGNIFICANT EVENTS Issuance of bonds loans
Subsubsection Text: On May 20, 2020, the Group issued a bond loan maturing on May 20, 2027. The nominal value of this loan is 40 million euros, or 400 bonds with a nominal value of 100,000 euros each. The bonds bear interest at a fixed rate of 4.00% per year until May 20, 2021. From that date, the applicable annual interest rates will depend on the leverage ratios, note that the annual rate applicable may in no case exceed 3.75%. On December 23, 2020, the Group issued a bond loan maturing on May 20, 2027. The nominal value of this loan is 60 million euros, or 600 bonds with a nominal value of 100,000 euros each. The bonds bear interest at a fixed rate of 4.00% per year until May 20, 2021. From that date, the applicable annual interest rates will depend on the leverage ratios, note that the annual rate applicable may in no case exceed 3.75%. The debt relating to these bond issues has been recorded at amortized cost and the issue costs are amortized in profit or loss over the life of the bond.

Subsection Title: Syndicated loan Agreement renegotiation
Subsubsection Text: On March 12, 2020, the Group signed a new syndicated loan agreement for an amount of 780 million euros. This loan, repayable over 5 years and bearing interest at variable rates, breaks down as follows: - 500 million euros intended for the acquisition of Iecisa and to refinance the remaining amounts due under the old syndicated loan. This credit line was the subject of a drawdown of 447 million euros and a repayment of 22 million euros during the financial year; - 155 million euros intended to finance part of the old syndicated loan and the issue of a new bond loan. This credit line was the subject of a drawdown of 65 million euros which was repaid in full during the year. - 50 million euros to finance the Group’s acquisitions and investments. This line of credit was not drawn down during the year. - 75 million euros to finance the Group’s working capital needs. This line of credit was not drawn during the year. -----

The Group operates on the financial markets only for hedging commitments related to its activity and not for speculative purposes. Indeed, the Group has set up derivative financial instruments such as interest rate swaps to hedge against the risks of interest rate fluctuations. These derivative financial instruments are initially recognized at fair value as soon as the contract is negotiated and are subsequently measured at fair value. Derivatives are recognized as assets when the fair value is positive and as liabilities when the fair value is negative

INTEREST RATE RISK ON CASH FLOW** The interest rate risk arises mainly from variable rate bank loans. The main objective of managing this risk is to minimize the cost of debt and therefore to guard against fluctuations in interest rates. In addition, the obligation to cover this risk is also justified by the contractual clause stipulated in the financing contract for these bank loans. As such, the Group is committed to hedging, within certain limits, to an increase in the 3-month Euribor rate. As illustrated in the table below, the fixed rate / variable rate breakdown, before the effect of rate hedges, highlights the Group’s strong exposure to the risk of interest rate fluctuations. Variable interest rates . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 66% 374,001 154,699 Fixed interest rates . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 34% 194,579 89,985

This risk is managed by setting up hedging instruments such as zero swap + floor contracts. After considering swaps of interest rate, 68% of the Group’s debt is at a fixed interest rate as of December 31, 2020. In a context where hedges would be made active, the analysis of the sensitivity to the interest rate shows that a marginal increase of 1 point in interest rates would have an impact of 1,320 thousand euros in the Group’s consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2020.

When hedge accounting is applied in the context of a future cash flow hedge, the profits or losses resulting from changes in the market value of the hedging instruments are recognized in equity for the percentage of effectiveness of the hedge. If the Group chooses not to apply hedge accounting, the profits or losses resulting from changes in market value are recognized in profit or loss The financial liabilities presented in the consolidated statement of financial position correspond to the hedging instruments recognized at fair value. Rate hedges are signed for a constant amount until maturity. The valuations of these hedging instruments are carried out per level II of the amended IFRS 7 standard, ie based on observable data other than a quoted price on an active market. At December 31, 2021, the Group used two hedging instruments, recognized under “Current financial liabilities”the characteristics of which are presented in the table below. The change for the period, recognized as a counterpart to shareholders’ equity (other comprehensive income), amounts to 1,699 thousand euros. Subsection Title: Factoring agreement
Subsubsection Text: Inetum has, via factoring contracts, financing lines based on the amount of trade receivables sold. These financing lines, capped at 150 million euros, were used up to 147,9 million euros as of December 31, 2021. The amount received, 147.9 million euros, was recognized in the balance sheet under “Cash and cash equivalents”.

Subsection Title: Bank overdraft facilities
Subsubsection Text: The Group has negotiated bank overdraft lines capped at 40 million euros. At December 31, 2021, the Group had used 18 million euros of these bank overdraft facilities. The Group has negotiated bank overdraft facilities of up to 35.0 million euros. As of December 31, 2019, these bank overdraft lines were used for € 17 million.

Subsection Title: Agreements featuring so-called default
Subsubsection Text: The credit agreement of March 12, 2020, with a pool of banking institutions, includes so-called default covenants in the form of financial covenants with which the Group must comply (see Note 6.7 Off-balance sheet commitments relating to the Company’s financing activities). -----

Section Title: CONTRACTUAL LIMITATIONS TO THE GROUP’S DIVIDEND PAYOUT POLICY
Subsubsection Text: The Group has agreed to adopt a dividend payout policy in the line with debt reimbursements and payment of related interest. These payouts are limited to 40% of net income attributable to the Group if the ratio is greater than 1.75. The Group is committed to adopting a dividend payout policy that considers the debt repayment requirements and payment of related interest. These payouts are limited to 40% of net income attributable to the Group if the ratio is greater than 1.75. The Group is committed to adopting a dividend payout policy that takes into account the debt repayment requirements and payment of related interest. These payouts are limited to 40% of net income attributable to the Group if the R2 ratio is greater than 1.25.

The Group must comply with certain ceilings on net investments. As of December 31, 2021, the limits imposed by the syndicated loan were respected. The Group must comply with certain ceilings on net investments. As of December 31, 2020, the limits imposed by the syndicated loan were respected. Section Title: 7.2. RECONCILIATION OF THEORETICAL AND ACTUAL INCOME TAX EXPENSE
Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 7** **Income tax expense (continued) 7.3. DEFERRED TAXES
Subsubsection Text: Deferred taxes are: - Recognized to consider the time lag between the book values and the tax values of certain assets and liabilities; - Calculated using the variable deferral method based on the tax rate applicable on the year-end date; - Recognized either in the income statement or directly in capital depending on the assets or liabilities to which they relate; - Assessed and adjusted per known changes in tax rates and / or tax regulations in the event of a change in tax rates, deferred taxes previously recognized are adjusted either in the income statement or directly in capital specific and depending on the underlying to which they relate; - Appear at their nominal value, no discounting being applied.

Section Title: 7.2. RECONCILIATION OF THEORETICAL AND ACTUAL INCOME TAX EXPENSE
Subsection Title: Deferred taxes generated by tax loss carry forwards
Subsubsection Text: Deferred tax assets are recognized if it is probable that taxable profits will be realized within a reasonable period in future years. The book value of deferred tax assets is reviewed at each closing to ensure the recovery of these recognized assets. It is therefore reduced when it is unlikely that future taxable profits will not be sufficient to allow the use of all or part of these deferred tax assets. Conversely, it will be increased if it becomes probable that future taxable profits will be available on a sustainable basis and allow the consumption of tax losses not yet recognized. Deferred tax assets are recognized if it is probable that taxable profits will be realized within a reasonable period in future years. The book value of deferred tax assets is reviewed at each closing to ensure the recovery of these recognized assets. Thus, it is reduced when it is unlikely that future taxable profits will not be sufficient to allow the use of all or part of these deferred tax assets. Conversely, it will be increased if it becomes probable that future taxable profits will be available on a sustainable basis and allow the consumption of tax losses not yet recognized.

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued) 8.2. GOODWILL
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill corresponds to the difference between the purchase price (increased, where applicable, by non-controlling interests) and the net amount of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed. In the context of an acquisition of less than 100% (giving control but with existence of minority interests), the Group may choose to apply the “full goodwill” or “partial goodwill” calculation method. The “full goodwill” method assumes that all the revalued net assets, including the share of minority interests, are included in the calculation of goodwill. The unearned fraction is then valued either at fair value or at the amount of its share in the reassessed equity. The “partial goodwill” method, for its part, assumes to be retained in the calculation only the acquired share of the revalued net assets. When the calculation of the goodwill results in a negative difference (case of an acquisition carried out under advantageous conditions), the negative goodwill thus recorded is immediately recognized in profit or loss under “Other operating income and expenses”. Price adjustments are recognized at their fair value on the acquisition date and therefore included in the calculation of goodwill. In accordance with the provisions of IFRS 3, their subsequent variations give rise, in the period of 12 months following the acquisition date, to a modification of goodwill. Beyond this period, they are recognized in profit or loss. Goodwill is allocated to Cash Generating Units likely to benefit from the synergies of the business combination and represent the lowest level within the Group at which they are monitored for internal management needs. In addition, they are not amortized but are subject to an impairment test at least once a year under the conditions described in Note 8.3 “Cash generating units and impairment tests”

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued)
Subsubsection Text: - the combination of the discount rate and the perpetual growth rate is in line with the values usually used in the sector for groups of comparable profile; - the terminal value is calculated by summing up to infinity the discounted cash flows, determined based on a normative flow and a perpetual growth rate. This growth rate is consistent with the development potential of the markets in which the entity concerned operates, as well as with its competitive position. - Because of the application of IFRS 16, the Group has opted for a transitional approach known as “preIFRS 16”, which consists of: - maintain rental charges in estimated future cash flows; - determine the discount rate per the pre-IFRS 16 methodology; - include the right to use the assets in the book value of the assets test.

Section Title: 8.3. CASH GENERATING UNITS AND IMPAIRMENTS TESTS CASH GENERATING UNITS (GCU)
Subsubsection Text: CGUs correspond to homogeneous groups generating identifiable cash flows. It is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generate cash flows largely independent of the cash inflows generated by other assets or groups of assets. The CGUs correspond to the geographic areas in which the Group operates. The recoverable amount of a CGU represents the higher of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. The value in use is determined by the discounted future cash flow (DCF) method per the following principles: - the cash flows are taken from the operating budgets approved by management for the coming fiscal year with forecasts for changes in turnover, operating margins and working capital levels for the following four years; ----- CGUs correspond to homogeneous groups generating identifiable cash flows. It is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generate cash flows largely independent of the cash inflows generated by other assets or groups of assets. The CGUs correspond to the geographic areas in which the Group operates. The recoverable amount of a CGU represents the higher of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. The value in use is determined by the discounted future cash flow (DCF) method per the following principles: - the cash flows are taken from the operating budgets approved by management for the coming fiscal year with forecasts for changes in turnover, operating margins and working capital levels for the following four years; - the combination of the discount rate and the perpetual growth rate is in line with the values usually used in the sector for groups of comparable profile; -----

Subsection Title: Cash generating units (CGU)
Subsubsection Text: The identification of CGUs is made based on the geographic sectors used by management and per the “Services” and “Software” activities. At the level of each country, the two activities can be developed (such is the case in France and Spain). Indeed, the various “Services” activities generate strong complementarities, while the “Software” activity has a certain independence, given its specific characteristics. In view of this articulation (geographic sectors and activities), the Group presents 10 CGUs, of which 2 CGUs in France, 2 CGUs in Spain. During this fiscal year, the Morocco CGU was renamed to Africa CGU because it included the goodwill of the entities: Bridgéo (Cameroon) and Cynapsys (Tunisia). The identification of CGUs is made based on the geographic sectors used by management and per the “Services” and “Software” activities. At the level of each country, the two activities can be developed (such is the case in France and Spain). Indeed, the various “Services” activities generate strong complementarities, while the “Software” activity has a certain independence, given its specific characteristics. In view of this articulation (geographic sectors and activities), the Group presents 10 CGUs, of which 2 CGUs in France, 2 CGUs in Spain. During this fiscal year, the Morocco CGU was renamed to Africa CGU because it included the goodwill of the entities: Bridgéo (Cameroon) and Cynapsys (Tunisia).

The valuation of CGUs is carried out each year, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value is likely to have occurred. For example, the achievement of performances significantly lower than the budgets is considered as an indication of loss of value (those having served as a basis within the framework of the assessments previously carried out). The value test consists of evaluating the recoverable amount of each CGU whose calculation methods have been described above. When the recoverable amount thus determined of the CGU is less than the contributory value in the consolidated balance sheet of the fixed assets (including goodwill), an impairment loss must be recognized. This depreciation must be allocated as a priority to goodwill and recognized in profit or loss. The valuation of CGUs is carried out each year, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value is likely to have occurred. For example, the achievement of performances significantly lower than the budgets is considered as an indication of loss of value (those having served as a basis within the framework of the assessments previously carried out). The value test consists of evaluating the recoverable amount of each CGU whose calculation methods have been described above. When the recoverable amount thus determined of the CGU is less than the contributory value in the consolidated balance sheet of the fixed assets (including goodwill), an impairment loss must be recognized. This depreciation must be allocated as a priority to goodwill and recognized in profit or loss.

Subsection Title: Sensitivity testing for each CGU
Subsubsection Text: At year-end, the Group’s assessment of the reasonably possible change in key assumptions corresponded to the brackets of values used in the sensitivity tests which are presented below: - 0.5 point increase in the discount rate; - 0.5 point decrease in the growth rate to infinity; - 0.5 point decrease in the margin rate over all the 2022 to 2026 flow periods; - 0.5 point decrease in the turnover growth rate over all flow periods 2022 to 2026; - 10% deterioration in working capital assumptions. Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued) DEVELOPMENT COSTS
Subsubsection Text: Development costs incurred as part of the creation of software packages (new projects and development of existing modules) are recognized as intangible assets when the Group can demonstrate: - the technical feasibility of the intangible asset with a view to putting it into service or selling it; - its intention to complete this asset and its ability to use or sell it; - the fact that this asset will generate future economic benefits; - the existence of resources available to complete development and; - its ability to reliably assess the expenses incurred for the development project. Development costs that do not meet the activation criteria defined by IAS 38 are recognized in current operating expenses, as and when they are incurred. These development costs are amortized from the date of internal “acceptance”of the project, over the expected useful life of the software packages, which is capped at eight years. Research and development costs are assessed annually, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value may have occurred. The balance sheet value of activated development costs is compared to the recoverable value. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. Value in use is determined by the discounted future cash flow (DCF) method, based on operating budgets for the coming year and forecasted sales for the next four years. Depreciation is recognized if the balance sheet value is greater than the recoverable value.

Intangible assets are recognized at their acquisition cost less accumulated depreciation and any impairment losses. The valuation of fixed assets is carried out annually, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value is likely to have occurred. Achieving performance that is significantly lower than the budgets used as a basis for the assessments previously carried out is considered as an indication of impairment. ----- Intangible assets are recognized at their acquisition cost less accumulated depreciation and any impairment losses. The valuation of fixed assets is carried out annually, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value is likely to have occurred. Achieving performance that is significantly lower than the budgets used as a basis for the assessments previously carried out is considered as an indication of impairment.

After their initial recognition, they are valued at cost less accumulated depreciation. The amortization periods are from 2 to 21 years. After their initial recognition, they are valued at cost less accumulated depreciation. The amortization periods are from 2 to 21 years.

Subsection Title: Evaluation method applied to research and development costs
Subsubsection Text: The valuation method used to determine the values in use is that of discounted future cash flows. The activity forecasts are based on the operating budgets adopted by the Management for the financial year 2022. For the years 2023 to 2026, the growth rates used are then between 7% and 9% for all the software packages. Given the assumptions used, the performance of impairment tests for 2021 did not lead to the recognition of impairment. The valuation method used to determine the values in use is that of discounted future cash flows. The activity forecasts are based on the operating budgets adopted by the Management for the financial year 2021. For the years 2022 to 2025, the growth rates used are then between 2% and 5% for all the software packages. Given the assumptions used, the performance of impairment tests for 2020 did not lead to the recognition of impairment.

Subsection Title: Right of use
Subsubsection Text: The rights to use the goods are recorded on the assets side of the consolidated balance sheet. They are initially valued at a cost including the amount of the rental debt adjusted for rent payments made in advance, any direct costs incurred and the incentive benefits granted by the lessor. These rights are depreciated on a straight-line basis over the term of the contract. The rights to use the goods are recorded on the assets side of the consolidated balance sheet. They are initially valued at a cost including the amount of the rental debt adjusted for rent payments made in advance, any direct costs incurred and the incentive benefits granted by the lessor. These rights are depreciated on a straight-line basis over the term of the contract.

Subsection Title: Lease liabilities
Subsubsection Text: The rental debt recognized as a liability is initially measured at the present value of the rents due and not yet paid. The valuation is made based on a marginal debt rate determined per the nature of the asset, the rental period and the geographical area. The debt is then increased by the interest charge and decreased by the amounts of rent paid. The rental debt recognized as a liability is initially measured at the present value of the rents due and not yet paid. The valuation is made based on a marginal debt rate determined per the nature of the asset, the rental period and the geographical area. The debt is then increased by the interest charge and decreased by the amounts of rent paid.

On the date the asset is made available, a right of use and a rental debt are recognized and recognized in the consolidated statement of financial position. Leases that are short-term (less than 12 months) or whose individual value is less than $ 5,000 are recognized directly as an expense. On the date the asset is made available, a right of use and a rental debt are recognized and recognized in the consolidated statement of financial position. Leases that are short-term (less than 12 months) or whose individual value is less than $ 5,000 are recognized directly as an expense.

Subsection Title: 10.4. DIVIDEND AND APPROPRIATION OF INCOME FOR THE PERIOD Dividends paid in 2020
Subsubsection Text: Due to a decision of the General Meeting dated June 9, 2021, Inetum did not distribute any dividends for the 2020 financial year. Due to a decision of the General Meeting dated April 24, 2020, Inetum did not distribute any dividends for the 2019 financial year.

Subsection Title: Appropriation of parent-company income for 2021
Subsubsection Text: The proposed appropriation of parent company income presented to the Annual General Meeting would allocate parent company income equal to 24,273 thousand euros as follows: to the financial statements in the legal reserve account in the amount of 251 thousand euros and the balance in retained earnings.

Subsection Title: Appropriation of parent-company income for 2020
Subsubsection Text: The plan to allocate the corporate income submitted to the Annual General Meeting proposes to allocate the corporate income, amounting to 24 234 thousand euros, to the retained earnings account.

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 10** **Shareholders’ equity and earnings per share (continued) 2019 CEO free share allocation plans
Subsubsection Text: Within the limits of the authorization granted to it by the 20th resolution of the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of June 7, 2019, the board of directors, of June 7, 2019, approved this plan and proceeded, within the limit of 300,000 shares, to the allocation of performance shares to the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Vincent Rouaix. By decision of the Board of Directors on October 27,2021 and February 24, 2022, certain performance conditions were modified.

Subsection Title: 2020 free performance share allocation plans
Subsubsection Text: On April 24, 2020, the extraordinary general meeting of the Company authorized the issue or transfer of free performance shares, for a maximum amount of 1.36% of the Company’s share capital (corresponding to 900,000 shares at the time of of the decision), so that they are allocated to certain corporate officers and employees of the Group. In addition, it decided to authorize the Board of Directors to adopt, within the limits, terms and conditions set by decision of the shareholders, and to allocate free performance shares within the framework of the so-called plans: Plan 1 & Plan 1 bis, Plan 2 and Plan 3. On April 24, 2020, the extraordinary general meeting of the Company authorized the issue or transfer of free performance shares, for a maximum amount of 1.36% of the Company’s share capital (corresponding to 900,000 shares at the time of of the decision), so that they are allocated to certain corporate officers and employees of the Group. In addition, it decided to authorize the Board of Directors to adopt, within the limits, terms and conditions set by decision of the shareholders, and to allocate free performance shares within the framework of the so-called plans: Plan 1 & Plan 1 bis, Plan 2 and Plan 3.

Subsection Title: Allocation of performance shares to beneficiaries of Plan 1 and Plan 1bis
Subsubsection Text: Using the right given by the extraordinary general meeting of April 24, 2020, the Board of Directors on April 24, 2020 and October 13, 2020, respectively approved the “Plan 1” and “Plan 1bis” and have decided to allocate free shares to certain employees and the corporate officer. - under Plan 1, 603,812 free shares were allocated for the benefit of around sixty Group employees and the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; - under Plan 1bis, 115,000 free shares were allocated to 23 employees of the Inetum Group. These performance shares will be acquired gradually from the beneficiaries, subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period. However, it should be noted that under plan 1bis, the minimum vesting period of 2 years will be calculated from the grant date, i.e. October 13, 2020.

Subsection Title: Allocation of performance shares to beneficiaries of Plan 2
Subsubsection Text: Within the limits of the authorization granted under the 11th resolution of the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of April 24, 2020, the Board of Directors, on April 24, 2020, approved Plan 2 and proceeded, on one or more occasions, and on its sole decisions, to the allocation of free existing or to be issued ordinary shares of the Company, for the benefit of three employees of the Inetum Group, up to a limit of 85,000 shares. By decision of the Board of Directors on October 27,2021 and February 24, 2022, certain performance conditions were modified. The performance shares will be delivered to the beneficiary subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period. Within the limits of the authorization granted under the 11th resolution of the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of April 24, 2020, the Board of Directors, on April 24, 2020, approved Plan 2 and proceeded, on one or more occasions, and on its sole decisions, to the allocation of free existing or to be issued ordinary shares of the Company, for the benefit of three employees of the Inetum Group, up to a limit of 85,000 shares. The performance shares will be delivered to the beneficiary subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period.

Subsection Title: Allocation of performance shares to beneficiaries of Plan 3
Subsubsection Text: Within the limits of the authorization granted under the 11th resolution of the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of April 24, 2020, the Board of Directors, on April 24, 2020, approved Plan 3 and proceeded, on one or more occasions, and on its sole decisions, to the allocation of free existing or to be issued ordinary shares of the Company, for the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the company, up to a limit of 100,000 shares. By decision of the Board of Directors on October 27,2021 and February 24, 2022, certain performance conditions were modified. The performance shares will be delivered to the beneficiary subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period. ----- Within the limits of the authorization granted under the 11th resolution of the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of April 24, 2020, the Board of Directors, on April 24, 2020, approved Plan 3 and proceeded, on one or more occasions, and on its sole decisions, to the allocation of free existing or to be issued ordinary shares of the Company, for the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the company, up to a limit of 100,000 shares. The performance shares will be delivered to the beneficiary subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 10** **Shareholders’ equity and earnings per share (continued) Progressive acquisition under Plan 1 and Plan 1bis
Subsubsection Text: The Board of Directors meeting of February 24, 2022 noted the partial achievement of the performance conditions based on the financial results for the 2021 financial year. Consequently, it decided to allocate 57% of the number of free shares corresponding to the Tranche 3 for the benefit of the beneficiaries (i.e. 22.8% of the total number of beneficiaries of free shares likely to be paid to the beneficiaries), it being specified that the other conditions provided for in Plans 1 and 1bis remain unchanged.

Subsection Title: NOTE 11** **Other provisions and contingent liabilities
Subsubsection Text: Provisions are recognized when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) because of a past event, when it is probable that the Group will be required to settle that obligation, and when the amount can be estimated reliably. Provisions for disputes are analyzed on an individual basis. Provisions reported in the balance sheet under Disputes correspond to the risk as estimated by the Management of Inetum and may differ from the amounts sought by the other party. About provisions for restructuring, the estimated cost of the restructuring measure is recognized to profit or loss when these measures are the object of a detailed plan that has been announced or has started to be implemented. Contingent liabilities are not recognized but are described in the notes if they are significant, except for Business Combinations where they are identifiable. Provisions are recognized when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) because of a past event, when it is probable that the Group will be required to settle that obligation, and when the amount can be estimated reliably. Provisions for disputes are analyzed on an individual basis. Provisions reported in the balance sheet under Disputes correspond to the risk as estimated by the Management of Inetum and may differ from the amounts sought by the other party. About provisions for restructuring, the estimated cost of the restructuring measure is recognized to profit or loss when these measures are the object of a detailed plan that has been announced or has started to be implemented. Contingent liabilities are not recognized but are described in the notes if they are significant, except for Business Combinations where they are identifiable.

Subsection Title: Customer dispute In 2015, Inetum signed a software package integration and license agreement with an
Subsubsection Text: insurance customer. After postponements in planning and major disagreements concerning the implementation of the integration project, the contract was terminated at the end of 2017. After the failure of mediation, legal proceedings before the Tribunal de Commerce de Paris was initiated by the parties claiming compensation from each other for their damage, the Client claiming 40 million euros and Inetum 12 million euros. As part of the procedure, legal expertise is in progress and aims to determine the responsibilities of each of the parties. Due to the uncertainty and the importance of the claim, a provision of 2 million euros was recorded at the start of the investigation. As of December 31, 2021, the net exposure shown in the consolidated statement of equity amounts to 1.2 million euros.

Subsection Title: NOTE 14** **Financial instruments 14.1. FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS RECORDED ON THE BALANCE SHEET
Subsubsection Text: Financial instruments are made up of financial assets and liabilities. Financial assets include, among other things, trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents. Financial liabilities consist mainly of loans, rental debts and supplier debts. These financial instruments are classified per their nature and the reasons which motivated their acquisitions. In addition, they are measured either at fair value (profit or other items of comprehensive income) or at amortized cost. Financial instruments are made up of financial assets and liabilities. Financial assets include, among other things, trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents. Financial liabilities consist mainly of loans, rental debts and supplier debts. These financial instruments are classified per their nature and the reasons which motivated their acquisitions. In addition, they are measured either at fair value (profit or other items of comprehensive income) or at amortized cost.

Subsection Title: 4.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 10** **Shareholders’ equity and earnings per share (continued)
Subsubsection Text: - “CEO 2019 free share plan” for the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Company; - “2020 performance share allocation plan” reserved for employees and corporate officer. This plan is made up of the plans: “Plan 1 + Plan 1 bis”, “Plan 2” and Plan 3”. Thus, in 2020, four free performance share allocation plans for the benefit of more than eighty employees of the Inetum Group and the Chairman and CEO of the Company are established.

Subsection Title: 2019 CEO free share allocation plans
Subsubsection Text: Within the limits of the authorization granted to it by the 20th resolution of the extraordinary general meeting of shareholders of June 7, 2019, the board of directors, of June 7, 2019, approved this plan and proceeded, within the limit of 300,000 shares, to the allocation of performance shares to the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Vincent Rouaix. The performance shares will be delivered to the beneficiary subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period.

Subsection Title: Allocation of performance shares to beneficiaries of Plan 1 and Plan 1a
Subsubsection Text: Using the right given by the extraordinary general meeting of April 24, 2020, the Board of Directors on April 24, 2020 and October 13, 2020, respectively approved the “Plan 1”and “Plan 1bis”, and have decided to allocate free shares to certain employees and the corporate officer. - under Plan 1, 603,812 free shares were allocated for the benefit of around sixty Group employees and the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; - under Plan 1bis, 115,000 free shares were allocated to 23 employees of the Inetum Group. These performance shares will be acquired gradually from the beneficiaries, subject to the presence and performance conditions being met at the end of the vesting period. However, it should be noted that under plan 1bis, the minimum vesting period of 2 years will be calculated from the grant date, i.e. October 13, 2020.

Subsection Title: 4.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 10** **Shareholders’ equity and earnings per share (continued) Progressive acquisition under Plan 1 and Plan 1bis
Subsubsection Text: The Board of Directors meeting on February 25, 2021 noted that the performance objectives relating to Tranche 2 of Plans 1 and 1bis had not been achieved in view of the financial information for fiscal year 2020. However, the Board of Directors, given the exceptional circumstances that marked the 2020 financial year (covid-19 pandemic and its consequences on the Company’s performance), proposes to allocate 40% of the number of free shares corresponding to Tranche 2 for the benefit of the beneficiaries (i.e. 18% of the total number of free shares potentially allocated to beneficiaries), it being specified that the other conditions provided for in Plans 1 and 1bis remain unchanged. Consequently, 191,825 free shares were canceled.

Section Title: FINANCIAL ASSETS AT THEIR FAIR VALUE WITH THE OFFSETTING ENTRY IN THE INCOME STATEMENT
Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 14** **Financial instruments (continued) HELD-TO-MATURITY ASSETS
Subsubsection Text: Non-derivative financial assets associated with determined or determinable payments and a fixed maturity are classified as investments held until maturity, if the Group has the manifest intention and the ability to retain them until their maturity. The profits or losses are entered the income statement when these investments are removed from the accounts or depreciated.

Section Title: FINANCIAL ASSETS AT THEIR FAIR VALUE WITH THE OFFSETTING ENTRY IN THE INCOME STATEMENT
Subsubsection Text: The financial assets valued at their fair value with the offsetting entry to profit or loss is the financial assets held for transaction purposes. A financial asset is classified in this category if it was principally acquired for short-term resale. Derivative financial instruments are also designated as being held for transaction purposes unless they are classified as hedging instruments. They are classified among non-current liabilities. ----- The financial assets valued at their fair value with the offsetting entry to profit or loss is the financial assets held for transaction purposes. A financial asset is classified in this category if it was principally acquired for short-term resale. Derivative financial instruments are also designated as being held for transaction purposes unless they are classified as hedging instruments. They are classified among non-current liabilities. The financial assets valued at their fair value with the offsetting entry to profit or loss is the financial assets held for transaction purposes. A financial asset is classified in this category if it was principally acquired for the purpose of short-term resale. Derivative financial instruments are also designated as being held for transaction purposes unless they are classified as hedging instruments. They are classified among non-current liabilities.

Loans and receivables are non-derivative financial assets with fixed or determinable payment that are not quoted in an active market. They are included in current assets, except those whose maturity is more than twelve months after the closing date. They are included in current assets, except those whose maturity is more than twelve months after the closing date.

Subsection Title: Liquidity risk
Subsubsection Text: Managing this risk involves maintaining a satisfactory level of liquidity. The Group’s objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of financing and flexibility using factoring contracts, overdrafts and bank and bond loans. This point is developed in note 6.2 “Liquidity risk”.

Subsection Title: Interest rate risk on cash-flows
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s objective is to protect itself against interest rate fluctuations by covering part of the financial debt. To do this, it contracts derivative instruments, mainly interest rate swaps, the hedging methods of which are presented in Notes 6.2 “Financial liabilities” and 6.4 “Interest rate risk on financial cash flows”.

Subsection Title: Credit risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk mainly concerns trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents. The Group’s exposure is linked to possible failures of the third parties concerned, with a maximum exposure equal to the book value of these instruments. The risk associated with trade receivables is assessed based on an analysis of receivables due and not impaired which are continuously monitored. Regarding receivables transferred to the factor (factoring without recourse), insurance has been taken out to cover the risk of non-payment.

Subsection Title: Currency risks
Subsubsection Text: The currency risk in respect of commercial transactions is not hedged, as most transactions are made within the euro zone. Elsewhere (outside of the euro zone), revenue is generated in the same currency as the related operating charges, thereby limiting exposure to foreign-exchange fluctuations. Few intercompany operating transactions are denominated in currencies other than the euro. The Group’s net assets and liabilities in foreign currencies are broken down in the table below. The impact of a uniformly negative one-centime change in the euro would total € 1million. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 14** **Financial instruments (continued) Net balance before (in thousands of euros)** **Assets** **Liabilities** **hedging

Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents reported in the balance sheet comprise cash in hand, cash at bank and short-term deposits for less than three months as well as short-term highly liquid investments that are subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Marketable securities are considered as being held for trading and are therefore measured at fair value on the balance sheet date. Changes in fair value are recognized to profit or loss. As these securities are adjusted to fair value with the offsetting entry to profit or loss, no impairment losses are recognized. Fair value of these securities is determined mainly by reference to listed prices. In the consolidated cash flow statement, cash and cash equivalents comprise the items indicated above, from which are deducted current bank overdrafts.

Subsection Title: Impacts of changes in consolidation scope
Subsubsection Text: The cash flows linked to the impact of changes in scope mainly relate to the acquisitions for the period.

Subsection Title: Subscription and repayment of borrowings
Subsubsection Text: Repayments made mainly related to the syndicated loan and bonds for an amount of 44.6 million euros. -----

Subsection Title: Non-compete agreement and post-engagement commitment
Subsubsection Text: On December 18, 2007, the Company signed a non-compete agreement with Vincent Rouaix. By way of payment for the non-compete commitment entered by Vincent Rouaix, this agreement stipulates the payment to the latter, on the day his office ends, of a lump sum of 850,000 euros by amendments of March 29, 2013. As at December 31, 2021, there are no anticipated payments in respect of corporate officers after leaving office.

Subsection Title: Awarding free shares
Subsubsection Text: The Boards of Directors of June 7, 2019 and April 24, 2020 decided to grant, under the following plans: Plan 2019 “CEO 2019 free share plan” and Plan 2020 “Plan1 and Plan 3” free shares for the benefit of related parties. The number of shares allocated under these plans is 487,612. These shares will vest after a minimum vesting period of two years and subject to performance and attendance conditions.

Subsubsection Text: The Board of Directors of Mannai Corporation QPSC approved, at a meeting held on January 18, 2022, to enter into exclusive negotiations with a group of investors led by Bain Capital Private Equity, of which NB Renaissance is a member, to sell its entire stake in Inetum S.A. The proposed transaction concerns the entire shareholding of Mannai Corporation QPSC, which represents approximately 99% of the share capital of Inetum S.A. on an undiluted basis. Inetum S.A. is the parent company of an international group providing digital services and solutions. Bain Capital Private Equity has worked closely with management teams to provide the strategic resources to build great companies and help them grow since its inception in 1984. Bain Capital Private Equity’s international team of approximately 250 professionals creates value for its portfolio companies through its global platform and deep expertise in key industry verticals, including healthcare, consumer products and retail, financial and business services, industrials and technology, media and telecommunications. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 19** **Subsequent event (continued) Hubtobee acquisition
Subsubsection Text: A company under French law, Hubtobee’s activity focuses mainly on the B2B development of software in SaaS mode. The two software currently used by Hubtobee are Flex (office space management software and flex office organization management solutions) and Travel (business travel management software). The acquisition of a stake in Hubtobee will make it possible to refocus activity around the development of Flex, of which INETUM holds 70% of the intellectual property rights, and to develop and sell a SaaS solution addressing a growing market (following the Covid) with the Hubtobee team.

Subsection Title: The conflict in Ukraine
Subsubsection Text: The impact of the Russian-Ukrainian war has no major impact on the Group. The Group has no direct or indirect subsidiaries in these two countries. The Group’s activity in Russia, Belarus and Ukraine is negligible. The accounts were closed after the beginning of the Ukraine-Russia conflict. In view of our activity, we do not envisage any significant impact at this stage on the accounts for the beginning of 2022. -----

Subsection Title: 2.5. SUBSEQUENT EVENTS Acquisition of Projixi Eurpe
Subsubsection Text: On March 5, 2021, the Group acquires the company Projixi Europe, whose activity is focused on expertise in automation and Cloud Computing. Projixi is an expert on competitive factors for organizations, such as the automation of business processes for low value-added activities, or the orchestration of processes for better efficiency and fluidity in the control of tasks, which has become an answer. to the multi-channel environment of many companies. The company is also recognized for the contribution of its solutions in the integration of a Big Data environment for organizations, with the challenges that this represents in terms of centralization of internal sources, and data processing needs.

Subsection Title: NOTE 3** **Revenue and trade receivables 3.1. REVENUE
Subsubsection Text: Rules for the recognition of revenue are summarized below: — -----

Subsection Title: 4.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 3** **Revenue and trade receivables (continued) TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, CONSULTING AND SYSTEMS INTEGRATION BILLED AT COST PLUS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue arising from these services is recognized as and when the services are rendered. Revenue is determined by reference to the contractually agreed price and to billable chargeable hours spent on the job. Invoices to be raised or deferred income are recognized when billing is out of phase with the stage of completion.

For sales of software packages and hardware made independently of any service, the turnover is recognized when the control is transferred to the customer. For sales of software packages and hardware made independently of any service, the turnover is recognized when the control is transferred to the customer.

The Group’s borrowings include bonds and bank loans. When they are initially recognized, borrowings are measured at their fair value to which are charged the transaction costs which are directly attributable to them on the issuance of the liability. Loan issuance costs are amortized as financial charges over the life of the loan using the effective interest rate method. In the event of early repayment, the residual value of loan issuance costs is recognized as an expense in the year in which the repayment is made. When initially accounted for, borrowings are recorded at fair value adjusted to account for transaction costs directly attributable to the debt issuance. Costs and issue premiums for loans are not included in the initial cost but are taken into account in calculating amortized cost using the effective interest method and are therefore recorded in income in an actuarial manner over the life of the debt

The Group operates on the financial markets only for hedging commitments related to its activity and not for speculative purposes. Indeed, the Group has set up derivative financial instruments such as interest rate swaps to hedge against the risks of interest rate fluctuations. These derivative financial instruments are initially recognized at fair value as soon as the contract is negotiated and are subsequently measured at fair value. Derivatives are recognized as assets when the fair value is positive and as liabilities when the fair value is negative

Subsection Title: Factoring agreement
Subsubsection Text: Inetum has, via factoring contracts, financing lines based on the amount of trade receivables sold. These financing lines, capped at 150 million euros, were fully used as of December 31, 2020. In fact, based on the factoring contracts subscribed, the Group benefited from an amount of 150 million euros recognized in the balance sheet under “Cash and cash equivalents”.

Subsection Title: Bank overdraft facilities
Subsubsection Text: The Group has negotiated bank overdraft lines capped at 40 million euros. At December 31, 2020, the Group had used 13 million euros of these bank overdraft facilities.

Subsection Title: Agreements featuring so-called default
Subsubsection Text: The credit agreement of March 12, 2020, with a pool of banking institutions, includes so-called default covenants in the form of financial covenants with which the Group must comply (see Note 6.8 Off-balance sheet commitments relating to the Company’s financing activities). -----
