Subsection Title: 4.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued)
Subsubsection Text: - the technical feasibility of the intangible asset with a view to putting it into service or selling it; - its intention to complete this asset and its ability to use or sell it; - the fact that this asset will generate future economic benefits; - the existence of resources available to complete development and; - its ability to reliably assess the expenses incurred for the development project. Development costs that do not meet the activation criteria defined by IAS 38 are recognized in current operating expenses, as and when they are incurred. These development costs are amortized from the date of internal “acceptance”of the project, over the expected useful life of the software packages, which is capped at eight years. Research and development costs are assessed annually, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value may have occurred. The balance sheet value of activated development costs is compared to the recoverable value. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair value less costs to sell and the value in use. Value in use is determined by the discounted future cash flow (DCF) method, based on operating budgets for the coming year and forecasted sales for the next four years. Depreciation is recognized if the balance sheet value is greater than the recoverable value.

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued)
Subsubsection Text: These development costs are amortized from the internal “revenue” date of the project, over the expected useful life of the software packages, which is capped at eight years. The value of fixed assets is assessed every year, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value is likely to have occurred. The achievement of performances significantly lower than the budgets used as a basis in the framework of the assessments previously carried out is considered as an indication of impairment. The balance sheet value of capitalized development costs is compared to the recoverable value. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair value net of disposal costs and the value in use. The value in use is determined by the discounted future cash flow (DCF) method, based on operating budgets for the coming financial year and forecasts of turnover for the following four years. Impairment is recognized, if applicable, if the balance sheet value is higher than the recoverable value.

Development costs incurred as part of the creation of software packages (new projects and development of existing modules) are recognized as intangible assets when the Group can demonstrate: ----- Development costs incurred in connection with the creation of software packages (new projects and development of existing modules) are recognized as intangible assets, when the Group can demonstrate: - the technical feasibility of the intangible asset with a view to putting it into service or selling it; - its intention to complete the asset and its ability to use or sell it; - the fact that this asset will generate future economic benefits; - the existence of resources available to complete development and; - its ability to reliably assess the expenses incurred for the development project. Development costs that do not meet the activation criteria defined by IAS 38 are recognized as current operating expenses, as and when incurred. -----

Subsection Title: 4.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 14** **Financial instruments (continued) LOANS AND RECEIVABLES
Subsubsection Text: Loans and receivables are non-derivative financial assets with fixed or determinable payment that are not quoted in an active market. They are included in current assets, except those whose maturity is more than twelve months after the closing date.

Non-derivative financial assets associated with determined or determinable payments and a fixed maturity are classified as investments held until maturity, if the Group has the manifest intention and the ability to retain them until their maturity. The profits or losses are entered the income statement when these investments are removed from the accounts or depreciated. ----- Non-derivative financial assets associated with determined or determinable payments and a fixed maturity are classified as investments held until maturity, provided that the Group has the manifest intention and the ability to retain them until their maturity. The profits or losses are entered into the income statement when these investments are removed from the accounts or depreciated.

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Liquidity risk
Subsubsection Text: Managing this risk involves maintaining a satisfactory level of liquidity. The Group’s objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of financing and flexibility using factoring contracts, overdrafts and bank and bond loans. This point is developed in note 6.3 “Liquidity risk”.

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Interest rate risk on cash-flows
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s objective is to protect itself against interest rate fluctuations by covering part of the financial debt. To do this, it contracts derivative instruments, mainly interest rate swaps, the hedging methods of which are presented in Notes 6.3 “Financial liabilities” and 6.5 “Interest rate risk on financial cash flows”.

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Credit risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk mainly concerns trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents. The Group’s exposure is linked to possible failures of the third parties concerned, with a maximum exposure equal to the book value of these instruments. The risk associated with trade receivables is assessed based on an analysis of receivables due and not impaired which are continuously monitored. Regarding receivables transferred to the factor (factoring without recourse), insurance has been taken out to cover the risk of non-payment.

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Currency risks
Subsubsection Text: The currency risk in respect of commercial transactions is not hedged, as most transactions are made within the euro zone. Elsewhere (outside of the euro zone), revenue is generated in the same currency as the related operating charges, thereby limiting exposure to foreign-exchange fluctuations. Few intercompany operating transactions are denominated in currencies other than the euro. -----

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents reported in the balance sheet comprise cash in hand, cash at bank and short-term deposits for less than three months as well as short-term highly liquid investments that are subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Marketable securities are considered as being held for trading and are therefore measured at fair value on the balance sheet date. Changes in fair value are recognized to profit or loss. As these securities are adjusted to fair value with the offsetting entry to profit or loss, no impairment losses are recognized. Fair value of these securities is determined mainly by reference to listed prices. In the consolidated cash flow statement, cash and cash equivalents comprise the items indicated above, from which are deducted current bank overdrafts.

Subsection Title: Non-compete agreement and post-engagement commitment
Subsubsection Text: On December 18, 2007, the Company signed a non-compete agreement with Vincent Rouaix. By way of payment for the non-compete commitment entered by Vincent Rouaix, this agreement stipulates the payment to the latter, on the day his office ends, of a lump sum of 850,000 euros by amendments of March 29, 2013. As at December 31, 2020, there are no anticipated payments in respect of corporate officers after leaving office.

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Awarding free shares
Subsubsection Text: The Boards of Directors of June 7, 2019 and April 24, 2020 decided to grant, under the following plans: Plan 2019 “CEO 2019 free share plan” and Plan 2020 “Plan1 and Plan 3” free shares for the benefit of related parties. The number of shares allocated under these plans is 487,612. These shares will vest after a minimum vesting period of two years and subject to performance and attendance conditions. All the provisions of these plans are presented in Note 3.7 “Compensation of corporate officers”in Chapter 3.

Section Title: 14.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsubsection Text: Because of its activities, the Group is exposed to various types of risk such as liquidity risk, interest rates on cash-flows, currency and credit. Financial risk management consists of minimizing the potentially unfavorable effects of these risks on the Group’s financial performance

The financial statements are presented in euros rounded to the nearest thousand. Estimates as well as critical judgements must be used in preparing the consolidated financial statements in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Management must also use its judgement in the application of Group accounting methods (see “Valuation methods” below). The areas in which assumptions and estimates may have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements notably include the measurement of retirement benefit plans, testing of goodwill for impairment, provisions for liabilities and charges and the recoverability of deferred tax assets.

On March 21, 2019, the Group acquired the Peruvian companies Hundred, software publishers. Consolidated since April 1, 2019, the Hundred companies are mainly involved in Agile projects, architecture, consulting, but also in mobile applications. Having a customer network mainly concentrated in the telecoms, banking and insurance sectors, this acquisition allows the Group to strengthen, in LatAm and Spain, its commercial links with banking clients already present in its client portfolio.

On September 6, 2019, Gfi Informatique via its subsidiary Gfi Portugal acquired the I2S Group companies, a software publisher specializing in the insurance market and the leader on the Iberian Peninsula and in Africa. I2S Group was consolidated on September 1, 2019.

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 2** **Consolidation scope (continued)
Subsubsection Text: Capital consulting has been included in the consolidation scope since May 1, 2019

In April 2019, the Group acquired 70% of the capital and voting rights of the Moroccan company Capital consulting. Its activity is mainly focused on consulting services in strategy, information system, human resources, and the rest on IT project management. -----

Subsection Title: Mergers and other legal operations
Subsubsection Text: To streamline its organization chart, certain subsidiaries (French, Belgian, Luxemburg and Moroccan) have been the subject of a merger-absorption (Cf. Note 19 scope of consolidation). The Romanian Impaq Addstones Services has been liquidated.

Subsection Title: Changes in ownership interests and company name changes
Subsubsection Text: In September 2019, via Gfi Informatique Entreprise et SolutionsSA, the Group acquired 35% of the share capital of its subsidiary Novulys from its minority shareholders. Subsequently, this subsidiary is the subject of a merger absorption

Archos Technology, software publisher and computer systems integrator, was integrated on May 1, 2019. T&BS Consulting has been consolidated since May 1, 2019. The Bridgéo Group was integrated on October 1, 2019.

RETIREMENT BENEFITS PLAN** In the case of defined benefit plans covering post-employment benefits, the costs of these benefits are estimated using the projected unit credit method. The projected unit credit sees each period of service as giving rise to an additional unit of benefit entitlement applying the plan’s vesting formula, taking into account the linearization effect when the rights do not vest uniformly over subsequent vesting periods. Future payments corresponding to the benefits granted to employees are determined using various assumptions (rate of increase in salaries, retirement age, mortality, etc.) and these defined benefit obligations are then discounted to their present value using as discount rate the market yields on high quality corporate bonds. When assumptions are revised, this results in actuarial differences that are recognised in the period in which they arise, not to profit or loss but directly to equity under “Recognised income and expense”. Pursuant to the French pension reform act, the minimum legal age of retirement will increase gradually, by four months per year, from 60 in 2010 to 62 in 2019. Excluding retirement benefits, the Group does not operate any other defined benefit plan in respect of postemployment benefits in Gfi Informatique Group companies. -----

(3,161) Changes in actuarial differences . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 11,497 **PROVISION OF RETIREMENT INDEMNITIES AT DECEMBER 31, 2019 . . . . . . . . . . . . .** **65,566** - including taking on staff under outsourcing agreements In accordance with the revised IAS 19 standard, legal and contractual allowances are provisioned for each of the employees present according to their theoretical seniority on the day of their retirement. These commitments are determined with an employee departure hypothesis in 100% of cases and its calculation takes into account: - a coefficient of presenteeism based on turnover by age group, the average rate used in 2019 stands at 12%; - an average rate of social charges applied is 47%. - a salary revaluation rate of between 2.25%—3.00%; - INSEE 2011-2013 mortality tables by sex; - a discount rate of 0.77% (versus 1.66% at the end of 2018) and an estimated duration of the plan at 12.3 years. In terms of sensitivity, a drop in this discount rate of 0.25 points would generate an increase in engagement of 3%.

Subsection Title: NOTE 5** **Operating profit 5.1. OPERATING MARGIN
Subsubsection Text: OPERATING MARGIN The Group’s main indicator of operating profitability is the operating margin. It corresponds to operating profit before non-recurring items (including goodwill impairment) and before depreciation and amortization of the intangible assets affected. Gfi Informatique’s sectoral information is based on geographic sectors, in line with internal management data used by management.

Subsection Title: Other operating income and expenses CONSOLIDATION TRANSACTIONS

Research Tax Credits (CIR) are recognized in underlying operating margin when they are not linked to activated development costs. They are presented as a deduction from staff costs. Otherwise, they are recorded as a reduction in the cost of activated development costs.

The rental debt recognized under IFRS 16 is, upon implementation of the contract, initially valued at value updated rents due and not yet paid. The evaluation is made on the basis of a marginal debt rate determined in depending on the nature of the asset, the rental period and the area geographical. The rental debt also includes the debt recognized under leasing contracts

Subsection Title: (in thousands of euros)** **31.12.19** **31.12.18

Subsubsection Text: The Group’s exposure to variation risks in market interest rates is linked to the level of the Group’s financial indebtedness. Interest rate management forms an integral part of debt management. The Group sets fixed rate / variable rate allocation standards. With this aim, the Group implements hedging instruments such as swap +floor zero contracts. As at December 31, 2019, after taking account of the interest-rate swaps, 68% of the Group’s debt is at a fixed interest rate. In a context where hedges would be made active, the analysis of interest rate sensitivity shows that a marginal increase of 1 point in interest rates would have an impact of 900 thousand euros in Gfi’s consolidated accounts IT, based on financial liabilities as of December 31, 2019. With regard to its principal financing contract, the Group hedged this loan within certain limits against an increase in the three-month Euribor.

Subsection Title: Current financial liabilites DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS AND HEDGE ACCOUNTING
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s current policy is to enter into transactions on the financial markets only for the purpose of hedging commitments arising from its activity and not for speculative purposes. The Group uses derivative financial instruments such as interest rate swaps to cover itself against the risks associated with interest-rate variations. These derivative financial instruments are initially entered into the accounts at their fair value at the time when the contract is negotiated and later valued at their fair value. The derivatives are entered into the accounts as assets when the fair value is positive and as liabilities when the fair value is negative. The profits or losses resulting from the variations in the market value of hedge instruments, taken out to hedge future cash flows and for which the Group chose to apply hedge accounting, are recorded as equity capital at the hedge effectiveness percentage. When the Group chose not to apply hedge accounting, the profits or losses resulting from the variations in market value were entered into the income statement. Current financial liabilities correspond to hedging instruments recognised at fair value. Some interest-rate hedging instruments are for a constant amount until maturity, whereas others are for amounts that decline gradually until maturity. These hedging instruments are valued in accordance with IFRS 7 revised, Level II, i.e. based on observable data other than a price listed on an active market. At December 31, 2019 the Group used two hedging instruments, recorded under “Current financial liabilities” and with the following features: -----

Subsection Title: 7.2. DEFERRED TAXES Deferred taxes
Subsubsection Text: Deferred taxes are calculated according to the variable deferral method on the basis of the tax rates known at the closing, for all temporary differences between the book value recorded in the consolidated accounts and the tax base of the Group’s assets and liabilities. A tax asset relating to tax loss carry forwards is only recorded in the event of reasonable assurance of future allocation. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset by tax entity or by tax consolidation group. Deferred taxes are shown at their nominal value, no discounting being carried out. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued)
Subsubsection Text: When the Group acquires an entity, it measures the acquired entity’s assets and liabilities at fair value. When the business combination takes place in stages (Step Acquisitions), the investment held by the acquirer prior to control being obtained is measured at the fair value on the acquisition date, and the difference between this and the previous carrying amount is recognised in profit or loss under IFRS 3R. Price adjustments are recognised at their acquisition-date fair value. They will give rise to the recognition of an asset or a liability, the subsequent changes in fair value of which will be recognized in profit or loss. The valuation differences identified during the acquisition are recognized in the relevant assets and liabilities. The residual difference, representative of the difference between the acquisition cost of the securities and the Group’s share in the fair value measurement of the identified assets and liabilities, is entered under goodwill and allocated to each Cash Generating Unit likely to benefit from the business combination. Subsequently, this goodwill is valued at cost less any impairment losses in accordance with the method described in the paragraph “Subsequent measurement of non-current assets”.

Business combinations are accounted for under the purchase method. The cost of an acquisition is measured as the sum of the consideration transferred, measured at acquisition-date fair value, and the amount of all non-controlling interests (NCI) in the acquiree. For each business combination, a choice is made to measure the non-controlling interests of the entity either at fair value or in accordance with their proportionate share of revalued net assets. The acquisition costs incurred are recognised as operating expenses for the period during which the corresponding services were rendered. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued)
Subsubsection Text: - the terminal value is calculated by summing to infinity the discounted cash flows, determined on the basis of a normative flow and a perpetual growth rate. This growth rate is in line with the development potential of the markets in which the entity operates, as well as with its competitive position. The recoverable value thus determined from the CGU is then compared to the contributory value on the consolidated balance sheet of fixed assets (including goodwill). Impairment is recognized, if applicable, if this balance sheet value is higher than the recoverable value of the CGU and is allocated in priority to goodwill

Subsection Title: Cash generating units (CGU)
Subsubsection Text: CGUs are identified on the basis of the geographic sectors used by management and according to the “Services” and “Software” activities. At the level of each country, the two activities can be developed (as is the case in France and Spain). Indeed, the different “Services”activities generate strong complementarities while the “Software”activity has a certain independence, taking into account its own characteristics. In view of this articulation (geographic sectors and activities), the Group has ten CGUs, including in particular 2 CGUs in France, 2 CGUs in Spain.

The value of fixed assets is assessed every year, or more frequently if events or circumstances, internal or external, indicate that a reduction in value is likely to have occurred. The achievement of performances significantly below the budgets used as a basis in the framework of the assessments previously carried out is considered as an indication of impairment. In particular, the balance sheet value of goodwill is compared to the recoverable value. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair value net of disposal costs and the value in use. In order to determine their value in use, fixed assets to which it is not possible to directly attach independent cash flows are grouped together within the Cash Generating Unit (CGU) to which they belong. The CGUs correspond to homogeneous sets generating identifiable cash flows. The value in use of the CGU is determined by the discounted future cash flow (DCF) method according to the following principles: - the cash flows come from the operating budgets adopted by the Management for the coming financial year with forecasts of changes in turnover, operating margins and WCR levels for the following four years; - the combination of the discount rate and the infinity growth rate is in line with the values usually used in the sector for groups of comparable profile; -----

Subsection Title: Measurment method applied to continuing operations
Subsubsection Text: The valuation method used to determine the values in use is that of discounted future cash flows. Because of the setting in application of IFRS 16, the Group was led to apply a recommended “pre-IFRS 16” transitional approach which leads to: - Maintain rental charges in the estimated future flows; - Determine the discount rate according to the pre-IFRS 16 methodology; - Include the right to use the assets in the book value of the tested assets. The perpetual growth rate is 2.0% for the all CGUs. (2.0% at 2018 year end) The discount rates used for the year are presented below. - 8.5% for the France CGUs (8.5% at 2018 year end), - 8.9% for Benelux CGU (8.9% at 2018 year end), - 9.8% for the Spain CGUs (9.8% at 2018 year end), - 9.7% for the Portugal CGU (10.8% at 2018 year end), - 10.1% for Poland CGU (10.1% at 2018 year end), - 9.0% for Switzerland CGU (9.0% at 2018 year end), - 11.4% for LatAm CGU (11.4% at 2018 year end), - 11.7% for Morocco CGU(12.3% at 2018 year end). Business Projections are based on operating budgets set by Management for the 2020 financial year. For 2021 to 2024, the growth rates used were then between 3% and 8% for all CGUs. -----

Subsubsection Text: Given the assumptions used in terms of profitability and working capital requirements, the tests carried out in 2019 did not lead to any impairment being recorded.

Subsection Title: Sensitivity testing for each CGU
Subsubsection Text: The ranges of values used in the sensitivity tests allow the appreciation of the reasonably possible variation of the key assumptions presented below: - 0.5 basis point increase in discount rate, - 0.5 basis point decrease in growth rate to infinity, - 0.5 basis point decrease in margin over all 2020 to 2024 cash periods, - 0.5 basis point decrease in revenue growth rate over all 2020 to 2024 cash periods, - 10% decrease in working capital assumptions. Sensitivity testing also uses the combined decrease of several of these assumptions, depending on their sensitivity. At December 31, 2019, except Sofware CGU in France and CGU Morocco (see table below), the results of the sensitivity tests show that no reasonably possible change in key assumptions brought the recoverable value of these CGUs below their net carrying amounts. The client relationships acquired from a business combination are entered into the accounts at their fair value on the acquisition date. Subsequent to their initial entry into the accounts, they are valued at cost less the cumulative amortisation. Amortisation periods are 2 to 21 years.

Subsection Title: Evaluation method applied to research and development costs
Subsubsection Text: The value in use is determined using the discounting future cash flow method (DCF). The activity forecasts are based on the operating budgets set by the Management for the 2020 fiscal year. For the years 2021 to 2024, the growth rates retained are between 2% and 10% for all the software packages. Given the assumptions made, the achievement of the impairment tests for 2019 did not lead to the recognition of impairment

Computer software purchased and computer software internally developed are amortised from the date they were brought into service so as to write off the cost of these assets over their estimated useful lives, using the straight-line method. - software purchased: 1 to 5 years; - software developed: 1 to 10 years. In the case of internally developed computer software, development costs capitalised by Gfi Informatique comprise all costs directly attributable to software development and programming.

Tangible fixed assets are recorded at their acquisition cost less accumulated depreciation and any impairment losses. The book values of intangible assets are reviewed at each balance sheet date to identify any impairment in the value of each of the assets considered (see 8.2 “Subsequent monitoring of the value of fixed assets”).

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 8** **Intangible assets and property, plant and equipment (continued) LEASE CONTRACTS
Subsubsection Text: In the context of rental contracts, the assets used give recognition of rights to use goods. These rights of use are recognized in balance sheet assets on the start date of contract which corresponds to the date on which the lessor makes available of the lessee the assets leased. The evaluation of usage rights is made on the basis of the initial amount of rental debt adjusted for rent payments made in advance, any direct costs incurred and benefits incentives provided by the lessor. These rights are subject to amortization linear over the duration of the contract.

Depreciation is charged so as to write off the cost of the assets, other than land, using the straight-line method over their estimated useful lives. These useful lives are principally as follows: - land: not depreciated; - buildings: 20 to 40 years; - hardware: 1 to 5 years; - motor vehicles: 5 years; - office equipment and other assets: 5 to 10 years. -----

Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 9** **Shareholders’ equity and earnings per share (continued) 9.5. FREE SHARES PLANS
Subsubsection Text: The Boards of Directors dated March 29, 2019 and June 07, 2019, using the power given to them by the General Meetings ordinary and extraordinary shareholders on June 8, 2018 and June 07, 2019, decided to allocate free shares to certain employees and the Chief executive officer of the company’s shares in the form of so-called plans. - “2019 Tier 1 and Tier 2 performance share allocation plan” reserved for employees and corporate officers, ie 808,817 shares free and, - “CEO 2019 free share allocation plan” for the benefit of the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Company, ie 300,000 shares free.

Subsection Title: “2019 Tier 1 and Tier 2 performance free share plan”
Subsubsection Text: Using the faculty given to it by the ordinary general meeting of June 08, 2018, the Board of Directors dated March 29, 2019 has decided to grant certain employees and the corporate officer free share rights, the number of which amounts to 808,816. These shares will be allocated to beneficiaries after a minimum vesting period of two years and subject to conditions presence and performance. Given the overly restrictive performance conditions of the plan, the Appointments and Remuneration recommended, at its meeting of February 24, 2020, not to proceed with the free allocation of shares, by way of express waiver of beneficiaries. Thus, the Board of Directors of February 24, 2020 taking note of the express renunciation of the whole of beneficiaries cancels the 2019 Tier 1 / Tier 2 performance share allocation plan in order to replace it with three new plans having performance objectives more suited to the Group’s activity. These new plans will be adopted by the General Meeting ruling on the accounts for the year ended December 31, 2019.

Subsection Title: “CEO 2019 free share plan”
Subsubsection Text: Using the faculty given to it by the Extraordinary General Meeting of June 07, 2019, the Board of Directors held on the same date has decided to grant the Chairman and CEO free share rights, the number of which amounts to 300,000. These shares will vest by the beneficiary at the end of the acquisition period subject to compliance with the presence and performance conditions.

Subsection Title: NOTE 10** **Other provisions and contingent liabilities
Subsubsection Text: Provisions are recognised when the Group has a present obligation (legal or constructive) as a result of a past event, when it is probable that the Group will be required to settle that obligation, and when the amount can be estimated reliably. Provisions for disputes are analysed on an individual basis. Provisions reported in the balance sheet under Disputes correspond to the risk as estimated by the Management of Gfi Informatique and may differ from the amounts sought by the other party. As regards provisions for restructuring, the estimated cost of the restructuring measure is recognised to profit or loss when these measures are the object of a detailed plan that has been announced or has started to be implemented. Contingent liabilities are not recognised but are described in the notes if they are significant, except for business combinations where they are identifiable. -----

2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 13** **Financial instruments 13.1. FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS RECORDED ON THE BALANCE SHEET
Subsubsection Text: Financial instruments are made up of financial assets and liabilities. Financial assets include, among other things, trade receivables, cash and cash equivalents. Financial liabilities consist mainly of loans, rental debts and supplier debts. These financial instruments are classified according to their nature and the reasons which motivated their acquisitions. In addition, they are measured either at fair value (profit or other items of comprehensive income) or at amortized cost.

The French companies Gfi Informatique and Gfi Informatique—Production were subject to tax audits for the years 2015 to 2017. Apart from the recovery under the CIR (Research tax credits) for the financial years 2015 and 2016 of the company Gfi Informatique, no significant recovery has was identified by the administration. In addition, tax and social audits are currently underway on the companies Gfi Progiciel (fiscal years 2016 to 2018) and Roff France (fiscal year 2017 and 2018). -----

Section Title: 13.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Liquidity risk
Subsubsection Text: Managing this risk involves maintaining a satisfactory level of liquidity. The Group’s objective is to maintain a balance between continuity of financing and flexibility through the use of factoring contracts, overdrafts and bank and bond loans. This point is developed in note 6.5 “Liquidity risk”.

Section Title: 13.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Interest rate risk on cash flows
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s objective is to protect itself against interest rate fluctuations by covering part of the financial debt. To do this, it contracts derivative instruments, mainly interest rate swaps, the hedging methods of which are presented in Note 6.3 “Interest rate risk on cash flows”.

Section Title: 13.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Credit risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk mainly concerns customers, cash and cash equivalents. The Group’s exposure is linked to possible failures of the third parties concerned, with a maximum exposure equal to the book value of these instruments. -----

Section Title: 13.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: 2.** **Notes to the consolidated financial statements (continued) NOTE 13** **Financial instruments (continued)
Subsubsection Text: The risk associated with trade receivables is assessed on the basis of an analysis of receivables due and not impaired which are continuously monitored. With regard to receivables transferred to the factor (factoring without recourse), insurance has been taken out to cover the risk of non-payment.

Section Title: 13.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsection Title: Currency risks
Subsubsection Text: The currency risk in respect of commercial transactions is not hedged, as most transactions are made within the euro zone. Elsewhere (outside of the euro zone), revenue is generated in the same currency as the related operating charges, thereby limiting exposure to foreign exchange fluctuations. Very few intercompany operating transactions are denominated in currencies other than the euro. The Group’s net assets and liabilities in foreign currencies are broken down in the table below. The impact of a uniformly negative one-centime change in the euro would total 0.4 million euros.

Section Title: 13.4. OBJECTIVES AND FINANCIAL RISK MANAGEMENT POLICY
Subsubsection Text: Cash and cash equivalents reported in the balance sheet comprise cash at bank, cash in hand and short-term deposits for less than three months as well as short-term highly liquid investments that are subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Marketable securities are considered as being held for trading and are therefore measured at fair value on the balance sheet date. Changes in fair value are recognised to profit or loss. As these securities are adjusted to fair value with the offsetting entry to profit or loss, no impairment losses are recognised. Fair value of these securities is determined mainly by reference to listed prices. In the consolidated cash flow statement, cash and cash equivalents comprise the items indicated above, from which are deducted current bank overdrafts.

Subsubsection Text: El Corte Inglés and the Gfi Group have reached an agreement under which the latter will acquire 100% of the shares of Informática El Corte Inglés (IECISA), a company specializing in technology consulting with high added value projects, especially in the field of processing digital. This merger will allow the two Groups to combine their expertise, access new markets and enrich their offers respective consultancy and services.

Section Title: RENEGOTIATION OF THE SYNDICATED LOAN CONTRACT
Subsection Title: Covid 19
Subsubsection Text: In early January 2020, the discovery of a new coronavirus (Covid-19) in connection with grouped cases of pneumonia was announced by Chinese health authorities and WHO. In late January 2020, the first cases of coronavirus infection were detected in France. The Gfi group is following the evolution of this epidemic very closely in order to put in place all the appropriate actions to, as a priority, protect the health of its employees, customers and all third parties working with the Group, but also reduce the impacts as much as possible economic aspects of this epidemic. A dedicated crisis management unit has been set up at Group level and remains in communication ongoing with the various Group entities to assess the situation and take appropriate measures. The impacts linked to the COVID-19 epidemic on Gfi’s activities, at this stage are still too uncertain for the Group to be able to communicate on quantified forecasts. -----

Section Title: RENEGOTIATION OF THE SYNDICATED LOAN CONTRACT
Subsubsection Text: In the context of the acquisition of Iecisa, Gfi Informatique renegotiated its syndicated credit agreement signed on February 21 2018 with a banking pool. On March 12, 2020, the Group concluded a bank loan with the banks involved in the syndication providing: - an acquisition and refinancing loan in the amount of 500 million euros intended to finance the acquisition of Iecisa and refinance the remaining amounts due for syndicated credit; - a bridging loan for the purposes of (i) refinancing, if necessary, the balance of the sums remaining due under the existing syndicated loan referred to in point a) above, and (ii) if applicable, finance the reimbursement of the existing Euro PP issue (issued on July 31, 2018) in the event of non- obtaining from -----
